lectures were very confusing and unorganized, sesh talked more about AI than actually teaching content. people stopped showing up and ends lectures early. exams are brutal with zero prep. I had to self teach most if not all of 213. he doesnt care anymore

approachable and good attitude! however, his lectures are primarily chatgpt conversations, and his lectures aren't quite engaging to begin with. exams are brutal. while the cheat sheet seems like it will help, there's so many dense questions--far worse than the problem sets for practice. enjoyed the HW assignments, but grading is very unforgiving.

I think he's a good person, but his exams are way too difficult. There isn't any review, his slides are confusing and overstimulating, and exams are way harder than what he makes it out to be. For a level 200 course, why are exams this difficult? We aren't told what to expect for them. Everything about the class is fine but exams. Fix your exams.

By the end of the semester literally almost no one bothered to show up anymore. Wastes your time by showing off his ai generated code during lectures, but the exams are all on paper and difficult. They grade the exams so harshly like they have something to prove.

sesh lowkey hates talking to students but his lectures are decent. Learned a little bit of advanced java. the projects are kinda superadvanced to apply the material to. group projects are miserable if you are paired up with a bum. exams are hard and like the rec problems TAs grade your exams like theyre trying to get rid of the competition.

Very bad experience with this prof. Admittedly, this class was late in the day, but he seemed like he actively did not want to be there to teach, sighing and taking breaks during lectures. Very uninspiring and unhelpful lectures, and an extremely tough grader, both on exams and on projects.

Sesh is very kind and knowledgeable, but his lectures are extremely useless. All his notes are screenshots from GPT, and he just reads them. Exams were mostly knowledge-based, and HWs were relatively easy. However, you are better off learning the material on YouTube or somewhere else. Grading depends on your TA, and recitation is mandatory only.

Sesh is very knowledgeable and an overall great guy, but this class was so AI-reliant that you could definitely get a decent grade if you never show up to lecture and AI your way through assignments if you really felt like it. Exams are pretty difficult and TAs are incomprehensible, so be prepared to do a lot of self-studying.

4 projects (2 in-group), 3 exams. His lectures involved screenshots from ChatGPT to organize syntax and "teach us how to use AI properly". Some exams had little chances to receive partial credit, so that kinda sucked at times. The topic itself isn't too hard. Memorize syntax, practice coding on your own instead of relying on AI, and you'll be fine.

honestly a difficult class. professor relied on chatgpt for his lectures but his exams were very difficult and handwritten for a coding class. TAs were hard to understand but recitation was mandatory. i would not take this again. also the cutoffs were not adequate for the grades that most students had.

213 is a must take course, it is without a doubt the course that I have learned the most in at Rutgers. However, it is definitely not easy and you need to be prepared for that. Sesh is a good lecturer, but a little boring. The projects are great and force you to learn the concepts well. Must-take and I recommend with an otherwise light courseload

Challenging class even if you know Pythonâ€”goes deep into Regex, Pandas, and Numpy with handwritten coding exams. Easy assignments. Annoying that he relied on GPT and recitation is required. TA often canceled last minute, which sucked as a commuter. Emphasizing AI usage while forcing us to handwrite Regex for exams felt outdated and contradictory.

Sesh's class is tough but rewarding. Lectures are dense but worth attending. Projects are challenging but great practice. Exams are tricky, so Unstuck study and practice are key to success. Overall, an excellent course that will make you a better coder.

Previous reviewer said it best. Sesh will make you a better coder whether you like it or not. It's basically adapt or die on the projects and the exams are rough but I came out twice as confident in my work. Lectures are great but surface level. If I took 213 again I would spend more time practicing the concepts on my own to prepare for the exams.

His class was tough, but man he is a good professor. He is very approachable and easy to talk to once you get familiar with him. Software Methodology was a difficult class, but it cleared up all the confusion I had related to coding, especially Java OOP. He will make you a better coder whether you like him or hate him.

The professor was overall a good lecturer, and I could understand Python pretty well because of that. Recitations aren't that useful, however. Projects are pretty tedious but worth it in the end. Exams were difficult. The one thing I had an issue with is that for our assignments we aren't given any test cases. Our class did not get curved.

No curve even though he said he would curve the final grades. Didn't even round by .2 which would've gotten me a higher letter grade. His way of teaching is understandable and clear and projects were fund to work on, just wish he gave test cases so we'd know what exactly to expect. I would recommend taking this class but be aware of the exams.

Lectures are boring, but usually useful. Projects are hard and require advanced planning, but very rewarding. Exams aren't too difficult if you attend lecture and practice recitation problems. Material and projects are very practical for software engineering jobs.

Sesh's 210 was ok. If you have some knowledge of Python and coding in general, this class isn't too challenging. However, for a class where prereqs are just CS111 or CS142, if you're just learning to code in Python, this class easily becomes very difficult. Projs were annoying to code imo. Exams were a bit intense but fair. He's a decent lecturer.

Great job w/ course & assignments. Cheat sheets on exams. But final grade hinged heavily(45%) on timed paper exams with strict grading & esoteric questions. Nobody codes without incremental live testing, so expecting students to write perfect code in one shot is abnormal. Also lied about curving. Please reconsider how to more fairly test students.

Wasn't a bad professor but was very disorganized with his presentation of content and gave difficult assignments and exams compared to the other professors. Wasn't impossible but wasn't very fun either. Said he would curve but clearly didn't.

No curve despite most of the class getting C's. He said there would be a curve for the final grade, but all evidence points to there not being a curve. He did not release grade cutoffs because he did not want to respond to emails about rounding. The cutoffs are standard Rutgers cutoffs.
If you have a bad partner you're screwed. Exams are graded very tough. He wants to see answers exactly as he described them in class. He's socially awkward and will judge you based on your star sign.

The type of professor that takes pride in how low his class averages are. To make matters worse, he's a terrible lecturer that overcomplicates concepts and also doesn't release class slides until AFTER lecture.

Assignments were tough and there was a lot of self-teaching required. Tests were difficult and the averages were low on them. No practice problems for tests but there are problem sets which are similar. That being said he told us he was giving everyone a generous curve. You will learn a lot but also get frustrated. GET A GOOD PARTNER!

Sesh is probably one of the worst professors I have ever had at Rutgers. He is extremely unaccommodating. This class is the hardest class I have had in my entire degree, and I am graduating this semester. The class is graded based on partner projects, and I have had 3 different partners who have done nothing. The exams are ridiculously hard. Avoid.

All else aside, Sesh is a good lecturer. But as a professor, he only wants to teach you and does not want to answer any of your questions. The first thing he did after class was to run away because he had many side jobs. Even though you paid the tuition, he still wants you to google your questions. Never received an email reply from him.
Horrible lectures that do not teach anything useful, and tests with information that will never be useful. Least understanding professor and will not accommodate circumstances in any way.

Sesh was perhaps one of the profs to who I had to tryhard for to get an A. 60% homework, 15% midterm, 25% final. There was a 2-3% curve for the A. Projects were hard and they kinda pile on during mid semester and there are no practice exams, but he does mention that studying or understanding the psets is an advantage. Good prof, but intensely hard

Great lecturer and nice guy. Understanding of students. Applied VERY generous curve to final grades (but didn't release cuttoffs). Project-heavy. This class is a MAJOR time-sink. Find a good partner or you will suffer (you can just filter people by CS112 grade). Easy midterm on intermediate-level Java, but horribly difficult final on advanced Java.

The way that Sesh teaches 213 makes it extremely informative -- there are so many aspects of Java that you learn in this class as well as general software standards to work with. Lectures are great, only notes are the slides, and the exams are NOT easy, but he gives you everything you need to do really well. Assignments are doable w/ good partner.

Sesh seems like a classy guy. His course is really useful and practical but it could get tough. Assignments were long and a lot of it felt like it had to be self taught. I also found the exams to be pretty difficult. Find a good partner.

Sesh's class was my first official compsci course. 4 assignments are time-consuming but straightforward if you study the material. 3 exams are tough but TAs are open to changing grades if you make a case for yourself. CS210 was definitely the best and most practical class I took at Rutgers
He's an alright professor but the exams are extremely difficult and take up 40% of your course grade. Be prepared before taking cs213 with him.

He goes about his lectures in a way where he kinda expects you to know the basics of everything he teaches and thus he'll ramble about more deeper concepts that might have you lost if you never knew or learned the basics of what he's teaching first. Besides that, finding a good partner is imperative as the projects can be your new livelihood if not
I only passed because of the partner assignments .. but the exams were crazy difficult and I would not take this class again -  avoid him.
Literally does not go over material needed for assignments.

I Don't Like the Structure of His Class! The lectures are really really boring and just teaching some simple stuff in a complex way! Only read the python code in each lecture, it does not relate and does not help with the Assignments and Exams. Simple lectures, very hard and tough assignments, and exams. A horrible professor.

He's a good lecturer and helps you to understand the material. For 210, assignments are fair but they will take time, start them early. Exams are fairly difficult so you need to study. It is a new class to CS so things were a bit disorganized and instructions were a little vague. Ignore the negative comments. Do the work, attend lectures, you pass.

Waited until senior year to review Sesh. Had him 3 times(112,213,210)and he was consistent throughout. Knowledgeable on topics and explains clearly. Assignments have clear instructions and exams are difficult but fair. Has low ratings because freshman/sophomores haven't been through all the CS professors and don't know a good prof when they see one

Worst class I've taken. Course material isn't that hard, but do not expect to learn anything from his lectures. Assignments are disorganized and often changed a couple days before it is due. Exams are extremely hard, class average is usually around 40%. I'm not sure if this class is curved but if it isn't, god help us all. Wouldn't recommend at all

disorganized with content, homework, and tests. Unclear on directions and expects us to know what's in his head. Unpolite when students ask questions and make them feel insecure for not knowing it already.

I have not taken any other course sesh taught, but for CS210, DONT TAKE HIM!!!! He changes the assignment description and requirements two or three days before the due dates every time. The exams are very hard the average was around 50% and seems like he does not give curves or extra credits even he knows everybody was bad. Very horrible professor

A terrible professor that doesn't know what he is doing. Exams are way harder than they need to be and he makes the questions confusing for no reason. He is very unorganized and the structure of the class is extremely bad. Wouldn't recommend him, find some other professor if you can.
Awful

This course is python heavy and while the syllabus makes this class seem interesting and fun, sesh ensures it's nothing like that. Every time I email him with a question, he tells me to email my TA. The TA I was assigned doesn't know English. Exams are poorly structured and graded by unqualified TAs. This class doesn't reward you based on hard work
Horrible content and structure.
He is not good at explaining things, nor having any idea of organizing this course. Don't take this course with him

Fair professor, well organized, fair grading, very useful topics and assignments. Lectures were prerecorded due to COVID. One downside is the forums were the only means for communication between TAs, prof, and peers and were not ideal or engaging. Exams were straightforward. Overall highly recommend.

This semester was weird, class was asynchronous and lectures were online due to COVID. Nevetheless, he's a good lecturer and was pretty leinient this semester. He also gave quizzes which were not bad. However, make sure you really study and understand all the material. This class is NOT easy and expect to put effort in coding assignments and exams.

Weird semester where Sesh split lecture/quiz-creating duties with another professor, and he was much better. Overall I'd say Sesh as the course coordinator did a good job of leading us through the material without making it too overwhelming. It certainly wasn't easy at all, but manageable. If you're coming from CS111, make sure you study big O!
great guy good professor nothing bad to say about him

CS112 was very difficult weed-out course. Lectures were not always most informative, but were good. Some lectures were recorded years ago. Class is graded by a few assignments, so don't expect an A unless this is the only class you are taking

He doesn't teach! He is my assigned professor but I've had little communication from him other than telling us what assignments and quizzes we have and syllabus information. Class is taught by someone completely different.

Some of his assignment's instructions and lecture materials are ambiguous, but in general he's a solid choice and the best option for 112. He doesn't like going out of his way to help students, rather pushes them to figure it out for themselves. This helps in the long run, but can be very unhelpful in the short run. Overall I'd recommend.

BEST PROF - THE LEGEND HIMSELF! If you are looking to really learn data structures and are up for a challenge this is your man. Very clear lectures and very patient with his students. He creates the exams so maybe listen... Find a study group, engage in class, do the hw sets, practice the past exams, start projects early, and join the discord chat
Sesh best CS112 professor.

He knows a lot. But he teaches me nothing. This is the reason I don't like him. I learn this course all by myself. He cannot give clear words for the course. He is not the worst; notwithstanding, he is not good at all.
Erudite, Respectable professor. I believe CS213 he taught is the most useful course for CS major. Also, the assignment is very heavy(thousands of lines codes), so choose your partner carefully.
He makes data structure a little bit easier. Work hard and pass the exam.
Great guy, tough class. Specifically, the exams will really test your CS knowledge. Overall, Sesh is a great professor for this class.

Sesh is a good professor and his videos on YouTube do a great job of explaining the material, but the projects and tests in this class are hard. You really have to put in a lot of effort to to understand the material in order to do well.

If you pay attention to what he's saying/ask questions/engage with the material/use online resources to learn, then this class is okay. He's a good lecturer and very knowledgable. He uses eclipse rather than sublime for ide, and eclipse is so much easier so take him! Time consuming class though!

He's a good guy who definitely knows a lot about java and data structures. I don't really think lecture was critical, but there were a few questions on the tests about something he explicitly mentioned during lecture only. His YouTube videos are extremely valuable though.

First few projects are very good applications of the lecture concepts. UI stuff gets tedious towards the end and is not taught well. Be prepared to spend some time learning on your own. Exams are frustrating with very specific criteria and harsh grading. In general, I perceived a lack of compassion towards the students from the instructor.

He is definitely knowledgable about cs but the way he teaches does not make it easy for people to understand, especially if you have no prior knowledge of programming. I never understood what he was talking about during lecture and his writing on the board is illegible. However, the recitations helped me a lot in understanding the material.

Condescending and arrogant. The type of instructor who thinks this is your only course at RU. Be prepared to teach yourself everything. As much as I dislike Sesh, you should only bother going to Sesh's lectures. He coordinates this course and develops all graded assignments for it. Centeno is always behind, but is reasonable, at the very least.
He's not the best lecturer but not the worst either. Prepare to learn some stuff on your own and work to earn your grade. Projects have a lot of code, and exams get harder and harder.
This class isn't really worth taking because you'd get a better education just looking up the topics on the syllabus online. Sesh is not good at explaining things.
Good Professor. Hard course
Easy to pass but hard to get A

Sesh is an extremely knowledgeable Professor. Most people don't go to class because he posts the slides online but if you're there to learn, I advise sitting for the 80mins. Class is project heavy - don't wait last minute to start them Tests are pretty hard as well Overall: average difficulty with maybe 10-12 hours of work a week? Would reccomend

Sesh's lectures are good for understanding big O concepts, which I found that he went over more in depth than Centeno (the other lecturer for CS112 this semester). Although going to lecture is useful, what will ultimately help you is self-studying and doing the projects on time.

He is so terrible at explaining things in my eyes. Not only do his lectures usually make me more confused about concepts that I am familiar with but his exam questions and assignment descriptions are extremely difficult to understand. The content of the course is not actually that hard, but the way he explains everything makes it so confusing.

He is terrible; he doesn't explain things so students get points off for using methods he didn't clearly say not to do. Also, he assigned a project that was due the day before break and another due two days after break...
Professor Sesh isn't bad. Answers any questions you have during or after the class. Study through his lecture slides and recitation to get away with the exams.
Sesh is a good professor. He knows what he teaches and explains things thoroughly with example programs. The rest is up to you.; go to recitations and start on your projects asap.

Comes off a little condescending at first, but he's a great lecturer. The class itself is very rigorous and while lectures aren't mandatory, you have to go to them if you want to pass. Best advice would be to do the problem sets as you get them, and start the assignments early, cause they take a while even if you're confident in the material

Lectures include a lot of interesting asides about industry best practices and the history behind standard, useful (but boring) object-oriented programming concepts. Almost no guidance on the group projects -- don't take a heavy course load with this class becaus eit also involves a lot of self-learning and group partner negotiation.

Sesh is an amazing professor. He drills the concepts into your head by making you discover the topic as you learn it. I felt enlightened after every class. Sesh was also very funny and was so respected no one even thought about skipping his lectures. Clearly tells you what to expect on the exams and how to prepare for them. Definitely recommend.
Best teacher for data structures. Lectures are pretty good and if you pay attention and engage yourself you will get a lot from them. Has a tendency to be curt at times, but overall is very nice.
Amazing professor for 112, just make sure you dont procrastinate on your assignments and getting an A shouldnt be too hard

Prof. Venugopal is a solid professor for Software Methodology.  His class is generally very applicable in the real world (speaking from experience), and he lectures well.  Lecture slides are posted online, but I chose to attend lectures since they were helpful  I would've done better if I'd taken the group projects more seriously. Great overall. :
Solid professor, 112 is a tough class but you can pull through if you have a passion for the material. Sesh gives you every opportunity to pass the class as long as you put in the effort.

This class is responsible for my internship. Sesh teaches you everything you need to know to pass most java interviews. He's a very fair grader but isn't too lenient for people who don't follow directions. Beware of the group projects. The exams are difficult but I expect a decent curve.

Sesh is absolutely amazing! He is hilarious, especially when some student in his class thinks they know more about the concepts he's teaching than he does. As long as you go to lecture and fully understand the previous lesson before moving on to the next one, you'll be fine. The course builds on top of its own material so keep up!
Tough grader. Unclear instructor.
Sesh is the man

I took only 12 credits at the time, but the amount of work that I put into the class was insane. Often times Sesh would explain a concept poorly and when I went to office hours, he would give me vague answers.

His lectures are often not clear so I ended up having to rely on other professors or videos. Every time I asked him a question, he would not respond or he would give a really vague answer. I would try to take Tjang instead.

Sesh is clear in his teaching and knows his stuff. But he has his own world when it comes to grading and what his assignments and exam questions mean. And if you aren't aware of what he wants, which often times requires reading his mind, your already unable to get full credit. Data structures isnt easy, but he makes it way harder than it should be.
Sesh is extremely intelligent and friendly. He's always there to help, as long as you put in the effort. I had him for 111 and 112, and I wish I could take him again. Gonna miss the man next year.

When he writes on the board is it not legible at all, he talks so quickly and is very unclear about certain subjects unless you stop and ask him. I personally did not like him as my professor but he can be a good one to others.

I don't think he's a bad teacher. Personally, I think that there should be a class between 111 and 112 because the jump in difficulty is ridiculous. You have to self teach yourself a lot of things that he uses is 112 that  weren't taught in 111. Tough assignments and exam but he's willing to help if you're willing to put in the work.

I really hate that people say he's a bad prof because he's not! He just doesn't spoon feed you answers like many people want. The class is tough but so is computer science! If you go to his office hours, he'll help you out. If you're not willing to put in the extra work, this isn't the class for you. But don't blame him because he is a great prof!
I would not take him... His expectations are too high.

Not exactly a teacher but a broker-type of a professor. He expects prior knowledge/experience from CS industry in 100 level classes and wish to hand out degrees only to those people. His lectures will rarely help you unless you had strong grasp of materials to begin with.

Sesh gives us difficult material to work with so we have room to learn. He wants to make sure that people understand the material. I can say that everyone who does well in the class definitely has a strong grasp on the material. Those who don't fare well are the ones who don't pay attention in lecture and don't put their mind to the challenge.
So unhelpful. Every time I tried to speak to him he deferred me to someone else. Taught an intro class as if you were supposed to have prior knowledge of programming.

A very good teacher. You will learn a lot from him. But he is tough. Exams are tough. He is a tough grader. I got 30 out of 100 on my 3rd hw assignment because I didn't use one  and only one method from the IO module which was to display the result. Ofcourse professor Tjang was the course coordinator I went up to him he hollered at me and brushed m

Professor Sesh is a really nice and genuine guy. He's clearly extremely knowledgeable and very kind during office hours. His class has made me switch my major to Computer Science. Side note -- he also wrote a very good novel that has nothing to do with computer science.

hes super chill once we had class outside  i had sesh for 111 and 213 and andrew for 112 do not take sesh for 111, andrew is the better option there and for 112 sesh or andrew will do  in 213 sesh just reads from slides ,pretty dull, so i never went to class got a b+ (my assignments were all As, cant say the same for exams)

Sesh  is a great lecturer, though they can be at times long and boring. His exams are really difficult, but with some effort, good grades can be pulled off. As for assignments, they were fair for the most part. In regards to prior exams and hw, the grading was nit-picky. As a heads up, the final avg was 47% and min pass grade was in the low 50s.

I really enjoy Sesh's lectures. He  explained the material well. I had Tjang for 111 but I wouldn't say that Tjang is better or worse for 112. But I was told Sesh's section usually scored higher on th exams than the rest.

The course could definitely be better, the assignments are dated and he tries to cram as much material into the semester as possible. Instead of assigning smaller projects like in 112, in 213 he gives you a few GIANT projects - ALL WITH PARTNERS. Assignments have nothing to do with that's taught in lecturerecitation. Amazing curve though.

Sesh is a great professor for Intro to Comp Sci. He is very approachable and will help you with whatever questions you have whether during class or outside of class. Do note CS 111 is not an easy class, so going to him when you have trouble with something will definitely help.
If your reading this, its too late. lol seriously though as far as teachers go sesh is fair, tough grader, but helps you understand the material
This professor told me to reconsider my major, no motivation here. Horrible professor.

please understand that to do well in the exams you have to do the problem sets and also read the text book because he wrote the text book so reading it will definitely help you for exams. I am talking from experience so anyone planning to take this class please do the work and do not try to take shortcuts because i payed the price for doing that

Sesh is a knowledgeable guy and a good lecturer. If you're looking to learn you came to the right place because he literally wrote the textbook. He is a fair grader and applies fair curves. That being said he is merciless if you dont follow instructions. I spent 15 hours on an assignment and submitted it incorrectly and received zero credit for it.
Really hard assignments and exams.
He needs to change his teaching habits and attitude towards students.  He might be a good person but it has nothing to do with making the students feel comfortable and at ease.
Very knowledgeable and willing to help. He has a bit of an accent according to classmates, but he is definitely understandable.

Very knowledgeable on Java and will be able to answer any questions / problems you're having with ease. Lecturing however is brutal and even "front-rowers" find it very difficult to maintain focus. A general lack of enthusiasm toward the subject matter. Exams in all his courses are hard and this one is loaded with heavy Java assignments as well.
His exams were really challenging. Assignments/Projects were hard too. But he is a nice person. Would help you to understand materials if you go to his office hours.

Very boring and doesn't create interest in the material. He is not really helpful with Android development at all. Assignments and projects feel like two classes. His exams are famous for being difficult. You need a partner for the projects so make sure you end up with a capable person, or this class can get overwhelming.

It's hard to follow him during class. He'll just type in stuff into eclipse, but wouldn't explain what he's doing. I ended up going to Tjang's lectures and learned a lot more. Also, his lectures are very dry. Wouldn't recommend.

Good prof. clear and organized. DO THE PROBLEM SETS! I cannot stress that enough. He always puts one problem from them on each test. Hard material, but read the book and do the work and you should manage at least a B. what he asks is reasonable though as long as you are trying.

There is a ton of work involved in CS213, almost feels like two classes. He did a great job of having the information laid out for you to learn, but his actual lectures were generally unhelpful. I also think he writes the worst exams in the department. I feel like writing programs on paper never works out, and his questions are hard to interpret.

Good teacher, dry lectures at times. Assignments are average difficulty, quizzes are fair. Read the book he writes! Assignments once about every two weeks, each count up from 7% to 10% of your grade. Midterms and Finals are very difficult, but do well on assignments to anchor that. Overall difficult but manageable class.

Really good teacher overall.  Explained everything visually using both the computer (eclipse) and the chalk board.  Answered all questions asked in class thoroughly.  I do not know how he is at office hours though.  I've never been to one of Tjang's lectures so I do not know where Professor Venugopal stands when compared to Tjang.

This course starts off at the same difficulty level as CS111 but quickly esclates in difficulty before the second exam. I recommend you do very well on the assignments to do well in this class. Sesh's exams require a lot of efficiency analysis & he teaches it very well but many people dislike his teaching because it's dry compared to Andrew's.

This man is an amazing teacher and I'm so glad I took him. If someone complains about him it's probably because they expected this class to be easy like 111 but it's much more difficult and actually requires you to think a bit more. Great guy and he speaks English well!

His exams are really hard, especially the 2nd midterm and final. Clicker Quizzes are also hard, so HW is your saving grace. He basically makes you learn the material on your own, and then he'll just scratch the surface of it in his 50 minute lectures. He knows what he is talking about, but he just appeared bored in class. HW is long but doable.
Take Tjang for CS111. This guy is intelligent and knows what he's talking about, but the course is organized and ran by Tjang.

First class he told us we will not need the book, but then assigned reading almost every week. Also uses Eclipse. He told us we don't have to, but then required assignment submission as an eclipse project. He covers the basics and doesnt explain harder material that well, then expects us to know the material inside-out by next class.
Extremely dry, boring, uninteresting. Acts like you know the material like a genius. Exams are impossible. HW is your saving grace but its hard too. Average is F.

the class it self is hard, big programming assignments, and they are kind of hard, if you do them all than you should be good. Overall if you know what you are doing than you are good, otherwise you'll be stuck forever

He definitively knows his stuff and his lectures were good. His book is okay. But the exams are beyond HARD. The average is normally F (below 50). The good thing is that the hw assignments help your grade by A LOT. So do not get lazy on those!

Great professor, take 111 with him! Come to lectures, sit in front rows and participate. I did that and got 100 on both midterms without studying, and I never did anything computer science related before. Unlike all my other professors, Sesh actually bothered to teach the material in an interesting way and make sure students understood it :)
What an amazing professor!!! He knows his material and covers it well he is such an asset to Rutgers' CS dept

The assignments do NOT make scence in fact its a gussing game to how the skeliton code works, i rather do it from nothing then to use it sometimes. He wrote the book we use so he fallows it pretty closly, in fact you can just no go to class and read that days work in around 20 min .... awesome!

Honestly, I think he doesn't know much of his stuff. His lectures are confusing, which makes a hard course even harder.  His lectures seem to have less or no connection with what the actual course and assignments. Trust me, his teaching methods need to be rectified.

He is a fairly good teacher... Alot of people say crap about him cause they compare him to Hari, but he ain't so bad... I actually learned a pretty decent amount in his class... Be sure to do the hw assignments tho... they help alot when it comes to learning java

While his exams are hard, he does try to tell you what will be on it since he creates the exams. However, sometimes there's just too much material too know. Your best bet to even passing the class is to do well on the homeworks so you have more cushion for the final exam! The final exam is the hardest!
Super boring. not helpful. not understanding. In fact, he is very rude. class is extremely hard and his teaching methods are very very boring.
Classes are unbearably boring! Doesn't really lecture, just comes to class and opens it for discussion.

He is one of the smartest Profs at RU for CS. Very helpful and understanding. His exams are pretty hard but he curves them. So hope the whole class screwed up like you did and you'll be fine! His projects are ok and if you can work heard on them, you'll be fine. Overall, he is the best if you need to take this class..

One of the cool professors at RU. Very helpful and pretty intelligent. Exams are pretty hard. But projects and assignments are relatively the ones that scores points. So, if you do them, you are gold. He is not arrogant as some quoted.. Seems to be he is fairly reasonable.. A good guy to get advise on your CS Future.

He is one of the smartest Profs and is willing to help you out. He is really good at explaining things. Not sure what people mean he is thick headed. He is a cool dude. Willing to answer any of your questions. If you know Java You are gurenteed to get a B. His notes are of not much help. Do the HWs and assignments. His exams are not cool. Some Hard

Seth is a cool dude, but this class is entirely too hard and he is not a good teacher. He really is meant to do research and teach 113, he will make you absolutely hate compsci after 112 unless you are VERY competent with compsci. This class is basically just crazy difficult and sesh is no help, take Hari, he enjoys teaching much more than sesh
No Comments
Ok professor, course is very basic. All theoretical, not really useful for most people. He wrote the book and his attitude shows it.
DECENT- do your homeworks, you'll be fine
cs113 is a useless class.but Sesh is good. His class is not hard , as long as you go to class and listen to him, do the assigments and problem sets, you pretty much get a B.
Interesting material, good teaching, hard exams and questionable grading.

Sesh is really knowledgeable about what he teaches and is a great teacher. However, the class is just WAY too hard. If you thought CS111 was hard, I suggest that you rethink taking CS112 as it is hellishly hard. He's good at teaching the subject matter, but the assignments and exams are killer. Sesh looks like an indian version of George Clooney.

Sesh is interesting, some days he is strict and stubborn, and other days he is friendly and extremely helpful and understanding. In 112, he changed the grading policy mid-semester which cost me a grade and pretty much told me tough luck. In 113, he gave me an extension on a major project. On the whole, he's a good prof and generally knowledgable.

That book of his has gotten to his head. Just because he wrote the text-book for his class doesn't mean he's the best teacher (don't fall for this). He asks very in-depth questions on the exams, but doesn't prepare you for them in class.

I think Sesh knows his stuff, but he makes this class too difficult, discouraging students from pursuing computer science. This is sad that so many students changed their life long goals because of this single class.

Great teacher! One of the best teachers I've had at Rutgers. His book is very well written. He knows the material well, and can relate to the students very well. He's also funny. He's very clear on the topics, and breaks them up into very nice segments. Yes his exams may not be the easiest, but he's trying to prepare us for the future. Study notes!
if u r not a CS and if u have to do this class....ABSOLUTELY do it in the summer...sesh is a good professor...but he makes it DAMN hard.

He didnt like me and along with half the class, I failed. He was a good professor, he knew what he was talking about. But those exams, were way too hard and with averages of 15 out of 100, its hard to do well.

He's a good professor in the mix.  He is one of the most interesting CS professors in the Rutgers department - this doesn't say much, but it is still pretty good.  He likens recursive programming to acid.  It's pretty sweet.  Take his class.

Sesh rocks.  If you actually care about your work and you want to learn CS the right way, then you'll find he is very helpful.  All of you who gave him a bad rating will most likely change your mind after taking more classes in CS.

I don't understand the arrogant comments people have made...Sesh is very approachable and always does his best to help. The material is extremely difficult, but he breaks everything up and makes it seem simple.  All in all, a great teacher!

horrible horrible teacher.  very unhelpful and arrogant.  he cant teach for s**t.  i mean, does an exam average of 33% with 90 people taking it say much about his teaching skills?  hell yeah, he cant teach, simple and plain.
Horrible.  He is isanely arrogant and won't help you out at all.

Awesome teacher. DONT TAKE HARI...TAKE SESH...Much better teacher. if ur good at computer u'll do fine.  just go to class and pay attention...and really pay attention during recitations..gets harder at the end...
He is one of the best CS teachers I ever had. But be ready to work hard.

wow i love sesh. hes great. he may seem arrogant and that hes so much better than u, but he is a really good professor and u start to understand that hes kinda putting u in your place and prepare u mentally for upper level classes.
No Comments

At first, Sesh seems so hard and students complain about him.  But if you stick around in the cs program, you'll see that he is one of the best teachers at Rutgers, especially for DBMS.  Yes, he's challenging, but if you wanna be a cs major, get used to it.  At least he explains things clearly.
Very good

Sesh is the most beautiful human being I have ever laid my eyes on.  His smile makes life worth living.  The class is difficult, but his gleaming eyes make everything seem ok again.  Sesh, if you're reading, will you father my children?
worse CS prof

At the time I was a CS major I felt that prof's were not adequately prepared to teach material. Sesh is soooo arrogant in class, walks around with his chest pumped up, makes students feel stupid. On top of that, teaches absolutely nothing that helps on Programming assignments. Easy exams-I got 99.

Great professor. For data structures, does great job teaching material. For DBMS, did an awsome job making seemingly boring material sound practical and interesting. Tests are hard, but you will walk away prepared for upper-level classes and real life experience.

Sesh is a great professor but the material is just hard.  If you never had a computer science class before don't take this class! Most of the people i talked to failed and were retaking it. If you need to take it i heard Sesh is so much better then anyone.

This guy should be locked up he's soooo bad!!! He is sooooo freaken bad as a professor that he makes the whole cs department look bad! What a waste of good rutgers money! This guy is really terrible and all the students deserve better.
HOT!!!
One of the hardest classes I've ever taken because of his impossible teaching style, but he was still one of the best teachers I've ever had.

I was so stressed out the entire semester. My parents even thought I was****d or something after one of the programming exams because I was crying. But I studied like a mad person for the final and got a B for the class. Looking back, the class wasn't so

I got a B in cs111 and then an F in this class. What really sucks are the sunday programming exams - 3 methods in 2 hrs. if it doesnt compile you get 0/100. The problem sets definetly help the most for the programming exams.
Wow, he knows his stuff and he presents it clearly.

Good lecturer, but sometimes does not go into as much detail as I'd hoped he would.  Class is not hard, go to class, do the project, B without a sweat, A with some elbow grease.  Sesh seems very approachable, but sometimes can be intimidating.
i was so stressed out for this class until i finally bought first class notes. They eased my pain and helped me comprehend better.
he's good at lecturing but if you ever approach him for help after class or in his office hours he's way too disparaging
SMART guy. Really knows his course work. Great sense of humor. The course is INSANELY difficult and the prog assignments are rough.
tough conceptual material presented clearly.  He is  hands on  and funny.
He knows his stuff and can teach it quite effectively and he's funny too. But the class is kind of hard though and grading is pretty tough.
excellent posted notes and lectures for a difficult intro class, pretty cool
liked how the course allowed you to make up your grade if you messed up on an exam as the hws really helped raise grades and personally I learned more through the hws than exams.
You can tell he is genuinely a nice person, but unfortunately his lectures aren't the most helpful and the class isn't the most organized.

really liked everything I learned. This was the first class where I really used Python, and it was really exciting to see how effective the language is in data cleaning and processing. In addition, I knew very little about machine learning, but now I'm confident in my skills, especially after the final project. The class was always exciting.

Really like him, made lecture enjoyable. Offered career opportunities and was a lovely person to learn from. Class assignments were manageable. Easily recommend this professor, he makes this easy class fun to be a part of.

He will make you enjoy data science and coding. Though he is a little disorganized and uncoordinated, he is excellent at teaching concepts. He always patiently answers all student questions as well. Definitely try to take him for CS210.

although he is disorganized, he is a very nice professor and is also enthusiastic about lectures. class is project heavy with 4 assignments (30%), 5 quizzes (20%), participation (10%), midterm1 (10%), midterm2 (15%), and final project (15%). there is no final exam but the final project is comprehensive.

I thoroughly enjoyed having him as a professor for this class. I feel like I've learnt so much useful information and am definitely now considering data analysis as a future career path! I've even registered for other data science courses that align with the major because of how much I've come to appreciateÂ data management this semester.
The shining star of the Rutgers CS Department.

prof is Enthusiastic, cheerful, and approachable. He encouraged curiosity, linked lessons to real-world use cases, and supported student learning with extra resources (e.g., Cubits videos). I liked the class.

He teaches alongside an AI, which would be fine if he actually knew what he was teaching. He seems to not prepare for his lectures, and changes his exam dates several times in the week leading up to the exam. His assignments are reasonable, and he grades reasonably, but it's his way or the highway, and nothing is his fault. Don't recommend.
He's a great teacher. The class was enjoyable and getting a good grade was very doable.
Chill guy, chill class. Would take again

Guna is fine, but I wish he coordinated with his TAs more, since they had a lot of conflicting information. I don't like his required attendance policy, its all very unclear too. I probably could have gotten an A if I bothered to show up more. Final project was cool though, I liked how he let you go wild as long as you fulfilled his requirements.

Attendance required but easy class if you do the work. 4-5 Labs:35%, 5 Quizzes:20%, Midterm: 20%, Course Project:15%, Attendance:10%. Project seems tough since you have to come up with your idea for what to do but they are easy on the grading. Recitation attendance also required. Uploads lecture slides online. Does a curve based on everyone's grade

He's a good lecturer and fair grader. Genuinely cares about his students learning, and his lectures reflect that. That being said he is very disorganized and does not give clear criteria on how he will grade you on assignments and even for the class, so be prepared to just guess on a lot of things. However he is very approachable and understanding.

Really nice guy, but incredibly disorganized. The labs are difficult not because of material but because you have to decipher what they're asking you to do in the first place + TAs will all respond differently on the piazza. There is literally no review material given for examsâ€”barely any practice problems and any given won't have solutions.

super nice professor but the organization was questionable. every hw (lab) was vague and often had errors or missing information that made it so you spent more time figuring out what the questions were asking than actually solving them. The midterm review materials given was not thorough enough
Professor Gunawardena was great, just great. An extremely caring and talented professor that taught Discrete I in a very digestible way that was easy to understand.
thoroughly enjoyed intro to Computer Science and Discrete I classes. his teaching style was just really inspiring and engaging.

I have previously studied under his guidance in Discrete Structures 1 and found his teaching style very approachable and effective. I appreciated how open and responsive he was to my questions, which greatly enhanced my learning experience. I plan to take another class with him.
it was an amazing semester, I really enjoyed the class lectures and cubits videos and also the practical labs. It is hard to get into the class, but highly recommended.
I really enjoyed the discrete 1 class along with his teaching style. great class

Although I took two other Computer Science classes this spring semester, this is the one professor whose class I truly enjoy. I was not a fan at first, but as time went on this class allowed me to think in a very different manner. Allowing me to think outside of the box, which is what I enjoy doing.

Students had to correct Guna in almost every lecture, multiple times, for contradicting himself. He rarely considers his students' feedback seriously and stands his ground when he's wrong or being inconsistent. In a standardized class like 205, it's crucial that concepts are communicated and tested with the same standards.

thoroughly enjoyed lectures and discussions, finding them insightful and engaging. The diverse topics covered in lectures, from data visualization to machine learning, provided a comprehensive understanding of data science. great semester!

Pay attention in class, do the work (labs, practice exams, quizzes, note problems, cubits), ask questions if you're stuck and you'll be fine. There are plenty of resources in the class. Personally learned much more ML than my ML professor last semester. Labs can be confusing at times by wording. He was disorganized with final exam prep for our sem.
bro.

Prof Gunawardena isn't the most engaging lecturer but he does enough. Grading is pretty lenient but some problems on the problem sets can be a bit confusing. Luckily, many answers can be found in the textbook, cubits, or online. Practice exams are given but the solutions are often wrong and after the class is the only real time to ask questions.

the course was great to not only develop the fundamentals of artificial intelligence and data science but also shape passion for the field. I like professors excitement about the subject and his involvement with the various research projects is really interesting.

Professor Guna is a fantastic professor and is a really nice guy. Having a professor who is positive and happy throughout a lecture can make the topic more enjoyable. His lectures are pretty good/decent I would say, but he is fair with grading. For exams, he gives points back if the question was extremely difficult and if no one got it correct.
I learned so much from this course and he is an amazin professor. after taking the class it really feel like I am prepped well for a data science career.

This class with Guna was alright. If you pay attention and take the class seriously, you'll do well. The projects and material were actually very interesting. The problem is just that his lectures are boring and his projects are VERY disorganized, to the point where I stopped caring about the class. Take this class with friends and you'll be fine

Nice man who thinks smiling and being friendly makes up for his horrendous organization. The lecture slides and notes are totally incoherent, even though I had experience with ML, I felt like I actually unlearned things by trying to piece together what anything meant for the exams. The labs were full of typos and unclear questions.
I learned a lot of relevant material for my career, and found the projects to be thought provoking and interesting.

Disorganized. All the labs were filled with errors (wrong values for problems/telling us to solve for the wrong variables), typos, etc. Couldn't even edit the text boxes code is supposed to go in because it was set to read-only. Grade reports were also wrong and he counted attendance wrong despite us filling out attendance forms every day of class.

Prof. Guna at Rutgers is intelligent but disorganized. Always late and a slow grader. He doesn't attend his exams, leaving TAs in charge. Bittner's students also just pulled out their phones during the exam; meanwhile, Guna had a seating arrangement. Avoid his section; he's less accessible for questions compared to others like Bittner.
I learned a lot from his teaching. he is great a professor

Pretty solid professor. His slides are good, but you need to attend if you want to know the answers to exercise problems. Quizzes are annoying but doable. His labs are a dumpster fire though; it feels like they were made without proofreading and instructions are often very unclear, while some of the questions were just flat out dumb.
I took his class because one of my senior friends, always talks about how interesting this class is and how great a professor he was. I had fun.

Intro to Discrete Structures was an eye-opening experience for me. Despite initial apprehensions about the perceived difficulty of discretee mathematics. Profs ability to simplify complex concepts and make them accessible to students like me is truly commendable, and it made a significant impact on my learning experience.

I loved the class. his dedication and enthusiasm for the subject matter were evident in his teaching style and the assignments. Lectures delved into the subject matter with remarkable depth. I highly recommend this professor.

very great professor. he like to explain concepts carefully with some clear examples, which really helped me a lot. Before I took this course, I had no foundation in Data Science. After taking CS439, I really learned a good deal.

Nice guy but horrible at teaching. Dude will lecture about something random and then do one hard math example and expect you to know it from there. Not to mention he makes so many mistakes and never corrects them and expects you to know and correct it yourself. Labs are enjoyable though. Also you have to use his IDE, his vid platform, his gradebook

He is a great and funny guy, but I recommend actuallygoing to lecture, however annoying it may seem, because intro to comp sci with him is very fast-paced. So actually go to lectures or you will fall behind

Data Science to is my most likely niche that I will be building into as I look to graduate College.  I could not ask for a better opportunity to learn and further develop my Data Science knowledge taking the class with this prof.
I have taken several classes with him, and I like his teaching style and find it to be very engaging and enjoyed all of them.

I liked his lectures as he is a great professor, but he did get confused at times and missed many things. He isn't very detailed; he is just the professor for a self-studying person who needs help revising and reviewing the course materials. Solves the doubt instantly and doesn't care about anything except teaching.

Everything in the course is very fair, and grade-wise lectures and recitation are counted as extra credit, as well as online supplemental videos that can give a lot of EC as well. Homework (problem sets) are very doable and cover lecture/supplemental material and TAs are quick to respond to any questions. Informative lectures as well.
This course was great! The labs were definitely my favorite part and I could've done without the final, but overall very enjoyable class!

Labs and assignments are well designed; however, he forces you to use an IDE developed by him, which is still in beta. Good luck dealing with library compatibility issues if you prefer your own IDE. Everything else in this course is poorly designed. Exams are pointless in this course; it's a coding class; let me program and learn.

He is just fine, lecture can't help you a lot, you have to read the book to do more practice. Something I don't like it's the cubits video, there are some quizzes on it, for some of those are "choose all that apply" which means the correct answers only show up when you got the correct answer. He is a nice guy, but .... yea
amazing teacher.

Awful lecturer, very boring and doesn't know the subject that he's teaching. Can answer very simple questions (though sometimes gives the wrong answer), but doesn't know enough to be able to answer questions that will be on quizzes, exams, homework, etc. Many people give him a 4 or 5 because of his "personality", so don't look at the rating at top.

Puts 0 effort during lectures. Constantly makes mistakes and have to correct him. He never thoroughly explained any concepts. His cubits are useless and full of mistakes. The cubits are also just stolen content from Youtube.

it was engaging to learn about CS topics more theoretically. Taking a step back from writing code pushed me to see how I could design more efficient and robust algorithms. The in CS 205 designed by this professor made me reinforce healthy study habits and sharpened my ability to understand complex technical concepts. I would recommend this class.
TA does better job than professor. He needs to retire!!!

Great professor. Lectures reflect his interest in the subject and he has a lot of interesting things to share about Computer Science, though he makes mistakes during lecture. Only complaint is that the midterms and exams can be hard. Best advice is to do textbook problems, quizzes, and watch his CuBits.
YO GUNNA IS THE GOAT
Ngl Guna wasn't the best at teaching and a lot of the material I had to learn on my own. But I loved Guna's class because his of personality and quirks.

I found CS205 to be rather difficult. Guna is a great professor and has really entertaining and fun lectures, but the class was graded hard. Exam questions are difficult, and the problem sets aren't much easier. You will have to do a lot of studying on your own with the online videos to understand all of the material
learned a lot in the class and really enjoyed the labs, especially the mid-semester project. Class gave me a lot of new perspective and insights which will be helpful as I join the industry.
Boring lectures
Great professor! Gives opportunities for students to be successful!
Amazing professor! Take him for CS 111 if you have prior knowledge of Java.
I really liked his style of teaching. He wants you to be prepared by watching lectures and then you can follow his lectures well.

START YOUR PROJECTS EARLY. Data structures is only hard if you make it hard. Make you sure you have a firm grasp of each data structure you learn as they are the foundation for your future in comp sci. They arent difficult to learn. Guna is a straightforward lecturer, good but nothing special. The exams arent difficult if you know your stuff well.

I had Prof. Guna for Intro to Data Science (439). Overall, it was an easy class, but his lectures were mediocre. We were given quizzes about every two weeks, and they were very easy, but the final exam was much more difficult (though it was graded pretty leniently). The assignments/labs are the best part of the course, they were fun and interesting
Really great teacher who explains topics and questions, one of the best comp sci teachers.

Didn't go to class too often, but when I was there he was relatively engaging and would ask questions and all. When I went to office hours there were a couple people, but he still gave me time to answer my question and was helpful. He also tries to keep lecture light-mooded which is nice.

He's a good professor. Very friendly man! Clearly knows the material and explains it well. He makes videos and uploads them online which I find very helpful! His exams are surprisingly HARD though not impossible with enough studying.

Professor Guna was a very funny nice and caring professor. I think the way in which he organized the class could have gone much better. His exams are not super hard but I found the quizzes to be somewhat unfair and people failed them. The labs are easy but dont prepare you for any of the assessments. Overall he tries his best to help.

Andy was unclear at times, but usually, he knew what he was teaching and you could tell that he was pretty knowledgable in discrete structures. The class was a bit disorganized, but for the most part, it wasn't too challenging and you learn tons from it.

A really good professor! He knows his stuff, really nice and understanding. Adds video lectures online for more details. Lectures may be a bit boring like everyone else has said, but strongly recommend him!

Willing to answer any questions you have and explain concepts well. Lectures can get boring, but makes it up by being genuinely interested in the material and makes jokes here and then. Also does in lecture coding workshops so you get a chance to code. Go to his lectures and recitations and you'll understand everything. Overall Andy was great.
Funny dude, lectures can get boring. Often goes off topic, paying attention helps. Recitations really help in reviewing.
I love Andy

This professor DOES NOT round up. I was missing A by 0.45% and he refused to round up due to â€œcourse policiesâ€ he says. He isnt obligated to change my grade but never expect even a single point of extra credit from him. And he DOES NOT curve, even when the class average is really low.

Very boring professor, he literally introduced the course saying that it won't be as exciting as we might have imagined. Outright admitted that he lowkey ripped off UC Berkeley's AI course for us. Didn't reveal much information about exams, we had to constantly consult outside material to understand what was going on. Disappointing experience.

His exams were worded confusingly, and on top of that he didn't show up to a single exam to be able to answer questions about these confusingly worded questions. So with exams you're kinda left on your own and there's no curve. Also his lectures are very hard to understand and read and they are all ripped off of UC Berkeley's course.

This guy is a legend in terms of giving you chances to improve your grade. Gives you many extra credits and gives you a second chance to take midterms again and get a higher score, which helps your grade. But he does speed through the lectures so have to catch up on what he taught. Overall he is a nice professor and TA in section 9 is helpful too.
super easy A
The TA'S are unhelpful. professor is a nice guy tho

Professor Lau is an outstanding instructor. His lectures are clear, well-structured, and engaging, making technical concepts feel approachable and manageable. He creates a positive and welcoming classroom environment, and his teaching style makes it easy to stay motivated throughout the semester. Highly recommend Professor Lau to anyone.

First time it's taught in a while so a lot of the instructions were confusing, but really nice professor. 30% zybooks, 70% 2ppl semester long project (midterm/final are checkpoints). I think this class will run a lot smoother in the future and I would recommend it, he wants you to get an A if you listen and do the project properly.
Cares for student success

This professor is highly approachable, engaging, and creates a positive, welcoming classroom atmosphere. He brings humor and warmth to every lecture, even bringing candy on Halloween and pizza on the last day. Although the course isn't the easiest, he makes it feel manageable through his clear and supportive teaching
Amazing professor with a lot of opportunities for extra credit. Lets you replace your final exam score for any of the exams during the semester so plenty of opportunities to improve your grade.

Professor Lau is an amazing instructor! His lectures are very clear and well-organized, making even difficult coding and concepts easy to understand. He is always willing to help students and patiently answers every question, both during and after class. You can tell he genuinely cares about his students' learning. Highly recommend taking his class

Please take Professor Lauâ€˜s class! He is extremely fair and transparentâ€”he tells you exactly what's important for each exam, gives plenty of review material, and genuinely cares about his students' success. He knows the class is tough, but he makes it manageable with extra credit and a generous curve. You'll walk away with real understanding.

A lot of self-teaching. I learned more from youtube than from him. He flies through lectures and expects you to know everything already. He was nice, but whenever I would ask him a question, he would make me more confused. Exams were super hard and so was the homework. If you don't have any prior comp sci knowledge, this will be a difficult class.

Great dude. I suck at coding, but I got a B+ from all the extra credit that was offered. Super chill, super nice. Textbook is there, but I didn't buy it. You don't really need it, and to be honest, if you know how to code, super easy class. If you don't, there's tools online to help you understand. 10/10.

Take Lau!! He tells you exactly what you need to know for each exam ahead of time, gives 20 points of extra credit, and genuinely wants to see you succeed. He knows the class is hard and does everything he can to make sure everyone passes with a good grade. It is rare people get less than a B with the curve at the end of the sem. Super nice guy!

At this point, I feel like some of the good reviews are fake. He's barely helpful and the exams are very difficult. If you are not a coding savvy person, pick another professor because he cannot teach properly.

You probably don't need to go to lectures. The link to the videos from the professor who teaches the async section were on canvas, so I watched those to do the labs and study for tests. Attend recitation if you want some extra credit points. The labs can get difficult and time consuming (with no cs knowledge) but the tests are nowhere near as hard.

Avoid at all costs, and do not let these ratings fool you; he is very bad. He doesn't really teach and rushes over the slides. He's also not helpful, so your grade mostly depends on how good your TA is. The assignments are tedious, and the exams would be crazy. He could've given better reviews, but he just chooses not to.

This class can be very easy if you know what you are doing, lectures were not that helpful in my opinion. But the professor is a very nice guy who will try to help if you ask for it. There is alot of homework though.

Every time I go to class, I feel like there was a prereq I should've taken beforehand. He spends like 2 seconds on the slides and talks as if you know what he's talking about. The assignments are easy if you go to office hours. Exams are in person. He gives extra credit every Thursday and gives you the answer but the content is confusing imo

Mr Lau goes over the slides during class but won't cover all the material. He gives extra credit in class, which is easy. As long as you study, you will get a good grade. The homework doesn't really take long either, and if you don't know how to do it, you can go to recitation and ask for help. If you have a question, you can also ask him for help.

Professor Lau gives extra credit every week basically and mostly gives you the answers but shows he wants you to genuinely learn the material. He reviews material that students request and sometimes the HWs are confusing, but TA recitations and lectures should help. Have heard that other professors aren't that great so Lau is probably ideal.

Knowing nothing about coding at all going into this class, he definitely is so knowledgeable, and I feel like I learned a lot. He is always available for questions at the end of lectures. He would have so many extra credit opportunities that directly related to the assignments we would be doing.

Lau is a really nice guy and was always willing to offer extra explanation when needed. The way the class is structured it's not hard to get an A. Goes through slides kind of fast sometimes but you can always ask for clarification. Exams/assignments were not bad

Nice dude and easy prof, lots of assignments so there are many opportunities to do well outside of exams. The extra credit from the lectures helps a lot especially if your TA is a tough grader for the assignments. As long as you do the work it's really hard to fail

Amazing prof. Makes the class as easy as it can be. Lectures are optional but he gives a lot of extra credit that help a lot. Parts of the class are hard but most of it is easy. If you're taking it in person take him.

JUST TAKE HIM HE'S AWESOME!!!!! literally an easy class coming from a person who knew ZERO coding. super nice guy, lots of extra credit, homework doesn't take too long.  the sample exams are all you need to study before the exam. (everyone either gets an A or B in this class he told us)
Literally such a hard class and he hasn't responded to any of my emails literally save me

Professor Lau teaches the course material well; I understood some topics better after he taught them in class. He does skip over some topics due to the 55 minute class, so make sure you read the textbook for the exams. Try to do the extra credit he gives! For the course: DO the assignments, ask TAs for help with concepts, study the vocab as well.
Really cares about his students and will definitely help you if you ask for it!
Prof. Lau is impressive! I took his class before and it's really helpful. And Prof. Lau is so nice and he has answered all my questions in a short time. Highly recommend.

he posts all the slideshows which are useful. however, there is one extremely long and tedious assignment for homework each week. your grade in the class depends on your ta. unfortunately, my ta was a really tough grader and unclear when teaching.

The professor's professional abilities are highly commendable. Their teaching style is both unique and effective, simplifying complex concepts for easier understanding. The professor's dedication to student understanding and passion for the subject matter are truly inspiring.

Lau is a great professor. Recitations for this course are the most important. You don't really have to go to lecture to pass. Earned an A from attending weekly recitations. Make sure your recitation instructor is good and clear, or you prob won't do well. Assignments can be very tedious. Recitation instructor grades every assignment and exam.

Straightforward in the lessons he gives. I think that he does a better job in showing code and its processes rather than the conceptual stuff though, I nearly fell asleep whenever he'd talk about conceptual things. Assignment heavy, but he is open to answering questions and answers them in good fashion.
Professor was great and really showed great insight into the material. It is an assignment-heavy course, and feel free to ask questions if you are stuck. Made this difficult class easy for me.

Focus on the assignments cuz they're worth almost half of your grade. Attend lectures to do the extra credit which adds up to a lot. Recitation is where you really learn everything. He says everyone gets an A but not completely true just do your very best. Very chill and will answer any questions and be a resource to you.

He is a very sweet professor who gives understanding lectures. The class is a lecture-based course with powerpoints with a recitation once a week with a TA. There is one assignment a week, which will take about 1-2 hours. The tests and quizzes are open notes. A good class!

Professor Lau really wants you to learn the material and is always available/open to talk to his students concerning questions about the course. His explanations are very clear and he wants the best for his students.

He is an awesome professor.  And his lecture is very interesting, I can listen to the lecture with great devotion. I thought the professor was very friendly and very interesting, and made the boring lectures very interesting. That's one of the main reasons why I recommend him. Homework is very simple, just study hard. You can get good grades.

I found this class to be pretty fun and interesting. Many struggle if they have no motivation to learn coding and stuff but it can be fun if you make the most of it. The class has three main units: HTML, JavaScript, and Excel. I did not attend most of the lectures, but go to the recitations for sure to learn what you need to know.

Amazing Professor! This class was pretty ok considering I had no experience in computer science whatsoever. His lectures really helped with exams and he even points out problems that he knows will be on the exam and tells us to study that. There are also so many opportunities for extra credit and I noticed his extra credit was fairly easy. Take him

Had Prof. Lau for Comp Apps 170 and he is truly a great professor. He responds quickly to student emails for questions and has great lecture presentations in preparation for the exam. Comp Apps can be tricky when it comes to learning Javascript but Prof. Lau helped break down the material and made it a lot more understandable. Highly recommend!!
Took Prof. Lau for CompApps for Business. He is a very responsible teacher. He explains clearly in class and is willing to interact with students to answer questions
A good professor. His class materials and recorded videos are clear and easy to understand. Homework are not very hard.

He is a very sweet professor and even gave extra credit when we were in person. The material itself may be a little confusing if you have no prior programming experience. The TA's are the ones who usually help out with assignments and teach you the material more in-depth

Took Prof. Lau for CompApps for Business. The programming gets really difficult if you haven't done HTML and JavaScript before. Prof. Lau helped me with all my questions. If you study the slides and make sure you understand what you're programming, you'll be fine.

He's enthusiastic about the material and quite knowledgeable. The slides are also easy to follow and full of information. Other parts of the course could be better - he didn't give any homework assignments despite saying we'd have 4-5, kept pushing back deadlines, and wasn't very reachable outside of class.

Great prof. Detailed lectures, answers questions, very amicable in person. Don't be afraid to approach him in person. Some homework assignments were a bit difficult, but Prof. Patel is still relatively new, so we were the "test run".
Good guy who cares about his students. There were some VERY hard assignments and tests, but curves and points back were generous and there was extra credit offered.

It was his first time teaching so it may be better later but my personal experience was horrible. The project assignments were not the best and some were unreasonably hard. The lectures were extremely boring and makes you sleep but you have to listen to them because studying just the slides is not enough. You cannot be lazy in this class

There were hiccups as this was his first time teaching undergrad, but he's accommodating and overall a good prof. The course itself is hard so be prepared for the difficulty. Cutoffs were determined from the final grade distribution as follows: A 83, B+ 78, B 73, C+ 68, C 60, D 50.
Amazing professor and lecturer, would highly recommend.
He is undoubtedly one of the best professors in the department ! ! !

I'd 100% recommend taking this class with him. One of the best professors I've had. His explanations are clear, structured, and easy to follow. Even for a complex subject like Computer Architecture. He breaks things down step by step and makes sure students truly understand the material. He's incredibly helpful.

Lectures not required but very much recommended, they're incredibly engaging and make a lot of the material digestible. Deadlines, assignment requirements and expectations were incredibly clear and the professor was incredibly accommodating towards students. Highly recommend
Very organized, cares about students, good and recorded lectures.

He's articulate when giving lectures and explains things in an easily understandable way. If there seems to be something students are struggling with, he goes back to clarify with new examples or from a different angle. He seems to care a lot about students learning. He's very organized. His lectures are recorded, so you can review them later also.
He is super nice and really wants to teach something to his students !!!

It's my only second week with this Professor, but it is so refreshing to see an organized and passionate professor in the Rutgers cs department. This guy has given us tons of resources, including this site called ed, where you can ask questions anonymously, and it's so helpful. Whenever someone asks a question, he makes sure to get them the answer.
Nice guy and really cares about comp arch

Good lecturer, and gives a lot of useful info in the beginning. Assignments vary in difficulty and tedium quite a lot, but there is a lot of extra credit. Grad students need to do extra credit parts of assignments. Some disconnect between assignments and slides.

50% HW grade. Two midterms, two finals. Each 25%. The finals are optional and can replace your midterm grade. He also grades leniently and gives partial credit on exams. The material is challenging but you will be rewarded with an A if you put in the work. Great personality and makes well timed jokes during lecture.
if you want a math heavy, no coding course. Definately make use of office hours. He cares a lot if you show him you work hard. First homework is the HARDEST

Prof A is cool, he knows his class is difficult and so all 4 HWs are 160/120 pts.  2 straightforward midterms with a review midterm given before each. Lectures can make you feel lost but read notes, and go to the office hours, it will make sense. The course has 4 parts - roots of an equation, interpolation, norms, and solving SOLE(matrix).

Prof. Aanjaneya is awesome! He is very helpful in class and provides ample opportunities for students to ask questions. All his homework assignments have extra credit and he provides practice exams as well. He is very approachable and he regularly stays behind after class to answer all immediate student questions.

Doesn't really go into detail on lectures and they leave you walking out more confused than you were the previous day. Didn't go over Python whatsoever when it's literally needed to complete one of the homework problems. Also gets visibly annoyed when someone asks a question for a class that's very theoretical and difficult to grasp. Not a fan.

CS323 Numerical Analysis. Grades depend on 4 assignments + 2 midterms, and final is optional. Class is a bit boring, but homework and tests are very manageable. Recitation is super helpful with lecturer Sutariya.

This is one of my favorite classes and professors I've worked with at Rutgers. He was a good lecturer, approachable, caring about students' needs, 5 late days to use throughout the semester, 5 assignments all with extra credit, open notes midterm, and a final project. TBH if you did bad in this class it's because you really didn't try at all.

I heard 428 was supposed to be chill with this prof but it's really not if you're not familiar previously with the material. The grad and undergrad classes are mixed which makes it much harder and there aren't any materials/resources he gives you to actually do well. Definitely regret taking this class.

Brilliant professor. I learned a great deal in this course. Assignments were in Rust and we built an end-to-end compiler from a C-like language to x86-64. Allowed us to use any large language model for the assignments. The final exam forced students to read and pay attention. Overall a great course. Would love to take another class with him!

Great professor but significantly harder than the others for this course.
