He really hammers the course content into your mind and makes it clear how important the concepts would be when applying for internships and etc. However even though lectures arent mandatory, you HAVE TO go or else you will fall behind very easily. Read the textbook.

To put it best, professor Santosh is a proponent of tough love. He's very passionate about what he does, and he seems to have a genuine interest in making sure every one of his students is successful. However, this comes at the cost of him being SIGNIFICANTLY more challenging than the other 211 professors, so be prepared to put in a lot of effort.

Santosh's course is more intensive than Yipeng's or Jay's. You learn a lot a lot though. Do all the assignments (even without the extra credit), you will get a C.  This year's exam was fair. Many questions were straight from the practical final. I liked his lectures.  Getting an A requires doing well in the exams. 92+ was an A.

Midterm is only 10% so it won't hurt you much but the final is 25%. EC PA (Programming Assignment) was 10% but was very difficult. A is normally 95.Since a C was a 50, if you get a 100 on all PA's and nothing else, you can pass the class. Take the class with Huang if you want a better grade, he is more project based. You learn more in Santosh.

His class may be difficult, but you get a lot out of it compared to eery other professor who teaches 211. He has a genuine care for ensuring students are well versed in the computer science field and learn from the mistakes. He does answer questions pretty well and his accent isn't as thick as it may seem like. Overall, I really enjoyed his class.

Comp Arch is a super hard course. IMO, Santosh's lectures are really good. His assignments are hard but well designed. He also gave videos for all the lectures when we asked, which I found it to be useful.  I have learned a lot this term.

CS 211 is a difficult class. His lectures are significantly better than other two instructors teaching right now. I attend Santosh's lecture even though I am registered with other instructors because I like his teaching style. I did his PA2 even though it is not required and it was a great learning experience.

A difficult but fun class. Assignments are challenging but have been fun. I learned a lot with PA2. I didn't know shortest path can be computed just using BFS. His lectures convey the important points.  He uses the black board which is refreshing in contrast to most other CS classes. Midterm was long but fair.

I saw the reviews and had high hopes for him. It was a big mistake. Assignments are long and don't relate to the lecture. He has a heavy accent and is unwilling to help when people ask questions.  He doesn't look at students when they are asking questions and brushes them off. Great researcher maybe, a terrible professor.

I like that the class does not punish you hard in the beginning for messing up. I wish that the difficulty curve of the course was more linear. PA2 was way harder. In contrast, the bomb lab and pa4 were very easy.  Lectures were awesome. The professor made it interesting.
The professor is very organized and a great lecturer.

The topics covered were great and clearly a lot of thought went into designing the course. We saw a very good breadth of different topics and I feel I gained a basic knowledge of many aspects of the field. At the same time, enough time was spent of them to get a good flavor of each.
This course was very challenging. It taught me valuable coding and thinking skills. I am happy to have taken it with Prof. Nagarakatte.
The Professor was engaging and taught in a clear manner. I liked the assignments and helped me become a better programmer. Lot of work but learned a lot.

I mean, he literally gets off to stressing students out. Also teaches irrelevant concepts while promising that we'll him later in interviews. Decent assingments but tests, especially the final were exorbitantly difficult and unreal expectations are set about reading the textbook. Take a professor that's more up to date with what's actually useful.

Professor Nagarakatte's lectures are well organized. It was easy to follow. He provided lecture videos to supplement the live lectures, which was awesome. Professor Nagarakatte challenged us with the assignments. I would not have done such assignments otherwise.  In summary, Professor Nagarakatte really cares about helping students learn and grow.

Santosh is a very intelligent and difficult professor. He is very well-versed and knowledgable about the material he is teaching but I felt his coding assignments were unreasonably difficult based on how much code he actually taught us in class. Highly recommend getting a good foundation in C before taking his class. Will make you a better coder.

His class is faster paced and more challenging than the other sections but you learn a lot. Take if you want to learn and be challenged, don't take if you just want to get by. Pros: Good lectures, pretty helpful, and is enthusiastic about what he teaches. Cons: Difficulty, weekly quizzes, and heavy textbook use expected.
His lectures are excellent. He provided recorded lectures from a prior version of his class. He's always there in discussion forums to answer questions. 89+ was an A. I enjoyed his course.
I was in Mennys section but attended Santosh's lectures. Clear and well organized lectures. He was patient in answering questions.

A difficult course but you will learn a lot. Much harder than 111 and 112. Struggled a lot with the assignments. Debugged some of them for hours. Santosh helped me fix many bugs in my code in his office hours.  Santosh is helpful in office hours and in the discussion forums. His TAs could more responsive though.

Amazing course. Santosh makes his course challenging with programming assignments.  I loved them. He was very responsive when we asked questions. He also picks his TAs well.  Santosh cares about his students and teaching methods. Great course for a CS major! Would love to take class with him.

Assingments were straight up abnormal. One assignment had 10 coding tasks and only had 2 weeks to complete. Basically, he makes thr deadline too short to possibly finish only to give a deadline to seem like a more forgiving and accommodating prof. Imo, he also focuses too much on assembly level coding.

Sections of CS211 taught by Santosh are much harder than the other sections. Santosh is a great lecturer and lectures were helpful. However, he expects his students to read the textbook and do a lot of follow up work. My programming skills significantly improved at the end of the course. If you want to get a good grade, start early.

CS211 is challenging. But, Santosh is a great professor and hands down the best professor . Learned a lot in this course. Santosh helped me a lot during office hours.  He really cares about his students.  Take this class if you want to be challenged and want to improve your skills. If you need an easy C,  take it with the another instructor.

Definitely a great professor for anyone who wants to learn and be challenged. Also fair with extensions and extra credit. But his exams and assignments are hard and he expects a lot from you. His TA's were also good. He definitely cares a lot about teaching, and if you are prepared to work a lot I would recommend him.

I freaking loved taking Comp Arch with Santosh. His class definitely challenged me but I would say the stress was all worth it. He is by far the best lecturer I've had. Lessons are engaging and he always gave extensions and multiple opportunities to succeed. His TA's are also very well-picked and helpful.

He can be very idiosyncratic about things. Take another professor instead. He's a very good lecturer but expects a LOT of work outside class - probably because he's used to teaching grad students rather than undergrads. He's also pretty unclear on what the cutoffs are. Computer Architecture with this professor is arbitrarily extra challenging.

Interesting lectures, you can tell he likes teaching. But he has a weak ego, if anyone is talking quietly or smiling/laughing at something he'll stop his lecture to scold them for disrupting the class. Overall I enjoyed taking this course

Very good lecturer and fair grader. As long as you get above an 80 on all of the coding assignments and a 75 on the weekly quizzes, he will pass you. Assignments might take longer than previous cs courses, but they teach you the core concepts and prepare you for the exams. Exams are graded very leniently

The exams are very fair if you study the programming assignments. You can tell he cares a lot about his students. He's always enthusiastic and quickly answers any questions in the discussion forums. Tons of extensions for the hw.

Amazing professor. His lectures are very helpful. I tried reading the textbook before the lectures but was difficult. It was much easier to read the textbook after the lectures. His assignments are challenging. Not a easy course but you will learn a lot.

This professor is very respected, and his lectures are very thorough and interesting. However, he gives a lot of work and it does get hard to manage at some points. If you want to challenge yourself, take this class with Professor Santosh.
This guy is very respected, and po o!!!! Study under him for PDhD!!!!

Prof. Nagarakatte did an excellent job of presenting really complex material in an interesting way. Assignments were just awesome. Great hands-on experience on security. He covered all the basics needed to understand concepts in Systems security even when they were outside the scope of the course.

Professor Santosh is a great teacher. He is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about his subject. It reflects in his teaching. He was also very accommodating with multiple extensions for the assignment. Lots of programming assignments in the course but worth it.

Prof Santosh answered questions regularly and quickly on Piazza. He gave numerous extensions (sometimes more than necessary). Summarizes and highlights things in each lecture. Definitely a very smart professor. Overall an excellent teacher.

Not a terribly engaging lecturer, but he was fine when I paid attention. Personally I got most of my learning out of the TA led recitations, which had clearer notes. Most of the grade was based on fairly difficult assignments that ensured you really understood the concepts. He's nice to a fault, and gave extensions on pretty much every assignment.
Very hard course, makes you work hard to earn a good grade but he gives amazing lectures and clearly is knowledgable about the subject.

Throughout the semester I was completely overwhelmed with the work in this class and considered withdrawing many times because of my low scores on the projects. But, Santosh was SUPER lenient with final scores and ended up making 70 a B in the class! Do not take him if you have little to no experience with programming; the projects are impossible.
Judgmental.

Absolutely, 100% go to this guy if you want to learn something. He turns the difficulty up to 11, but it's worth it. Easily the best CS teacher I've ever had. If you want to do well, you gotta go to recitations, and you gotta pay attention/ask question during class.
Professor Santosh is the smartest professor I had the pleasure of taking.

Santosh is one of the worst professors I've ever had. I would avoid him at all costs. His projects were insanely hard and time-consuming compared to the other sections of this same class. When you asked him a question, he did not answer it without making you feel stupid first. The final consisted of things we never learned or barely went over.

He does really care and gives many opportunities to do well, including extra credit, which is usually do-able and at one time, it was easy. He also extends projects many times so that students can finish it. I also personally thought that he taught well, but others think differently.

Great teacher. He covers more advanced stuff so you really learn about C.A. topics. If you get 90s on the projects and do the extra credit, you will be fine. I got 70s on the midterm and final and still got an A. Do the textbook problems for the exams. He is a nice guy and gives inspirational speeches. Don't cheat; he will get you!!!
Awesome prof, gave extra credits and multiple extensions
Professor is really good at teaching and wants his kids to learn the material rather than just by with a passing grade.

Advice: Get 100's on first 3 projects, last 2 are impossible. Study some C code before taking this class, you'll rely heavily on it. Do not rely on extra credit there are lots of opportunities for it but they are practically impossible. Don't think you'll pass just because there is a large curve. Go to lectures and try your best to understand him.

Santosh is a great professor, and he really cares about making sure students learn the material. His lectures are very clear and informative. There's five projects, four C programming and one bomblab in assembly. If you do well on the projects, you'll do well in the class. The projects are a fair amount of work but not too crazy if you start early.

Professor Santosh is a good lecturer, and is helpful in office hours. This class is not easy, but you can do well if you are willing to put in the effort and ask for help. We had 5 programming assignments, worth a total of 50% of the grade. An A in this class is an 80. The material is difficult, but you can ask for help in office hours/class forums

He is a really good professor and really nice. He once gave us extention on a project 3 times. The projects are generally hard, but doable. He does expect you to learn the programming language mostly by yourself.
Assignments were hard but it forced me to a lot. Auto grader helped me get 100 in many assignments.  If you want to improve your programming, take this course.

Santosh is not an easy professor. He genuinely wants his students to learn the material. That is the best part about all of this. As long as you are willing to put in the work, he will work with you to great extent to make sure you understand what is going on. He gave multiple extensions to assignments. There is no reason why you cannot get an A.
I liked Dr. Nagarakatte's enthusiasm. Assignments were good programming practice. Lots of opportunities for extra credit. Exams are a bit hard. Recommend the course for a CS major.

I enjoyed the interactive lectures and brief insights into details of computer architecture. Prof. Nagarakatte is able to talk passionately on this topic. He clear understands and knows the answer to every question a student has. I found his ability to provide an interesting and informative response to a student to be stellar.

In this course, I learned few ways to become a better programmer. Santosh got me thinking about research in computer science for my future. He is one of the best professor I have had the pleasure of taking the class

Prof. Nagarakatte is one of the best professors I have ever head, hands-down. His standards are tough, but his teaching methods are excellent to compensate. I'd take another course with him again despite the difficulty because he's such a great teacher
Best CS course i have taken so far at Rutgers. Liked how Professor Santosh taught the class and was helpful during office hours.

Professor is really helpful. The course is great and I liked it, however i think exams are not good enough to accurately evaluate my performance. Generally I do learned a lot, but exams are tricky and not relevant to the real hands on experience.

Santosh is a great professor - he is clear, concise, and fair in his lectures and in his expectations. The grade that you get is largely the grade that you deserve.  Of course, the material itself is hard, and some may complain about getting bad grades, but I attribute that largely to students themselves not putting in sufficient effort.
Really difficult accent to remember and very condescending. Try taking it with Russell if you have the chance.

He puts lectures slides up but they are useless if you don't go to class. However, i could barely understand him and gave up going to them. Cost me 5% of my grade but the projects are a big chunk of you grade. You need to spend a lot of time with them but if you do an A is possible since his curve is around a 80.
One of the best professors in CS department. I have learned a lot in this course. If the professor is interested, he should take more systems graduate courses in the department.
Bad accent. He tries to teach a lot, but the exams and assignments are very tough.

The class is hard but there's not much he can do about it since the content itself is inherently difficult. The assignments are autograded and HE GIVES YOU THE AUTOGRADER TO CHECK! Easy 100 for 30% of your grade if you actually check. Tough exams, but a ton of extra credit and a huge curve (80 was an A LOL) basically makes it a joke
Professor cares about his students. Don't miss his office hours. His recommendation letter helps with transfers!  Ofcourse, you have to do well in his course :-)
Learned a lot in this class. Good class to practice  programming. Pay attention  and do extra credit assignments.
Hard course but good prof.  Get ready to do 4 or 5 programming assignments.

If you are are CS major, this is a good class. Lots of programming assignments and extra credit.  I got a 0 in the first assignment and a low score in the second assignment. The professor took the best 4/5 assignments. If you want to learn and are  willing to work hard, take the course with this professor.

The class is difficult. Lots of material for a term. The professor is helpful and helped me a lot in office hours.  The assignments are hard and require lot of work. I thought I would get a bad grade but got A.

He wants you to learn and will extend the due dates if necessary. BUT he is a brutally honest person. Straight to your face, he'll tell you "you are looking at an F". For CS geeks, the best choice because you will learn a lot and his curve is generous.  For non CS geeks or don't like coding, this class will  be a nightmare! plus very condescending!

I took Computer Architecture with Professor Nagarakatte.  He's a brilliant lecturer, and an excellent teacher overall.  He is, however, a very tough grader both on assignments and on exams.  To put it in perspective, a 48 was a C for our class in Fall 2015, and a 72 was a B+.  You will be fine- just pay CLOSE attention to lectures and work hard!

Took Santosh in Fall 2015. He made his sections work a lot harder for a good grade than the other professor did, and exams were definitely not easy. He also tended to be condescending sometimes unless asked for help in a very specific way. He does "want you to learn" for sure, but he makes things more difficult than they need to be.

Take him if you love cs and want a good challenge. I learned SO MUCH from his CS211 class(fall 2015). Wants students to learn A LOT but this means he is VERY hard. Exams averages are around 50s but 80% is an A. His office hours, he is very helpful. Will need to put in the work. Toughest class I took in cs so far but also the best class.

Santosh is an incredible professor. He wants you to learn and for that to be your focus, so he's not a strict grader. He's helpful in person and he remembers you if you ask for help. He's also a good lecturer - if you don't get anything out of his lectures, it's because you're not listening/asking questions. Work hard, the grade will follow.

He comes off as tough and a bit intimidating, but Santosh really just wants his students to learn. If you truly put in effort you definitely have a shot at an A in his class. Don't be afraid to ask questions and use office hours if you feel like you need help. The first week I was concerned whether or not I could get a B, I ultimately got an A.

The professor is good and makes you learn real programming and structures. However, the class itself was difficult and 70 is curve for B! Unfortunately, I earned a very low grade despite my hard work.
Fairly easy class once you grasp the material. Not as bad as many people make it out to be you just need to put in a little bit of dedication.

He is a very demanding professor and his exams are awful. His curve was low too! He does make you learn the material, but his teaching probably isn't great! He does fail some students and I was one of them.

This was a good class to learn C programming. However, Santosh was really demanding and he likes to embarrass students a lot in lecture if they don't participate. You can learn a lot from class, but I would recommend taking it with a different professor who really has more patience.

Santosh often talks to fast. I really wish he would  regularly ask his students what they do and don't understand. My top two complaints are: I wish he would express his material more simply and not to have crazy grading standards. For example I wrote 4 programs which worked but I recieved a 0 because my submitted folder was named incorrectly.

He can come across as rude, impatient, and condescending, but I also learned a lot in his class because he was so demanding. Curve was generous, but his timing of assignments was poor. You can feel confident that you will learn a lot on his class, but he isn't the most approachable guy.

Wow what a terrible professor. Extremely condescending and unhelpful. Did not take the 20 minutes to look over what we did in CS111 and CS112. Avoid him if possible. I got an A and I don't recommend him.

I think most people have a love/hate relationship with Santosh. His assignments were hard and his expectations were ridiculously high. He is not necessarily clear or approachable and can come off as condescending. Many of us felt like we were drowning in class but, as it turns out, he genuinely wanted us to learn, which we all did. 60% was a B.

Santosh really cares about his students learning the material and if you go to his office hours he is very patient and helpful as long as you show him that you are trying. If you get the opportunity to take a class with him I recommend it! He may challenge you as a student but, if you work hard and truly understand the material you'll get an A.

Very helpful if you showed effort for his class and the material. Really cared about his students and wanted them to do well. True, the exam averages were low but the curve at the end basically ensured you would at least pass if you bothered to do any work at all. He's a little intimidating, but ultimately an excellent professor. (got an A)

Extremely unhelpful, lectures are power points with very little information on them. Glosses over important topics and goes into detail about easy/simple topics. Exam averages range from a 20-30%. Examples are terrible and not useful. Don't take.

He was chill, but grades things at the last minute and also never made Canvas grade public, which made it kinda hard to know how you were doing in the class. Gives a few opportunities for extra credit though.
Biggest shortcoming was that he disabled the grade calculation in the Canvas, making it hard to gauge your progress. Other than that, he was an alright professor.
Prof is fine it's the TAs that are the problem. They are racist and grade based on your skin color. The only way to have them leniently grade your exams/HWs is if you are an abg and go out with them.

Lectures are good, exams are okay, but grading is abysmal (zero room for error). TAs are execrable, especially Xinxi Zhang. He shared a sob story about past bad reviews then proceeded to deliver drivel and live up to them. He doesn't teach; his work is shoddy at best. I blame him for my poor scores.

112 is coordinated so he's not in charge of exams/assignments. Great lecturer. Doesn't have much personality but has good pacing, explains thoroughly and gives good + relevant examples. Sometimes went slightly deeper conceptually than was really necessary for the class but not often. When he's not in charge of organization, he's a great teacher.
The goat ðŸ
You can't really hear him in a lecture hall, even if the place is only 1/4 full.  He doesn't even try to speak louder, and sometimes just makes you want to sleep of boredom.

He is a nice professor and his class is informative. He posts online lectures and has participation exercises at the end of each one for attendance. There were also 3-4 homework assignments, 3 exams, and a programming project. The class itself was straightforward and doable, but he does take a while to grade things. I recommend him for this class.

Professor Garcia makes this course a little too mathematical to the point that students have difficulty understanding the concepts. He is also disorganized and teaches way too fast. Avoid him if you can, though if you can't make sure to watch YouTube videos before lectures to understand the material or else you'll have difficulty following along.

HW:20%, Course Project: 25%, 2 Midterms: 15% each, Final: 15%, Participation Exercise: 10%. Doesn't take attendance but does in class participation exercise at the end of lectures that are submitted there. They are graded based on completion but that his "attendance". Allows max groups of 4 for project. Tests are easy if you pay attention in class

This professor was unprofessional. He never responds to any of the emails (I am not even sure if he look at emails or not). Perhaps he did not even look at Piazza. Over the half way of the course I do not even know how I am doing. He said that I will see my grades between 1 week to 10 days. After 13 days passed, no grades were ever posted!

pros: nice, good lectures, easy(ish) HW and exams
cons: doesn't reply to emails, stopped replying in piazza halfway into the semester, grades insanely slowly, whether he posts his slides on canvas is a coinflip

Professor Garcia was a good lecturer and clearly explained the concepts and ideas. However, the lack of communication regarding assignments, tests, and the overall course was not there. The lack of communication between the professor and students was tremendous and caused confusion among many students.

He often cancels office hours with no clear reasons. Sometimes when I tried to go to his office hours that he wrote on the board on his door that his office hour was cancelled, no prior notice on canvas. Some test problems were rarely covered in class. Assignment took weeks to be graded. He often arrives late to class.

Completely agree with CS112 Rating below (Aug 19th, 2021). This Professor NEVER responds to emails. He NEVER answers questions on Piazza. He grades towards the end of the semester. His lectures are LOUSY. VERY, VERY unprofessional. This is an important course (Data Structures). Please Do NOT take ANY course taught by this professor.

Does not grade quickly which means you don't really get feedback on anything. Doesn't answer Piazza which was so annoying. The work problem sets he gave were barely taught in class. Overall do not recommend but I also took it over the summer (online) and do not go to this school (used it for transfer creds).

Does not reply to emails, had everyone thinking the summer class was in person until the Canvas open the week of class starting, does not post expected materials like answer keys. I had to withdraw from the class with no refund simply because he couldn't reply to my emails I've been sending for months beforehand. Worst prof I've had at rutgers.

Absolutely by far the worst professor I had at Rutgers. A synchronous class turned asynch with 40 min videos, no feedback on any assignments, no accessibility, and no clarity. He never responds to any emails and does not even have office hours. Do not take this professor.
Absolutely terrible in every way. He doesn't care
garbage
terrible. dont know if im passing or failing at all. 2 days away from exam 2 and dont know how exam 1 went. i lost time and money taking this asscheeks professor.

I think he's underrated. Good lectures and the exams and projects are fair. His online lectures were especially good. His 2 flaws that bother most people are that he takes forever to grade and he doesn't respond to emails and piazza enough.
Great lecturer and feel like I learned a lot. However, his grading is slow and is disorganized. The group project and exams were overall fair. Overall a decent professor.

Very disorganized. His lectures aren't too bad but his notes are either missing entire units or are hard to understand. He takes forever to grade and he seems to grade randomly. Also gives out a project and expects us to do it even though most of us don't know what we are doing. Never seems to be reachable. Really bad professor, do not take.

The teaching material has a very low difficulty level but the assignments and especially the exams are very unrealistic. There's test every week, which impacts the time we learn in the class. The notes are decent though, but would highly recommend not to take this course.

Although he gave extra credit for certain assignments, his main flaw is just grading and releasing assignments. He did not grade our final exam for the summer until recently and did not bother to upload on canvas along with out final grade. He rarely answers emails, shows no interest in what he teaches, and releases assignments late. Frustrating!!

I enjoy Data Structures and the ideas behind them, but this professor does not care and it shows. Lectures frequently cut inbetween his sentences and he spoke faster than you would be able to think about the topics. Having tests be 60% of your grade and actual coding assignments being 20% is rough. Would not recommend, especially over the summer.
Go to a thesaurus and look if you want an antonym "for accessible outside of class", you'll see a picture of Antonio Miranda Garcia

Grading took ages. Some assignments submitted towards the beginning of the semester did not come back until the last week of the course. Professor never responds to his emails and is generally really disorganized. His lectures, and more importantly his notes were fine though, if a little boring and bland. Overall, He's fine, I guess.

Saved grading until the last minute. Made Final exam 15 multiple choice questions and worth 30% of the final grade. Final exam had 5 MULTIPLE CHOICE questions worth 16% each and 10 questions worth 2% each. If you're following: 5 multiple choice questions for 4.8% of your entire course grade each. Cherry on top: Did not curve the final grade! :D

Antonio Miranda is an okay person but not a good professor. He is painfully slow at grading any sort of work. If work is not graded then he blames the TA's and expects students to email the graders to get grades out. Most the content can be learned over 1-2 good youtube vids. The only redeming quality this class has are the examples he gives.

Grades were VERY slow to come in, lectures felt like a waste of time when more concise videos would be posted right after class. This class could be done in your sleep but it's the kind of sleep where you wake up more tired than when you went to bed. 4/10 would snooze again.

This is a math intensive course but it is hard to know if you are doing the math right. He doesn't post the answers to his study guides or participation exercises so you never feel confident for the exams. There are also not enough examples given. The math could get very confusing too. His lectures are boring and he's overall not a strong professor

A very very messy professor without patience and respect!! Never reply to student emails! The tone of the reply to the email is extremely impatient! He always wants his students not to bother him and his only duty is to attend classes to give boring lectures. He is not a competent professor!

Just whatever you do, don't waste your time taking this class with Miranda. The first half of the semester is spent learning database design and basic MySQL, you can learn that on your own in a weekend. Of all my classes this was the most time-consuming, the work is not hard it's just tedious and unnecessary. Grading also took forever.

Hes just lazy. Nothing got graded after week 3. No questions on piazza or emails get answered. Lectures actively worsened my understanding of the material and I ended up just avoiding them entirely (other than the mandatory quizzes) and instead looking up youtube videos.

I took CS112 over the summer, and it was by far the worst college course experience I have ever had. Assignments took weeks on weeks to be graded. Office hours and recitation were more likely than not to be canceled. Questions asked on Piazza are practically never answered. For such an important class I do not recommend. Especially over the summer.

Very disorganized, every video and assignment was recycled from previous semesters. Never responds to emails and sends out announcements telling students to not email him. TA grading took a very long time with only 1 HW assignment graded, the midterms, and some participation exercises by the time I took the final.

CS336 is an amazing class to take at rutgers for a CS major but this professor and his TA's will make you go insane with grading and emails. Very very poorly organized. the content of the class (SQL, HTML, javascript) is relatively easy tho

CS336 is a relatively easy CS Elective. The class was structured well and had a clear syllabus. But Miranda is so lazy. Doesn't reply to emails, we get most our grades back literally the day they were due for the semester (MAY 14). Uses pre-recorded lectures 2 semester old and blocks access to piazza towards the end of the semester. VERY LAZY!!!!!!

He's whatever as a teacher but he has terrible communication and 336 was just an extremely disorganized course. All the homeworks were graded a couple of days before the final and office hours were always being moved around or canceled.

Miranda was pretty bad for CS323 but was very good for 336. He spends a lot of time on ERDs and SQL, which are the more important parts of the course. A good choice for an important class to actually learn the material. Solid Lectures with a Portfolio worthy final project, that only takes a few nights if everyone in the group pulls their weight.

He never responds to emails no matter how much you reach out to him. Wont actually help you during office hours but acts super nice. Took him for Spring 2020 and Fall 2020 and easily the worst professor I had the chance to take. Just Lazy, un-inspirational and does not care. Felt like you were doing him a favor by taking his class - STAY AWAY

Had him for DB async. Recitation attendance not mandatory (even tho he says they are). There's a participation exercise every lecture but its graded mostly on effort. 5 homeworks that are nothing crazy, do them. Exams are fairly reasonable, but you do need to study. For the project, make sure you find a good group and start early. Fairly easy A.

Class isn't horrible however its not good by any means. This class is so out-dated its laughable, they do not even bother to update the project slides&description outline they use it's unclear and leaves a lot to be explained. Overall just shows they are not organized at all. The exams aren't bad, you really need to follow lecture and HW's thats it

Prof Miranda is very irresponsive always cancelling office hours last minute and never gets back to emails. During this wonderful 2020 Fall semester he also used the same exact recordings from the Spring 2020 semester, goes to show how lazy this guy is, can't even be bothered to re-do a lecture video. The class is ok just watch lecture/use textbook

Worst class ever. Seems like you are made to fail desperately. If you email him to pass you than you have a regular curve plus a booster curve otherwise you get the normal class curve. Lots of homework STRAIGHT 10+ h, projects work hard and they are not graded at all. no reply to emails, no emails during exams even if you have no net you just FAIL

Based on the 1st half of semester, prior to the transition to online learning.(he did a pretty terrible job online)Like students, he did not ask to be teaching online class, nor do we know his home situation, so this experience should not be representative of his teaching for next semester - good lectures/notes -long hws -fair but hard exams(exam1)

The semester long project isn't horrible. However him as a prof, he's pretty bad, I didn't think so at first, I thought he was ok ya know not good not bad just eh. But toward the end of the semester, it really showed how unhelpful he was and how he didn't care, honestly killed my motivation for the class.

Doesn't respond to emails or class forum (disabled the class forum right before the final). The final was ridiculously difficult, and absolutely nothing like anything we had learned during the semester

The course became absolute trash after the semester went online due to COVID. Instead of making it easier for himself and the students, he made it so hard by refusing to answer anyone's questions and he disabled piazza. The final was ridiculously hard and had weird theoretical questions. He was not at all helpful, and the TA's were bad too.

The class is not hard but this professor makes it very hard. no email replies, makes mistakes while teaching always, gives daily participation exercises but no solutions. The study guide says study topics A and B but ignore C and guess what the exam tests you on to topic D. The TA gets done with recitation in 10 mins and doesnt answer questions.

DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR EVER. MADE THE CLASS HARDER THAN SUPPOSED TO BE. He thinks we have no other class so gives homeworks that take 10+ hours, He wanted to assign a homework during reading break. never replies to emails. exams are made so you fail and retake the class (money making). Prof cancels office hours to avoid student complaints.

The worst class and professor ever. during covid 19 theprofessor, TAs made the situation worse for students- homeworks( 10 hours), participation exercises(2 hours), exams(18 hours straight). What is worse tough grades with no feedback, no replies to emails from professors, ta. A student scartched himself and posted on the forum cause of workload

Terrible and unclear lecture notes that he copy pastes from the textbook, and has the handwriting of a 6 year old. Assigns a lot of work, yet takes days to respond to questions if he chooses to respond at all, and never gives a clear answer. Avoid like the plague.

This man takes simple, easy concepts and gives the longest most ridiculous homework and attendance problems that involve EXTREMELY tedious calculations with excessive iterations and expects accuracy up to the 6th decimal place at times. By no means is this a hard class, he is just an awful professor and who will waste so much of your time. Avoid...

i really dont know who's spreading the rumors that this a good class to take. HW is super long and tedious (10+ hours to complete), no grading feeback EVER (this includes midterms, projects), and does not want to have anything to do with grading,help, or anything outside of just lecturing

His cannot explain anything well in the lecture and his blackboard expression is awful af that his handwriting is so small I cannot clearly seen even in the third row of the classroom and the whole structure of this course such as HW and exams are very poorly planned. Questions on HW are flawed, grading points are bad among other bad things.
Lectures are disorganized, and exams are way harder than review sheets/class examples. Does not really prep you for much so have to self study a lot of the class. Would not take again
Great lecture. But hard exam and many homework and quizzes.

Miranda's teaching style is writing out all concepts and examples on the board. The project can be easy if you start early. SQL and database concepts are not hard to grasp if you put in the time and watch videos to reinforce concepts from class. There is a lot of credit given for hw and attendance and its a nice boost to your final grade.

This is honestly one of the worst experience I have ever had in Rutgers. The project is really heavy and even if TA will take off points for no reasons, he does not care about the grade at all. Never ever had response by emailing him. Lecture and exams are pretty disorganized. Avoid
he sucks at explaining things, i dont learn anything during lecture

I made a rating below and wasn't really sure about the class, but after the midterm, I can successfully say that the lectures are really unorganized and hard to follow. The professor cancels way too many office hours, they've made it so you can't use any frameworks/tools, and there's way more ER diagrams than actual code. Regret taking 100%.

I'm usually the first person to enjoy diagrams and visuals, but this class makes it extremely difficult to follow along. The class is really overcrowded and that makes it hard to get a spot near the front. This is just from the first couple classes, so it may get better later on.

Not bad. Sometimes he may make some easy concepts very confusing, but in all quite good in teaching skills. Some class and take-home tasks may make you better understand what you learned on class. Need to spend some times on this, but worth it.

He is a great professor! His teaching style is amazing - writes everything on the blackboard. Explains the toughest topics in a very understanding manner. Take his CS512 - Algorithms class and you will emerge having a strong knowledge of algorithms and their workings! One of the best CS professors at Rutgers.

Very nice professor. Took his CS334 and CS336 before. Concepts are well explained and everything is written on the blackboard. Practice problems are assigned to record class attendances. Homework is set once a week. Lecture notes and study guides are very useful for exam preparation. Start the project early if you are taking CS336.
Excellent professor. Great teaching style. Listens and thoughtfully answers questions. One of the best professors at Rutgers. Take him if you want to know the material

Very generous curve. I liked his teaching style of writing everything out on the board- it makes it easier to go back and study. Concepts might be tricky at times just go to office hours. In order to do well go to class and pay attention
Professor Miranda is a nice guy. Team project takes up 25% of your total grade. The midterms are not hard, and the final exam are all multiple choice problems.

Nice guy but not a good lecturer. He had various mistakes in his code and was using another professor's slides (though it can be common for CS professors). I asked him to look at my code once and he said "I can't see anything wrong with it" after looking it over for some time but it failed 2 or 3 (can't remember) test trials.
Good at explaining concepts and answers questions well. Really nice guy.
Explains concepts well and has a very generous curve

Took him for databases. Honestly he's a really nice guy and a pretty solid lecturer. Use slides and HW to prepare for exams. Go to class - mandatory! Get started early on your databases project. There are virtually no guidelines for the project, but if you start early and get a working website, you can meet with the TA and get questions answered.

Took for Data Structures. Hard to judge based on assignments, exams, etc because Sesh organizes the same stuff across all professors. Miranda's lectures were all pretty good and clear Sometimes he's not good at understanding students' questions but he always gets it eventually and cares about answering any questions. Good overall, will take again.
He tries not to fail anyone,is upfront about the class,in class exercises were 10% so try to come to lecture,helpful in office hours,tries to make sure class passes,made this class bearable.
He is a decent professor who proved a good curve.  Make sure you go to all of the lectures as the proof section is difficult.

Nice guy, good lecturer, and a big 5 to 10 point curve. Assigns homework every 2 weeks with a quiz the class after the hw is due consisting of a single problem from that homework. Together they are 50% of the final grade. Exams are easy for the most part, but second midterm is tough because of proofs. Would take him again.

Barely came to class (including the final exam), made "creative problems" on the exams even though he never even came to teach. Luckily, attendance was not mandatory, so better to self study or take another professor.

Bottom 3 profs in this department imo. Dull, uninteresting, practically a ghost when trying to reach out. Also, prob the worst final grade distribution ive ever seen. Final is worth 40%, so no matter what you get (with the exception of an A+) be prepared to witness your final grade fall some letter grades at the end of the semester.

Difficult to follow and genuinely does not care at all. He was abcsent for half the semester and didn't even bother showing up for the final. Makes the final weighted at 40% and gives the most stingy curve if you can even call it that? Avoid and take Zhang instead

Really unreliable professor. He is not accessible even in the slightest outside of class. He missed the first month of classes because he was busy working in another country. Aside from that, his lectures are okay, and homework isn't too bad. But I wouldn't recommend him to anyone.

Horrible class. Honestly horrible teacher. His exams are so hard, people complained to the dean and they said they couldn't do anything because he's famous. He sings in Hungarian during exams. Sometimes lets his daughter teach the class (and she is better lol). Very disorganized content. Do not recommend professor.

This class was a disaster. He openly admitted to being a terrible teacher + not wanting to teach, and even let his daughter take over the class at times. If you want to get anything out of this class, please for the love of god take it with someone else (I would say it's worth pushing it back a semester if Mario is the only option). Easy A tho tbf.

I attended every lecture, but found that I learned more just from reading the textbook (and could learn the same topic in half the time). He did things slowly and we were far behind the other prof's sections of 344. He made interesting algorithms boring. Granted, he is caring and tried to learn many people's names. But take a diff prof if you can.

I like the way you walk, the way that you talk
I like the way you lecture
I like the way you grade
lectures were a mess. unclear grading. no curve even though i was above upper quartile on every assignment and exam.

Professor explains concepts, mentions there is a curve in the beginning of the class but when grades come out there is no curve. Often mentions this course is easy but in reality there are some fundamentals to go through and needed to be explained properly. Disorganised and not a good experience overall.

Nice dude, kinda funny. Class is very not good. No hate to the dude, but going to his lectures and trying to listen to them was like trying to figure out a maze. First day of lecture, he jumped straight into a random topic, and didn't explain the relevance of it. Super disorganized way of teaching. Grades kinda lightly though. Don't take.
Prof. Szegedy taught advanced concepts in algorithms and absolutely killed it. Lectures were heavy and homeworks took time, bit it was worth it.
Exams are easy. Very little theory. Course was geared towards passing interviews.

Nice guy, but didnt seem to care about the class, and as whole it was very unorganized; it wasnt always clear what he expected from you, which made it hard to prepare for exams even though they were open book. Told us things at the last possible minute. But he does his best to ensure that you pass. Brilliant researcher, but not the best professor

His lectures were 3 hours long, but he still managed to not make them boring. His tests were tough, especially more towards the end of the semester, but he offers a lot of extra credit (everything adds up to 105% and he gave 40 possible points of EC on the final). Not super tough, but a good professor for the course and a very accomplished one.

Interesting lectures , really nice guy , exams are fair , credit for attendance, and I feel like I learned a lot by completing the work and participating in lecture. You get out what you put in like every other class.

Why the raving reviews? In all honesty it HAS to be the grading.  Ended up with a B+ for doing almost fail work. His curve - which he'll tell you doesn't exist, gives extra points on test but grades out of 100 anyway without scale - is AMAZING. I did D work and got a B+ anyway. He is a TERRIBLE lecturer.  Brilliant but deff here for the research.
One the best prof I've had

Very nice guy, but a bit confusing. He wants to teach well, but sometimes you don't know what he's trying to teach. The textbook is horrible. Totally awkward in an endearing way =) P.S. - go to recitation, don't rely on the textbook

he tried, he really did, he just didn't know the material very well. the project was torture, but worth it. the exams aren't too bad if you understand the material. I haven't gotten anything below an A yet.

Pretty good professor.He tries hard to explain things and honestly wants people to learn. Slight accent makes it difficult to understand him and sometimes the way he says things can be confusing. First time teaching this course so it seems like he is still getting the grasp. Project is cool (bit torrent client), the exams are hard I hope he curves!
After the first class you will question this guy's ability, but he really lectures and teaches well.  Go to all classes, and you won't ever crack your book.

This dude ROCKS! Awesome prof, great lectures, very helpful .. wants you to learn... his exams can be hard - but he's pretty cool with the grading.. u can get an A if u put in some effort and go to his lectures.
Three words:  Big.  Orange.  Sweatshirt.  This guy rocks.

Very well-structured course. The professor was knowledgeable and her lectures were engaging. She explained algorithms using interesting real-world examples, encouraged active class participation, and made the course more interactive through interesting in-class quizzes. I would definitely recommend this course.

Professor Biswas is fantastic. Her lectures were intellectually stimulating, and the course helped me develop many valuable problem-solving skills. She encouraged questions and encouraged us to explore our ideas deeply. The biweekly problem sets were very helpful, and the regular quizzes kept me consistently up to date with the course material.

Well organized and interesting lectures. Slides were made available for references. Many interesting problems were covered in class and I learnt a lot. Professor was accessible outside the class and explains patiently. There were opportunities for EC through class participation.

Even though I initially struggled with this course I ended up being satisfied with what I learned from the course. The lectures were clear and engaging. Get ready to write pseudocode, formal proofs, and think out of the box for counterexamples. Professor Biswas is very knowledgeable, also kind and helpful. Lots of EC opportunities.

It was an extremely rewarding course, but it had a huge syllabus. However, the lectures were very interesting and the professor provided clear guidelines before exams and posted practice materials. There were group-quizzes that helped me stay up to date with the syllabus and learn better. Also, the professor was very kind and supportive.

Professor Biswas is wonderful! Although the course was challenging, her engaging presentation of the material made it easier to understand. She was always approachable outside of class and took the time to answer questions and clarify concepts, helping to strengthen my understanding. I completed the course with a much deeper grasp of algorithms.

I would definitely recommend taking this course with Professor Biswas. She explains concepts clearly, is very supportive, and genuinely cares about student learning. Her lectures were very well-structured, and she always provided thoughtful and genuine feedback whenever I reached out. I would love to take another course that she would teach.

I enjoyed the course thoroughly. I learned a ton from the course and from Dr. Biswas. She happily answered my doubts and helped me develop intuitions on how to apply various algorithmic techniques to different problems. She made the lectures very interesting and used real-world examples to motivate the problems she covered in class.

CS 344 was the most rewarding course I have taken, and it strengthened my understanding of algorithms to a great extent. After taking the course, I am more confident on solving problems systematically and I can now critically think whether I come up with a better solution. I am extremely grateful for the opportunity to learn from the professor.

Professor Biswas is one of my favorite professors so far. She is incredibly knowledgeable and explains algorithmic concepts clearly and with ease. She made CS 344 very engaging and accessible, and she patiently cleared doubts during office hours. Her lectures and teaching style greatly increased my interest in algorithms.

Dr. Biswas did a decent job considering this was her first time teaching this course. I believe that in the future, she will easily become one of the better lecturers for CS344. I think that the current way this course is taught is not useful to students. Recitations should be for practice, and the course should be graded by more things (homework).

Amazing lectures and extremely well-organized slides that were very helpful for studying. Learned a lot and enjoyed the lectures--my favorite so far. The professor was accessible and accommodating when needed, but also very firm with the course policies. The exams were medium level but very interesting. Practice problems given. No assignments.

Challenging but extremely rewarding course. The professor explained algorithms and proofs clearly and was genuinely invested in our learning. Many interesting real-world examples were discussed. No coding required but a lot of stress given on writing proper pseudocode. There were quizzes. Definitely recommend if you want to really learn algorithms.

Professor Biswas is an excellent instructor who explains complex algorithmic concepts with clarity and rigor. The course was very well-structured, motivating, and greatly strengthened my algorithmic skills. I found the concepts were difficult for me initially but the professor was accessible and helped solving my doubts.

Arpita is sharp and clearly understands the material, but sometimes struggles to explain her reasoning clearly. She contributes good insights during discussions, though they can feel a bit rushed. Overall, she's a strong student who could stand out more with clearer communication and pacing.
Over 75% of the class ended up with an A, extremely accommodating, and there was a final project instead of an exam ðŸ Lots of EC as well

The course required us to have active participation and discussions in class. No homeworks/assignments, other than reading materials. There was a final course project and we had to submit a report. The professor is kind, understanding, and was available to listen and provide feedback. She provided many opportunities to get bonus points.

Professor Biswas cares about the students in the class and is very accommodating. Her lectures were well organized. She made all the lecture slides available online. She laid out a clear grading criteria at the start of the course. I'll learned a lot and would definitely want to take her courses again.
The lectures were insightful and engaging and the grading scheme was clearly laid out. The professor encouraged class discussions and critical thinking. I learnt a lot from the course.
She has little material to teach, and most of the lectures consist of mandatory presentations that we have to give.
The professor is knowledgeable on fairness-related topics in AI but she gives very low marks

I really enjoyed this course with Dr. Biswas. It was by no means an automatic A, but standards of evaluation seemed fair and were clearly laid out from the start of the term. If you show up to class and put some effort into the assignments, it's not difficult to get a good grade.

The content is dense, but only a subset is relevant for exams and assignments. For exams, be comfortable with running algorithms manually and recalling factoids from the slides. For assignments, be prepared to search beyond the lecture slides to complete an assignment. Dr. Yu applies a liberal final curve.
Easy A if you read the textbook. And more than 70% of students receive a B or better.

TONS of material, but only a subset of it is actually needed in HW's / exams. HW's can be more in depth / detailed than what's on the slides. No prep for exams but they are (imo) pretty surface level and just ask questions / problems from the slides. Prof can be VERY stingy when asked questions. Gave 3% extra credit and 85% = A this semester.
way too much material is covered with not much depth, final was fact recall and "run the algorithm by hand"
Reply quick to emails and really caring

He may be smart, but some people should just not be teachers. He's told students to use ChatGPT for help. Material in lecture, recitation, and HW are all different. HW can't be completed without prior knowledge, not covered in class. When students ask questions, his answers are smug, unserious, and unproductive. There is one TA for the whole class.

Has a thick accent, but is very understandable. Recommends to read textbook, but most questions in the exams appear from the lecture slides and assignments. Grades very graciously, put in a decent effort and scoring an A should not be tough.

He's not great. He has a thick accent which made him hard to understand sometime. His tests were full of trick questions and it was really easy to make a mistake. He does teach well though and super willing to help during office hours. Responds really quick to emails. I joined the class late and he got me up to speed. Watch the videos, take notes.

Probably the best professor I have had in terms of teaching the topics, and he is more than willing to help out during office hours. However, he is also the hardest professor for CS 205 in terms of the difficulty of homework, quizzes, and exams. You'll need to really work for an A but it is definitely possible. Quizzes and exams are open book/note.

This professor is blatantly rude. He is not fit to teach students if he cannot communicate properly. I have reached out to him multiple times about quiz and exam answers for which his explanation was just reiterating the given answer or telling me I have a "lack of logic" or "wrote too much". If you can't be a teacher, then don't teach at all.

Does not care about you or the topics he's teaching. Just read the slides at home. No point in going to a lecture where the professor barely teaches. Recitation attendance was mandatory but not a single topic in the recitations related to the lecture material. Such a joke

Lectures are boring and monotone. Don't bother going to office hours, he'll either refer you to the textbook or won't answer your questions. Don't bother emailing him with questions either, he'll just tell you "ask the TAs." Grading on homeworks and projects is extremely strict and unfair. Curve on the midterm was pretty good.

Terrible lecturer (just reads the slides), unclear assignments, and poor communication. Grading is lenient and exams are mostly word-for-word from the homeworks, so it's a relatively easy A, but I've never seen a more poorly run class. On day 1, he said he does "25 % teaching, 25 % services, 100 % research", so it's clear where his priorities lie.

Easy professor. 35% As when I took it. Only curved the final. Terrible lecturer and does not go in-depth with the material. Quality homeworks. Programming assignments are too basic. Easy class with a math background. Hard class for most CS majors.

2nd worst CS lecturer I've had at Rutgers. Assignments were written in broken English, and were often incredibly unclear. Same with exams. Just avoid the class if it's taught by him, it's not worth it.

Not an easy class. Cover huge amount material and need a lot Math. The hw and mp are pretty hard and time consuming. But you put in time you can get it. The professor himself is wise and lenient with grading, huge curve; 75 means A in midterm. The exam was totally based on hw. If you actually did and understood the hw you would find it quite easy.

It is the first time he's ever teaching this class and the first midterm is this Friday. Yes, the materials sound interesting at a glance but it's SO MUCH (theoretical and abstract) MATH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! and occasional programming
If you really do the homework and read the textbook, there is no reason that you cannot get a B. Lots of bonus, and generous curves. Wanna good grade? Take him!

Boring class, but he tries to make the material interesting. It's pretty easy to pass, but be prepared to put in a ton of effort if you want the B or A. The homework assignments and midterm weren't too hard, but the final was impossible. If you're the type of person who is happy with C's (you know who you are), take him. Overall meh professor.
Greatest Professor ever. Definitely take him again. Easiest professor in CS205 ever. Straight forward quizzes and exams.
His lectures are dull and not engaging. It is hard to learn from him. You're better off reading the book on your own. If, like me, math is not your strong suit, this class will be difficult.
His quizzes and exams are straightforward, and easier than other CS205 professors. He gives curves and extra credits. Do the homework and you'll get a good grade.

The content is dense, and Dr. Kim races through the material. The scope of each quiz is large, and it took me several hours of studying to feel well prepared for each quiz. In addition, the timing for a quiz felt a tad rushed but doable. The assignments take time and effort but also serve to deepen one's understanding of the material.

Just do yourself a favor and dont take him. Difficult exams, dense and dry lectures. No partial credit, but the main issues are the TAs. Several of them are self-entitled and want to see the class fail, and the prof isn't any help. Looks like a 76 is an A, which goes to show you how badly ran this course was. All in all, prof: hard, TA's: the worst

Good professor in terms of learning new things, teaches an insanely large amount of material. Good part is you learn alot, bad part is there's a lot of brand new content to learn that's tough to think about which makes "quizzes" (midterms) extremely tough. Assignments were definitely confusingly worded, but I think that's a TA problem.

10 assignments, Wiresharks and Coding. Lectures difficult to follow as he'll go really fast and jump around topics. Exams were definitely studyable, people say we didn't have enough time but it was more than enough given the freebie questions he'd give us. Nice & approachable professor, can really tell it was his first time teaching this class.

Too many people yapping. If you studied enough, you can easily secure a B, maybe an A. The tests were definitely not easy and the time restriction was a bit of a tism. TAs were very angry little goblins who took grading too personal. I hope they don't aspire to be professors at Rutgers or we're cooked. The end.
Hes hard and would not take again

This is by far the worst class I have ever taken. The TA's offer no partial credit to the point where the professor went back and regraded each quiz, to that he is also a harsh grader. Lectures are not understandable. The slides give little to no information. Take this class with literally anyone else. Or rather just don't take it at all.
bad bad bad

Yes, this class has a LOT of content, but just study effectively. His lectures are strenuous, but just lock in, ask questions, and take note the  diagrams he draws. Your study habits reflect your grade in the class, if you consistently draw out and add new concepts to the TCP/IP model as you learn, you will understand. You will learn SO MUCH!
too much content and workload in too short a time. this class had me genuinely tweaking out. take this class with another prof

Genuinely one of the most disorganized classes I've ever taken. Quizzes that are really just exams and are only 45 minutes, which is not enough time at all for the material. TAs grade harshly, professor gives absolutely no partial credit for exams (quizzes), the topics are extremely complex and confusing. Overall a horrible class, do not take.

Professor Kim has done an extremely poor job of teaching Internet Technology, focusing on the most niche aspects of the subject, giving long exams dubbed as "quizzes" that need to be completed in 45 minutes, homework assignments that are completely out of sync with our learning material, and has harsh and very uninformative graders.

DO NOT TAKE.

He's really nice, but that doesn't necessarily make him a good lecturer. He has a slight accent, but he's not particularly difficult to understand because of that; it's far more about the way he organizes his information in his lectures, which can be disorienting as we jump from topic to topic. Also, no partial credit on "quizzes" (midterms)

The prof has a lot of content in his lecture, too complex with hard to understand handwriting.We get 2 quizzes(NO partial credit) but only half the class time to finish it which is unreasonable for the length and the type of questions given. Unclear and harsh grading standards. Vague assignment instructions. knowledgeable but doesnt teach well

The profs handwriting and speaking was hard to understand; We got midterm-length quizzes with half the time and very hard qns(NO partial credit); Grading standards were awful/harsh and varied per grader; The prof was not helpful with student qns; Programming assignments were long/complex/unclear; DO NOT take with this prof; unnecessarily difficult.

This is a Slideshow presentation type class where, handwriting is terrible, accent bad, all resources are the slides.

There are 2 quizes 8 assignments and a final
Hes a perfectionist but wont help you on anything if you ask him.

Quizzes: No partial credit at all, Extremely quick
Assignments: Numerous Contradictions and Typos in all of em.

RIP
Just too chaotic of a course. Everything always seems on the fly, and I don't know what to even expect in terms of a grade. Personally not worth the stress compared to other CS352 professors

Dr. Tang assigned 3 open-note take-home quizzes, but the final project is the bulk of the work. If your proposal for your final project is well thought out, and your group delivers a research-driven final project accompanied with a solid 8-page report, 15-minute video, and a functioning prototype, then you should earn high marks in Data Mining.

I took him S25, and he's a very fair professor. He's a newer professor, but he still did a pretty good job. The only thing I didn't like about the class was the unclear grading criteria. I'd still take him though, it's a good class.

Nice guy. Helpful, smart. Not like a tenured CS professor, he is a grad student so not lazy yet. Class was easyish and useful skills in data analysis. Terrible and very slow grading. Very disorganized.

Professor Tang essentially taught Guna's 439 in the first half leading into the midterm (our only exam) and then left it to the students to decide how in depth they wanted to go for their final project while teaching bonus topics for the second half. Sometimes hard to understand and soft-spoken but very knowledgeable and gives great suggestions

Professor Zhang was really passionate about the subject and gave great lectures. Although they were not mandatory, I gained a lot from going to lecture. He is very thorough in his explanations. The grading was also very lenient on homework and exams. I would 100% take professor Zhang for CS344.

The lecture slides are very well designed and easy to follow along with. Professor Zhang encourages students to ask questions, and takes his time answering and clarifying any students' confusions. The homework and lecture slides are good preparation for the exams.

CS334 is graded on 4 homeworks, 1 midterm, and 1 final. Homeworks are 50% of your grade, and so are the exams, which are nice. There were also extra credit problems on question 4. He is very nice and kind, and is very good at answering questions in a clear way. Overall, he is a very good professor.

Professor Zhang is one of the best computer science professors at Rutgers. He is so patient with explaining things, and he can make even the most difficult concepts intuitive. If you have the chance, would highly recommend taking a class with him.

Great professor! 4 HW Assignments, 1 Midterm and 1 Final. Lectures are pretty easy to follow along with and HWs are doable. Would recommend Professor Zhang for CS344 as his grading is very lenient. This is also not a very intensive class which I greatly appreciate. 

An A is 90 â€“ 100, B+ is 80 â€“ 89, B is 70 â€“ 79, C+ is 60 â€“ 69, C is 50 - 59

We had 8% EC to our final grade, the final was taken home, and the in-person midterm was heavily curved. Honestly, if you have a pulse, you can end up with an A in this class. The only caveat is that you won't learn much from his lectures.

The material for the class itself was pretty interesting, but you could tell that the assignments were copied from his data mining grad course. Assignments were few and extremely easy (the average for everything is consistently above 90). Easy A class -- I didn't really learn much because there was no incentive to.

Excellent lectures. Math heavy class with only a couple of small pseudocodes required. 4 HWs, 1st is hardest. Midterm and final are quite difficult easy grading. HWs have extra credit so easy to get As. He likes when we ask questions in class, always solves doubts with a lot of detail.

The best professor I've ever had at Rutgers. The class material was pretty hard, but the class was made to be very easy as long as you did your work. We got a bunch of extra credit which I didn't expect at all and the grading was extremely lenient. Was stressing at first hoping to pass and ended up with an A

He's what I would call an above average professor. His class is shamefully easy, he has insane extra credit problems (maximum +7% to final average), and final was take-home. He's also a very caring and humble guy. However, I wish he taught more content, like backtracking algorithms. I feel like I didn't learn too much from this course...

This professor is outstanding. He excels at explaining complex algorithms clearly, making even the most difficult concepts accessible. He encourages questions and thoroughly addresses all uncertainties. His lectures are well-organized and his grading is extremely fair. Take his class if you can - you'll learn a lot and be graded appropriately!
The best professor in CS dept for 344
the goat
Great professor. The class project was very helpful for my job seeking.
Great professor; very lenient grader

He's good at teaching, makes complex topics clear. But some of his grading policies are a little questionable at best. His accent makes it hard to understand him sometimes and when talking to him outside of class (during office hours), he is very visibly awkward and uncomfortable which only makes you uncomfortable. He's still a solid professor.

He is probably the best professor since I joined Rutgers. Very much enjoyed his class. His teaching style is patient and clear. Would stop and patiently answer the questions from students. He also helped to connect the algorithms in this course with other subjects such as OS, AI and Networks, which helped me to connect the dots. Highly recommend!
Knowledgable professor and nicely organized class. Highly recommend!

Teaching was clear and well structured, learned a lot of useful knowledge and skills for designing algorithms from his class (already helped me in my job interviews). Overall a great class and great professor. His class is highly recommended.

Amazing professor! He is very knowledgable and his lecture is very insightful. His lecture is neat and clean and very well structured, making everything easier to understand for me. He also introduced several advanced topics which increased my interest in the area. Strongly recommend to take his class!

Professor Zhang is amazing ! Took him for CS344 and the class was super smooth. Even though it was online due to the pandemic, the class was well organized and straight forward. I love the way he teaches, goes over every small detail and never assumes that you know anything in prior, which is incredibly nice. He really cares about his students.

Zhang is probably the best professor I have had since attending Rutgers. He taught in a very clear and concise way, and planned his lectures very very nicely. The material was tough, but he was a fantastic professor.

I took algorithms this semester (remotely) with Zhang, and the course has been pretty easy. He uploads lectures every week, and while he isn't super engaging you can understand the concepts pretty well. The homework assignments are also easy, since you have plenty of time. There is no ProctorTrack on the midterm and final, and he gives you 24 hours

344 Algorithms is a difficult class overall, mostly due to the nature of the subject (lots of theories!) But I find the prof's lecture to be clear and patient, making the subject a lot more fun. His materials are clear and neatly organized, making online learning easier to follow. yet you have to be self-motivated and keep up with the weekly pace.
Lectures are very long and boring hard to pay attention
Explains step by step. Very clear in his thoughts, lenient and caring. Always available for doubts.

Prof. Zhang is genuinely always available for students who want to learn. He also explains material step by step and difficult subject is easier to understand. He also supports student to come up with new idea or do great research. He genuinely praised student who come up with great idea. I recommended him for rutgers student to take his course.

Great professor, knows his material well. He gives valuable feedback and he is very accessible outside of class. This was the first time he taught a course at Rutgers and won best professor award for it too.

The material covered is very baseline compared to the exams and weekly quizzes. The questions are sometimes convoluted and felt like they were trying to "trick" you. His teaching method is great (chalk), but he fails to clarify details and has made several mistakes in his proof work. Exams consisted of writing pseudocode and proofs. Be prepared.

Grading was all over the place and super late all the time (would get 95's despite having a lot of wrong answers). Garcia's lectures are sometimes inconsistent and hard to follow, but they are all posted. The material itself isn't that bad and there are a lot of sources online if you need help. Tests are difficult and need to be studied for, though

Lectures were useful and homework was manageable, but grading too a long time. Responded to my emails quickly. Very test heavy but some extra credit was offered near the end. Exams and the final project were brutal, but I enjoyed my stay.
Great professor, lectures were mandatory but were very helpful for understanding material. Exams were based on everything we went over in class and in homeworks, so it was very doable.
Explains the material well, so it's essential to attend lectures. The grading can be somewhat disorganized. As long as you keep up with the work and self study and don't slack off, you'll be fine.

Mandatory lectures, but absolutely worth the time. Learned a TON from lectures, and being attentive in those guarantees the A basically. 3% extra credit, 30% grade comes from problem sets that are graded leniently. 10% in attendance as well. Super free class just dont slack.

Uploads recorded lectures to study for exams, 3 exams (20%) each, 15% project, 15% hw, 10% participation (end of class activities). Exams are okay, repeated from previous semesters (10 MC worth 20%, 80% OE for midterms, full MC for final). Accommodating with exams, not responsive through email. Class isn't too hard if you study a few hours per exam

Professor Garcia makes this course a little too mathematical to the point that students have difficulty understanding the concepts. He is also disorganized and teaches way too fast. Avoid him if you can, though if you can't make sure to watch YouTube videos before lectures to understand the material or else you'll have difficulty following along.

He's a pretty good lecturer. Problem sets and exams are very straightforward and reasonable. Very lenient grading structure especially for a CS class (10% participation). Downsides would be he's a little disorganized and takes a long time to grade. Recitations were absolutely useless which sucks because they're mandatory.

Class is coordinated, so assignments, tests, and content is the same no matter the prof. He does not follow the slides for the course but rather uses the chalkboard. Lectures can be helpful but are boring. He's chill in general, just not the best lecturer. Recitations are super helpful though. He'll answer questions, even dumb ones.

Prof cares about the class and is great at explaining things, speaks a little softly. 
For data structures 112 specifically, the course itself is disorganized and (lol) unstructured, so it's easy to find some concepts out of place or pointless during class. Also many of the big coding assignments have glitches in the auto-grader, which is annoying.

Garcia is a great lecturer. He makes the material very clear and easy to understand. The project is a little outdated but is easily transferrable to more modern technologies. I really enjoyed the content in this class but he is sadly not very accessible outside of class and office hours. Very helpful in person but does not respond to emails.
This teacher is very bad at lectures, really boring actually. But his homework is very good at teaching you things and the exams are really straightforwards

Miranda gives you the absolute bare minimum. The content is good - Miranda teaches it passably - but that's it. He doesn't care to answer emails or grade work meaningfully(how do you get feedback?). TAs(hit or miss) take from his example. People openly cheat/work together on exams. It's a free A at the end of the day. But you can do better

Professor Garcia is one of the most amazing professor at RU cs department. His lectures are interesting and inspirational. Even though he did not reply to email oftentimes, he is really accessible during his office hours and is willing to help. The exams are not that hard as long as you prepared well and the final project is super interesting!
Pay attention in class

Lectures are great: He's solid at explaining the material and is super nice and open to questions. Homework can be difficult sometimes but it prepares you well for the exams. The exams themselves are fair difficulty-wise. As for the cons, he's inconsistent with communication on Piazza, and grading is horribly slow. Regardless, he's a great CS prof.
