Solid professor but very unorganized. Didn't get final project grade until the day grades were due. Disappeared from piazza a few weeks into the semester and very rarely replied to emails. Lectures were solid though; he explained concepts pretty well. Homework and exams really weren't an issue either. But the final project was a MESS.

As a Professor, he is knowledgeable and his lectures are good. The problem is trying to reach him out through email, its horrendous. The class itself is a rollercoaster but if you go to every lecture, you will get a B+ at least. Just be prepared to have your doubts solved a bit...late!

Very disorganized prof. Took months to grade assignments. Doesn't answer questions during exams. Exams are mid. Doesnt respond to emails/piazza. Gave little help/resources for intensive group final project. Submitted final grades on very last day. He's a chill dude and isn't a jerk. I'll give him that. He did curve final grades a bit this sem too.

Pretty good lectures and explains the material well, but damn does he take long to grade assignments/tests.

He also barely responds to emails so good luck trying to reach out to him without going to office hours.

Very engaging lectures. Explains concepts pretty clearly, for the most part. The material was super interesting. You won't learn the material nearly as well if you don't attend lectures. Besides explaining the concepts, he goes through more difficult problems in class that come up on problem sets and exams. Almost totally inaccessible out of lass

Completely agree with CS112 Rating below (Aug 17th, 2021). This Professor NEVER responds to emails. He NEVER answers questions on Piazza. He grades towards the end of the semester. His lectures are LOUSY. VERY, VERY unprofessional. This is an important course (Data Structures). Please Do NOT take ANY course taught by this professor.
Awful

This may be the most disorganized course I have ever taken in the CS department. He is MIA the entire semester, so don't expect to hear anything. Reused recorded lectures from years ago. Exams were brutal which makes up most of your grade. Projects are ridiculous. Kind of like learning 1+1 and then doing calc on a test. Avoid at all costs.

Professor Garcia's lectures were online and the tests were extremely difficult. They were much harder than the material taught in class. Tha TA's also take a long time to grade your work but he legit gives good curves and helps correct problems in tests. So, I will not complain. This is a difficult class , Be prepared to put in the work.
The worst class I have ever taken in my life. This guy gives the hardest exams, teaches nothing and his projects are next to impossible to complete

please avoid at all costs! by far the worst professor ive had here. he does not provide any feedback on how we are performing in the course, slow grader, lectures are 40-60 min videos, has little to no communication regarding exams, and no office hours.

Probably the worst professor I ever had at rutgers. For a 3 hour class that was supposed to be synchronous, we have only ever gotten 40 min videos and no communication from him regarding office hours. Assignments take forever to be graded, so we do not even have feedback for how we are doing.

He gives nice group projects and doable homeworks. Kind of underrated. I think it's because he doesn't reply to emails quickly or respond on piazza. Also, he grades extremely slowly. But clears all questions in class when approached. Lectures are straight to the point, does not waste time on anything unnecessary.
Awesome lecturer. Really enjoyed the group project. Grading very slow however. I agree that he's underrated

Honestly, underrated. His lectures are great especially the online ones. I took two of his classes and both were fine in terms of difficulty. Just make sure to have good partners for 336's project. His only real significant flaw is how long he takes to grade things. Also, he isn't easily accessible.
Professional.
Why is he such a great professor? I like this professor so much. If you see him, take it.

My name is Daniel, and I really love Prof. Garcia's lecture. Very professional, very kind. I think I'm going to be a successful computer science professional because of this professor. I would definitely recommend taking this course and he will take care of you.Thank you, Prof. Garcia, you are the best professor that I met while attending Rutgers.

Extremely disorganized teacher. This class was not good in terms of organization and communication. He has not graded anything and it is towards the end of the semester. He is also not good at communicating with his students because he probably does not check his emails. Do not take this professor if you're looking for an organized professor.

Lectures were fineeasy to understand and succinct enoughbut this guy is nowhere to be found. If you email him a question, he never responds. The TAs only respond seemingly once a month. The final project instructions were unclear and the TA kept changing instructions on Piazza. This class was a disaster, for thousands of dollars of tuition, sad

Databases was the most disorganized thing that I've ever been a part of, and I was in an underground beyblade club in 4th grade. Tests and homeworks were graded months late, and when Sakai deleted the test answers, Garcia didn't respond to emails and wasn't at office hours. Vital project information was released on the due date.

I got grades back in December for stuff that I submitted in September. The class is severely understaffed, and to add to that Miranda is impossible to get in touch with. Exams were difficult and the group project is a nightmare if you have a group that doesn't want to do anything. Miranda also uses lectures that are 2 years old. Such a lazy "prof"

I think the material isn't hard, however, the homework is graded heavily and the exams are graded even more harshly after they are graded over a month. Hard to talk to him. The TAs and project graders are irresponsible. Never got an email back. No feedback. Not Recommended.

Material isnt hard, however the HW is graded pretty heavily and the exams are graded even harsher when they eventually get graded over a month later and the hw to study for them wasnt graded until a day before the final which was over a week after the end of classes. Good lectures but they were two year old recordings, impossible to chat with him

This professor is the most lazy CS professor that I have had at Rutgers. All his lectures are pre-recorded from years ago. His HWs and midterms would take a month or longer to grade. When he finally releases the grade, you can find no help at answering or regrading because all this TAs and himself would ignore your questions on email or piazza.

I took CS112 over the summer, and it was by far the worst college course experience I have ever had. Assignments took weeks on weeks to be graded. Office hours and recitation were more likely than not to be canceled. Questions asked on Piazza are practically never answered. For such an important class I do not recommend. Especially over the summer.

She was honestly a decent teacher, but did speed through concepts quite a bit. The workload for this class is very heavy, and can be a nightmare if you don't have a good project partner. The only unfair part is the exams, which are worth too much considering how long the projects take and contain a lot of vague concepts which weren't applied

The most BORING lectures. The assignments got better towards the end, but the exams are a different story. She does not provide any practice exam material. She will except u to memorize her 300+ slides and will ask the most niche things on there. Her exams are a memory game, and her open-ended questions are assignment-based. Know your assignments.
A lot of labs and assignments throughout the course. Professor was clear and explained the topics. Open to questions and very nice.

Would not recommend this class. This class is definitely time consuming so make sure your semester isn't loaded with other heavy classes as projects have a lot of different criteria that has to be met. And make sure to get a good partner. Only take this class if you are going to be a SWE and/or have a strong interest in software engineering.
Nice class.

This class was phenomenal, and I'm told harder (but felt easy) than the Eng version. Her lectures correlated perfectly to the projects and very organized. Partner projects, useful skills. Highly recommend.

Professor Chang is awesome, sweet, and available after class. However, this class sucked. She goes FAST, and I couldn't process what she was saying so fast. Midterms and final are hard, very few grades (3-5 projects and exams).

Surprisingly very organized. 5 long (but not difficult) Java projects. One midterm and final (no practice questions / exams given). Not an easy A but good if you actually want to learn SE. The exams were not as detailed-oriented / trivia-like as some reviews might suggest.

Professor Chang is a very nice professor, and her lectures are actually quite good despite what people are saying. She didn't stand out as superb, but she is better than the average CS professor. Group projects suck; get a good partner. Medians: Midterm 66, Final 63. You can easily get a 96 on both like I did by making flashcards of her notes.

Great professor for software engineering, it is a lot of material and information to take in but she explains things pretty well. The project is also graded leniently. The exams are lots of random information from the slides though, and can be difficult, so make sure to study a lot. You will learn a lot throughout the project's development.

took her for data structures and didn't mind her then but this class was another beast. shes a nice professor but just not a fan of her teaching style, that mixed with an 8:30 made me stop going to lecture entirely lol. shes also not the most approachable and rather unforgiving on the grading for the projects. exams are tough.

Do not take her please. Her assignments are crazy for no freaking reason and extremely time taking. They can be doable with a good partner and if you get a bad partner you are done for. Just avoid this professor!!!!

I never went to class and when I did it was hard for me to pay attention. Having a good partner helps. The exams are tough. She was easy to talk to one on one and extended a project once. I just really didn't like the exams. Also, the graders don't all grade the same. Someone had a bad uml diagram and got full points.
Boring lectures, hard to pay attention. She knows her stuff but does not do a good job of teaching it.

Chang has great lecture notes-- study all the info on them for exams (50% multiple choice, 50% open ended). She's very nice when answering questions about grading criteria for projects and curves exams when necessary. However, I gotta say I never paid attention to her talks during her lectures-- I just took notes from her notes. Befriend your TAs!

Group projects were long but substantial and helped you prepare for her midterm and final. They are pretty difficult, so make sure you do well on the group projects. She added 10 points to the final and curved final grades slightly (my 89 was an A, for example). I strongly recommend it if you plan on going into Software Engineering professionally.

Professor Chang wasn't that terrible. If you really pay attention to her lectures, you'll understand the material. One thing I did not like was that she BARELY codes in class, which sucks because it does not prepare you for the midterms and final coding questions.

The lectures were very mundane and hard to follow. It was better to learn the material through reading online sources. Projects were time-consuming but doable, but exams were just random trivia from notes that were super obscure information

slide HEAVY barely codes anything in front of you (unlike centeno) and therefore doesn't prepare you for the coding sections of the exams. you'll get the concepts if you can manage to pay attention, (a lot of just reading slides boringly), but be prepared to have no idea how to approach the assignments. then wonders why people skip to go to centeno

I found her class to be very interesting and I learned a lot from it. She was very nice when approached and answered any question I had. The midterm/final are VERY difficult. You need a good partner for this class for the projects; they're very time consuming and challenging. I'd take her class if you can ensure you'd have a reliable partner.

She teaches the tools, rather than just the concepts, in lecture - very helpful. However, she gives near no leniency in grading/late projects (which are a majority of your grade) even if you have documented medical special circumstances. Best taken if you have a dependable partner, are physically healthy, and can maintain a heavy workload.

She's not a bad professor, but she's not amazing either. Her lectures are very monotone and boring, and she usually goes over the content on the lecture slides. All of the CS112 classes follow the same curriculum including exams, assignments, and lecture slides, so you could skip her lecture if you find the other professors more helpful.

Chang is a kind professor, and is very flexible. I have a friend who's partner ghosted him, and Chang extended the deadline for him. The midterm was fair, focusing on OOP concepts. The Final was JavaFX and Android trivia ,but that's expected since it's the only thing we learn after the midterm. If you're taking this class, find a good partner.

Very nice person but not a great professor. Her lectures use lots of examples in order to show how specific data structures operate (which in it of itself is good), but they tend to become drawn out for too long. Also cannot answer questions for the life of her. Expect to self study with this professor.

The projects are doable without attending lectures. She was quick at responding to emails. The only downside is her exams. However, I do not think she is as bad as people say. Make sure to get a good partner for the class and if you have solid memorization skills for the exams, you will be fine
Projects are easy, exams are brutal literally memorize every class structure in java and maybe u have a shot of getting above the average on the final which was a 49

Nice person. But lectures are very boring and not effective at teaching the material. The final required you to remember very precise details. Projects are very easy but the tasks aren't interesting. Some of the tech you learn in this course is outdated i.e. JavaFX (I don't exactly blame her for this because it's probably part of the curriculum).

She's a completely fine professor. Projects are easy if you start early and I honestly did learn a lot in this class. No denying it though, there are so many lecture notes, and you need to know them like the back of your hand for the exams, which is easily the worst part of the course. Still, I don't think she's as bad as some people say.
Boring, strict and lecture heavy

Class is a joke, assignments are boring and uninspiring. Lectures are mundane, barely anyone attends (you can also learn everything she teaches in a quarter of the time by googling). If you're trying to become a better programmer, you'd honestly be better off just doing a personal project with OOP. But if you want an easy A, take this class.

5 Java projects (55%), 1 midterm (20%), and 1 final (25%). Group projects with a partner of your choice or a random pick. Partner can be in her other sections. Tests are all right as long you know Java and its minute details. Lectures are not mandatory, but you can go if you want to pay attention. She does upload her slides from lectures.

Prof lacks clarity, lectures boring, assignments confusing. Unhelpful office hours, inconsistent grading, minimal feedback. Creates a demoralizing learning environment, hindering academic growth. Learning should be a two-way street, not a dead-end. All i can advise you to stay away from this professor. Period.

Took her in the Fall. Literally just read off her slides and barely did any actual teaching. Her exams are hard because they were basically trivia questions so it's useless in practicality. She also doesn't curve despite low averages on exams. Her labs weren't too bad though, but start early.

Overall, professor chang wasn't a bad professor, but if you could get centeno take her over chang. Chang does not code anything during class while centeno. Chang I also found to be a quite bit boring and hard to understand. Luckily, CS112 doesn't depend on your professor so go to another professor's lecture.

I had her for 112 and she was a great professor! She was very attentive to questions and explained everything in an easy to understand way. 112 itself wasnt easy but she made the slides easier to understand than if I didnt go to lecture. Just sit in the front bc shes kinda quiet and uses the chalkboard a lot.

She is a nice and caring person outside of class. However, in class she spoke monotonely and was difficult to follow which made it hard to pay attention. I passed the Data Structures class with an A due to my extensive preparations before the class took place. The exams and projects were doable but time consuming.

Honestly I wouldn't listen to these other reviews for 112. Chang was a very nice, responsive, attentive, and helpful lecturer. She made things easy to understand and I always came to her lectures. It showed she tried her best to make us understand the concepts.

Dr.Chang's projects were easy but always taught me something new. She responded to emails and provided us with her lecture notes which were extremely helpful when it came to studying for exams. With that being said, her lectures were extremely boring (& I eventually stopped going). The exams require you to memorize 100+ pages of notes.

Really nice person. Extended the deadline for my group when we really needed it. Gave back 16 points for everyone for the final exam. Responds to emails. Projects were manageable but the exams require a lot of memorization. Get started early and you will do fine.
Nice professor, gives really detailed lecture notes but exams are extremely difficult. Projects weren't bad at all and given plenty of time to complete.

5 coding assignments over the semester which are lowkey long. She is an alright lecturer, I recommend getting seats at the very front of her class because shes not that loud and she likes using the chalkboard/whiteboard a lot.

She just reads off slides her entire lecture, I stopped going. I went to her office hours for help on an assignment and she kept saying she could not "give me answers"..I needed help, not answers. Take her and you're basically on your own, she won't really help, if you know how to code, take her. If you don't, you'll learn nothing.

For data structures, she was about average as a professor. Her lectures were kind of boring and uninspiring and I felt like most of my learning happened when I was reading on my own. She wasn't bad but she wasn't anything to write home about either.

Honestly, one of the worse professors I've had at Rutgers. Her assignments are a little hard to understand in terms of what she wants. Once you understand, it's pretty straight forward. Her writeups are confusing. Lectures are dry, but okay; better off reading them. Her exams are VERY difficult. Doing bad on the exams guarantees you less than an A.

Lectures are literally just the professor reading off the slides. The projects were easy but they only count for half of the grade. The rest is in the tests which are brutal because it is just memorizing random java trivia. Even if you know java and feel confident in the projects, if you are not good at memorization do not take this professor.
Take her class only if you can memorize all of her lecture slides because she will just pick a random fact off of each slide and put them on the test.

Projects were easy enough, but they only count for half the grade. The other half comes from exams, which were absolutely brutal. Be prepared to memorize the intricate details of 100s of pages of lecture notes if you want to pass those.

Professor Chang was a great lecturer and really knew the concepts of Data Structures well. She often related the topic of discussion to practical, real world examples which was very helpful. For homework and exams, she guides you in the right direction and informs you of what material in particular is important.
She's a wonderful professor i would take her again for all my computer science courses, chang gang

The projects are easy, but tedious. I was however still able to solo them in 6-8 hours, so overall workload is manageable. Projects are for the most part super basic showcases of inheritance. Not much useful material is covered in this course. She's also not  very understanding. Her exams are very hard, mostly because they're random Java trivia.

This class was tough yo. Legit back-to-back projects which were doable but can be tedious. PLEASE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD GET A GOOD PARTNER BEFORE YOU TAKE THIS CLASS. You have to do assignment with a partner. The tests were mad hard, 69% avg for midterm and 50% avg. for cuml. final. NO CURVE btw so step up ur game. U learn OOP/JavaFX but at what cost

In CS112 I found the assignments to be very easy but the exams to be moderately difficult. Chang's lectures are okay but they are mostly just reading from the slides. You wouldn't miss anything by skipping her lectures and teaching yourself directly from the slides, which given the low lecture attendance I bet many people did.

Do you enjoy the world's longest slide presentations on boring, unimaginative material? Then Prof. Chang is for you. She reads off the slides, which makes coming to class pointless since most of the material is lists of definitions. A group project counts for half your grade and is graded very easily, but her exams are tough and overly detailed.

CS112. As long as your read the syllabus, you will see what you are graded on / letter grade criteria, and she follows this perfectly. Answers questions well in lectures and takes the time to explain concepts clearly. Lectures not mandatory as she posts all the slides online but follow that at your own risk

Throughout the semester there have been back to back to back projects that are very intensive. Not to mention that I have other classes to worry about too. The stress from the projects is ridiculous and the amount of work required is absurd. I would avoid it at all costs.
I took her for Data Structures. The projects were easy for me, while the exams were a bit more difficult. She takes class time to explain the projects, which helps people who struggle with them.

Chang's office hours are formatted where only students can attend one at a time. She also does not assist you on the projects and only responds with semi-vague answers. Her exams are very MC-intensive, with only a bit over a minute per question. She also reads off of the slides. The only good thing about the class is that the projects are easy.

So, honestly, all she does is read off her slides during lectures (which she actually posts later (online semester)), gives really poor explanations to questions that people have, and I would honestly be happier if she just gave us a textbook to read and gave us projects based on what we read (you basically teach yourself the material anyway).

For a class where a lot was overhauled from the previous semester, Chang's lectures really did not help. She skips over a lot and explains everything poorly, so you effectively have to rely on self-studying. Albeit, I can't blame her that much, as most of my other complaints on the course comes from how awful it ran this semester.

Must work with a partner, has very specific requirements and does not really communicate them very well which is annoying. The exams are the most difficult part since some questions can be kind of random or irrelevant. But projects are the main part of the class and they are not very difficult. If you have a good partner the workload isn't bad.

Projects were on the easy side, possible to be solo'd. Exams, especially the Final was very difficult. Lectures are fair, a very solid choice for CS213. Would definitely recommend over Sesh if your current schedule is already Programming assignment heavy.

For a professor that highlights communication she is the least understanding when it comes to individual circumstances. Ironic. Did you submit a quiz accidentally and email her? Nothing she can do about it. Had a family member die and missed a submission? Nothing she can do about it. Want to learn useful information? Nothing she can do about it.
Professor has strict grading criteria and she cuts points for stupid stuff and grader and TA are useless as they do not help at all. All they do is point fingers at each other
This class was really fun and the professor is really nice. You learn a lot of stuff that will prepare you for working in the industry and the group project is nice for your resume.
She is really nice and helpful. Her projects are easy but she is strict on documentation. Exams are a bit tricky but easy to do well if you study her lecture notes.
She is a great professor. The projects are very easy and straightforward. Exams are a bit tough because they are very specific, but if you study her thorough notes it isnt hard to do well.

Projects are easy to do alone. But as the semester went on, she went from an 8 page project instruction to 1/2 a page of project instruction. You need to guess what she will take points off for. If she shows you the project in class, make it exactly that, steering off to creativity gets points off. Exams: 46Q in 60min midterm, no time to get stuck.

In order to reuse the test bank, the professor does not release midterm questions to students after the exam. You had to make appointment with TA/professor to check your exam, which is unacceptable. For her own convenience, students' learning experience is sacrificed. Overall, easy projects, tricky midterm and unfair policy.
THe Professor is so mean for the grade, she tries her best to find any bugs of projects. And for the exams, she only gives us 70secs per question.

Lily is an excellent teacher. Projects are very chill: partners are required but doable with 1 person. She's BIG on documentation and style so that's her main grading criteria on projects since they're so straightforward otherwise. Her tests are very specific so memorize details from her very thorough notes. But seriously, Lily is fantastic.

Prof. Chang was great IMO. Her projects for software meth were pretty easy, but there were many specific requirements that needed to be met in order to get full credit. The exams were hard, but all the info is in the slides and notes she gives you. She focuses on the code rather than the concepts which made it hard, but the class is still doable.
Decent lectures, easier projects(50% of grade), somewhat difficult exams. If I have a complaint, it would be how small the curve was for what the avg was on the final

The evaluation of group projects is too strict. It is not easy to get full credits. For the exams, there are two exams and they are really hard including coding and basic knowledge questions and there's no curve.

Be prepared to self study and complete all the assignments and you'll be all set.  The professor is nice and will answer any questions or concerns you might have. Attendance isn't mandatory and lectures are posted online so just lock in especially for the midterm and final.
Not the best but not the worst either. Lectures consist of just reading off slides which are posted on canvas. Grading also takes forever despite there being very few assignments.
Idk lol. Nothing great about him, but nothing to complain about besides the fact that he does no curve. If theres a better option take them, otherwise take him, def wont be stressed
Assignments were tough, exams were tougher. Take menendez instead. This class required more time and more stress than necessary. Barely any curve even though midterm and final averages were about 50%

Attend all lectures to understand the material. Will go over every question you ask, including ones about homework. Exams are tough and he switched up on us by giving some open ended when previous years only had multiple choice. Said he would not curve the class, but curved at the end anyway. Definitely likes hardware more than software.

He did change the structure of the class so exams matter more (40%) and there are open-ended sections (the majority is still multiple choice). I would say that he is moderately difficult if you are new to CS, but the class was not impossible. He's a good lecturer, though sometimes it can be hard to distill what you have to know.

Final exam was very hard, the assignments were tough. 
PLEASE CHOOSE MENENDEZ AND FIRNIER THEIR CLASS IS EASIER. Do not take this professor if you care for ur GPA

hes very smart does a good job simplifying basics. but ramps the difficulty up so fast and expects you to know the ins and outs of every detail. i dont think lectures were bad and certainly taught me to code better. but exams are brutal and full of gotcha questions. that final was real bad, the review was nothing like it at all.

I would not recommend taking this professor. Exams significantly differ from the practice material, lectures were not very helpful, and assignments were overly difficult. Comp arch is a hard course and he made it more stressful than it needed to be.
DONT TAKE HIM. He completely changes his syllabus. The lectures are boring and unclear, and it's hard to know what matters. The assignments and exams are brutal. Goodbye, 4.0.

Great professor, lectures can be a little boring but he's extremely knowledgeable and genuinely cares about helping us learn. Assignments are hard but fair, exams are pretty difficult as well. Definitely take if you have the chance
Takes his time and answers whatever question you have. Concise. Sometimes seems like he assumes that we already know something but overall amazing and much better than other professors.

CS211 is a hard class, regardless of who your professor is. However, Professor Huang gives several quizzes, assignments, and exams which gives you several chances to increase your grade. He explains topics very well and will stop and answer questions/address concerns. I do wish I got to see him smile though.

He cares about teaching the class and it looks like he might really care about the subject of computer architecture but he doesn't care at all about you as a student, no matter what is going on in your life. Annoying amount of assignments that make up most of the grade.

Very easy professor for 211. Class grade is primarily based on group projects, allowing you to throw exams as long as you do the projects, which are easier than other 211 classes. Lectures are very detailed and it shows he knows what he is talking about. They can be boring if you do not participate in them. Very responsive to questions.

Prof Huang is a very smart professor who clearly enjoys what he teaches. He covers most things very in depth and gives ample time for assignments. He also often extends deadlines when a lot of people have not finished. He is avaliable after class for questions and responds to emails and on Piazza. The class is difficult but not too bad.

Doesn't help on Piazza anymore. He was better before, but now he only responds to easy questions. His assignments are hard, and doesn't grant many extensions. His midterms are MCQ, but very hard and unfair. Class average was 60. No curve. Only nice thing is that he records lectures on Zoom and you can also join through Zoom. NOT an easy A.

I requested the Professor twice to delay the deadline for the assignment, but he did not respond and ignored my request. The assignments are difficult, and there are no extensions allowed. There is a 30% late penalty. He is not easily reachable outside of class. Any questions asked on Piazza are ignored, and the responses received are not helpful.
Professor Huang is by far one of the best professors at Rutgers. He is very well spoken and knowledgeable during his lectures. He answers questions clearly and has a great personality.

His lectures are well-explained and easy to grasp. He is accessible during his office hours and active over piazza. 
The course was very well organized!

Huang has a really lenient grading criteria and he explains concepts well. However during the second half of sem he got very behind where you were clueless on the material each PA covered. He gave exams this sem which were pretty brutal. As long as you do all the assignments you can do absolutely terrible on the exams and still get a decent grade.
not horrible, but not great. just average. teaches ok-ish. very lenient with extensions, which is good because the assignments are usually hard to accomplish in

He is an extremely smart man and it shows, but assignments are a little too difficult. Be prepared to make this class your whole life. Gives extensions when not many submit which is nice, but you don't learn everything you need for the assignment up until about the due date.

I would say he's really good. There are just two things to note about him. 1 he doesn't finish teaching you about a subject before he gives you an assignment on it. 2 he gives you code on each assignment. A lot of the time he will ask you to make his code faster. So, you have to solve a problem and understand what he has already done. Makes it hard

He's going to get a lot of flack by the end of this semes, but he's a genuinely good professor. The midterm is exactly what you expect from it and the PAs are hard by default. I think people's perception of him got warped this semester because they expected an easy class when 211 is just really badby default. Take him if you care and want to learn.

Just took an exam in his class, and it was awful. He took off points for picking wrong answers. So you are even punished for making an attempt. Speaking of assignments, it is almost impossible to tackle his hard questions (last set) and that is going to have a huge impact on your grade. I don't even know if I will manage to pass this course.

His back-to-back assignments are soo hard with no extra credits so far and they are worth so much of our grade. And he newly added exams this semester with no reviews or practice exams. His class overall got so much harder than before. With his current grading scale, it is definitely hard to secure an A or even a B+ in this class.
Cares a lot but the first couple weeks is very heavy textbook reading. Fall behind in those first weeks and you'll have a rough semester
Does NOT give enough time for reading, as he required in the syllabus a large portion of reading the first two weeks, which is near impossible to do when handling other classes.

Huang is probably one of the best, if not the best professor in the whole department. He's very understanding, a genius, and really helpful. And a great lecturer. He is however quite difficult(although everyone is for 211). If you pay attention in lectures and start projects early, you can definitely get a B+ or an A.

Honestly the best CS teacher I have taken so far. He's the only professor whose online lectures are both interesting and helpful. He gives all the test cases for a code, which makes it so much easier to understand it. He is also willing to give extensions if we are all struggling, but also gives us hints to get us started.

Probably the best option for 211 at Rutgers at the moment. His lectures are outstanding and you will learn a ton from them. He always gave extensions on every programming assignment and even did some of the problems on the PA in class. Some PA's were tough and some were easier. If you try hard you will probably get an A if not B. He doesn't curve.

Actually THE BEST CS professor at rutgers. Extremely knowledgeable and understanding, and he rewards real effort while also making sure to help us out when we're struggling. A few times, he paused teaching his regular lecture just to help us out with the homework assignments. His quantum computing class is awesome and he explains things very well!

The BEST! An Ideal Professor. Optimized his teaching methods for an ideal level of understanding and learning comfort: lectures were crisp and precise, communication was intelligent and caring, all workflows of this class were well organized and perfectly executed, TAs well trained, feedback was meaningful. THANK YOU!

Overall good teacher. Watch lectures and you will be fine. Projects are fair and he gives you all material/information necessary to do projects on your own. Encourages meeting with TAs and/or coming to office hours. A very respectable professor who equipped students with everything needed to succeed -- but it's up to you if you want to succeed
Great professor, gave very nice lectures.

Professor Huang is an amazing professor who cares about his students a lot. He wants to make sure they are learning and answers piazza swiftly. His projects are quite difficult so you will have to start early

Awesome professor. Super knowledgeable on complex topics but good enough at explaining them for your average student to easily follow along. Made expectations super clear early on, writeups for assignments were very organized. Good dude overall. The actual class was pretty hard for me, but I lucked out w/ Professor Huang. A+ prof
He is super caring about every student. If you ever have question, go ask him for help
This guy is an actual homie. Probably one of the best profs I've had. He's just so smart so he can answer all your questions and inspire you abt the topic as well. Cracked teacher bruh

Professor Huang is one of the few professors that actually care about his class. He goes through every topic and makes sure everyone understands it. Lectures are very informative. His projects are straightforward you should have no problem finishing it as long as you understand the core concepts. Highly recommend you take this guy's classes.

Although comp arch is a hard course, he made this course much easier to understand and he is so caring. He is glad to answer questions during lectures, on piazza, and also by emails. I would definitely take his course again.
He clearly cares that everyone understands before moving on to the next topic. All the assignments so far are fairly straightforward, and he provides helpful comments to get us startedGoated CS prof.

I wasn't sure how'll I do in this class but so far bc of this prof ,this class seems very doable and if you start your assignments early then you are defn going to get an A. JUST DONT PROCRASTINATE! and he's one of the best prof. !

He slows down and answers all questions people have during lectures, even if they were already answered. For assignments, he provides half of the code and explains what we need to do for the rest. The class is low stress: weekly quizzes with multiple attempts, and six programming assignments with weeks to complete, that's it. No exams or anything.

Professor Huang is outstanding. Zoom lectures are great. He spends a lot of time teaching by demonstration. He introduces topics gently, thoroughly, thoughtfully and digestibly. Prof Huang takes the time to understand EVERY question asked and delivers a beautiful answer. Challenging assignment at the right difficulty. Recommended
CS211 (computer architecture) with Huang has been absolutely everything I could have wanted in a course. He teaches clearly, answers questions, and makes good assignments with good instructions.

Prof Huang is really amazing. He takes time during lectures to answer through questions, works through similar code as the projects assigned, and is very considerate in giving extensions or assistance on assignments. I would definitely recommend taking him for comp arch!

Prof Huang is amazing. I literally could not have asked for a better professor in comp arch. He gave us extra time to work on projects, worked through similar concepts during class time, and was extremely helpful during lectures. I would recommend everyone to definitely take this course with him.

This guy is a legend. Great lectures. Projects are well made and help is always accessible. He is always open to questions in lecture and seeks to help whenever he can. I would 100% recommend taking Professor Huang!

You have three weeks to do the projects, with half the provided code given in the package, and the other half given in lecture, and an extension, so you should be okay as long as you don't procrastinate terribly until the day it is due - February, 15, 2021, for example. If you email him your questions, or post on piazza, he would gladly help.

(Remote class) If you do the projects and pay some attention you'll do fine. You have two tries on quizzes which are open notes and he lets you copy and paste the code into ilab. He gives very detailed instructions on projects and also more than enough time to complete them. He gives a lot of guidance about the project during lectures as well.

He is the type of professor that will ruin your mood for the entire semester, doesn't care about how you learn only cover the Linux system for 1 lecture and make us jump from our mac or windows system to the totally new system, and give us assignments that require Linux of terrible difficulty. If you are not familiar with C and Linux DONT TAKE HIM!

This class was challenging for a Python beginner. I suggest practicing Python beforehand, as the pace can be fast. While some units are easier, the workload is heavy for a 100-level course, with assignments taking up to 1.5 hours. Fran Tress is very kind and supportive, but participation is heavily emphasized.
Nice teacher and hated for no reason. Pay attention and study and the class is very easy. Got As on all exams.
Very nice teacher. Hated for no reason. I found the class to be very easy but this could be because I had prior knowledge.
Good luck. She's the worst you'll ever have.

She pushes participation heavily and also chases you down to do group things, a bit boring and dull in lectures with liberal opinions and very direct agendas. Not a bad professor just a bit boring, wasn't interested in sticking it out especially not for CS110.

Lectures were very monotoned. The slides tended to dump information without restraint. She was a good lecturer although she was a bit boring. Recitations also were behind on lecture topics so there was an uneven pace. If you want to do well, self-studying is the way to go. The topics of the class go at a really fast rate after the first few weeks.
Just run. Take Centeno if you can.
Teaches the topics well but lectures can get a bit boring at times. But in general very helpful

CS is not easy. But Trees is nice, simple and direct. You can tell she knows what she's talking about in lecture. Available during office hours. Never met her in person, but is definitely a solid professor. STRONGLY recommend. You'll understand the concepts but grade can plummet just based on homework though so beware. Piazza is your best friend.

I took Comp Apps, it was the easiest class ever. The class, in general, is very easy no matter what professor you take. Trees lectures are very clear compared to the other professors though. Overall, a very easy class, and literally you can get 20 points worth of extra credit.

She's a fine prof, but I personally don't really like her teaching style (I used Centeno's LOs and lecture recordings outside of class). Attendance isn't mandatory if you're taking in synchronously, and honestly she wastes a lot of synchronous class time tending to questions and concerns that should just be answered through email or office hours.

CS170 is a pretty easy class that covers HTML, Javascript, and Excel. The programming is not too bad and TAs are generally helpful. The class has lots of EC opportunities, weekly quizzes, weekly HWS, 2 midterms and a cumulative final. Stay on top of the work and a B is definitely manageable.

As someone who didnt code before cs111, Professor Trees is a good professor. She creates a learning environment in which you feel comfortable in asking questions, even in a big lecture hall. The topics in CS111 arent the easiest if you haven't done java before but they are definitely manageable if you work for your grade.

I had Trees for CS111 and she was great! She was very friendly and had a clear teaching style during class. She makes sure that everyone has their questions answers and is easily accessible outside of class. Having previous programming knowledge really makes the course easier, but Trees does her best to let everyone succeed in the course.

As someone with zero Java experience before taking CS111, I struggled heavily with the material. Professor Trees is very nice in person, but she would speed through the lectures while not writing a lot of code on the board. Fast talker and it was hard to keep up. She did however upload her code on Sakai, which I did find helpful for assistance.

As a comp sci major who knows nothing about CS, I took this class to learn a lil something before diving straight into CS111, etc. This class taught me so many useful things and even though it was SO much work, this class was super useful--at least for my major. But If I weren't going into CS, I'd be pissed for taking such a workload heavy class.

Her class teaches quicker and more advanced than the other teachers which could be a good or bad thing. I took AP Java in high school so I had prior knowledge which made this class easy for me even though I got a 3 on the exam. Tjang is a much slower teacher. Both teachers explain the material well but it is personal preference for the pace.

This is not an easy A. It requires a lot of work. Assignments weekly that take about 2 hours to do. Don't bother going to lectures, the recitations are most of your grade. Not too hard but not as easy as you think.
The class was so easy

this class is crazy. wasted so much time on 100 level class because the exams are soo much harder than what you learn in class or recitation & I spent so much time outside of  this class because the prof and ta are so vague at teaching. if do not have to take this class, DONT!

Must show up to recitation. Test are very hard and have to get As on all assignments-go to office hours they will help. Never worked so hard for an 100 level class do not take lightly, but it is doable just have to study a lot.

If you wanna say cs110 is a fairly easy A course, not accurate. This course still requires a great deal of practice. I did 81/85 on exam 1 because these concepts are easy, and 60/85 on exam 2 regarding to Scratch, which is a tough part of the course. U must do the homework very cautiously, and ask you TA for questions. Finally 113/130 in final
Soooo easy!

Nice professor. Didn't go to many lectures but when I did I always enjoyed myself. She engages the class in her lessons, and ties the curriculum into your everyday life to make it simpler. Very easy class overall.

By far the easiest class I have ever taken. TA was horrible, but the fact that I still did well exemplifies the easiness of the course. If you are attempting to fulfill a core requirement take this course. So easy. No textbook, just a collection of web readings that you dont really need to read.
Assignments every week, Recitation & lecture are two completely different classes. Most of the grade comes from recitation - so ace that and you will be okay.

RIDICULOUSLY EASY CLASS the main program you use in class is scratch which is pretty fun. Prof Trees is super nice and helpful and clearly likes what she does. There's assignments every week but they're not hard exams are middle school level of difficulty finished with a score >100

Lecture is pointless as you don't learn anything. Lecture notes are posted. You definitely MUST go to recitation because that is where you will actually learn. If you do not go to recitation you will fail.
Very easy to get A if you work hard. Assignments are every week. Lots of work but not tough. TA's are extremely helpful.

Super easy class. Impossible not to get an A if you do all the homeworks. Gives like 20 points extra credit and the assignments are pretty easy. Don't have to go to lecture, but prof Trees to pretty helpful if you're struggling

Beginning material pretty straightforward, Scratch programming a little harder. 3 exams, weekly projects and sometimes 5 question online quizzes. Trees is a nice lady but TA is who mostly helps you. Taking class now so don't know what third exam is on but make sure you don't fall behind on Scratch programming. No textbook.
I'm in this class right now and she seems pretty good. Nothing too intense yet, however she goes they slides quickly.
Topics were hard to understand at first but if you put in the work you will understand them.

I had no CS experience and if you're the same, do not take Trees. She doesn't explain concepts and just jumps into coding and gets annoyed at questions tbh. I started going to Amiel's lectures on top of Trees to understand concepts. I spent too much time on this class, which affected my other courses, just pls go to Centeno or Amiel I BEG!

Having Professor Trees as a freshman (which most of us were in my CS110 class) was challenging. If you follow along with the course material, follow rubrics, and complete all study guides, you will succeed in this class. Her TAs were the worst and inconsistent, with each section having a hard time coordinating with each other.
Really bad at teaching, speak fast, type fast, explain vauge. DONOT CHOOSE.

Honestly I did have previous java experience from high school, but this professor was really nice and helpful. A few other people I knew who did not have any java experience before learned it well from her lectures. Also whatever comp sci professor you get for CS111 does not really matter much because you will get the same assignments and exams.
She's very chill and pretty good at explaining concepts. I would go to office hours and she would help me out and be very nice. Chill class, just don't fall behind
She is very diifficult.
Doesn't explain the concepts properly and if you are a beginner don't take her.

She goes way too fast, seldom goes in depth regarding the rationale behind practice problem solutions, and sometimes calls upon concepts that haven't been introduced. For an intro class that is supposed to be for students with little to no coding experience, all this creates an environment in lecture that can be confusing and stressful.
she goofy fr

I would not recommend Trees for someone without coding experience. The class starts slow and then throws you into harder material. I often found myself going to Centeno's lecture videos on the CS website to actually learn the material before exams. Trees is not bad, but certainly not the best. Assignments can be hard and take a while to do.

Professor Trees is so dry in her lectures and gets frustrated easily when lots of students ask many questions. Sometimes she ends the zoom call when a student is in the middle of asking a question and pretends as if she cant hear them. Her grading scale was not bad, but expect her not to curve the grades. She takes ages to respond to your emails.

I was new to coding when I started taking Intro to CS with Trees, so I had no prior coding experience before taking this course. Although Trees is a bit monotone, she does explain the concepts well and I recommend taking it with any professor like Trees who offers help. This class is doable and helps a lot especially for a beginner.

She is so monotone and goes extremely fast. She will answer your questions though, which is good. But it's so hard to actually learn because of her teaching style. Luckily, CS111 is an easy class and you can pretty much watch any of the professors. I had to switch over to watching Centeno's videos because Trees just wasn't cutting it for me.

Professor Trees is a great teacher. However, the class can get difficult so make sure to catch up on the lectures and don't fall behind. There are many assignments where you can earn most of your points if you did not do so well on the exams. Overall, she is an amazing teacher who is ready to help her students.

Prof Trees is a great lecturer and really cares about her students. She did a good job explaining the material. CS111 is difficult for beginners so make sure you put the work in and practice otherwise assignments and exams are hard. Overall, a great class and teaches you good problem-solving skills.
A very knowledgeable and great teacher for computer science. Will answers questions and is helpful.

Monotonous lectures, but he's down-to-earth and accessible. Homeworks are very difficult, so be sure to do well on them or else you won't pass. Tests are also difficult but they are mainly conceptual, trivia-type questions with little-no coding. Also, the curve is negligible, so don't rely on it and do the best you can.
I did not do well on exams and only passed because of projects. So, try your best at every project and also do well on exams.

poor teaching skills, cannot keep students engaged in lecture, and focuses on teaching info that is irrelevant on exams, HW, and in careers. review session before exam is helpful tho. recitations were very disorganized; none of my classmates attended. final was very fair & reasonable.

david menendez is a RACIST. on the day of the final he said 'ik its tight in here hopefully you all showered' excuse me???? MIND you this is the most indian dense state and the major is primarily south asains. he also only gave us review q's the day before and they had multiple errors that were very misleading (watch out for 4 b-e)!!!!

David Menendez is a RACIST. he said "ik its tight in here, hopefully you all showered" now MIND YOU this is the most indian dense state, and the subject is statistically indian majoritied (computer science). I thought this was unprofessional. he posted the review questions for the final a day before, contains wrong answers (watch out for 4b-e)!!!!!

I have had Menendez for two classes now, and I can confidently say that you need to stay focused on the assignments. The assignments are very important, and doing badly on them means you will not pass. The tests are not particularly difficult and more closely resemble trivia exams than coding exams, as they are filled with random questions.
Simply underrated. If you can't read your assignment requirements stop complaining.

Menendez is very dry and pretty by the books, but he is very knowledgeable about computer architecture and went through examples multiple times for students who were confused. His class is hard and the projects MUST be started early if you want a good grade on them, but its doable and manageable. Tests are not heavy on coding, more regular problems

There are 3-5 projects and the rest of the grade is exams. Exams are very hard. Projects are very hard to do right, and perfection is pretty much required to pass the class. Hard cutoffs, had to retake class for a 69.5%. Unhelpful lectures. Unhelpful Canvas. No updates on Canvas, and VERY slow grading.

The class is not as bad as Algos, but it's not great, especially that one project. Most people get to phase 3 or 6 of it, but I finished, and it took ALL my time for two full weeks. Exams are hard, but doable. Projects are hard, some not doable. This professor's lectures are not very helpful. And speaking to him outside of class also isn't helpful.

made me hate coding in C, made me hate everything computer architecture. please save yourself and don't take him if you're someone who's dependent on a teacher to pass a class. i passed but i fought for my life to

Prof. Menendez is a very good teacher; his explanations of C and low-level architecture are thorough, cohesive and delivered in perfect English!!! (rare for Rutgers). The midterm and final exams include code-on-paper, so you'll need to put in real effort to do well, but his class is absolutely worth it.

The lectures were dry, but luckily everything gets posted online so you can just skip pretty comfortably. Recitation optional as well. 50% projects 50% midterm/final. Absolutely 0 respect for students' time. Assigned projects without giving enough time on occasion. Class averages were very high with fair exams though, so overall the A is free.

Insanely disorganized class. Lectures weren't helpful at all and felt like a fun facts session more than an actual lecture (coming from someone that listened and took notes every class.) Projects and exams required self study from start to finish but were doable. Did not give enough time for the projects for the amount of work required in them.

Great teacher in a difficult, weed-out course.

I did not go to class much but can say that it's just a very challenging course.

He's objectively a good teacher and a very nice person.
It was alright, does not deserve all the hate. They were very nice when grading the projects and exams, the averages for the class were very high for every single thing.

I took this class knowing people complain about the way Menny organizes his courses. Unsurprisingly, my assignment grades came out 2 days before finals. However, he's a great professor-- definitely knows his stuff. GO TO LECTURES and ask questions. Exam questions seemed fair difficulty wise, but they were all open-ended.
Lectures aren't very useful, big curve at the end of the class. Grades very slow, doesn't post any material to prepare for exams.

I don't understand the criticism of his attitude, because he actually answers all questions with patience and is actually quite nice. The only problem is his lectures consisted of him talking and typing sentences into a text document, which was not really an effective way of learning. The assignments and exams were fair in difficulty.
Literally just infodumps into a text file and doesn't to emails pls avoid if u can

Very smart guy. That being said, he assumes that his students are as smart as he is. His projects and tests are difficult. He's not really available outside of class, so make sure you ask him during lecture. Overall, decent professor. Just keep up with him and ask worthwhile questions.

My only criticism is that he rarely responds to emails. His exams are fairly straightforward, and he even lets you bring a cheat sheet into the exam. The projects are going to take time, but are fair. I took him for both CS211 and 212 and got an A both times. VERY generous curve at the end of the class

It's not an easy A but it's not super hard. The curve usually helps people. If you need to reach him you have to go to office hours. You should always check your midterms because graders made a lot of mistakes. Grades take a little while to come back. He's kinda sassy to some people, he was nice to me tho.

Get a good partner with this class. Professor writes all his notes in .txt files making self study very easy. Exams are very lenient in terms of grading and there is a curve at the end of the class. Fall 2024, the semester I took the class, had very high medians (90 on projects, 70 on exams) compared to other semesters. Responsive to questions.

he answers questions well, he's definitely knowledgeable. i stopped attending lectures after a while because it's just him writing on a text file which he posts after class. projects were interesting and clearly described, a little bit challenging. make sure you choose a good partner --  i had to do all our work myself.

There was a generous curve at the end, however, the class was pretty difficult. The exams were tough and the TAs graded pretty harshly. The beginning of the semester was disorganized because there weren't any TAs which caused the class to move at a weird pace and we also had an assignment cut out.
Challenging class, but the projects are interesting. Lectures can be hit-or-miss, so Unstuck AI was a lifesaver for study prep. Grading is disorganized, but the content is useful for industry.

Not a bad professor, but the lectures can be extremely boring.  Recitations were useless, and half the time, the TA didn't even attend. Programming assignments were fair, and the exams might seem straightforward, but the TAs can be harsh on grading. However, he was very generous on the curve. As long as you know all the topics, you should be fine.

Gave a huge curve at the end of the class which wasn't even needed but he is just too nice I guess. Lectures can be a bit dry sometimes but he is very knowledgeable and will answer questions if you ask him during lecture or office hours. Spends time in lecture going over exam material before exams, and project material when projects are released.

He's a chill dude. Study his slides in detail and you will do just fine in his class. He's a bit monotonous but is very knowledgeable. He's organized but grading for the assignments was slow. More than enough time for the assignments and he gives notice of the midterm pretty early. Not a lot of practice material for the final but it wasn't too bad.

Dry lectures, so dry that it was hard to attend lecture. Uploads exact notes from class on canvas so lecture attendance isn't neccessary. Midterm 25% Final 25% Projects 50%. Study for the exams because one bad grade will put an A out of reach. TAs slow for grading as always with menny's classes because he takes too long to give them the rubric.

Grades are split 50/50 between exams and C-based projects. The exams match the lecture material well, and the slides are all on Canvas. Projects are pretty doable with plenty of time to finish, and the grading cutoffs are lenient. The content can be interesting and is definitely important for understanding core CS concepts.

Lectures consist of him talking about topics and writing everything down in a text file which he uploaded to canvas after every class. Three projects that are all manageable by yourself but you can work with a partner. Easy midterm and final each worth 25 percent of the final grade could bring one page of one sided notes.

Lecture was straightforward and he does a good job explaining the concepts. He'll answer questions in  class but does get annoyed if your question is off topic. He has 2-hour office hours twice a week but he doesn't really respond to emails. The exams were fair based on the topics he taught. Any disorganization seemed to be from his TAs and not him
I had the worst experience of my Rutgers career in this class. He is visibly annoyed at questions during lecture. Do NOT expect any type of study guides for the tests worth 50 percent of your grade.

Horrible! He literally just reads off slides. Even if go to class it is hard to understand what he is teaching. If you try to look at the slides in your own time, you won't even understand most of it. I learned more from Youtube that I did from him. Avoid him and take anyone else!

I love the way he teaches, he just infodumps everything he knows into a txt file while narrating his thoughts, though I realize that this is a minority opinion. There were only 3 projects and 2 tests that decided the final grade which isn't ideal, but other than the amount of work needed to complete the projects this class has been a lot of fun.

Compared to past reviews, he's lightened up this semester. Yes, his lectures can be a bit monotonous and may not always make sense. But he's a lot more relaxed, funny at times, and answers questions adequately without rudeness. Projects aren't too crazy, and grades come out at a reasonable time. Midterm also had material that was taught in class.

People generally hate on Professor Menendez, I disagree with that assumption. While he can lack empathy at times, he teaches well. If you just pay attention, read, take notes, reference old exams that are online, you'll be fine. 

I really enjoyed taking Systems Programming. I learned a lot from the lectures and projects.

Never answers emails, exam material rarely matches up with lectures, and grading scheme on projects is ridiculous, considering there's no rubric and no test cases. Not a single grade was posted till the week of finals and he blamed his TAs, but this seems to be a recurring theme with him. Absolutely disorganized, don't take anything with him.

Class overall was alright. Projects were interesting and intensive. Grading was slow and awful. Content was pretty cool and seems very useful for industry. Exams were fair. I never found Menny's lectures to be effective so I never went. Good class to take to hone your programming skills and craft

Super easy course if you're good with programming/Linux. It's mainly project-based and you can have a partner but it's honestly easy enough to solo it. Very late/disorganized grading though. Professor clearly knows a lot about low-level programming so if you're into that then his lectures are interesting, but he doesn't take attendance or anything

No grades are posted till a week before the final. I don't know how this is even allowed. The only reason I got an A was because I bet the graders don't even grade and just threw out random numbers and I got lucky. Absolutely 0 information on any of our project grades couldn't even work with feedback.
Be ready to learn by yourself He acts like you already know the stuff he is teaching, Boring lecturer!! Haven't got any grades of project one week before final!! Don't take CS214 with him!!

Basically, you're on your own in this class. He goes over the few basic stuff covered in the chapter but you would need to study and learn yourself for the homeworks, midterms, and final! He doesn't go over the homework or the midterm review or even a final review! Take the class if you like teaching yourself the material!

The professor's lectures were adequate, but the midterm exam content did not align with the lecture material. Additionally, no grades were released throughout the semester, including during the reading days and after regular classes concluded. This made it challenging to gauge progress and prepare adequately.

week away from finals, not a single grade in,

 lectures = bad, goes very fast, acts like you should know what he's talking,

 gets annoyed when you ask him dumb questions,

 All assignments must be done with a partner, assignment details are not very clear, projects are extremely long/time consuming,

 He has a friendly demeanor though

Menny's 214 is not for the faint of heart, but there is something satisfying about learning such an expansive curriculum. I learned more in this class than 111, 112, and 210 combined, but that comes at a cost--namely, the projects are brutal, but you will appreciate how much they teach you. Four stars bc no grades two weeks from the end of sem.

Treat this as a 3.5 rating. Very friendly, talks like a CS student, and contrary to some reviews here, he is NOT condescending when people ask questions. He is just direct (uses the word "no"). Unfortunately, disorganized. Networking assignment got cancelled since we were low on time (he got COVID; not his fault but not handled in the best way).

Avoid him if possible. His lectures are good but boring, as he just types into a text editor. He's rude when asked questions. The class is very disorganized, different TAs grade differently and they don't provide feedback. There were only 3 assignments and 2 exams, so there's no room for error. I still learned a lot, and there's a good curve.

He's a friendly dude and is very passionate about CS. Also very friendly in office hours. I know his lecture style is unpopular but I find how he teaches (typing in a text editor) easier to follow than slides. However, assignments are not very well defined and their autograders sometimes do not work, leading to stressful regrades. Exams are okay.

His projects are extremely tedious and take forever to do. On their own it could be manageable but we have 3 other classes we are also studying for at the same time. Lecture slides are poorly worded, no practice problems for tests, and grades take forever. Projects are also confusingly written at times. He said the curve is good though.

Can't believe Rutgers lets this continue. Class was a disorganized mess. Lectures slides are useless on their own. Must attends to grasp his material. I love CS topics but this class was a chore to get through. No partial credit. Do not take.

People said he is a douche when people ask questions but honestly he didn't seem to be like that for me. Assignments are not bad but are VERY LONG. The exams themselves aren't too bad either but he provides 0 practice questions or exams so you're basically just sifting through hundreds of slides for information unfortunately.

Had Menendez for Comp Arch, Prin Prog, and Systems. The worst thing about this teacher is that he never posts practice problems for his midterms and finals. Studying for them involves going through a laundry list of red herrings. Sometimes he's also disorganized with assignments, too. He has a good curve, though.

He is very smart and experienced, so unfortunately he thinks things are easier than they are on exams and assignments. He bites if you ask trivial questions, but he seems to have mellowed out over the years. Generous curve.

I had a bad experience taking this class, not because Prof. Menendez taught poorly or because he didn't present the material in an effective manner. I learned a lot in this course. The reason I say I had a bad experience is because when it came to grading (whether that be projects or exams), everything fell apart. Other reviews expand on this.

Even though this class was a disaster the curve he gives out make sure that nobody fails. The whole semester consisted of 3 projects 1 midterm and 1 final. I wouldn't be surprised if someone get a 20 on the last project as it is the hardest and the class avg in project 2 and 3 are usually astonishingly shitty.

Menny's 214 class is a total shitshow. Spring 23, he changed the last two assignments with poorly written instructions. In addition to that, he has little to no communication with his TAs, who grade very harshly in assignments, and sometimes do the opposite of what Menny expects you to do. Curve was 77 -> A, 64.5 -> B+, 55.5 -> B, 30->C, 17->D.

This course is tough, you really need to understand what is being taught throughout the lecture. understand the codes he uploads. Exams are pretty straightforward and easy. Start the projects(hard) when they are released, you might face some hardship, so you need all the time given to complete it. He is always behind on grading & dates are TBA.

This class was an absolute disaster. 3 insanely difficult programming projects as well as a midterm and final. An auto-grader is used and you get no test cases. TAs took weeks to months to grade projects. Exams were fair. Menendez was beyond disorganized for this course and it essentially set you up for failure in return. Get ready to read to pass

His lectures are not that good. The writeups are super vague so it takes a lot of clarification to understand what he actually expects. His grading on the projects is really harsh which causes the class median and average to be quite low. Hes rude when asked questions sometimes in lecture. Overall just a nightmare. Really good curve though.

While he was decent for Comp Arch, he ended up being a complete mess for Systems Programming. Projects take forever to get graded, and even when they ARE graded, they often have to be regraded because of errors in the autograder that give the class 20% averages on assignments. To his credit, i will say his exams were fair, and he curves heavily.

This class is a mess!!

He is a decent teacher but horrible at managing the course. Grading is at the mercy of the TAs and usually takes a month for them to grade a project. The final grade was split between 3 projects and two exams (final and midterm). The projects were way too hard for the material being taught in the class.
disorganized as hell

I took this class because I heard from many people that its a "must-take" for a CS major. While I learned a lot, this class is truly a mess. Its mental warfare with the projects given. Menendez doesn't care about whether we are actually prepared for the projects. TAs grade slow and extremely harshly. Skip this class with Menendez for your sanity.

The projects are like solving some P=NP bullshit. Hard as hell, inconveniently placed (one of the projects had a majority of the work time during spring break.) Not only that, while he expects us to work hard during breaks, he takes the entire semester to grade anything. It's the end of the sem and he JUST finished grading pa2. Hope curve is good.
If you go to lectures and do the projects it is an easy A. CS314 covers a lot of material but he explains it well. There was plenty of extra credit opportunities and a heavy curve

Cutoffs as follows: A = 85, B+ = 76, B = 62, C+ = 53, C = 44 (determined by class average). He is smart and his lectures are interesting, but the C projects are ridiculously hard compared to what is learned in class. Auto grader used, you get 1/2 of test cases. You'll have to study hard for exams too. Nice during office hours, not so much in class.

I don't understand why Menendez gets so many bad reviews. Lectures were interesting and Menendez streams and records them for people who can't make it to class. Menendez was always welcoming of questions, even if it is a repeat question. He also let us redo one assignment and even submit it in January when the semester ended on December 23.
He knows what he's talking about. He gets annoyed at repeatedly unnecessary questions(rightfully so). Very generous curve. Assignments take lots of time so start early!

Gives all the material needed in lecture slides, and lecture slides tend to be better than other professors that I've had at Rutgers. Exam was information that was taught on slides. He talks a little slow and somewhat monotone though, so it might be a little hard to pay attention for the full 1hr 20min.

Avoid if you can. He rarely responds to emails which is extremely frustrating. He does not provide practice exams or questions so you work extra hard trying to figure out which questions might be on the test. Lectures are not engaging. Lecture slides are poorly written and need to be deciphered. Curve is generous, though.

Menendez is overall an okay teacher. He gets somewhat annoyed when people ask trivial questions. The assignments are hard (especially PA4), and there is little time to cover them. However, he is very generous with the curve (you needed a 19/100 or less to fail his class).

In lecture he doesn't explain concepts well and he gets annoyed easily by questions (although sometimes they were unnecessary questions). The exams were difficult, although the assignments were not bad. also gave us a generous curve and recorded his lectures which was nice.
lectures are not that good and he sometimes gets passive aggressive at questions. Assignments are not that bad though
He's pretty average. The worst part about him is that he doesn't give practice exams/practice problems, so you'll be going into exams pretty blind.

Professor Menendez is a decent option for Comp Arch. I thought his lectures were fine (he even still recorded them this semester), but he sometimes fell behind other sections of his class and had to rush through some material. His programming assignments were doable and he gave the option to redo one of them to replace your grade. Exams felt fair.

But for cs214, that becomes a disaster.  yes, all the people in his class, receive their grades of projects  (there are 4 projects), midterms, finals at the day before the deadline for lecturers to submit their student grades. Huge curve applied. My roommate got a 45 out of 100 for total grade, but still got B. I got 70 % and is already A.

In spring 2022, I took menny's cs211 and cs214 at the mean time. He is all over the place. The disorganize of the whole course is second only to that of Fransisco. I think menny's lecture will soon become a meme like Franny's. cs211 has a autograder, so I receive my coding grade quite soon.

I took him spring of 2022, so the first few weeks of class were virtual. This jumbled up his schedule, so we had to rush through the material in the final weeks of class. His projects are pretty straightforward, but the tests do occasionally throw you in for a loop (such as the C questions). There's also a curve, which is nice.

He's smart, the content of his lectures are interesting. Gave extensions for most projects. Recorded his lectures which was really nice. However, he cannot teach effectively. Wrote mostly in a text editor. Went really fast and just expects you to know / figure it out for yourself. I'd send hours researching things he didn't go over properly.
Very rude for no reason... assignments took a long time to complete but were doable. If there is someone else teaching this course, go with them.
He is overall a good professor. He has a very big curve. I enjoyed his class but he does not respond to his emails. His class is overall easy if you study normally.

Menendez was late in grading projects by weeks, projects take weekends to accomplish (12-25 hours of work). Generally unorganized and typically rude/dismissive to students who asked (albeit unnecessary) questions during lecture. I gave him the benefit of the doubt and registered for cs214 the next semester - this was a mistake.
avoid at all costs

He's really smart. He really knows his material and has a lot of low level knowledge to offer; that was interesting. BUT, he's not a good professor. Waited 5 weeks for recitations to start. First assignment right during midterms. Super rude and rejected the entire class who was asking for an extension. The way he explains things is AWFUL.

Here's the thing - Menedez knows what he's doing, but his lack of organization and occasional rudeness definitely ruins his quality of teaching. If you're taking CS211, start assignments early, read the textbook, and have a good foundation going with the first 3 (or 2) assignments, which are doable. GET ILABS SET UP ASAP!

By far the worst CS professor I have had. The lectures are very boring. He sometimes doesn't respond to emails. He gets agitated when you ask him to repeat something. Project write-ups are okay. He was very disorganized, didn't have a TA for like 2 months. Projects take up time so definitely start early.

Worst CS prof. Had him online. Lectures are boring, just goes over his slides. 80% students skipped class to complete his difficult C projects. Never replies to emails. Really disorganized course. Took him 5 weeks to set up recitations (my TA was useless). WIll not recommend him. Class is curved. Hasn't even released final grades yet.

The worst part was the grading schema coupled with the fact that the final grade was so heavily weighted on so few quizzes (3 counted for 35%). In addition to this, the class focuses way too much on Haskell specifically, instead of going beyond Haskell and getting to the principles, he will quiz you on obscure Haskell syntax related problems.

Menendez knows his stuff but can be harsh with students. If you're taking his 211 course, start your programming assignments early, because you cannot rush them. They take about a week of dedicated attention to finish.
