The lecture is dry and boring, the professor likes to see his student fail the class and wish them to retake it again with him for next semester. The professor is mean and rude to students; the project was ok but the due date was too short. Overall, I would not recommend taking it with him.

This professor is not good don't take him, trust me. You expect to know C a lot of them at the beginning and then quiz base on the lecture stuff and hard. At the same time he doesn't answer the question when student asking about. He try to talk by himself. Project is heavy and no extend. The bomb website crash and give no time for us.

The professors lecture makes it difficult to understand what he wants to teach you. Although the homework is not difficult, the quiz is difficult and does not have much to do with the content of the lecture.

His lectures are extremely dry and not helpful. He did not assign TAs/LAs until like mid OCTOBER. This semester, a lot of us had troubles with downloading assignments/being connected to the ilab machines, but he was not of any help; he "extends" deadlines by extending the late submission late period. Highly DO NOT recommend.

I took it during Spring 2021. Quizzes were really easy if you watch and pay attention to his lectures, projects are standard for what other professors give in this class, final had the same format and structure as his exams. Would highly recommend because his class was a joke, but idk how that's gonna change with everything back in person again.

This class was the worst. Teacher did not grade projects for months and then blamed TAs for it. Stay away from him. Exam was really hard, there was a lot code driven questions on exam. Little to no communication when asked about updates by email. He is very unorganized.

Had the most disorganized class I've ever seen yet somehow at the same time has the self righteousness to be incredibly rude. Not a good lecturer, goes off on tangents too many times, and projects took literal months to grade (though that was actually the TA's fault but he never effectively communicated with them)

I've had Menendez for 112, 211, and now 214. This class was the most disorganized class Ive ever taken, in large part due to his communication with the TAs (not solely his fault). We had 3 projects & he'd spend entire lectures teaching us the necessary material to do them well after they were assigned. I don't recommend Menny unless nothing better
The course is not well organized. Sometimes he would just wind up off the topics he was intended to cover. Overall, he did his best
This class is kinda challenging for incoming CS students, but it is really many stuffs to learn. Not an easy class, but worth it.

Menendez is super knowledgeable; although comp arch material is pretty dry, he teaches it effectively and has interesting answers to good questions. He does get annoyed fairly easily when people ask him something he's already answered, so try to actually pay attention. He is very helpful if it's clear you're putting in your best effort.

While the lecture content was interesting, his teaching style was much less so, and I struggled to not zone out in this class. The project pacing was at first fine, but way too intensive later on. The final was a joke which had some topics only the other teacher had covered. (no communication between profs?) HWs and some projects had EC at least.

While I didn't appreciate some things like typos in the assignment write ups nor the prof's propensity to digress, I think the class was worth taking and useful for building skills and competencies related to lower level programming. The final was poorly done, but overall I'd generally recommend for people interested in the course's topics.
Good lecturer, easy assignments and quizzes. Final exam was annoying but doable (all MC, but wording of the questions made things confusing). Learned a lot.

Prof Menendez's lectures were really dull for CS214. He always goes on Tangents. If you want to learn something and actually have a professor that makes you interested in the material, attend Prof Francisco's lectures. I regret signing up for Prof Menendez's class.
He's really helpful and incredibly accomodating during online class. I really don't understand why his score is so low, he's a little sassy sometimes but he's incredibly intelligent.

The projects are too hard, especially the assembly one. Many of the codes are out of the bound of course without a instruction. The thing that surprises me is, I can't believe that over than a half of students get 100% on that hard one.

To my surprise, Professor Menendez was nothing like the negative reviews on here. Computer Architecture isn't an easy class. He provides a lot of material to perform good in the class, and carefully explains each concept. However, a lot of outside research and studying is crucial to succeed (as in any class). Exams are very fair, not too difficult.
Good lecturer, helpful on Piazza. Projects are a bit time consuming, but the class was overall enjoyable.
Seems to have turned the class around. He responds quickly on piazza and answers all questions during lectures. Has iClicker quizzes in class so you have to attend. Interesting class!

I was expecting horrible things because of his reputation, however I found the experience to be the opposite. Maybe he's changed or people exaggerated. He answered every question on piazza on time, gave us extra credit, made the last project optional and was very structured. The exams were extremely fair, i will say tho the lectures were a bit dry.
Study by yourself Useless lecture disorganized

Menendez does exactly what he's supposed to. His lectures are informative and he does a relatively good job of explaining the material. He does tend to be a little abrasive at times, but only if you ask some stupid question. Overall, he's a fun professor to have and both cs112 and cs211 have been fine.

Simply put, he's the reason I switched out of CS and went to Math. Maybe I found him worse than he actually is since CS isn't my strong suit but this man was the reason I was having midlife crises at age 19. He's a reality check and made me realize that I should do what im good at but he did so by not providing a fair amount of resources to pass.

LITERALLY THE WORST EVER PROFESSOR. EXAMS ARE OUT OF THE WORLD. NEVER REPLIES TO EMAILS. HIS OWN EXAM TAKES HIM 4 DAYS TO ANSWER AND EXPECTS HIS STUDENTS TO ANSWER THEM IN 4 MINS. WHEN IT DOESN'T WORK HE SAYS SORRY THIS SHOULDN'T HAVE BEEN ON THE TEST AND WHAT IS WORSE IS HE WON'T GIVE BONUS POINTS TO CORRECT HIS MISTAKE. DO NOT TAKE HIM PERIOD!!!!

Prof Menendez is a fine cs professor. The midterm exam is really hard, and the average is below 50%(But the final is pretty easy so everyone can get a chance to improve their grade by final exam). He is good at explaining concept but the slides are a little bit boring when you review by yourself. The assignment is not so difficult but time-consuming
It is the best professor in Rutgers CS department

He literally made me contemplate my major. Rude and talks down to people. Projects are insanely hard, it's a 200-level course but I honestly feel like the projects are 400 level difficulty. My advice going in: learn C as much as you can before the semester starts, and start going to church to pray to God you don't destroy your GPA

You either understand the lectures right away or do not. He is excellent at explaining concepts in office hours. Projects are fine as long as you view the examples in the check code. You can expect the exams to feature similar problems to assignments and projects. However, the exams are as difficult as Math 3xx Honors Classes, so be prepared.
If you ever have the idea of choosing CS as your major, please avoid his classes. You will graduate without any hassle if you don't take his classes. That's all I gotta say.

He's not a bad person however he is very bad at explaining the concepts. Projects are confusing. Tests are also confusing. Hard to research the course material on your *which is what you might have to do because chances are you won't learn much in class." Not much I can say that's good about him. He's smart but jesus teaching is not for him!
bad prof

Principles of prog languages. He reads off the slides, you don't need to come to class. All you need is the slides. Assignments are very easy. Dry lectures, not sure I would recommend, or take for another class.
would take again
So bad. His lecture is useless!

I found the slides to be somewhat helpful outside of class but sometimes during lecture I couldn't grasp the concepts as he explained them. The exams were pretty difficult. Sometimes he was kind of rude. I would give him a 3 but he somehow lost the grades for the most time consuming project which didn't affect me but I still find it inexcusable.
Avoid him, try to get a better professor who isn't so disorganized with notes, homeworks, and projects. IMO he is a terrible teacher, and I learned nothing from him.

Overall, he's a good guy. Pay attention, do the homework, ask questions when confused, take advantage of office hours if needed. He wants you to learn, but there's nothing he can do if you don't speak up.

Menendez is getting a large number of dislikes here due to how he managed CS211 but he is not as bad as everyone is stating. Some of his answers and some of his statements may have been slightly harsh/arrogant at times and the tests may have been less than ideal but they were manageable. He is a decent professor, definitely not the worst.

Only cares about not being behind on lecture slides. Mocks students' questions. Skips around on questions on Piazza, even important questions, like about how many points sections of the project are. When he does answer questions, the answers are not clear enough/they mock how the questions are posed. Assigned last project in last week of classes.

He isnt the best professor but I cant say I havent learned from his lectures. He can make mistakes every now and then but will correct them. there are times where hes not very helpful and there are times where he tries his best to make sure the class understands. Hes pretty patient when students ask why or if he can do another problem.
His class isn't taught in an engaging way and we don't have enough time to do the projects.

Many of these people who has given "Awful" are most likely those that feel entitled. He presents the materials and you learn it, its college, if you want to be spoon-fed then good luck in life. Feels unapproachable during lectures with an attitude, but at Office hours hes different. I doubt many students who complain actually goes. PP are useless.
Worst lecturer I've ever had. Ended up sleeping through most lectures because of the way he teaches. Tried to stay awake but failed. If you have sleep problem would recommend.

Avoid taking him for comp arch, learned nothing from his class. I found youtube videos and recitation far more helpful. PA1 to PA3, make sure you score well in them, Pa4 and Pa5 would most likely screw you over.
Awful, do not take him. Disrespectful to his students, makes fun of them and not helpful at all. Exams are too hard and programming assignments are even harder.

Professor Menendez is a very intelligent person; however, as a professor he lacks a lot of simple things you would expect. He is very condescending and sarcastic to his students, and fails to answer questions straight-forward. He is not really understanding and has a very low amount of patience, especially to those who ask questions repeatedly.

Doesn't give extensions, when multiple people ask on multiple forums (Piazza, in class, in office hours). He's condescending when answering questions in class, makes it pretty clear to you if he doesn't like you. His exams are unreasonable and lacks any kind of empathy for you, and he blames his class's bad grades on lack of intellect of students.

Rarely answered question directly. He was sometimes condencending towards some students who asked questions. Barely ever explained any concepts all the way. He would sometimes get really sarcastic and it would be annoying.

He is a very nasty and unhelpful person. He talks down to everyone and is straight out rude when students ask questions. He is very sarcastic and does not go over material thoroughly, much less well. He also goes very quickly and reads off the powerpoints so lecture is essentially useless, besides the clicker quizzes. Try to avoid if you can.

He was very sarcastic and rude whenever people asked questions in lecture or went to him for help during office hours. He teaches important topics much too quickly, esp. topics that will be on projects. He did not give extensions despite the whole class asking. He doesnt seem to care that his students learn, or do well.

Menendez is an awful professor for 211. He has a highfalutin attitude and scoffs at students when they ask questions. He goes over material much too quickly and does not explain concepts well at all. Overall, his lectures are subpar and a waste of 1 hour 20 minutes. I would recommend not going to lectures, if not for his iClicker quizzes.

I felt that Menendez was a great professor. He gave multiple extensions when people would ask for them. He was clear in describing and explaining topics. His project guidelines were clear. The part I loved the most was that the stuff he reviewed for the tests is what was on the tests. No surprises. Would def take again.
Hard

He doesn't seem to understand how to teach 211. Often has an attitude in class, usually when answering questions. Average project grades were around 30s and 40s. My final grade was curved up about 20 points which is great for my GPA but I am now unprepared for my next class. Avoid if you actually want to learn properly.

Good lecturer. Explains things clearly and responds well to questions. If assignment descriptions are unclear, he will clarify if you ask. Covers material needed for assignments and exams well in lecture.
Great professor fair exams helpful during end of lecture or if you go to office hours. Gives extra credit on some of the programming assignments (5 programming assignments)
You will get a 30% on all the exams and this will be an A because everyone failed. Good lecturer but the class organization leaves much to be desired

This course will not be easy. Algorithms are painful to work with and trying to rack your brain on an exam to get the specific answer right with a decent chance you get a 0 on a question is painful. Luckily, Levin is all too aware of this. He's understanding, friendly, and a fantastic lecturer who makes the material easier to follow.

The homework was diabolical but taking the time to really dig into it helps a lot for the exams. Fair grading on the homework and exams. Lectures were really great, he never treated a question as stupid and would go over concepts multiple times if necessary. Very helpful during office hours too.

The class was hard, the exams were hard, but homework was worth 50% and there was a curve which made getting an A very achievable. Lectures were very good, and the challenge of the class provided an environment for real learning. Regardless of future grading structure, demonstrating that you learned a lot will earn an A. He is against using LLM's.

Exams are hit or miss: some questions were easy, others had stuff barely talked about (and I went to every class). Almost every single Canvas quiz had grading issues. Projects can be completed in a couple of hours but have confusing wording. Listen to every word he says in class because his slides are confusing. Nice guy, 87 = A this semester.

I felt like I did not learn much in his class. The slides are outdated for a class called internet technology and the exams were extremely difficult. No feedback was given for projects and he was not accessible outside of class.

underrated professor. lectures are him actually explaining topics and drawing things out rather than relying on just slides. connects everything back to the real world and challenges students to think critically. class consists of homework (8%), project (32%), midterm 1 & 2 (15% each), and final (30%). gives good resources to prepare for exam.

just atrocious. slides are incomprehensible and incomplete, recommended textbook is incoherent at best, assignments feel like they were written only using ChatGPT, and exam resources are ambiguous and confusing.

not to mention that somehow every single quiz, EVEN MCQs, have had grading issues. yes. MCQs on Canvas have had grading issues.
Extremely slow to respond, and has repeatedly graded our quizes wrong. Ive had to send a ton of emails just to get the grade I deserved.

Compared to other CS professors, Badri Nath is quite good. He provides sufficient exam preparation materials, (practice exams, homeworks), his class isn't graded by too few things, and his midterms are of very reasonable difficulty. Only complaint is he is very lackluster when it comes to replying to emails. He is a decent but not great lecturer.

This professor is pathetic and doesn't know how to teach. He doesn't explain anything and he doesn't respond to emails even during exams.Assignments are not clear and teaching style is bad. TAs don't clear the doubts and are ignorant to emails. Don't take this class in any way. Please avoid this professor.

Grades very fairly and lectures are good if a bit dry-OS is a theory-heavy class. Assignments are unclear but he clarifies well. He is friendly, passionate about CS, cares about students, and very helpful (in person, not over email). But be prepared to hear the names "Taylor Swift," "Donald Trump", or "Travis Kelce" at least 10 times per lecture.

Prof Badri Nath is good for lectures, but something I don't like is he never reply to emails even the TA also don't reply to emails so if you have any questions, your only option is ask after class or go to office hours. Curve at the end of the course base on class performance.
Above avg lecturer. Just like other cs electives, projects weight a huge percentage and graders are lenient in grading. Also contains huge curve like 60 is solid c.

This class was the most useful class I have taken in college (helped a lot in my internship)! During lectures, Professor Badri explains the concepts in depth and answers questions thoroughly. His office hours were also really helpful. I will say lectures moved fast and you have to put in the work to get the desired outcome. Highly would recommend!
Professor was not what was expected
One of the best professors in CS.  Very helpful, held long office hours, final review.   very knowledgeable in latest internet technology
Great lectures.  Explains concepts well.

Good lecturer but he is not responsive to student comments/questions at all... only checks Piazza maybe once a week, and once class was over there were tons of unanswered Piazza questions. Wording on assignments and exams can be very confusing sometimes, and even when he does answer piazza questions it's never clear what he's saying.

By far the worst professor I have ever had at Rutgers University. Has a Piazza that he rarely responded to, even during week of the exams, had so many errors on his practice exams / homework solution that made studying for this class even more confusing. Super condescending during class and overall a terrible professor.

His lectures are stale, which made me lose interest in the course quickly. The projects are interesting but then I found out he didn't even create the projects himself. Most, if not all, are from past professors of the course. That should alone tell you about his commitment to teaching. Do NOT take the course thinking OS is interesting, it's not.
Solid choice for operating systems. Teaches well. 2nd and 4th project will take a while. Exams are fair. Only problem is he doesn't respond to emails so you will need to go to office hours.

- Good professor for 416 - Very project-heavy course, - some take < 1 day to complete - others will take the full time allotted, start early - Curves final grades - Dropped 2nd midterm by popular demand - VERY BAD with communication - doesn't respond well to emails - skips his own office hours

He would annotate lecture slides & would get confusing at times. I mostly say attendance is mandatory for I def needed recitation to help me understand the course, but lecture not as mandatory. About an average to above average professor. Projects are reasonable (in python). Exams were a little rough, but the final was a freebie (maybe an accident)

Probably one of the worst professors I have ever taken. Made us take an on-campus midterm during COVID-19 and had way too many issues with online testing which he never resolved and gave everybody the grade they didnt deserve. And he is also one of the worst communicators. Dont expect a reply for your email.

I would have given him a higher rating but the sheer amount of mistakes he made and late responses to the questions during the semester got to my head. And for some reason he gets very awkward and rude once approached after lectures. I asked him if a certain numerical was going to be on the exam he said NO. It was on the exam for 20% of the grade..

You'd think the day before a university wide shutdown (due to coronavirus), exams would be cancelled, postponed, or posted online instead right? Not with Badri! Instead we all get to cram into a classroom and put our health at risk just for a grade!
Not a bad professor. He sometimes makes small jokes to lighten up the mood which is nice. His exams get very detailed so make sure to study everything in the notes!

Best CS professor you could take. Class can be somewhat challenging if you arent a CS major or don't have experience, but she is always willing to help. Just take advantage of meeting with her and asking questions. Quiz/Tests are mostly on what you learn in class and a bit of slide material. Focus on coding and things she repeats for a good grade.
Like the ratings say; she's helpful, and clear, which in turn makes the work easy (even though it does require some thinking).
I learned so much in this class.  She's super!  Very helpful.  Makes the most ambiguous stuff quite understandable.
She is the best

Really intimidating at first, but once you get to know that she won't bite your head off, she's approachable and pretty nice. Open to questions. Makes time for students. Gets programming languages confused at times, though. Overall pretty good.
Great professor! Cares if you understand the material and doesn't mind questions.
Excellent!

A great professor who clearly knows what he's talking about and is passionate about the topic. Makes things easy, throws in some humor every once in a while, and cares about you learning. Exams are graded fairly, but they are a big part of your grade. The only real downside is the 3-hour 7:30-10:30 PM lecture, but it's worth it.

The only bad part of this class was the 3-hour lecture that goes until 10:30 (and occasionally past that). PK structures this class in a way that if you just go to class and turn in your assignments it's impossible to fail. He has a dry sense of humor but one that I personally enjoyed. Projects were fun and the final was optional. Great experience

He was honestly the best professor I had at Rutgers. Very easy to understand, can be somewhat boring, but thats more the material. Participation quizes each class, easy. the only downside, lectures 3 hours long and no break and late at night. He uses 2 grading scales for the final grade and give you the higher grade, so super generous.

Monotone non-stop 3-hour-long lectures with zero interaction with students. Has made offensive comments about Windows users, Europeans, Asians, and Android users. Really easy A and his exam study guides are very comprehensive and concise. Tons of content. His rotten personality sometimes leaks out during lecture and many students feel offended.

A lot of his lectures are three hour lectures at a late time and his voice is very calm and monotone. This makes it very hard to stay alert and focused in class. On the other hand, his notes and slides are so well made, concise, and informative that taking his class feels like a breath of fresh air compared to other professors.
The prof made the class very easy and the exams are pretty easy. Just attend his classes

Took PK Spring 2024, and covered a lot of interesting material ranging from basic ciphers to network protocol in his 3-hour lectures. Four exams (includes final), worst grade dropped. Content is primarily from topics list + study guide, in more depth on slideshows - so look at them well. Projects were medium difficulty but graded leniently.

PK is a really cool professor who really goes out of your way to ensure you do well in the class. Lowest exam dropped, TONS of class resources on his website and he posts study guides a week before each exam. The material covers a lot of topics and is relevant/up to date. A must take professor during your undergrad at Rutgers.

Had him twice now. Dry humour and generates interest and intrigue in what would be dreary academic text alone. Generally teaches the high-level of complex concepts. His grading is generous, but exam-heavy. Projects advertised as "quick and easy" rarely are so, but they don't weigh much. Genuinely inspired me to start cybersecurity.

Projects are trivial but lecture material is top notch. Most students (class size ~= 30) can't pay attention for 3 hr lectures & skip. His notes and homework articles are rewarding & interesting. 3 Exams & 1 Final which are all content heavy (lowest dropped). Take cs417 if going into swe. Do NOT procrastinate learning the weekly topics.

Interesting topics, decent projects (even if only 2 this semester), consistent pace, generous grading scale, great TA, and high quality, well presented lecture materials. Quizzes were frequently tricky, but we had them weekly in lieu of exams. It was a well run class and also one the most interesting IMO. Highly recommend 417 with PK!

He's the GOAT. Class is super easy to pass or to get an B. But its not as easy as it was before the pandemic. His quizzes have very vague and hard to distinguish options, which kinda sucks because quizzes were like 70% of the grade. No exams thought. Didn't attend most of the lectures but still got a B+. He still lives up to his reputation.

I wonder why people say the class is really fun. 3 hours straight up reading from slides. Quizzes every week with most of the questions having two possible answers. Gave false hopes to everyone saying quizzes will be hard but curve will be generous. If you are failing curve is 20-30%. if you are above avg curve is <5%. Grading is not lenient.
Quizzes were bs and often had more than one answer possibility. Lectures were basically scripts as he simply read off of slides.
Dude doesn't care about the quality of education he gives and reads off slides for 3 hours once a week.

Hes the best CS professor at RU period. Total 3 exams and 1 final, you can drop the lowest one, even the final. Gives you your letter grade before the final so you can decide to take the final or not. He also shows you the points you need on the final to move up a grade. The projects depend on TAs, but the grading on them is very lenient.

Paul Krzyzanowski is one of the best CS professors at Rutgers. He is a working professional with real world experience and actually teaches because he wants to. As someone said before he takes a rather difficult subject and makes it easy for everyone to understand. The only drawback is his lectures are 3 hours one day a week. Would take him again.

PK took a really complex and tedious subject (Computer Security) and made it easy to understand, while also giving lots of relevant and interesting examples. The curve was extremely generous for exams and overall, with one exam being optional, and the projects were relatively-simple. Homework is fairly light too. Overall a great experience.

This professor is really a fantastic guy. He teaches because he really likes to teach, not because he has to. Actually he has a FT job that is related to his field and more experienced then almost any other professor in the real world in the department. Take him if you get the chance, go to class, and talk to him.

Outstanding. I can't recommend him enough. He's extremely informative, but not difficult. He provides you with EVERYTHING you need to succeed. In depth study guides, notes with plenty of examples, sample exams etc. His curves make the exam averages just below an A. One of my favorite CS classes of all time. He's also just a cool guy in general.
Must take! He is too nice and well experience in the field. He teachers from experience, not from the book. 4 exams, but final is optional depends on your grade. He will help you pass.

One of the best CS professors Rutgers has to offer. PK has a wealth of industry experience in distributed systems, and covers incredibly useful topics. I got a job offer because I was able to talk in depth about things covered in this course. This was my favorite class in my undergraduate studies, and I highly recommend all students take it.
My favorite professor during my undergraduate Rutgers CS career. Learned a lot!

Not much to say about this class that isn't on his website (pk dot org). Since he lives 6 hours away, he only teaches 3-hour lectures, which is not for everyone, especially since the material is very straightforward. Highly recommended though since you do learn a lot and there is next to no programming necessary. Optional final and easy homework.

VOLUMES of information, which makes it feel like an introductory survey class of networking concepts/history/details. So both boring+very interesting (depending on your interests).  3 hour lectures are brutal, but it helps that Paul has a troll-sense of humor.  Huge study guides, online notes.  Light workload for a CS class. Optional final!

I had Prof. Krzyzanowski, for CS 416 & CS 417, if you are looking to take CS electives that you learn useful material and have practical assignments, this is it.  Only down side is lectures are long (once a week). Besides that exams are exactly what's on study guides and past exams.  He says "you have to try to fail my classes", he's right.

One of the best professors at Rutgers, at least in the CS department. Although lectures are long they are not that boring, despite the topic. Exams are pretty easy (they are multiple choice) and he posts study guides in preparation for them, memorize it. Definitely worth taking if you are a Rutgers CS major.

Lectures are usually long (mine was 3 hours) but he gives breaks if students ask.  The lectures, notes, and readings are all posted online, but he give a little extra notes if you go to class (really good at explaining material and answering questions (even with homework)). Programming assignments weren't tough really, START EARLY! (groups allowed)

Professor K makes 416 a breeze. He writes his own exam reviews for you to make studying easier and even uploads previous exams! The second and third projects are a lot of work but aren't hard if you know C. He gives out quizzes that use the presented powerpoints to force attendance since lectures are almost 3 hours long. He's a wonderful professor.

Exams are 70% multiple choice/30% explain.Multiple choice questions are okay but some of them are tricky.The written part sucks, he will take most points off because he doesn't feel you answered the question.The projects are okay but the second one is useless and the most important one HADOOP wasn't mandatory because it was given towards the final.

Reads from a powerpoint for 2-3 hours. Extremely boring. Tests are mostly multiple choice and easy if you study. I got an A without paying attention in class. The programming assignments were extremely difficult, but the hardest one (Hadoop) was dropped.
Nice professor, always helps students. But the course was extremely boorring ! It starts at 6:40 and ends at 9 (PM !!) without giving any break.
This class was well worth it.  The projects were easy and fun!  The final becomes optional if you do well on the midterms.

best CS class I've taken so far. Easy A and I learned a bunch. Programming assignments are pretty easy compared to other classes too. I strongly suggest taking this class if you're thinking about it, it's well worth it.

One of the coolest professors you will find in Rutgers! He is actually a succesful CEO who teaches just for fun. Extremely helpful and well organized despite the fact that he is so busy. Answers emails within minutes any time of the day! The class is interesting and intertaining, programming projects are pretty cool - nothing boring.

you can choose to do well on the exams or the programming projects (which are mandatory). i found the exams to be pretty challenging (consistently lowest grade), and my grade seems to be based on my perfect attendance and projects. The projects are tough, be in touch with him from the beginning as soon as you get stuck. He *will* help you!
Awesome and useful course!

Would 100% guarantee her to anyone else. Very kind on the exams and grading. Cares about you learning the topics well and doing well in her class. Lots of Extra Credit, lenient grading, and she answers quickly on email outside of class.

Burns is definitely the professor you'd want to take for 211. I had her F24, and she made this class incredibly straightforward. There are also many extra credit opportunities, and compared to some of the other professors teaching this class, she reduces the stress tremendously.

Took Prof. Burns in F24 and if you're lucky enough to have her, congrats! Homeworks are a lil difficult but there's a lot of extra credit opportunities that make the class extremely hard to fail or do poorly. Exams are straightforward. Random attendance checks but it's worth going because she actually makes the material enjoyable. 5/5 definitely.

Easy professor for CompArch, lots and lots of extra credit opportunities, quizzes and tests were straightforward and pretty easy if you pay attention and look over the lecture slides. Attendance is taken randomly. She's very nice and kind, definitely recommend for 211.

F24 She was very understanding and gave a lot of extra credit. The class is so much better with her, she is super understanding and gave extensions to multiple assignments. Took feedback and responded. Assignments were also not super difficult, she was also very engaging during class.

Super nice. Lectures were engaging. She took attendance randomly. If you start all of the projects early, it's an easy A (don't do them the day before like I did). Bomb lab was super fun, don't be intimidated by it. There's really great YT tutorials you can follow. Take-home exams(initially in-person). Oral exam was graded super leniently.

F24 was her first non-summer session teaching at Rutgers and Prof Burns was great. Flexible with due dates and the assignments weren't impossibly difficult. She also gave a ton of extra credit so it was basically impossible to get a B. She was also j really nice and pleasant which was a plus.

this professor lowkey the goat, and why well my class only had 3 people me and two others and he was ery active and talktive doesnt sound boring, when it comes to lectures he really dumbs it down and he likes it when you ask questions, midterm is online and so is the final book can be found as PDF labs are easy he'll walk step by step 
W professor

Networking class and all he did was talk about his life. He would blurt out crazy claims that could have been very offensive. He had no right to say some of these things. DO NOT TAKE HIM IF YOU WANT TO LEARN. The class is kinda easy if u want to take a useless class but I would pick something else.

He barely knows the material. He wastes over half the class talking about money, AI or his life. He gives quizzes every class &gives the answers to them without explaining. Says"if you want to know why go look it up on your own".Made us do a discussion post about how Big Tech is "unfairly censoring conservatives".Don't take him if you want to learn

Professor Orbe is a really nice guy who has tons of knowledge but does not know how to transmit that knowledge to students. There's no lecture, There's the text book and teaching yourself linux. There are assignments that you will inevitably complete incorrectly and then after the entire class does it wrong then you will be given the answer.

Professor Orbe is great! For summer class (2024) he was easy going and very understanding. He ended class early and pushed back assignment dates. Assignments were not too difficult and he thoroughly explained things needed to be done. 11/10 would recommend!

He is easily one of the best professors I've had. Though his approach to teaching the material was initially iffy for me, I found that the space he gives us to learn the materials ourselves through hands-on experience was in the end, super worthwhile. Super responsive and helpful as well as empathetic and lenient. Treated everyone like adults. 5/5
If you want an easy A for IT Fundamentals, Orbe is your guy.

Didn't teach at all in class, so be ready to go home and teach yourself (attendance is mandatory tho). Really hooked on politics and never talks about class unless its the last 10 minutes. His exams are allegedly from the textbook, but half the questions never are, so you end up sitting there wondering why you're an ITI major. Find someone else.

Professor William Orbe is without a doubt one of the greatest professors I've ever had the happiness to take from Rutgers.  He's very genuine and is willing to teach and support you which is unfortunately something really rare amongst professors in Rutgers.  If you have questions, he will go out of his way to ensure you are good.  INCREDIBLE Prof.

Professor Orbe was a very helpful and kind professor. Although he sometimes gets off track during class by discussing about politics, he made assignments very easy and was accommodating to all students.
He's a great professor, very chill classroom environment! Willing to help outside of class.

This class with Orbe is a complete waste of time. Completely disorganized so nothing really gets done and you don't learn too much. Constantly gets off topic and starts talking about politics instead of class. Best to skip this prof, but easy A atleast.

Professor Orbe is a really nice guy who wants all of his students to do well in the course. He does tend to get off track during the lectures, leaving very little time to focus on the actual class material. If you want an easy class with an understanding professor, I recommend taking him but be ready to go over the lessons on your own
I had professor orbe for the summer. he's the best and extends deadlines. very approachable after class and gives tips to do well on assignments and exams.

Professor Orbe is a very cool professor. He will always offer to help you with labs and will often extend deadlines for people. My main problem is that I left the class feeling I didn't learn very much. His lectures mainly focused on iti jobs, tools, and current events. I wish he had actual ppts and spoke more about what was on the syllabus.

Professsor Orbe is a really understanding professor who is always open to working with students so they can get the best grade possible. However, I had to teach myself everything which was difficult because I am very new to the ITI major. In class he didn't really teach any material which was frustrating but he extended deadlines often for the labs
Prof. Orbe is an awesome professor! He is chill, gives good feedback on assignments, and gives extensions on deadlines. He is a really knowledgeable professor and helps you.
He is very chill.

I highly do not recommend him. He is one of those teachers that ramble on about their own lives and not actually teach. He'll tell you all about how much he regrets not taking the job at IBM and repeat the story every class. All that said, he's pretty lenient about reopening assignments. He's a push over so there's that. He doesn't teach period.

Enthusiastic about teaching and explains concepts well. Gives a lot of resources for assignments, which are hard but fair. There is a lot of reading though, and a quiz every week. The lectures are informative and recorded. He runs the class very well and gives you every chance to do well. If he's teaching a class, take it.

Narayana is a great professor, but his exams are pretty hard. It is hard to predict what is on the exams. It is also because OS is also a hard course. Projects were okay. But I still think he is a great professor, and he has all his notes and recordings are available online. So you can review it. He is very helpful during office hours.

if this man is teaching any course, TAKE IT. he's the best cs lecturer I've ever had. if u ask him anything, he'll explain until u understand and he's very patient. even though lectures aren't mandatory and he records them, you will get an A if u go and pay attention. the exams are basically pulled from the lectures and you get a cheat sheet

one of the best CS professors at Rutgers. he makes the content very easy to understand and fun. lectures are recorded and posted. all projects are group/partner projects. lets you have cheat sheets for exams too.

Narayana is one of the best at Rutgers and 352 was such a well-structured, interesting, and relevant course. I thoroughly recommend any CS student to take any class he teaches. Attendance is not mandatory but going to and participating in the lectures helps the material stick and despite the lectures being recorded, they are way better in person.

A good professor that was open to student feedback. A quiz on every lecture and python projects. The TAs had hidden rubrics for the projects and it was difficult to get a 100 on them. However, Narayana was a patient and kind professor who kept the class otherwise fair in terms of grade distribution. Exams are weighed less than projects.

S tier professor. EXTREMELY knowledgeable and caring. I've genuinely never had a CS professor within Rutgers as good as this professor was. Projects aren't too bad at all but the exams are pretty difficult but aren't weighted too heavily. Also records his lectures so you could refer back to them.

If you see a course taught by Narayana, do yourself a favor and take it. Extremely good lectures (recorded) with amazing slides. The entire class can only be described as fair. You will learn a lot about the material, but most important is how caring he is. He is always ready to hear students out!

Hands down one of the best the CS dept has to offer. Very knowledgeable and great lecturer. Records ALL lectures. Reasonable exams and projects. Best of all, he is exceptionally caring and understanding, taking student feedback to heart (i.e. giving extra credit although he initially opposed it). There are few options as good as Professor Narayana.

Very passionate about IT and teaching. Free A because he allows 1, 1, and 2 pages of cheat sheets on midterm 1, 2, and final, respectively (you can just copy down all of the slides and it will give you the answers to almost everything). Super easy projects. TAs can get nitpicky with their project rubrics. Very difficult to choke the A.

Professor Narayana is a chill dude. Very nice guy who clearly cares for his students and knows the material well. His exams were a bit harder than other electives I've taken, but if you prepare well, you'll be fine. Projects aren't too bad either. You'll learn a lot if you take this class with him

He films his live lectures and posts online but the majority of students come in person because his lectures are really interesting. The exams match lectures perfectly, I actually forgot about the first midterm but did decent simply because his lectures had made the material easy to absorb. Super quick to reply especially with questions on projects

For a graduate course in networking, lots of really fundamental topics were covered in lectures that really helped put the bigger picture together. We also read semi-recent papers, and a lot of our understanding was tested in programming assignments. Would highly recommend this class for people looking to take the grad version of CS 352.

The class is challenging, but he explains things well. I learned a lot from him. He is accommodating outside of class. The only problem is that his exams are tough. To do well, you must also read the book and self-study to understand the material very well. The lecture itself is not enough to do well in the class. Expect to work hard in his class.

I absolutely loved taking his OS course. The course is programming assignment heavy, but his great lectures and the recitations held by his TAs truly help you complete them. Plus, you can also team up with a classmate to solve them.

He also seems very kind and understanding. He won't make it easy, but he will give you the necessary resources.
(CS 416) Good slides, good lectures, fair grading, and overall a swell guy. Listened to feedback a lot (project extensions,

HIS CS416 DOESNT HAVE A CURVE,  70% IS D. 80 IS B , 90 IS A
BUT FOR MOST OF THE PROFESSORS' CS416, C SHOULD BE AROUND 50%. AND D SHOULD BE 45%
Reads of slides and have a accent. quizzes are nothing like what he teaches.

One of the best teachers and classes I have taken at Rutgers. The professor explains the content in an easy-to-understand way and has clear slides and easy projects. The exams should be fine if you study the slides & problem sets and have a good cheat sheet. Overall, I liked this class because it gave me real knowledge in an easy-to-digest manner.

He is a great professor for Internet Tech and his lecture notes contain good illustrations of the topics that are taught in the course. Make sure you do the problem sets and the practice questions for exams and you will be fine. The projects were on the difficult side but definitely doable with a good partner.

Narayana gives great lectures compared to many other professors. I took internet tech with him and he was able to create easy to understand analogies with some more complex topics. His exams were sometimes difficult but the projects were very easy.
Easy projects. Crazy hard exams. Prof cares about students though so there's a nice curve.
The most disappointment cs class I have ever take in Rutger. The exams are super hard. The sample exams are useless. Don't take this professor's class if u want to get a good grade.

His lectures feel very entertaining and informative to sit through, but they did not reflect the level of depth which the exams required. Projects were super easy, but the exams were harder than any CS class I've taken (besides 437). He is very caring and values feedback, so I expect that he will improve this course's difficulty distribution.

One of the most frustrating experiences I've had here. He's a smart guy, but his lectures are mainly him just reading off his slides. Projects are easy, but the exams are some of the most specific and difficult I've experienced at Rutgers. Without being taught the exam material, you're expected to be a detailed expert on anything he throws at you.

Lectures were at 8 AM, and we were given pop quizzes. Some of the TAs graded the exams and homework much harder than others, which would mess with the grade distribution. They would post ChatGPT responses as the solutions for the homework, which was not a good look. The lectures were pretty useless, but the quizzes and exams are fine if you study.

Truly one of the best professors I've ever had at Rutgers. For the first time at rutgers, I've been enlightened to the fact that it's sometimes better to skip class and teach yourself the material, haha.

Extremely hard to understand with his accent. Jim Kurose, the book author has an amazing playlist on youtube that covers the book way better than lectures. The exams are the same questions as the quizes and are easy. The quizes are what is on the review section of the slides the lecture before and quizes are the lecture after each chapter review.

Very difficult to understand what he is saying. Watching the book authors youtube video playlist on the book is way better. The exams consist of what was on the quizes and are easy. The quizes are mostly what is on the review slides the lecture before. He does post his slides so the quizes and exams are easy, just hes not a good teacher.

Class is extremely boring and the slides are so long. Pop quizzes at 9am. Honestly I don't even think the material is that difficult objectively, but the teaching style mixed with MANY other things I could go on about ('solutions' being SCREENSHOTTED from chatgpt, and incorrect)... this class was just horrible do not take.

Desheng transformed difficult Internet Technology concepts into intuitive material through his methodological teaching approach. All you have to contribute to do well in this class is to GO to lectures physically, that's it.
We have five pop-up quizzes, three exams, three homework assignments, and three projects. Oh my god.
Boring material, bad lectures, pop quizzes at 8:30 am, TAs are also pretty lazy, clearly using AI for review material solutions. would not recommend at all

Personally wouldn't take this class or professor again. A bunch of pop quizzes that are open ended make up 10% of your grade. The exams are all open ended as well. Class is boring and is difficult to sit through especially at 8am
Too many pop-up quizzes, too many projects.

One of the most boring and worst classes ive ever taken. has pop quizzes in a 300 level course, and only reads off his slides. reading off the slides would be fine if the slides were good, but theyre useless. the material isnt crazy, its actually somewhat interesting but this prof manages to make it the most boring thing ive ever had to sit thru

Horrible professor, makes pop quizzes in a 300 level course, and he decides his best form of lecture is to read off his slides. That would be fine, if his slides were halfway to decent. Except they're the most useless thing i have ever laid my eyes upon. the material isnt crazy hard, but he makes this class the worst

I can't say if you should take this class if you want to learn, since I just wanted an easy A, but I managed without actually learning anything. His accent is a bit heavy, so keep that in mind if you struggle with accents. I found him still quite understandable though. The 2 projects were light, and I didn't struggle for not knowing python.

Very bad Professor. Have a very bad accent. Although this is an online course and all the hws and exams are take-home, the grades are very strange. I get 90%+ of the total overall grade and just get a B on my transcript. Do not take his course again.

I do believe that this class is an easy A so if your goal is that, then this dude will hook you up with the same recycled stuff from every year. The project is usually given to the TA to lead which is bad idea so usually stuff is vague for no reason. Overall if you want to truly learn then i would say dont take this class but he is a nice guy.

A really straight forward professor and very nice in person. Lecture is also pretty straight forward. If there is one thing that I am not satisfied, it is the project because he does not explain it. Except for that, he definitely worth taking. An easy A for sure

Very solid professor. He's very transparent about what's on the quizzes and exams. It is extremely difficult to do poorly on his exams. His homeworks are all taken from online examples so those are easy too. The only problem with this class is the projects. The grades are slow to be released but that's mostly the TA's fault.
Deshang is the best Professor. The quizzes will help you prepare for exam. The project are average. He is more than willing to answer question if you don't understand his concept.

Professor Zhang is a really good person and I love the way how he explain the concepts. The exams are easy and the project is a good practice to understand the internet. It helps me a lot in my other courses.

Desheng Zhang is probably the best CS professor I've had at Rutgers. He's nice and also really good at getting people to pay attention in class. His projects are clear and easy to do, but his midterms can be kind of challenging. Overall 9.5/10.
Great Professor.

Bad professor. His lectures are really tiring and he has no enthusiasm for anything. He also reteaches the exact same content with the exact same slides 3 lectures in a row. Every. Time. This semester the exams were easy though, because the questions were identical to the review and quizzes, but the project specifications were very vague.

For exams, he will give 25% credit on a problem if you write "I don't know", which is a great thing for this class. Exams were really difficult, and the lectures did not help at all. He is a nice guy, but his lectures were really confusing and not helpful. He gave a curve for every exam, but still an insanely difficult class.

Arbitrary grading, NO SYLLABUS, terrible lecture to exam knowledge ratio, study guides did not properly prepare students for the exams. This is the type of professor that is certainly qualified in their field but has no skill in actually professing their knowledge to their students. Survival is based on curve, be good at studying on your own.

Horrible Professor. This has been the worst course I've ever had in my 4 years of college. Expect doing homework 24/7, not learning a single thing and receiving a D in the end! Worst professor ever!!!!

Sitting thru the 55 min of a Chang Chen recitation is a brain-numbing experience. Her examples differ drastically from lecture, she includes extra info that complicates things & her English is incomprehensible. If attendance wasn't mandatory nobody would come. We'd all be better off not having to waste an hr of our lives on this pointless exercise.

She was really good at explaining everything that we learned, she was able to answer everyone's questions. We did have a lot of Programming assignments and HWs, but all of which was very easily handled. Also she gave out quite a bit of Extra Credit, so it worked in our favor. I wouldn't say its an easy A, but definitely attainable.

Professor Chaturvedi is a solid professor, and she definitely knows this subject very well. The class itself is very easy, just a couple of quizzes, a group project, but MANY lectures (cubits videos). For whatever reason, she decided to assign 20+ hours of cubits videos days before the class was supposed to end. I still recommend taking her though.

She is a nice professor and is lenient with the grading. Her online class was very easy with few assignments. Some quizzes, 2 homework assignments, group project, CUbits videos, and no exams. Even though the class was disorganized at times (assigned videos equating to 40 hours with a deadline of a few days), I still learned a lot from the course.

First half of the semester WAS SO HARD. We complained to the dean, and she eased up. Second half was easy. So not sure how she does it now. The homework is straight forward and I learned a lot of industry-usable skills.

Terrible lecturer, legitimately did not learn anything in her lectures. After enough people complained she just made the class extremely easy, I don't know if anybody finished with a grade that wasn't an A if they put in minimal effort.

Class didn't start of as good (check reddit for info!) but Chat def pulled thru. She actually values student feedback and made many changes in order for students to succeed. Def learned a great deal in this class and don't hesitate to take her for 210 if u want to get a good grade and also learn. Probably the easiest CS class of my life right here!
Professors who threaten students to keep them from dissenting do not belong at this university.

Professor Schoepflin is a nice and great professor! His lectures are engaging and he explains concepts very well. Even though his exams are difficult, the homeworks can help your grade. This class can be challenging but is doable as long as you engage with the material. I recommend taking him for this class!

If you really wanna learn, I highly recommend Prof. Schoepflin's class. The exams are challenging, but 50% of the grade is homework which is graded leniently. making up for it. His lectures are amazing and very well explained. If your only goal is an easy A I wouldn't recommend him but he is approachable and happy to help students who seek it.

Pretty lenient on homeworks, quizzes, and attendence. He is absent on canvas announcements and doesn't post many announcements. Good teacher but exams are ridiculously difficult and worth 50% and unless you have the full proof you will only get partial credit. Curved the class by 5 points did not curve the exams at all.

Super nice. Drops lowest hw and quiz grade. Exams are super difficult but he gives a lot of partial credit. The lectures are confusing if you don't have prior knowledge on the subject but the recitations can help clear some things up. Harsh late penalty so make sure to turn hw in on time, it can make or break your grade.

Really good at making his lectures not boring. He posts the lecture recordings and slides online. 5 HWs for the whole semester and there's small mini-quizes you do on your own time and they are pretty average difficulty. HW is very straightforward and helps you understand the material

Amazing lecturer, always made sure everyone understands  and answers everyone's questions. Hw is challenging but lowest is dropped. Exams are brutal but the curve is generous and partial credit is given if you write anything as long as it's an actual  attempt at the question. Lectures recording posted online. Overall amazing prof and great guy

prof schoepflin always made sure we understood what was covered 100% before moving on, and went over topics as many times as we wanted during class. he is a v lenient grader as long as you show work and it is clear that you made an attempt. weekly online quizzes (3 mc), 5 hw w/ lowest dropped, 5 point curve on final grade last sem. would recommend!

Super lenient grader on homeworks and the exams. Good at teaching and answering  any student's questions in lecture. Records his lectures and uploads them. hints a lot of the time what'll be on the exam during lectures. Makes sure the majority understands the material before moving on and wants the best for his students. Definitely recommend him.

Professor Schoepflin is very knowledgeable in discrete mathematics. He'll make sure you understand the material with the 4-5 homeworks throughout the semester that reflect his lectures. Any doubts you may have will be cleared right away upon questioning. Overall a great professor for Discrete Structures I.

This class is so hard. The professor is very nice, though a little hard to understand. The content is just so hard and so math-heavy. I passed, which surprises even me, but I do not recommend if you don't like math or computer graphics/vision/ML.

Honestly, Elgammal is super caring and sweet ðŸ¥º he truly wants students to succeed, understands if we struggle, and is never judgemental. Okay lecturer but gives enough materials to do well. Final and projects were not bad, midterm/quizzes are a bit harder. He is an AI researcher, so if you don't want to spend 2 months on AI, don't take 334.
He made an announcement on Saturday that there would be a quiz in two days on Monday.

DO NOT select this course unless you want to spent most of your whole semester time to finish this course's COUNTLESS and DIFFICULT homework/quiz. And you will not have much time to focus on other courses.

Very knowledgeable and helpful professor. He is very flexible with an assignment due dates and the grading was rather lenient. He is very motivating and wants to see you take on a project that you find interesting. The only drawback was the lectures were 3 hours long.

Lecures are fine, and he covers what he needs to cover. You absolutely need to stay on top of this class or it gets out of hand quickly. Quizzes are very tough, but homeworks are easier and leniently graded and make up for lackluster quiz grades. Provides exactly what you need to read, and you'd better read it or you will struggle.

He skips his own office hours without warning. When answering questions he repeats exactly what he already said and is condescending. Lectures are super dry and run the whole three hours. He says no python knowledge required but assigns an insane OCR project without teaching python or any of the ML concepts. The projects are individual.

The class is hated on a lot, but honestly it was not bad at all. I personally enjoyed the class and felt that we learned a lot. A lot of the material was from other fields, which made it more difficult to get a solid grasp on. The professor taught the class well and the TAs were very helpful as well.

I've never written a review for a professor but I will say this. DO NOT TAKE his cs334 class. You WILL REGRET it. I cannot repeat this enough. The exams are ridiculous and the homework have little to nothing to do with the exam or the material.
hours of poorly explained homework with vague grading guidelines using poorly document APIs; exams are more about trivia than applying knowledge. incredibly frustrating class

AVOID AVOID AVOID! Why did I not listen to other reviews?! 60% of grade is hw. There are NO solutions for the book that he uses. No way to know for certain the answer is right.  Book doesn't even give examples for the questions he assigns for homework. YOU ARE ON YOUR OWN. You don't know for certain if the TA or prof even grade your hw properly..
Elgammal does not care about his class. Comes in late everyday. Projects are time consuming. Very hard to understand his accent. I would not reccomend taking this class.
Really Helpful

Terrible teacher. Is very bad at explaining and does not prepate you well for anything. You will leave the room confused and not sure what you have just learned. Made the class harder than it should be and you suffer in the end. I strongly recommend someone else. Stay away from this teacher at all costs!

He doesn't speak English very well and has a very thick accent. He often speaks to the board so you can't really hear him. He's not very good at explaining either. Exams are open book so they weren't too bad. Assignments are a lot of work but doable. Unless you're very interested in the topic, take other classes!

WORST PROFESSOR EVER. does NOT speak english. DROP THIS CLASS and take it with a different professor.  Grading system is ridiculous and unfair.  Prof. does not know how to teach, recites from the book. His salary is $117k/year and does not deserve it. By far the worst class I have ever taken at RU, and the TA,who is heavily relied on, is no better

One of the worst professors i have ever had a rutgers. Comes to class late every day. Relies on the TA for everything. This man lacks basic social skills. He takes his slides out of the book. He confuses his p's with b's and his accent is unbearable. He should not be teaching at any level. He is a research professor who takes teaching lightly.

He is absolutely terrible professor. I ended up teaching myself everything. His accent is so strong and almost incoherent. He does a poor job at explaining problems and teaches right out of the book.Going to office hours did not offer much help. He takes a haphazardous approach to teaching, showing up late often. He does not care about students.

Awful Bad professor!!! Never explains the answers of the homeworks, always wants us to go and ask his TA. Gave us a project on weka but introduced with the tool weka and never answer any doubts.Very bad accent, haven't understood a thing in his class. He makes students suffer.
one of the smartest professors I've seen in rutgers. do the homeowork and the problems on the book then you'll get a good grade

Very difficult course. He has a thick & hard to understand accent, teaches from the worthless book using pages scanned into transparencies, and frequently arrived late or missed class despite being a 2 minute walk from his office. This was the 1st time he taught the course, so he might do better next semester. Curve was helpful, but not enough.

Absolutely terrible professor. Avoid at all cost!!! His lectures are almost as worthless as the book, no answers to check sample homework problems and TAs dont go over sample homework problems until after that homework has been submitted!!! Kinda hard to understand his accent. Curve helps, but grades are still bad. Another RU Screw CS course :(
Awesome prof! :) very helpful and kind

Doesnt care one bit about the students and still marks off for confusingly worded problems despite based on what was interpreted the solution would have been correct and demostrated proof of knowledge. Mumbles bad, writes worse, and reads completely out of the book. Lectures are worthless and the book isnt helpful because it has no sample answers.

Taught the material very thoroughly, so that if you're in class you don't have to read the book.  Very helpful in office hours.  The exams are impossible to finish, but he curves the final grade, so it doesn't really matter.  Overall, I would recommend taking him :-).
Well structured presentation of material, easy to learn manner. Best CS professor I had so far.
Good Professor. Very helpful, a little bit of an Accent with pronounciations of certain letters. Broaden your minds and ears and listen to him.
even though the class is curved, we all did so bad on our second exam, he made it a smaller part of our whole grade to "make us feel better."
Difficult to understand at times. Exams are relatively easy. Very fair grader, especially when it comes to the final grade (heavy curve)
mutters, stutters, V's and P's are pronounced B...in fact, what letter of the alphabet out of his mouth isn't a B. Exams more than fair.
a little bit slow of a pace, but taught us what we needed to know.

Horrible class. I don't even remember what it was about, though the content is useful. The professor was very hard to understand and all of her classes are at 8am *crying*. Very few grades and exams are HARD.

In all honesty, lectures were not very clear, and it was hard to hear the professor mostly. However, the professor is always open to clarifying questions and answers them well. Projects were not too hard, and exams were fair, very similar to homework problems.

You can get an A in the class pretty easily if you put the work in. Be ready to study a lot though because the professor is a bad lecturer. One midterm and One final worth 60% of your grade so you need to do good on exams. The grading is lenient though.
You would think she spoke Japanese if you were not listening clearly to what she was saying. The lectures are extremely hard to follow.

No curve, no study guide, and the exams are 60% . In general her lecture/recitation slides are helpful, and provide lot of useful examples. She goes over them in class. She accessible in office hours and is extremely helpful with hw questions. Weekly hw, 2 projects that were doable. if you understand the concepts you will do fine on exams. Just try

NO EXTRA CREDIT, NO STUDY GUIDE, NO CURVE! EXAMS ARE 60% OF YOUR GRADE! Doesn't care to answer any emails. Lectures are a torture as her teaching style is quietly reading from the slides at 8am. I needed .07% to get a B which is 1/900 points we had and she didn't curve it. Absolutely worst professor and class I've ever taken at Rutgers.

Lectures are useless. She basically reads off her slides and speaks too quietly for you to hear even halfway down the lecture room. Rarely responds to questions through email and Piazza. Laughably slow grading (midterm not graded until week before the final). Her final exam was generous, and she's a nice person, but she could do so much better.

A lot of reviews here are negative because there is no curve, no study guide, and the exams are weighted heavily. But I honestly think she's great at explaining hard concepts / answering questions, and she's caring. Weekly homeworks were not bad, and if you understand the concepts then the exams are ok too. The material is super important and cool.
Prepare to learn Ocaml and Scheme and try not to fail the exams which make up the majority of your grade. Boring and useless class made to be unnecessary difficult.
This professor should have never been given the chance to teach any class whatsoever, does NOT care about her students and literally wants you to FAIL. DO NOT TAKE HER UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES.

This was the worst class I've taken at Rutgers. Boring material, boring lecture, boring class in general. The professor is very strict, doesn't respond to emails about exams and refuses to give a study guide or questions similar to those on the exam. We have 1100+slides to memorize for the final and idek where to start. Eams 60% of ur grade

WORST PROFESSOR OF ALL TIME!!!!!!! Gave no topics list abd practice exam at all for the final which is 35% of the grade. Does not curve and gives A LOT of homework for that's only worth 10% of the grade. No extra credit either.

Nice person but not a good professor. Lectures are boring but so is the material however that's not the main problem. She doesn't curve, grades midterms super late like the week before final and gives 0 study guides. If you do all the hws, projects and go over lectures you will still ask yourself "wtf is this" on the exam. Exams are 60% of ur grade
Received grades for midterms a week before final. Which is 25% of grade. No final review and no practice exam for final. Lectures are early and quite boring to be honest.

Pros:
- She knows the material 

Cons:
- Can not really teach or explain things well
- Speaks too quietly and too fast, her English is not very good
- Very difficult grader
- Useless TA ( TA can barely speak English, not exaggerating! common at RU)
- She uses so many abbrevations 
- If you want to watch YouTube and learn it on your own, take her

For the final project, I messed up and accidentally sent code that didn't compile but I sent her an email and explained why it didn't compile and the exact line/position I needed to insert a parenthesis (the scheme project) for it to compile and work. Initially got a 0 but after my email she regraded for a passing grade

I am never felt more this discouraged and depressed by a class before. Her lectures are informative but does not relate entirely to her homework and projects. She teaches the surface of the iceberg and asks mostly from what's hidden underneath. Not worth the stress especially in this pandemic.
Learned a lot in this class. She was helpful and responsive to forum posts. The class material and projects were not easy but she did a lot to help us succeed. Get ready to do a lot of work.

I honestly did not really enjoy the class because of the boring and complicated material. However, Professor Zhang is very responsive to emails and on the forum page. Even though the class itself is not very fun, Zhang does her best to help everyone and I really liked her as a teacher.
Worst professor I have ever had and the worst class I have ever taken.

She is a very caring professor who goes into details in office hours. However, there is room for her to improve her teaching skills. Lectures are somewhat boring with a good amount of information contained. Lecture slices are posted regularly. It takes too long to post the first project and we are running out of time by the end of the semester.

"test heavy" meaning that the midterm or final is worth 60% of your grade, so if you perform poorly on them you're SOL. Ignore the CS415 reviews since u need at least a B in 314 to take 415 with her; a B doesn't reflect the majority of the grades people got (all very low). No curve, only teaches you C and scheme. This class was useless, busy work.

i'm not too mad that i had taken her over steinberg. but she's just only one level above him in terms of lecture quality. she's hard to understand, and her exams are poorly designed that i actually know a lot of people failing this class. she says there's no curve, but there is extra credit at least.

She is cute and nice. She is hard to understand in lectures, and by the midterm, only 1/4th of the class shows up for lecture, and only 1/4th of that 1/4th actually pays attention while at lecture. HW is hard, and her exams are terribly written. Projects are okay. Recitation doesn't help after the first 3 weeks. Not the worst, but not at all good.

A little hard to understand but she posts her slides online. Written homework every week and three coding projects. Projects are relatively straightforward and simple. Exams are medium difficulty but gives many extra credit opportunities.
Goes 30 min over class time because of her love for the subject.

Really great professor. Class gets dull if no one participates, and you'll definitely be missing out. This is her field, and she knows a lot of what's going on today. Workload isn't a lot. She's willing to help you get a decent grade, and at the same time, tries to make sure you are learning.

Sweet class.  She goes over the slides comprehensively and basically explains all of the algorithms and concepts you need to know clearly.  She doesn't speak very loudly though.  Workload is manageable.
CS 111 is a hard class for beginners. It takes time to learn the ins and outs. Professor Sorenson is cool, though, and he is one of the few good, caring CS professors I had at Rutgers.

He was a decent professor and explained the concepts and ideas well in the lecture. He makes a few jokes occasionally but is very savvy about time. He makes sure we leave 5 minutes before the class ends. Just make sure you don't talk during class, or else he will get extremely angry and yell at you. Even the quietest whispers at the back won't do.
it was okayish

The hardest part is the homework, they are way too hard for a beginner course and if you have no coding experience, good luck. Surprisingly the HW is a lot harder than the exams, the midterm and final are pretty chill imo as long as you study. Prof's Lectures are funny and useful, although I wish he would spend more time on the slides.
Seems to really care about the field and enjoy it. Explains the topics really well and helps understand it on more than a surface level.

I have never coded and I reached out to him the summer before and he told me to start on the first project and figure out VS code. He really believes in beginners. Spend time in the cave. I went from not knowing anything to helping my classmates with the code. Start the hw early and get a 100% on all of them. An A is possibly. Take centeno or lars

this is not a very good professor. whenever he teaches a concept, he makes it his mission to get sidetracked and get into the technicalities of stuff which nobody in the room understands. i guess it was to assert some sort of dominance for an ego boost.

Not a good teacher at all. Doesn't answer students' questions in lectures, which is quite the problem considering he is awful at explaining concepts. If I didn't have prior CS knowledge, I would not have survived this class. If you're a CS pro already, take him; if you're a beginner and or want a good professor, stay far away from him.

Sorensen's vague lecture is a complete waste. He is on auto-pilot and there is 0 engagement with students. Everyone is falling asleep or doing something else unrelated to the course. Scores of his students skip the class because it is simply a bad use of time. The course itself is ok.

I'm not sure where his reputation comes from.

I would highly recommend getting some coding experience before taking Prof Sorensen's Intro to CS class. Homework is very easy if you know what you are doing, but can be extremely difficult without. Very little class participation though, so all questions are left for the end of class. Lectures can get really boring and it gets hard to focus.

Very funny guy, I'll never forget the endless amount of times he said that the Java compiler will "tell you to go pound salt". He gives tips on assignments and repeats himself often so that you understand concepts. Only thing I didn't like was that he wouldn't take questions about anything until the end of class. Overall though, great professor.

Professor Sorenson's lectures were kinda boring but he seemed nice. His class is definitely hard without prior cs knowledge and there is homework due every week, which often takes the whole week. Lectures are info-heavy and the exams are quite hard. Outside resources for help are not great so be prepared to self-study if you want to pass.

Lars did a great job of making sure that students were aware of upcoming due dates, and material on tests. The class itself does move fast, however asking questions helps a lot. I recommend attending all his lectures as he will often giveaway test answers, and methods in the homework. Pay attention and you will do good.

He's definitely an interesting one. His lectures are fun and engaging, he gives extra credit sporadically, and always gives u a heads up on what's going to be on the next exam. definitely expect to stay after class if you have questions (he won't answer them during the lecture). If you are unexperienced with java, try to get prof. centeno instead.

Sorensen is a great lecturer, I recommend him. Class has very clear grading criteria and is based off homework assignments (which get progressively harder) and three exams. However as someone who has never taken a computer science class in their life, I'd say I struggled a bit too much for this being an intro class.

lars was cool, but I preferred learning on my own most of the time (Centeno vids)

if you go to lecture, you should sit near enough to see the blackboard 

It is a hard class no matter what, especially for newcomers. Assignments got progressively difficult (even tho I had some coding experience) and exams were far different than past/practice ones

If you are taking CS111, TAKE LARS. He is the head of CS111 so when the test comes around, he will give you a nudge to what is on it. He is also the best lecturer in CS111. Class is way too difficult for an intro course. If you have no coding experience in highschool, good luck lmao. Overall poor department and buildings.

Prof. Sorensen is the most caring professor I've met. Half of the course's grade is based on assignments, so it's not the end of the world if you're a bad test-taker. He repeats a lot so if you zoned out once you'll have the chance to hear it again. He keeps the course fun and entertaining.

Sorensen's lectures were interesting and include a lot of information. Coding assignments weren't too difficult. Exams had concept questions and coding questions. If you have no Java experience, this will be challenging. I enjoyed having Sorensen, although I spent most of my time reading slides and the textbook then at lecture.

Class starts off super easy but if you have no experience at all, you might get rocked towards the end. He's funny and not a bad lecturer but I definitely got bored and distracted a lot in class (being online was probably a big factor).

Easy A for people with CS experience, newcomers might have a hard time though. Also we used Java.

Professor Sorensen was an ok teacher; his lectures were hard to keep up with. My recommendation is to go to the cave on Busch Campus and work with people in your class. Its the only way you will get one on one help and understand the class
