Lectures are never boring. Cares about ur time and relates to you as a student. Assignments are the same throughout all professors but they get progressively harder over time so do not slack. Grading system is mid cause if u miss assignments your grade drops and no way to bring it back up. Lowest midterm score is dropped. Overall good pick!

He is a good professor. Indeed, he does not let students interrupt him during his lecture, which is not a problem. I feel that we have to study and practice by ourselves to learn more deeply. He is kind of funny. He keeps announcements up to date and makes sure students don't forget exam dates and assignment due dates.

The first guy with the Python class summarizes him pretty well. Pretty good teacher and he digs it into your brain that anyone can learn CS, experience or none. He really sucks when it comes to interacting with students though. I haven't heard a single student hold a single convo with him all semester and we can't ask questions til class ends.

Prof. Sorenson is awesome. I had him online and he's always organized. His lectures are very entertaining and he makes everything clear so that students have easy access to help. Gives hw/ exam hints. You can take surveys for EC. Attendance is not a grade but you need to go to do well. The textbook is online, not mandatory but good to go over!

He knows what he's talking about when lecturing and can be funny at times, but he doesn't really do a good job of interacting with students during online class. He makes you turn off your webcam and mike, so you can't ask questions during the lecture unless you wait until the end/ask other people in the chat.

His course and coursework are alright but he is bad with interacting with students. He just doesn't care about his students. He doesn't grade his students' work himself so if/when a problem arises, he doesn't handle it professionally. He is a fan of strawman arguments and slippery slope reasoning. If you take his class, just be a careful.

Your grade is dependent on 5/6 assignments. All requirements are clear and not particularly difficult, but start assignments early to get feedback before submitting, as he is a slow grader. The lectures are mainly a discussion/review of the readings, so you could skip all classes, but if you want to get the most out of the class don't do that!

dont know current grade yet. professor grades very slow. and then proceeds to grade very strictly... so you cannot even do anything about his feedback since all assignments have already been turned in by the time he grades. lectures are not engaging unfortunately.

he seemed very nice at first but it slowly became inline with the other ratings.

Very weird, elitist fellow. Called me by my initials- who does this? Classwork isn't organized or really insightful. Rants about how undergrads aren't supposedly bright. Doesn't seem he does much other than stay in that tiny room in CBIM.

Would you like to learn nothing in class, because the professor is incredibly boring and unable to teach? Are you ready for your final grade to be based on two assignments during the entire semester, because your professor is too lazy to proceed according to the syllabus? Then take Prof. Stone!
Excellent professor. Went over concepts, algorithms and formulas very thoroughly, and was able to clarify any questions. Projects were very fun and manageable. Very nice guy too.
Not helpful. Arrogant, elitist attitude.

Nobody in class could understand half of what the guy was saying in class. Went to the guy's office hrs and he actually yelled at me when I had a question. Ignores emails. Very rude. Every one in the class tried really hard and everyone got C's or lower.

Worst professor I've ever had. Hardest class in rutgers. This was suppose to be my easy class, spent more time on HW then any other class. Midterm was easy but final was killer. Homework was also very hard. Everyone got C's and D's

DO NOT TAKE. For a class for nonmajors he made it absurdly difficult, even the TAs didn't kno how to solve the hw. Midterm was really easy but he made the final insanely hard. Almost everyone got a C, D, or F. The guy didn't teach, was very vague and confusing
ya so the midterm may be a joke but took care of it in the final and was a jerk when I asked to see my final..  he was just mad that I stopped going to his useless lecturess...

he goes over stuff kinda slow, which he thinks is good so we learn it better, but whatever, I can stay awake in the class and the midterm wasn't bad at all. what's with the mandatory office hours though?

Do not confuse this guy with the Matt Stone of South Park fame. He's considerably more intelligent, considerably more hot (think Matt Damon in Mr. Ripley), and considerably less straight. His boyfriend had better be gorgeous!
Exteremely bad. Could not explain clearly the basic concepts. Midterm was a joke.
No Comments
this guy is ****in hot. i suspect he's****as well. he's the real thing. people know this man's name far and wide. if you can take a course with him, do it. he's not a let down at all.

Prof. Boularias is refreshingly passionate. The material is definitely tough but very interesting and almost immediately applicable to turn into passion projects once you understand it. This class is labeled as an introduction but is far from a 101 in terms of difficulty. Brush up on your linear algebra, probability, and some calc. PARTICIPATE.

His care and dedication toward his students understanding is heartwarming. I've never had a professor who genuinely cares so much. His disappointment toward students who ask "how much of this do I actually need to know?" is sad to see. Free A but soooooo much learned. He even wrote a sweet "thank you" announcement at the end of the semester. â¤ï¸

The best professor I have had at Rutgers. Lectures are very thorough and he really strives to make everyone understand. Very kind professor who genuinely cares about his students. Group assignments are tough and include demos, but grading is lenient. Prof is very accessible on piazza/email. Overall, learned a lot in this class and would recommend.
he's very passionate about what he's teaching but i got bored in lectures sometimes. however, he's chill and exams aren't bad, neither are the projects/homeworks.

Very passionate in what he does. Some homework's were really tough but they're graded leniently if you can finish them. Final was extremely rough, but by then your grade should be able to tank it. Good person and great professor, you don't see many of people like him nowadays

Great lectures and really cares about his students. Will stop the class for any questions. Very passionate about AI and tells us about latest AI research. Can be challenging but grading is very lenient.

I took AI with Boularias in Spring 2024 - he teaches very well and answers too many students' questions, which caused him to speed at the end to finish all content. The projects were straightforward & informative. Midterm was easy, but the final was only about stuff fully covered in in-person lectures (not much in recitation/slides) - so attend!
Really good professor. The materials are pretty hard to understand, but the professor made it easy.

Professor Boularias is honestly one of the most caring, respectful, and thoughtful professors I have had at Rutgers. He makes classes interesting and will delve into questions to ensure that students understand the material. Always available for extra support and assigns difficult, but very interesting projects that will challenge your knowledge.

Professor Boularias really cares about his students learning the concepts for A.I. Take him if you can. He always answers questions and concerns on Piazza relatively fast. In addition, his grading for exams, hw, and projects is very lenient. His lectures are alright, if you attend every class and pay attention the class is manageable.

He is a really caring professor and truly wants you to understand the complicated material. Really easy midterm,. 1st HW and final project were a bit difficult. If you really are into artificial intelligence, you will look forward to the lectures. He has also mentioned the vast majority of the class typically receives an A or B. Take him!!

For a class as topic-heavy as AI, Boularias has consistently shown that he cares about his students. Responds very quickly to Piazza questions, HWs are graded generously (HW1 had an average >100%!), always asks if anyone has questions, reveals the topics b4 each exam, and is very knowledgeable and makes each topic fun to learn, even if it's hard.

An easy class where everything is doable within the deadline. Kind and approachable professor, who explains everything clearly. The professor is sometimes slow, as in he sometimes falls back in covering lecture topics.  All things said, grading was very lenient and there is a lot of extra credit so don't hesitate to take CS 520/440 under him.

The course is pretty simple and you just need to do the assignments properly, to ace in mid and end semester. The final project was good and you will learn a lot. The grading is very lenient, almost everyone in the class got an A. Would 100% recommend to take this course. He is very approachable and will give you enough time for everything.
Could improve upon his teachings. Exams are way easy
Best professor in CS ive had. Very helpful and wanted you to get an A. But youll have to work hard for it.

The class was great, though the lectures were very long and dense. The lectures were all recorded so it was easy to go back through and fully absorb them. Some of the topics are quite difficult, but the exams accurately reflected the content in the lectures. The projects are all group based and are graded quite leniently, though. Exams are tough

As a professor Boularias is just okay. His lectures can drag on, and very often he'll go over time. He repeats info a lot, which can be a good and bad thing. However, there is A TON of work outside of class. The amount of time it takes to do his HW and projects is enormous. You're also only graded on 4 things, but grading is *very* lenient.
BOULARIAS IS THE GREATEST OF ALL TIME

AI is hard. Professor Boularias makes it easy to understand. He never assumes that you know something prior and explains everything extremely thoroughly. He gives A LOT of extra credit in the form of completing assignments in Latex (which I highly recommend). I would say on top of his very generous curve, his grading is extremely lenient. 10/10

Prof. Boularias genuinely wants his students to learn. He is very accessible and responds in a timely manner across all channels. He also is willing to help you with your personal projects. The course is not easy but he is willing to help you at every step.

Great guy who goes the extra mile to teach. Not an easy course, but you learn so much and there's plenty of time for the homeworks and projects. He has office hours all of the time and everything is graded quickly. Seriously love this dude.

The stuff he taught is not that hard compare to the graduate level course but still the workload is pretty heavy. I love this professor while he is extremely caring and inspirational. He knows stuff and good at explaining them. He will take you there if you have no idea how the assignment and project works. Highly recommend!

It's rare to find a professor that genuinely wants you to succeed as much as he does. With the amount of time he makes himself available to you, it's completely on you if you can't grasp something. He wants you to take something away from this class. Cannot recommend him enough.

One of the best CS profs in the department. His exams and HWs are fair, and the two projects are not difficult and pretty enjoyable. He is really kind and made videos as well as held many office hours to make sure that no student was left behind. Would definitely recommend him.

Really nice guy and makes sure to truly help his students with any concepts, has plenty of office hours and also posts slides of lectures ahead of time. The projects and hw are all fairly straightforward and the exams are very fair.

Awesome Professor - clears up tough concepts (AI is tough in general...), makes sure everyone who's in lecture understands before he moves on, and sends rather helpful resources in his emails to ensure his students do well. The assignments were the biggest part of the grade which you should definitely not wait last minute to do.

Prof Boularias is a great instructor and takes genuine interest in ensuring that students learn. Lectures are heavy and require good math background. The Professor tries his best to make things easy to understand. There were 2 projects and no exams. Both projects were really interesting and a lot of work! Overall, great course if you want to learn.

This Professor really cares that you learn. The 3 hour class format can be tiring, but the best way to utilize his class is to ask questions when you think you are losing focus. He will make sure you are satisfied with the answer, otherwise he explains in a different way until you understand.

Extremely good guy, but unfortunately he might not be very clear in explaining things. Easy grader, will help you out and see to it you do well. If you don't mind learning most topics via other sources on net, take this class.
The most helpful professor I have come across. Definitely take his class
easy A but don't take him if you actually want to learn something
The class is graded on 2 assignments, 2 quizzes, 1 project, and 2 exams. The exams have almost no material to study and also the professor will put stuff not covered in class on the exam.

Might be the worst prof I have ever taken. Extremely disorganized, lectures were useless. Recitation was where you learned anything. He had no clue where the class was going and randomly one night at 1am dropped an announcement we had our final in a week. Do not take this professor.

Worst CS class ever taken. Man just rambles on while looking at one slide and expects us to know many things about other course despite the pre-req for 440. Lectures give no information, and the slides are 50-90 slides long with confusing information.

He never communicates, didn't give us any grades, gave ppl wrong grades from the same group with the same submissions(literally the exact same file), never responds to emails, never got feedback, his exam had questions and topics that he didn't cover, not a good teacher, and he changes the course structure without telling us anything.
bro just puts up slides and rants about this conference that he did in 1975 about Ai. no actual lecturing. learned everything by self-studying. super disorganized.

I won't be surprised if the only grade we got back was the final grade on our transcript. It seems like he doesn't have a proper plan for this class and is making up the syllabus as we go. His lectures have no substance, and the recitations are where you learn the actual content.

This class was the most disorganized class I had to take at Rutgers. Our final exam date was announced at 1AM one week before and it's in the middle of April instead of finals week!!! Now, we have no idea what the grade distribution will be. We are near the end of the semester and absolutely nothing has been graded & no date when they'll be posted.

The professor was so hilarious and funny! He accidentally sat down on the chair and almost fell down! The professor gave us books about machine learning. However, the quizzes were very hard and lot of writing, so I tried to use ChatGPT and answered questions. The oral exam was pretty easy, and the professor was helpful with my answers.

The course is very disorganized, and he never tells you what's happening in class, and won't make any announcements. He doesn't really teach the topics well, have to self study all of the topics. If you are taking his course, you have to attend his lectures and recitations to even know what's happening.

Took a Byrne Seminar on AI and ChatGPT, but it turned into a confusing philosophy lesson. The discussions felt like ramblings on unrelated topics. Despite the boredom, the course was a Pass/Fail, and I passed. Not what I expected, though. He seems to be a nice person, but I do not recommend him for any CS courses.

Simply put: do not take him. I worked hard in this class but he is a horrible professor. He turns all lessons into a philosophy lesson rather than teaching us what actually matters. You'll end up teaching yourself which is what I ended up doing and I still did not pass. Seriously ridiculous we pay for teachers who can't perform their jobs properly.
I mean he was not that bad. As long as you studied, went to lectures, and completed all the quizzes you should end up with a fairly decent grade.

Professor Kulikowski is a great professor, but he is horrible at lectures. Worst CS major lectures ever. Literally learned almost nothing from lectures. Homework and quizzes are hard. Do not take his section trust me.

He's AWFUL! He didn't teach anything during lectures; just went on about random stuff trying to be inspirational, didn't teach anything! Learned everything on my own. He didn't even cover course material we were supposed to cover like graph theory. Quizzes/tests were really hard; all he talked about was his research being an inspiration to us.
Boring, off-topic lectures. Learned more stuff in recitation. Overall course was very disorganized. Would not recommend

Don't ever take this class. He is incredible boring to listen to and not a single person in my class had any idea of what he was talking about. There is not a single thing you will learn in this class and the math he teaches is so bad that not even youtube videos can help

I cant really tell what I learned from this class, I thought the exams and quizzes were unfair, the professor is really nice but disorganized with giving assignments and timeline. Overall its an easy writing class but be warned this class can get at times math heavy which makes no sense.

This professor is so sweet and caring towards his students. He truly wants to help others and see that they succeed. The quizzes were easy as long as you had the books, and he understood that this class wasn't for computer majors so he took it easy on us and I feel like he graded more leniently because of it. An all around great person.

Weekly quiz on readings, few papers, a midterm, and a group project. The class is very straight forward meaning he'll tell you exactly what's expected. Even though the quizzes are on the reading, all you have to do is skim the passages he assigns. The course is designed for everyone to get an A. Take it and fill a bunch of SAS requirements too!

Very nice professor who really wants you to learn. Unlike some professors I've known, he takes the time out to know everyone in class (he memorizes every student of every class and where they sit). His homeworks are difficult - I've spent 20 hours on some assignments - but really reinforces what he is teaching. Awesome teacher.

Bottomline: Take this class only if you want a good grade. He doesn't put any effort into teaching.<B>         30-45 minutes of quiz per 3 hr lecture, which is a big waste of time. The quizzes require you to memorize rather than they testing your skills.                       <B>Project: Some students get A's by presenting fake projects!

an extremely helpful professor. though the topic is very hard, the professor tries the best to explain it to the class. no student will leave the class without little understanding. responds to questions, emails etc. available to answer the queries of students and a fair grader.

This will be one of the most difficult courses you will ever take. He moves through the material very quickly and admits his teaching is geared towards the top 5%. His notes are poor quality and hard to follow by themselves. And homework, quizzes, exams, very hard. But if you have the time, and the interest, no one will teach the material better.

Very good professor. Does not have set office hours so you will need to speak to him to make appts. Fair grader. Lots of homework, and these can be lengthy at times. However, you will know Numerical Analysis by the time you are done with the class.
lots of homework, but not so bad on the grading. learned a lot. was my favorite class this semester. never was bored. good teacher
Very Hard professor.  Avg for midterm was in the low 30's (out of 100).  Just makes exams way to difficult
he is the cutest old man!! the material was difficult and the book sucked so bad. and his lecture notes are so messy, but he is a very nice man and probably curves like crazy.

A LOT OF MATERIAL...His numerical analysis course is a crash course in several topics...the issue regarding the final is not what's on it...it's what's not going to be on it...and he goes really fast...

Succeeds in making the topics (Discrete Prob./Numerical Analysis) relevant to real-world useage.  Puts a heavy emphasis on students being able to generate clear, written descriptions of the concepts - which is much more helpful than other quizzes.  One of the best profs. in the CS dept at Rutgers.

I was cursed by a terrible 205 teacher, so this course may have been much harder for me than most, but this course was insanely difficult. Good teacher and at the time a GREAT T/A. Teacher was kind, helpful, and very understanding. It was just a difficult subject.
His lectures consist of him reading from the book. And his essay tests/quizzes were annoying.
Organized and knows how to explain complex topics in a simple way. He's respectful, helpful, and actually wants students to succeed. Highly recommend taking him.

He's a solid professor. You can tell he has experience in the CS workforce and isn't just another boring CS lecturer. He tries to connect the topics with either IRL applications or directly in CS which I appreciate a lot - it really helped me grasp the concept faster. If you take notes and watch the lectures, you should do well in this class.

I took 206&210 w Blackmore. I highly recommend him. He makes content very easy to understand & curves generously, dropping lowest quiz, lowest hw & lower of 2 midterms! Also substitutes SIRS completion % w the last hw. 210 lecture was difficult bc of poor acoustics & a kid who often disrupted the flow. By October 90% of students were not attending.

Most of the material in the course was straightforward and there weren't any trick questions. I didn't like how all of his exams had strict grading criteria. There was no partial credit for answering any questions, so the average score for his exams were pretty low. Thankfully, he curved the class a lot.

He is a really caring professor who always responds to emails and provides many ways to improve your grades. There are 5 projects (lowest dropped), 5-6 quizzes (lowest dropped), 2 midterms (lowest dropped), and a final. Overall, it is a relatively easy course with this professor but get ready to teach yourself everything.
The professor is sweet but the course no matter the teacher is terrible.

His lectures are the most mind-numbing I have ever attended. His teaching skills reflect his 25-year absence from academia. Avoid taking any classes with him; you will gain nothing from them. You would gain more by watching a random Python tutorial on YouTube than by spending a semester attending this man's lectures.
Great Professor! Extremely concise and easy-to-follow lectures + many opportunities to earn points, wants every student to get an A!
Professor Blackmore is a very kind and chill person. He wants you to succeed and gives plenty of opportunity to do so. If you see him for CS classes, please take.

Incredibly generous grader and seemed to be in his element even in online lectures. Lowest quiz and homework grades were dropped and so so so many extra credit opportunities were presented. Please take a class with him when you get the chance

He makes it pretty easy to get an A. 75% of your grade was made up from HW, projects, and extra credit, which you can submit multiple times before due date and pretty much get a 100% on them. The exams are pretty hard, but you are allowed a cheat sheet. He is very lenient, you need to study on your own, the lectures give high level ideas.

Intenseâ€”3 papers per week, approx 10 1-paragraph responses per paperâ€”you WILL learn. Readings were thought out: from technical to ethical/philosophical. Martin was organized, friendly, passionate, funny, and very knowledgeable. 552 is seminar-style; discussions were very insightful and thought-provoking. One of the best classes and profs at RU!

Impossible to reach outside of class. Makes projects that should be relatively easy, practically impossible due to the fact that he won't provide any information on the testcases and the autograders constantly have problems. Exams are extremely easy, based off of the homeworks, cheat sheet allowed. 15% extra credit. Records the lectures.

Richard Martin gets a lot of hate on this platform. While I can't speak to his undergraduate experience, I can confidently say that Prof. Martin changed my outlook on computer science education. Great guy. Prof. Martin's seminar style classes are enjoyable and really educate you. Lots of papers to read, which definitely takes up some time.

This was actually the most boring professor I ever had. Somehow it felt like we were learning literally nothing in class but then the midterms were still hard. Also the recitation would often have identical material to the lecture.

An Easy A when all was said and done.
Avrged 40% on exams, still passed after curves. Coding projs are annoying but getting 100%'s is doable with "latest online tools". Quizzes are guaranteed 100%. Take advntge of EC
3 Exams,1 dropped: 40% | 4 Coding projects: 40% | Online Quizzes: 20% | Attendance: Up to 10% Extra credit for  (0.5% each lecture)

Professor Martin gets WAY too much hate. He has a very lenient grading policy (drops 2 homeworks, drops 1 exam), and offers so much extra credit that people could get an A while missing two of the three exams we had throughout the semester. If you're looking for an easy project-based class, definitely take Internet Technology with Professor Martin!

Before the ending of this semester this Professor had the record lowest rating in Rutgers at a 1.2/5. He gives 15% extra credit, 2 midterms and a final drop lowest. The only reason this prof was rated low: he is disorganized. Easy A minus the fact that he caught a lot of people cheating for a project that he did not have the auto grader working for

I'm not sure why most people are giving him a bad rating. Professor Martin was a very caring and sweet professor, lectures weren't organized, but he posted notes. Midterms were difficult, but he drops the lowest one. He gave 15% extra credit, which helped most people get an A without having to take the final. Overall, I recommend this class.

Nice guy, gives plenty of extra credit (up to 15% final grade) AND curves exams. Attendance was extra credit. Even drops lowest of 3 exams and lowest homework on top of that. Projects are short and allow a partner. The autograder had issues that took a while to fix, and writeups were not entirely clear, but he extended due dates to compensate.

I really enjoyed my time with professor Martin. A lot of people might have negative feelings due to the difficulties of midterms or assignments, but the professor was very lenient in grading (curve) and gave a gracious amount of extra credit.

I am glad he was my professor!

Project writeups are poorly written, professor is disorganized in general. Tests are very difficult, but he curves the tests. The projects, homeworks, and extra credit should be enough to get a good grade. The autograder for the projects is awful and seems to take credit off based on hidden criteria that it won't allow you to see.

This guy is a terrible professor. 1 star rating average for good reason. Do not take this guy. I should have heeded reddit's warning when people from more than 2 years ago were saying to completely avoid this guy. A lot of people cheated in this class this semester (for good reason, this guy teaches horribly). Take this class with someone else.

Weekly online HWs (20%), moderately easy, 3 in-person exams (40%, only top 2 count), 4 Python projects (40%). Projects are bad because his autograders are broken. Exams are hard, but he does allow 1 page cheat sheet. Reads off of slides during lectures but offers 0.5% extra credit for each lecture attended for a max of 10%. Final is MC. Easy!

Pretty chill professor just very disorganized with the assignments and his autograders never worked the first few days the assignment was released. The midterms are fairly hard but has a great curve. Attendance is extra credit, easy A if you do good on the assignments, pick a good partner.
pretty chill class. lectures are not useful but attendance is just for extra credit. projects are easy and curve on exams is massive.

I have genuinely no idea why his ratings are so low. This semester was not nearly as bad as I was expecting. There were a couple minor issues with some of the project directions, but overall lectures were interesting and grading was generous. The biggest criticism I have is some of the material was 20+ years out of date
IF YOU READ THIS. JUST GO BACK AND CONSIDER ANOTHER CLASS IF YOU POSSIBLE. THERE IS ALWAYS REASON "THIS THING" GET LESS THAN 1.5/50

Only professor I've had that was so awful I had to write a RMP review. Doesn't respond to questions for weeks+ at a time, if he responds to them at all. Doesn't follow his own syllabus, has a huge percentage of questions on the homework that are incorrect, assigns the final project a week before the final exam. If you can handle the stress, easy A.

He is absolutely the worst professor I have ever had in the CS department at this university. He is very unorganized when assigning projects and hws. His assignments are riddled with typos, missing diagrams, and wrong answers. You can easily tell he also does not communicate with his TAs as they are left confused as their response conflicts w/ his.

literally the most disorganized professor I have ever. He had ignored any emails or attempts to contact him for over a month from all students. forgot to assign three major assignments and then assigned one with less than a week to go of the semester.
Very disorganized projects, constantly changing criteria. Homework every week. Low final percentage. Overall not a bad class if you stay on top of things, but it needs to be more organized.
This dude is a terrorist. Stay away from this guy.
He uses a book for dummies, which is good because I am a dummy. It was very helpful for me to better understand the class, and I got way better and passed the class.

Class itself is not overly difficult, and while the project was entirely unorganized, it was an easy assignment. However, Richard Martin as a professor is terrible, he often does not understand his own slides and skims over material which is important for the class, is hard to reach, bad during office hours, and gives wrong/contradicting answers.

This class is a joke. Hard to take it seriously when the professor doesn't either. Lectures are very dry and the projects are completely unrelated to what is taught in the lecture. Recitations are useless.
Worst CS class I ever took at Rutgers, had to teach myself ALL of the material

Doesn't know anything about what he's teaching. Switched all assignments to Python, despite the fact that he doesn't know it and that none of his resources are for Python. Exams are really hard and random, even with a cheat sheet. His practice exam solutions are also consistently incorrect. He makes many mistakes when grading things, and is slow.

Believe me, Martin is lucky to get a 1.3. To be honest, .5 would be his highest score. I have never seen a professor acting so careless. He had no idea about the lecture topic in class. Midterms were just copies of previous exams, assignments were Python, which we never learned in class. Don't ever take his class, you'll be ruined.
He gave us cough drops and water during the final exam, just in case you wanted to "drop out"
Awful professor. I got more out of YouTube videos about IT than I did out of Richard Martin. I would give him a 0/5 if I could.

Projects and exams are often simple but this professor creates a lot of confusion due to his personal lack of knowledge or care for the class/subject. The best way to do well is to review past exams and the concepts in them. You'll be more successful consulting other students than going to office hours.
All around just a horrible professor. I've never seen someone care as little about doing their job as this guy (at least not without being fired, but that's academia for you...)

So unprepared for lectures and doesn't explain concepts well at all. Projects are poorly worded and solutions for practice exams can be very inaccurate. Textbook is somewhat helpful but has a lot of irrelevant info. Subject itself isn't bad but if you want to do well be ready to spend a lot of time figuring out what this guy is talking about

Easily one of the worst professors I have had. Do not take him, his classes are extremely disorganized and his power point slides are awful. He cannot even answer questions regarding his assignment directions until after the grades have been given back which is of no help at all.  I was really excited about Internet Technology, but yikes.

Spends every lecture going "uhh okay so what's this?... right okay" while looking at the powerpoints (which were pretty much taken from the textbook, literally) then just reads the slides. No guidance on projects, good luck with those. Exams are the only saving grace because a lot of the questions are copied from old exams, which he provides.
Extremely unorganized. Learned nothing from the class.
absolutely horrendous

Honestly, the worst CS professor at Rutgers. Maybe once in a blue moon you'll get something out of this guy that's relevant to what's assigned for the projects and exams. Reads straight out of his slides he photocopied from the book. Please avoid at all costs. Could not be organized to save his life, not even the TAs could get a hold of him.

It was a good course for researchers. He talks about published research papers from different domains which helps you to get a broad idea about research areas. It had a project as well that helps you to do something from scratch. If you properly utilize it then you could be able to publish a research paper.

lecture is reading slides & not are related to any project and HW. there's 3 project that is cumulative meaning if you fail the first part then you are most likely to fail the rest. no point in the course you are taught on how to write socket code. first project had 100% fail rate. overall the worst class in RU. don't take

THE WORST professor I have had at Rutgers. The class should also be updated. He switched the course project this semester (unsure why), and maybe two groups got it working. The project description was ambiguous, explanations he gave were worse. TA's did not help.

Not the worst professor I have taken at Rutgers (don't know why the reviews are so  bad). The topic is interesting to me and the project was also pretty interesting (we had to create a reliable transfer protocol). Did not answer emails so that was a bit annoying. Tests weren't extremely difficult since they were based on the study guide.
Ruined my interest in learning about networking. Was never helpful, and never replied to emails. Didn't seem to have put any interest or effort into the course. Very sad

Although the class material is interesting, Martin does not fail to suck the life out of you during lecture. He makes it obvious that he does not want anything to do with this course. The project was thrown at us with no help or supported readings at all. Hand down this was the worst Professor I have had at Rutgers.
Dont take

RIGHT, so -- we can only assume the guy realized the day before the first day of classes he needed to put together an entire curriculum, so he simply lifted every PowerPoint and exam from the ancient archives of Mario Szegedy. Lectures were completely useless and exams and projects were entirely detached from anything he had ever said.
This class is so awful it's made me question my life decisions in retrospect
Terrible professor, terrible assignment, terrible class. Do not take with him.

This was pretty much the worst class I took at Rutgers. Martin mumbles and when asked, never answers a question properly. His lectures have almost nothing to do with exams which are just old recycled exam questions. No one in the whole class had a working final project. When 100% of the class can't do something, its the teacher's fault.

Very clearly an inexperienced professor, not a great teacher just reads from the slides. You will learn more self-studying. Having said that, this course with him is the easiest A in the computer science department, the exams and homework assignments are very easy as long as you somewhat know what you're doing.

This course requires a lot of self-directed learning. The lectures primarily involved reading directly from the slides, so independent study is essential. However, the content itself is fairly straightforward.
Take if you're a self-learner and want an easy class. Extremely nice TAs with lenient grading. Might not learn much if you don't force yourself to but relatively easy to get a decent grade
He needs to be more experienced at teaching. I feel as if the TA's know more than him for midterms/final. A lot of people stopped showing up due to the lack of good teaching.

Professor does not seemed like an experienced, prepared lecturer. At times it seemed like the TAs for this course were running the class. Many of the lectures were incomprehensible at times, but much of the content he used was made accessible and the assignments, homework, and exams were easy to complete using his resources. Overall, easy A.
I did not get much out of the course; seemed like the professor was just winging it and using other people's slides. Low-effort.

With only two homework assignments, no mandatory attendance, and no project, students can take the lecture online and open-book exams with nearly no time limit. Only spend very little time on this course and get an acceptable grade.
Very clear lecture, and easy to earn high grade.

I would have given him a 1, but he is a fairly nice professor who usually listens to student requests. Other than that, the entire course is difficult and a mess. The professor reads off lecture slides copied from a CMU course, and is very bad at communicating. He changes the syllabus without notice, and his exams and projects are very difficult.
He is a really good professor who tries his best. As long as you put in the effort you should pass

He was so sweet. It felt like he really cared about his students enjoying the material and he wanted you to feel accepted in his class, and I think that is an uncommon trait in CS courses. Given that I had previous experience with CS, I can't speak to his teaching ability in a way that others may. But I think at times he missed some key points.

Pretty cool guy, always answered questions and made sure you understood the topic, and would always offer to spend more time on a topic. He was helpful with feedback. He tried to crack some jokes here and there, so it wasn't a snoozefest

Milonas is a nice, helpful guy. Going to lecture would probably help for more understanding because some of the Comp Apps content is really tricky, but I only went sometimes and still got an A. The class itself involves a lot of assignments, 3 exams, and some extra credit. You have to put some work in, but use your TA's (!!) and you can get an A.

Not hard, but I had Professor Centeno for 1 lecture when he was out and understood more in that one lecture than I did in any lecture in his class. I found he liked to just ramble and then forget what he was talking about, and lecture is just him reading off slides. Be prepared to learn most of the work on your own or with your TA in recitation.
Professor Francisco is a mixed bag - his lectures can be boring, but he's still a knowledgeable and accessible prof. Using unstuck study and the free textbook helped me prepare for his tough exams.

So far the most boring professor I've ever had. Francisco is very lecture-heavy and uses a very mundane and inefficient way of note-taking, it is nearly impossible not to fall asleep while watching this guy lecture. Assignments are straightforward however his tests are tough. Just avoid taking this professor at all costs.

Less work and cool guy, but he is so disorganized. He did not put in the final grades into Canvas or tell us what the grade cutoffs are but he did put in grades into the transcript, I don't even know what I got on my final. These good reviews were written by him. If you like going crazy over your grades and worrying during the holidays, take him!

Honestly, if you chose not to attend franny's lectures, you're really missing out. Great guy, really knows what he is talking about, funny guy, easy assignments (3 v.s 5) and midterm, avg final. It kinda pains me to see franny leave, another great prof leaving this shoddy cs department, but he's off to bigger and better things. Overall 10/10 tbh

Terrible lecturer. The lectures were boring and hard to follow. He's really bad at explaining concepts. The assignments weren't too bad, but the exams were pretty difficult. Pretty accessible outside of class. Nice guy tho, just bad at teaching.

Prof. Francisco is just a goat. I'm not sure if it was because he is leaving after this semester :( . But he gave us easier assignments(normally gives a 6 phase bomb lab, but gave us 3), and most profs give 5 assignments, Franny gave 3. Gave us bonus points on our final as well, has a quirky sense of humor. Very smart. Easy midterm, average final.
Very bad

I did not enjoy my time with Professor Francisco. His quirkiness made it very difficult to interact with him and ask questions to him. He  gave an exam everybody struggled on. The only reason I am not doing bad in his class was because I self studied C before attending lecture. I have not learned anything from hhim.

His lecture style is horrendous, he barely showcases the content of the class well and uses a text editor for everything. But while he is a terrible lecturer, the class is very easy, Francisco only gave three assignments and they barely required any coding. The midterms are horrible though, everyone struggled on them. Easy A or B though.

Franny is the goat and an L at the same time. lectures are boring af and basically pointless for most ppl. Recitation is 10x more useful and easier to learn. Optional recitation attendance was good. Surprisingly gave only 3 Assignments and the exams were pretty awful but they don't account for as much as the assignments & hw. Overall class was easy

Came in scared for my life, came out knowing that this was a blessing in disguise. Francisco is amazing! Engaging lectures, funny man. Every time I walked into that lecture hall it was as if my life goal was computer architecture. Super easy assignments, joke midterm, but moderately difficult final. Caches kind of rushed though. Overall a pleasure!

As other reviews have put it, JAF has (seemingly) stepped up this semester. MUCH less focus on C but in trade for much more emphasis on assembly and general architecture (e.g caches); few HWs that were all easy, but exams still required decent knowledge. All in was fair and fun even with the various quirks.

Came in upset I didn't get Huang - heard he was the "good" prof for 211. Couldn't have been more wrong. We got easier assignments and hws, tests were a bit tricky: midterm avg was 65, final was 54. Decent curve: 86 was an A, 79 a B+. Found the content tedious but still think JAF is awesome. Familiarize yourselves with 24hr time and counting from 0!

Professor Francisco is clearly a passionate, intelligent prof. His lectures are decent and he seems nice. However, he is very disorganized, and his quirks create a communcation barrier. Assignment instructions were very unclear, which made the course more stressful than needed. Overall, this professor does not inspire confidence in his students.

He gave 3 assignments (compared to Huang's 5/6 assignments), so if you like doing assignments, don't take him. The assignments were really easy (one of them was literally 3 lines) and he gives extra credit. Tests are kind of hard so make sure you study for them. I would recommend going to lecture but it is kind of boring.

tbh the tests are kinda obscure knowledge of what he goes over in class, but he does go over it. he teaches everything pretty well. caused some confusion on one assignment, but he made sure to make up for it by giving like 4 extra days to do it. 21 points of extra credit available for us (like an additional 3% to your total grade).

DO NOT LISTEN TO THESE REVIEWS. Something I've noticed about students here is that they do not want to put in the effort but still expect an easy A, which this class is. Everything is covered in class. He can be a bit disorganized (assignment descriptions messed up occasionally, but were easy) but he is overheated. 

Easy A, just put the effort in.
An unorganized terrible teacher doesn't provide any study guides or practice exams, his lecture notes are horrific. Also, the dude is left in the early 2000s he needs an update.

Never seen a more controversial RMP professor -- how do the older posts have up to 170 dislikes? Coming in was concerned, but he seems to have changed in that the course is easier. He def has a few quirks -- Notepad++/paint in lectures, miscommunication between TAs, etc., but nothing so bad that the course was heavily affected. Knowledgable & cool.

Best thing about the prof is his teaching style. He starts with a question, establishes a simple concept, goes on building over it to teach the actual complex concept. Step by step ez pz. Some concepts that he discusses in the class that are not in the slides will show up in exams. So make sure you attend all his lectures. I think he is cool.

Probably the worst CS professor. Projects and assignments were worded VERY POORLY. Lecture were okay. Would make major projects and homework assignments due on the same day. Very annoying about extensions when everyone needed one citing the next assignment would come out the following day, but never did. Came out two weeks later.Avoid at all costs.

Contradictory to many reviews here, I found JAF pretty amazing. His lectures were well planned and his teaching was cohesive. Exams and assignments were based on his lectures, so if you attend them you are good to go. He was flexible with his grading and the course was informative yet challenging. 10/10 would take again.

He's living in the past. Python 2? The iLabs have Python 3. Can't record lectures being a CS prof. when people may be sick. Lectures were fine, I guess. Lecture slides are stolen from another prof. and aren't that helpful. Would go really fast sometime. Avoid if you can, but he's good enough if you want an easy class. Not good if you want to learn.

I think he gets a bad rap. I liked his lectures and they weren't really disorganized. I think 314 was handled weird this semester though since some of the assignments were suspiciously easy; like a 100pt project that took 15 minutes to do and get 100% on. Grading was slow though and w/o clear test cases I couldn't tell if I did assignments right.

He is a smart guy and knowledgeable but he is not a good prof. We were supposed to have 5 programming assignments but he only gave us 3. Even though programming was 50% of the grade. Assignments were very hard. I asked him to open previous quizzes to study for finals and he said "I don't want you to see the right answers. " AVOID HIM !!!!

More then 80% of our final was comprised of material we spent 2 weeks on at the beginning of the semester. Don't expect emails/Piazza questions answered in an orderly time and don't expect any transparency as your final grade will probably just be a mystery box surprise. This is the first time I have ever felt scammed out of a good grade.

Francisco gets a bad rap. Yea his lectures are tough to follow a bit, and the grading is incredibly slow, but go to his office hours. He's a great guy and fun to talk to, not to mention incredibly helpful! I enjoyed him alot.

If I had a choice I would not have taken this class but Francisco was the only professor teaching systems programming. I have learned that Francisco is a terrible teacher. His lectures are bland, complicated, and uninteresting. Your assignments, exams, and projects aren't graded till 2 days after the semester ends. He is also very pretentious.

Francisco is easily the worst professor at Rutgers. I have unfortunately taken him for 3 separate classes (due to scheduling). His ego is a problem despite a lot of his knowledge on the CS he teaches being from the 90's and he clearly doesn't keep up. In his class its his way or no way, he refuses to work with students and takes no responsibility.

Pretty decent guy. Terrible professor. If ur taking 214 get ready to spend 90% of your time on the projects that youre going to ask for a regrade for anyway because they are poorly graded. Wack ass TAs and management of the course too

I firmly believe that taking a class with Franny is an essential part of the Rutgers CS experience. The sheer amount of disorganization from the lectures to the project grading is unbelievable at times and perfectly encapsulates the program as a whole. The man is a walking meme.

He has great lectures, just disliked because 1. unclear/difficult projects and 2. slow grading. The latter causes a lot of stress for you near the end of the semester, but usually grades come through. This semester we pulled in the dean to intervene after a certain incident happened, so perhaps this class is getting better. Only take if necessary.

Good lecturer, awful at everything else. Gives vague project directions. Messed up the testcases and had to not count some in the end. Takes an OBSCENELY long time to grade projects. Grades projects incorrectly until asked for a regrade. Teaches FALSE things, e.g. "realloc is unreliable" that are easily verified to be untrue w/ Google! AVOID!

THE MOST UNPROFESSIONAL PROFESSOR EVER. There was a transition to remote instruction is the middle of the semester and after that things get atrocious. NEVER reads piazza, NEVER replies emails, and NEVER gives out a grade for a past project. The semester has already ended and we don't even know our grade for a assignment given out two months ago.

Terrible, just terrible. Avoid this man at all costs. Let's just say that I didn't know my grade even after taking the final and i can't even approximate where im standing. Projects are so vague and TAs aren't any help.
My favorite professor thus far as a rising junior. Goes over all material 2 or 3 times and I learned a lot. Super knowledgeable, but his projects are hard.
Worst CS professor taken in Rutgers. Boring lectures, uselessnotes, confusing assignment guidlines. Did not learn anything useful from this class. AVOID.

Worst professor at Rutgers. If you dare to take his class, you're in for a wild ride. Useless notes, unclear guidelines, ignores student questions, and GRADING TAKES ABSOLUTELY FOREVER. He's pretty inconsiderate when you think of all that he demands from us as students vs what he gives us as a professor. AVOID.

The class material wasn't bad at all, but man, Francisco is the most disorganized professor I've ever had. He certainly knows his stuff when lecturing and is charismatic, but I've had enough of his cryptic instructions, unresponsiveness w/emails, and the fact that it takes AGES to get any grade back, even for the smallest assignments. avoid

Avoid this man at all costs, you will walk out of every lecture not learning anything new every single time. You're basically teaching yourself at this point. He's a smart guy and knows what he's talking about but he legitimately cannot teach. The good thing about him is his personality isnt bad I guess? Just avoid.

There are too many problems to outline in the few characters that I have so I will touch on the worst one which is the lack of useful slides to learn from outside of lecture. I would have much preferred having actual content on slides or text files rather than just a list of terms that I have to google and teach myself what they mean/do.
He is the best professor in Rutgers

This professor is notorious here. He is good at making jokes, but his lecture , homework and exam are also jokes. When you ask him questions, he always ignore your specific question, and try to tell you his stroy, which is really annoying and confusing. Anyway, avoid him.

I had him for OS(416) and it was my worst experience in all of Rutgers. If you can, avoid at all costs. His lectures are long, dry, and soft-spoken. Decent slides? That's about the nicest thing I can give him. His assignments and exams are completely unreasonable. The final in particular was asking about space stations. in a comp sci class

He really knows his stuff and made the class interactive by asking countless questions. He was also hilarious and his use of MS Paint makes the class even more fun. He also has this metal poking thing that he uses to wake students up in his class. I don't know about other classes, but he was great for data structures.
He is kind of disorganized but he teaches the material pretty well. There was a problem with the new assignment set which caused a lot of problems, but it wasn't his fault
I like Francisco, I enjoy his lecture. He is funny and nice!
If you value your sanity, don't.

His lectures were good and I learned a lot. The basic idea for the projects were good for teaching the material. HOWEVER he was extremely disorganized. The autograders were entirely dysfunctional, and although he was good at teaching material he was not great at answering questions. The exams were fairly easy if you went to lectures.

Francisco has this sort of God-Complex where he thinks he's the Savior of the Computer Science Department when in actuality everyone just thinks of him as an incompetent NEET who's degrees have long expired.

Think he's slick ripping off his students. Has managed to screw up every single grading rubric on all 4 projects. Gives false information during office hours. Somehow manages to blame the TAs for his "worst semester in 20 years". School only keeps him for his IQ-too bad his IQ doesn't stop him from being the biggest mistake in the CS department.
Although seemingly funny, actually unorganized, unreliable professor, really regret to take his course.

The professor is good. I realize it's not a popular opinion but the way in which I learn matches with his way of teaching well. I reached out often as I could to get a better understanding of the material and as long as your questions are intelligent you have a good shot at getting intelligent answers in return. Grading criteria can be unorganized.
Never take this professor's class, he is really unorganized everything, I really wish never see him again, one of the poorest professors in CS, RUtgers! Remember never take his class!

CSV sorters, unclear project descriptions, unreasonably strict grading for exams and TAs who consistently grade your project wrong are what you get with this class. Prepare to email TAs and the professor regularly. The content isn't hard, it's made hard through the unorganized nature of the professor and TAs themselves. I regret taking this class.

He's a pretty good teacher. The material he teaches is super interesting and his tests are straight forward if you go to every class. His TAs this year are a mess and I feel like they aren't on the same page as the professor in grading. Overall, really enjoy the class and the projects are okay if you have a good partner to start with.

If you don't take notes in class, you're screwed. Seriously, this guy posts his notes after class, but it's like trying to decipher hieroglyphics. He can make people laugh in class sometimes, but it's not funny when midterms are in 2 weeks and you have no idea what to study. He also announces his submission criteria in-class 3 hours before its due.

This was the worst experience I have ever had in a classroom. This experience actually ended my pursuit of a cs degree at Rutgers. It was impossible to complete assignments as a result of the lack of structure this professor had in class. He had not started any real material until three weeks into class and an assignment was due already. Avoid!

He relies heavily on lectures to spread any useful knowledge, but it is impossible to acquire this knowledge elsewhere. By this I mean if he explains that to complete your current project you need to use "this function", you have no way of knowing that any other way than from him. Avoid this teacher at all costs.a

The prof. knows the subject, however, his teaching is completely unorganized. Assignments were filled with mistakes and some were never taught on how to do them. He put things on the exam that were taught after they were taken, first grades were received after 3 months(last month of class), and his lectures are very unfocused.
Simple material, but he simply cannot teach. Had to rely on Youtube videos for 90% of his lecture material. Messes around way too much in lecture.

I have had the 'pleasure' of having him for three different classes within the Computer Science curriculum. He is an absolute brutal teacher. He spends more time horsing around during lecture than teaching and he is overlaps his graduate level class slides with undergrad classes. There is nothing favorable or honorable about this guy. Avoid.

He slacks on his lectures and then expects you to have expert knowledge and write these heavy code projects which make up 50% of your grade. Wouldn't recommend. Take Andrew Tjang if you can. Heard he was awesome.

He initially gave me a D but after he acknowledged the mistake he gave me a B+. While the class was disorganized, I really enjoyed having him as a professor. He did really well for teaching 4 different CS classes in one semester. He always answered student questions and was always more than willing to help. He's a nice, brilliant professor.

Lied multiple times about dates we would receive grades. Unaware of his actions: During tests would make jokes while students were cramming to finish, he would type things on the screen stating facts like the percentage of code similarity among the class like that's something you really want to know about while doing his impossible tests.

This was the poorest ran class I have ever taken. There is literally zero structure to the course. The assignments are always filled with mistakes which aren't resolved until late. No grades for months . Honestly the professor is in his own world and doesn't understand the way he handles the course is causing stress to his students.

He will not tell you what test cases your code needs to run on. Although class is not mandatory, he will state certain things only during class. He will not explain how the code is supposed to function in depth. Assignments depend on previous ones, so if you couldn't do the previous one, then you will not be able to finish the current assignment.

Terrible at explaining concepts and put material on the midterm that he hadn't even taught yet. He went over that material after the midterm. You're better off self-teaching yourself than going to lecture.

Prof. Francisco thoroughly teaches a very difficult/complex subject. I really like the slow pace of the lectures, as he rarely misses even small details with all the examples, but some people get bored and prefer faster pacing. Projects are extremely tough/tedious, but are also quite useful for real-world interviews/applications. Intense challenge.
10/10, would not recommend

assignment descriptions are so convoluted it's insane, he's (kinda) funny but doesn't explain stuff well, responds to questions horribly, takes forever to grade(seriously, 2 months into the course we had 0 grades). time-consuming assignments up until the last day. take someone else
CS214 He seemsto be making this class entertaining and the lecture notes don't match what you will learn in class.
This man is a god among mortals

Before I took this class, I thought I loved systems programming and wanted to go to grad school for it. After this class, I never want to touch C again. Instructions for the group projects were unclear and contradictory, and we did not get feedback for the last two assignments until the end of the semester. Exams were open-ended and tangent-based.

This guy is a meme lord but other than that i didn't really enjoy his class.  Ended up with my first D grade in all of college, high school, and middle school lol but it was mostly my own fault.  His sakai notes are complete garbage and his laptop keys didn't even work so he couldn't type anything properly.

This is the hardest class I have ever taken in Rutgers. In the end, I'm just happy I can pass. Be aware of the assignments, they are way too hard. Overall, Francisco is a good person, but he is not a good professor, at least on OS. Take OS with another professor. I really had no interest in C or in systems at all after this class.

Overall, he's a very average professor. The assignments/exams themselves (excluding string sort) are difficult and time-consuming, and it doesn't help that C is not a very user-friendly language. The first half of the course covers C, so if you know C you should only pay attention in the second half of the class. Gives vague advice in office hours.

Group projects which can be good or bad for you. First three projects are all easy, but the last will make you work for it. Tests aren't bad and are all based on content covered in lectures. If you're familiar with C, you probably don't even have to show up until after the midterm.

Well, like 4 of his keys on his laptop are broken, so while typing lecture he once said "pretend this d is an a" and preceded to have a bunch of d's everywhere. He's kinda all over the place, and his lecture notes really are not helpful. It's hard to prepare for exams since it's basically a guessing game of what will be on it. Projects are lengthy.

He makes you pay attention by selecting random students to answer random questions. He is extremely vague both in lecture and for assignments. He expects perfect assignments yet the descriptions for them give you almost nothing to go off of. He also assigned a project over spring break and wondered why most people couldn't work on it.

Friendly and willing to help out, especially if you have no experience in computer architecture. Speaks a little quietly in lectures, but always willing to repeat himself or elaborate. Homeworks are ridiculously difficult and impossible to do without lots of extra research. Exams are difficult, memorize all slides and lecture notes.

Very bad class experience. He is low on volume, give insensible homeworks,and horrible. He thinks students should learn everything and come to his class. The homeworks are so tough that the class could never complete the. The teacher has hubris and is not at all a good teacher. Its tough to LEARN in this class, you should be a pro already.

He's extremely likeable as a person (not to mention, attractive), but somewhat disorganized as a lecturer. If you took 211 before, the first month or two of lecture is very redundant. 50% of your grade is group projects, which are graded by a script that often gets things wrong: quickly learn how to appeal your grades. Read his good online notes!

Professor retaught CS211 for  most of the first part of the semester. Gave out programming assignments that were unclear. He wouldn't clarify it until close to the assignment due date. He also likes to call students out when they are not paying attention.

He is a good systems professor. He helps you a lot in office hours so be sure to go. Class itself was pretty boring, but that is probably because the subject is boring itself. Very reachable by email. Just be sure to sit in the front because he is hard to hear in the back and he speaks very quickly.

JAF is a quite professional, but his voice is too low and always speaks so fast that you'll find it hard to catch with him . His grading is not so strict, if you do your best in his class, you'll finally get a good grade.
Great professor. Great person. Would take again! Projects are fair, as is the grading.
He always answered student questions thoroughly and was available for office hours whenever needed. He liked to make us think for ourselves and gave  fair exams.

Francisco is a good lecturer, he definitely enjoys the material and is pretty funny during class.  He spent a lot of time in class to go over the assignments, and have out extensions generously.  Office hours were flexible and easy to arrange.  Only negative was that he was slow to post notes and exam grades.

Francisco only taught 2 of the sections for the class, and although we did the same projects we ended up severing ties with the main class because of the way Francisco taught. We spent many a lecture just discussing our projects, and he was very helpful in that regard. However, his lecture were awkward to learn from so I learnt a lot on my own.

John Austen was very fair, gave excellent preparatory tools for his exams, made himself available to give guidance on projects, and did his best to aid in student learning by reviewing every important piece of information in review sessions before each class.  You would have to try if you wanted to do poorly with this guy.   Also, awesome shirts.

Not for the faint of heart. Difficult subject, difficult teacher, but if you put your mind to the material and work your tail off you'll be able to knock out a very solid grade as well as learn the material very well. He rushes through material rather quickly, so going to class and paying attention are musts.
Very reasonable grader, helpful during office hours and during lecture. Our final project was due the day of the final, which was absolutely nuts.

He says, "It's a great day for computer science" everyday when it's clearly not. He gets every single thing wrong and doesn't know computer science. Our students always correct him. He has too much pride in his PHD degree which I clearly don't know how he got cause he sucks at computer science. He probably got it in another subject.

Highly disorganized - can't figure out how to use Sakai properly, and grades are always extremely late. Goes off on tangents and rambles during lecture. Makes easy material feel harder than it needs to be. Grading is unnecessarily harsh - a third of the class dropped out, and they weren't even factored in to the final curve.
Just take him if you want an easy class.

The class was pretty decent. He said attendance was mandatory but didn't end up factoring it into our grades at the end of the semester. His lectures are really helpful, but unfortunately really dry. He responds to emails quickly. This is a class that does require quite a bit of work outside of lectures as it was synced across the CS department.

Professor Bittner was a great professor, especially for his first semester teaching here he dealt with everything like a champ. Although I was skeptical at first when he was announced as our replacement, I enjoyed his lectures and he is very strict about the grading policy but overall is a laid back person.

Bittner is one of those professors who I find to be hard to listen to during class, but he is great at helping you when you confront him with questions/concerns after class or during office hours. He's a lenient grader that helps with regrading or fixing any problems on the assignments/exams and is very generous with giving points.
Good dude, easy prof.

bittner was definitely very nice, but he did not know anything. i asked him very basic questions multiple times, but he was never able to answer it. his exams and psets were pretty easy, but i had to teach myself everything for this class. kimberly brehm was the savior.

Hes a nice guy. The class is easy because the classwork is easy and you get a while to do it. His lectures were very boring. You honestly just have to self learn. But at the end of the day, if you want extra points, he will hook you up.

Honestly wasn't a bad professor, but the teaching materials he would use often had mistakes or sometimes he had difficulty explaining things in terms of the way the textbook powerpoint would show. Great dude, easy to talk to, just bad luck in terms of the overall class experience.
lectures are very clear. only graded by 2-3 assignments and the final group project. lenient grader and lots of opportunities for extra credit.

Course is structured around 2 homeworks (and an optional third) and a big group project that has a presentation and written element. Hao Wang was excellent at answering questions, and was very interested in the course material. I loved the final project because he basically just let us go wild, and do whatever we wanted.

I took Prof. Wang's Machine Learning course. He is a very knowledgable professor. His class was well-paced and he tried to cleared all doubts in class. Assignments are tough but very detailed, almost like a tutorial. Extra days and extra credit assignments are provided, to help with grades. Very interesting class with a good, practical curriculum.

This guy is the best professor I've ever had. His lectures are crystal-clear, and he's obviously passionate about the deep learning. He gives really great responses to questions, and office hours are always welcomed. If you take every lecture, then the homework are pretty easy. Would recommend him to anyone who has interest in AI.

My favorite professor, I've taken in the cs department so far. Although this course is rather complicated and demands high Maths foundations, professor Wang Hao always could find a concise and clear way to help us understand the formulas and applications. Four homework, a small final presentation, and a lot of extra credits.

Prof Wang taught me CS535 ML1, a challenging subject extraordinarily. His lectures are concise, yet covers the topics in great depth. Assignments are thought provoking and enjoyable. He is personable,patient and appreciates the unique problems of his students. He is one the most knowledgeable and humble people I ever met and strongly recommend him.

I think Dr. Wang is a nice and extremely knowledgeable professor - he's super responsive to emails and cares a lot about his students. IMO, the course would be better with slower lectures and assignments that are more thoroughly checked for bugs. But it's a new course, and Dr. Wang is open to feedback in my experience. BTW, go to recitations!

terrible professor, he just straight up doesnt care about students (wont properly address concerns and questions), lectures dont correspond with assignments, assignment has so many mistakes/typos that you literally need to make the question and then answer it yourself, useless prof, do yourself a favor and dont take hao wang for cs462 or any class

DO NOT TAKE THIS PROF.

assignments are impossible, lectures are incredibly hard to understand, and worst of all the professor doesn't seem to care when students try to bring up their concerns. 

STEER CLEAR!!!!!

I took this class as a senior in the Rutgers CS department, and bar none this man is the worst professor I have had. Mind you this is an incredibly high bar as we know many professors are geniuses but can't teach, but Hao Wang is probably the greatest example of this stereotype. He is an absolute genius (studied at MIT) but he is a terrible prof.
His lectures make little to no sense to us, and the assignments are impossible. I am not exaggerating when I say impossible, I literally mean they are not possible to complete as given.

She's really nice and stops to answer all questions. I had her when she was teaching 344 the first time and she didn't have any previous exams for us to practice. When we asked her for practice problems, she made them for every exam. She's accommodating and gave extensions when needed. Exams were bit difficult, but she was teaching the first time.
LEGEND LEGEND LEGEND!!!!
The 5.3/5 rating speaks for itself, even RMP can't handle how good this professor is
The curve is very reasonable. She records her lectures (which are pretty good). Only caveat with her is that she makes the exams very hard but gives a ton of extra credit on them so it balances out.

This was a very difficult class, but Gao gave a generous curve at the end. She is a very nice person and willing to help. I found the class fast paced and hard to follow, but I am grateful that she was understanding and receptive to student feedback throughout the semester.

Lectures were enough to give u the general idea of the subject but the hws were incredibly difficult in comparison (most likely because this was her first time teaching the undergrad version of algos she usually teaches the graduate version). With that being said gao graded very leniently and was very easy to approach for help

Reviewing for CS344. Not a bad professor, and by far the best thing was that she recorded her lectures for the entire semester. She also gives plentiful hints for homework assignments. On the other hand, this class is incredibly difficult. Homework takes up so much time and her exams are tough. Expect to work hard for a good grade in this class.

Incredible professor with extremely helpful lectures. The examples from lecture and homework problems serve as good examples involving the concepts from class. Professor Gao is also incredibly caring, as indicated by her grading and open-note exam policy, among others. I learned a lot in this class while finishing with above a 100%.

This was Gaos first time teaching undergraduate algorithms course (usually she teaches the graduate level) as a result the class was fast paced and incredibly difficult. With that being said Gao recorded lectures, allowed open note exams, and graded very leniently and generously.

This professor was soo nice. She was very easy to talk to and very understanding on your situation. When emailed she would try the best to figure out a good solution to help you. All in all a great and sweet teacher

Took CS344. 5-6 typed HWs (40%), Midterm (30%) and Final (30%). Midterm and final are open notes, but she switched to 5 pages printed rather than digital for the final. HWs are moderately difficult, but she grades very lightly, so a 90% average on HW is achievable. Records and uploads lectures. Gives hints for HWs on piazza and during exams.

She is so nice and always willing to give extensions on homework assignments. Grading on tests was also lenient and she was very generous with giving back points if there were ever mistakes on quiz or exam questions. She also answers emails very quickly and hosted an extra office hours before our final since a few students requested.

Actual best professor at rutgers. Take her any chance you get, so helpful on assignments, willing to regrade and look over any questions the TA's might have marked wrong. Wants to help you succeed and pass, very forgiving yet still learned a lot. Feel prepped for discrete 2, she is the absolute best and a gem in the cs department especially here.
W professor. Class itself is hard but she is amazing and sweet.

I took Discrete I Spring 2023. She gives weekly online quizzes that are open notes. There is only one midterm followed by the final, both of which are open notes. Recitation is optional; all the lecture material is posted online after class. The homework and quizzes will actually require reading/understanding the slides. Overall great professor

The best prof at rutgers. She is so sweet and caring, willing to help, and really wants to see the class do well. She extended homeworks and quizzes multiple times, explains things thoroughly and will go over something again if you ask. 11/10

Professor Gao is a nice professor, clear helpful slides, but her handwriting was very tough to understand. She quickly replied to emails and tried to help solve queries in office hours. Hard to understand her Discrete 1 especially HW, quizzes and midterms without prior outside class practice. Practice other than lecture or its hard to understand!!
Take Professor Gao for Discrete 1!! She was very easy and understanding of your needs. 4 hws, and 2 midterms + 1 final but it was very straightforward and as long as you study, you should be fine!!

Good teacher! She addresses questions and responds to emails fast. Make sure you read the textbook. Tho at times, she messed up Canvas quizzes and caused confusion with grading. Nbd tho, and overall a nice professor.

Professor Gao is a good professor across the board. She's nice, she quickly responds to emails, and puts effort in her concept explanations. She also responds well to questions or confusion. I only wish she provided more examples as Discrete 1 is kind of challenging to understand. Do practice problems outside of just her lectures.

Professor Gao is a great professor! She explains concepts really well, and is willing to spend time answering questions. She also responds to emails promptly. Her quizzes and homework sets are not too bad, and the midterm was a similar format to the homework sets!

Professor Gao is really good. She doesn't mind explain specific part multiple times during class or office hour. The homework sets are little bit hard but it won't be a problem if you start it early or go to her office hour. You can schedule extra appointments. She is kind cuz she dropped lowest quiz and gave extra credit.

Professor Gao was really understanding. My TA was a really harsh grader and I would go to the professor and she would personally regrade my assignments. I also had some tech issues and she was understanding of that too.

I had Gao for discrete 1. Overall she is a super sweet professor who will not mind re-explaining concepts to confused students. The material and psets are hard to understand but it is clear that she tries her best to clarify everything. She gave us extra credit and dropped our lowest quiz grade so I highly recommend
The notes barely help with the homework or the tests/quizzes because she only just reads off a powerpoint that only shows the worst examples. Try to get a different professor.

Oh my god. Terrible exam averages for an intro to python course and still thinks exams are easy. Provided 11% EC purely because of how many struggled, not because she believed the course was harder than previous sems. Projects are okay, can take 2-6 hours. 2 Midterms (12.5% each) hard, Final (20%) not bad. 4 Online Quizzes (20%), lowest dropped

Took her for Algorithms In Society in 2023. She invented the class and has many personal stories regarding her passion for the subject. Very knowledgeable. Kind of runs the class like her own personal psychology experiment. Unique projects. Surveys after each project and runs an "algorithm" to group the duds together(lol). So many fun moments.

The first two tests were rough, but Professor Marian made up for it with 11% extra credit and an easy final. Her lectures were chill, and the TAs were some of the best I've hadâ€”super helpful and knowledgeable. If you can handle a tough start, this class is fair and worth taking!
