This was one of the most disorganized and difficult CS classes I have ever taken. No study guides or prep until the final and even that study guide was way easier than the actual exam. We were given 11% EC to compensate, but doesn't justify what happened. We can't even ask for regrades on the final for points without risking losing more points.

She is a nice lady, but her exams were extremely difficult so be wary of that. She was very accommodating about the low exam scores and offered extra credit and very proactive, always responding to emails quickly. I would not recommend her for an intro course if you cannot learn on your own, but for more advanced courses she seems solid.

Her class is very well organized and structured. Her class can is definitely not an easy A but that challenge makes you learn a lot. Her accessibility both online and through office hours as well as clear and organized learning materials makes it a worthwhile learning opportunity.

I leave it as simple as it is for those of you who don't want to study don't take this class unless u have previous python experience. If you go to lecture its an easy A class, she tell u during the lecture of what can be on the midterm which 90% of time is on there. If you pay attention in class, you won't need to study outside of the class.

This was her first time teaching this class, and it was awful. Exams were insanely difficult and she gave ZERO way to prepare for these, no study guides and super vague instructions. Assignments were very time consuming as you are using boatloads of information from lecture to form answers to them. The lectures are a massive knowledge dump.

Reads off of jupyter lab, which can get very boring. TESTS ARE VERY SPECIFIC and HARD. If a certain topic has a 100 function, be ready to memorize all because you have no idea what will be on the test. She tests on very specific things. The classwork and homeworks are easy. Even while studying very hard for tests, I still got bad grades on them.

She eats and does her own thing during office hour who answers students' questions briefly. She is not responsible at all. At the same time, send emails to TA, and TA basically does not reply. TA often leave class 10 to 20 minutes early. In sum up,  TA and professor are useless. If you want to learn this lesson well, you can only rely on yourself

This was the first time "Algorithms in the Wild" was offered. Very lecture heavy. 3 Projects 20% each, midterm 20%, participation activities 20%. Python used for projects and are group work. Interesting topics but the projects were somewhat confusing. However, she is very accessible and more than willing to help. Overall easy and fun major elective
Difficult to understand ;-;

The assignments in Data101 are graded easily based on the LA/TA/grader that you have, there was one quiz that was announced on short notice. Like many CS courses there are minimum points requirements for letter grades so as long as you do the work it is fine. She did answer questions well in lectures and helped with the weekly assignments as well.

I took Data101 with Prof. Marian and she was really nice and forgiving to the students. She will answer your questions and help you if you reach out to her. The first part of the class was tricky because you have to learn how to code in R, but once you get into Bayesian theory it's more smooth sailing. The course is fast-paced.

She gave me an extension when I really needed it. More than I asked for. The class is geared towards people without a CS background, but you should have some coding knowledge before you take it. You should also have a stats background. She's a good teacher and teaches well, but in Data101, R was a nightmare. I'd avoid it if you could.

Oh boy, where do I start? Please for the love of God don't take her for DATA101. Her online lectures are a drag and her accent makes it kinda difficult too(not that much but still). The class is STATISTICS and PROGRAMMING heavy it's not a 101 class at all it's a 200 level class at least. Professor Imilienski is the best. Her cats are cute tho.

Prof. Marian should not be teaching a CS class that's designed for students with no CS background. Lectures are often unclear, disorganized, and sometimes containing errors, so you're referencing flawed info. She is more concerned with deadlines than she is with making sure students understand the material she presents. + no textbook to reference.

The lectures are usually quite unclear and difficult to understand. There is no statistics prerequisite for this class, however, there is a good amount of statistics material involved. Assignments are often quite difficult to complete.
Tough

Data 101 is one of the best classes you could take for almost any major. It's geared towards non-CS majors and the in a manner such that anybody could succeed as long as they put in the effort. However Professor Marian expectations are a bit too much for students that never programmed before! Responsive and concise, go to your TA for help though

Although she is very caring, lectures were dry and the exams were extremely difficult. Relatively lenient grading on exams because so many students do poorly. Only take this class if you're super passionate about database systems. Projects were kinda interesting, but wouldn't recommend as a general CS elective.
Good lectures. Good assignments. However, not very interesting course material.

Lectures are not very lucid.  Students present half of all classes. Be ready to read and present papers, confused by accents of some students. She is nice person, but prepare for the entrance exam in the first class.

You will learn a lot in this course. Take only if you are really interested in the course material. She's brilliant in teaching, her presentation slides will help you understand the topics easily. Expect the course to be tough, weekly reading assignments-4 to 5 research papers weekly. Assignments(and quizzes) are easy and there's just one exam.
Very useful knowledge combined with implementation. Make me learned not only DB knowledge, but also how to study properly. Excellent teaching, Wonderful person. Would try harder if I do it again.
Horrible grading scale,  students even do not know how it works
Very bad at grading. Made us work hard throughout the semester

Recitations are far more important than lectures for passing exams and online quizzes. All projects are solo, complicated and require a lot of work to finish on time. Grades undergrads and grads on separate scales. The professor is nice and the TAs are super helpful. Not an easy class, but worth it if you're interested in low-level database stuff.
mean teacher, and restricted with grade
Lectures were not lucid, but if you ask for help it will be there. Tough Grader
If you read, go to lectures and listen it shouldn't be too bad. Like any other CS class, but with an adorable accent
Great professor and interesting class. I learned a lot from her. She does have a quiet voice, but she provides a lot of resources and is generous with your grade. I recommend taking this class.

Very fair professor for computational robotics. Exams had 110 points but were graded out of 110. Each assignment also had extra credit (counted as A LOT if you're taking the undergrad version of the class).

The assignments and course overall was not difficult. The professor was incomprehensible at times and was very disorganized when it came to lectures. Much of her lectures were filled with mistakes and unclear explanations. Her teaching style caused lots of confusion and forced me to rely on self study. Aim for another prof. for this course.

I got an A so I can't really say anything bad. I got a D on the first test, over 100% on the final (13 pt curve), an A average on all the hw/quizzes and did the extra credit (I thought I was cooked). I didn't really pay much attention but most people say she didn't explain well. I like her she was nice and I went to office hours once. Just lock in.

While Professor Garg's lectures weren't the most entertaining, she offered a lot of extra credit to help students excel. In addition, she was also very lenient in giving partial credit. However, you must attend all lectures as attendance is 5 percent of the total grade. Overall, good professor, and I wish to have her again in other CS classes.
Gives some EC and has lenient grading. Lectures were also pretty good.

Very disorganized class. I don't know if this is her first time teaching or not but lectures were some of the worst I have seen. Answers questions well however. Exams are very easy and there is an insane curve for the class so it is not hard to get a good grade. Self-studying is recommended with her.

I could have gotten an A had I studied/did a bit better on the psets. The extra credit was unbelievable though, hard curve on the exams at the end of the semester after they were taken, giving many students a boost in grades. Solid lectures but a little boring, if you pay attention remotely and go to class, free A. 5% of the grade is going to class

One of the best professor I've ever had at Rutgers. I took cs463 this semester, and I would say if you attend every lecture and pay attention, you will be fine.There is a lot of extra credit to improve your grade, and two lowest homeworks will be dropped.

The best professor at the CS department at Rutgers. I took his CS463  He explained everything very well. Just show up to class and pay attention. If the homework gets difficult go to the office hours. He also gives a ton of extra credit for you to pull your grade up if your exams don't go well. He is a saint.
I learned a lot in this class because of his accepting and accessible teaching style

Bernstein gives extra credit in most hw & exams. Exam is non cumulative. Lectures are recorded.  Each hw usually have 1 very hard question. Exams are modified version of the hws. He will tell you which questions the exams are similar to. Very lenient on final grade 86 is A even though average is around 80+. Prev year A is 89. Got A without exam2
The goat, gives so much extra credit and a generous curve. If you have the option to take him for 344, do it!!!!!!

Even though it's a lecture-based class, he's a great teacher and his assignments are unique and thoughtful. The homeworks are difficult, but you learn a lot from them. He has office hours twice a week and is very helpful there too.

For a really hard class Bernstein was really good at teaching and explaining things. He was also very accommodating with students and was very transparent on his schedule. HW is group work but exams are solo, albeit take-home, which gives students more time to really figure out what the problems are. Overall, one of the better CS teachers.

the grading scale was 60% HW 20% each for midterms and out of 6 homework, 2 were dropped. It's bound to change tho. There's a fair amount of extra credit but it can get quite challenging to get. I think it's an all-out grind sometimes for these take-home tests which can kill you sometimes, but I think Bernstein was a great professor.

His lectures are excellent but most people do not go towards the middle/end of the semester. You get take-home homework that you can work on with a partner which is nice. He's always there to answer questions if needed. The curve is also huge at the end of the semester, 50+ was a C. Good choice for 344 I enjoyed his course

The professor is cool to have stream lectures and recorded lectures in zoom. The material was somehow harder than the previous semester according to my friend. The exam is very easy, it is similar to the HW problem. 6 Hw total but we get to drop 2 lowest HW and 2 exams. Overall the class is great since he curves a lot, 89 is an A and 50 is C.

Overall good professor. Class was in person but agreed to stream lectures on Zoom and post recordings, so those who wanted an online class could treat it as such. However, homework and exams got progressively harder to the point that it was impossible. Huge curve because so many people failed the class. But overall caring professor.

Professor is a good lecturer, but the class is based on homeworks that are pretty difficult to solve without guidance. I felt some questions were kind of ridiculous and niche and only loosely based on what was taught in lecture. I think prof definitely made the class harder after seeing some of the prior feedback about it being super easy

Pretty good professor, he's great at explaining the material and he responds to questions very well. Hw and exams can be very hard but theres extra credit, generous grading, gives plenty of time to do them, and two lowest hw grades are dropped. Overall Id recommend him

Easiest CS class you will take at Rutgers. You have 7 homeworks and only like 6 count or something, and there's 4 exams, which are literally no more difficult than a homework. They were all open book, take home as well. Don't even need to go to lecture.

Very lenient with grades (drops two lowest homeworks) and he teaches the content well. A must take for all Rutgers CS students! All in all, 6 homework assingments worth 70% of grade and midterm and final worth 15% each.
Very reasonable and kind professor.

An amazing professor, one of the gems in the CS department, really insightful and helpful in office hours. Explains the algorithms and everything in a very simple order and makes it easy to understand. HW is challenging , but he teaches you all you need to know to be able to do it. Exams are like HW but a little easier to do.

Had him for grad algo online. Reasonable homeworks (1 a week) and exams (2). Class is heavy in probability/proofs so make sure you are truly interested before taking it. There's EC and grades are returned quickly. Would recommend!
Simply the best CS professor I have taken. He makes it bearable for the average student and includes challenging extra credits question for those who feel confident.

Absolutely amazing professor. Algo is a notoriously difficult CS requirement which Bernstein makes really easy and bearable to get through. There are some real gem of professors in the department that exist, and Bernstein is one of them. He makes Algo easy to understand, and exams are straight up the HW problems.
He had final exams graded within 9 hours. Let that sink in.

Gives outlines of his exams and extra credit ON TOP of the final curve. In a school full of awful CS professors this man was sent from above. Was his first semester teaching and he nailed it. Bernstein drops the BS and teaches what matters in Algos passionately: how to approach and tackle these problems. Don't miss this gem of a class.

He's really nice and responds well to questions in lecture and office hours. But his class is extremely easy. Compared to the other algos section, we did not learn much. If you care about learning as much as possible, don't take this guy. I still did learn a good amount though. Data Structures 2.0 is apt

Very easy class. Review the homework problems and you should be good. However, he goes very slowly so not much material is covered. The pace of the class made it feel like data structures 2.0. He spent 2 whole lectures telling us how heaps worked and on graphs we only learned BFS, not even DFS or Dijkstras.

This is for CS520, and she is at UMass Amherst now. Very boring lectures that teach vague uninteresting content. Assignments frequently have poorly worded problems that people don't understand and she has to clarify. Thick accent that is hard to understand. You wont learn anything significant.

She only read slides. All content she teaches could be self taught in one afternoon by just reading the slides - waste of such an important CS course. HW and exam questions are worded poorly. Open ended questions are given either 0 or full credit. U could get 0 if ur close, or full points even if you are wrong. I ended with a B but still upset

Extremely boring, only sticks to the script. Her thick accent is tolerable, but have you put extra mental effort into understanding what she's saying, which makes it more difficult to actually understand the concepts she is explaining. Going to Centeno is your best bet.

Zhai gets a bad rep but is a decent professor. Yes, the lectures can get boring. The only slight issue for some is her accent, but she provides great examples for course content. Engages with the audience and asks questions. Great for data structures. Highly knowledgeable.

Gets a bad rep. She is really knowledgable. Literally the only thing is her accent, which if you can get past, is the only thing that I would say was "bad" about her. She explains things very well. Don't listen to the negative reviews for her in 112, she was great

Follows the curriculum provided by Centeno so the course overall is very well-documented. The first midterm was curved and lots of extra credit was given. However, lecture-wise heavy accent and hard to understand.

Her accent is very difficult to understand. She is great at answering peoples questions, but it is so hard to focus sometimes because you have to listen very hard to even understand what she is saying.

Only flaw is accent, which I got used to after 4 lectures. Otherwise an excellent professor. She isn't head professor so if you want head then choose Centeno (for some extra information about assignments and what will be on exam). I just asked a friend for that information. Zhai is so concise and fast and I loved it. Severely underrated professor.

CS 111 is easy enough, you don't even need to attend lecture (if you want to, just visit the professor of your choice). There's not much to say. She posts annotated slides on Canvas, which can be helpful. Only reason people consistently complain about her seems to be her accent, but I don't think it's much of a problem.
dont take
Thick Accent
The best sleep ive ever had
Thick accent and is generally unhelpful, if you ask her for help. Sticks to the script only. Do not recommend

She has an accent for sure but it didn't deter from her teaching. Her lectures were easy to follow and specific and straight to the point. Data Structures is a difficult course but her lectures definitely made it easier.

Don't be scared off by these people saying "she has a thick accent". If you speak English, you'll understand her easily. She's a GREAT lecturer. I took 112 with her during the online semester and I watched every professor's lecture, and Zhai explained the concepts and implementation of all topics the best by far.

Juan zhai is an amazing professor in terms of explaining the material of data structures. People may say her accent distracts them from the lecture, but I do not think so. Her explanations for various data structures are concise and easy to understand. Compared to other 112 professors, Juan zhai does a great job at explaining the concepts.

idk why people said she's bad. she's lectures pretty well cuz i thought data structures was gonna be hard due to the bad rep here but i got hooked into the material and juan zhai teaches it very well. some people might not understand her because of her accent but i understand her clear as day. would recommend for 112

I have been coding since I was just a kid, so the class was dead easy to me. If you took Intro to CS, go to lecture still and absorb what you can. She's not good at teaching, her accent makes it worse. It's really hard to follow her. You're going to have to learn to code by yourself (freecodecamp) then use her lectures as a supplement.

The other comments say it all. Professor Zhai's online lectures were structured well and her feedback was good, but her accent isn't easy to understand at times. It's definitely something to consider when debating taking her or another professor especially Sesh, who I think most people would agree is a better professor as of now.
Very hard to understand. Would recommend you to not take Intro to CS with her. Not worth the pain.
She is a knowledgeable professor but has a thick accent. Luckily I took AP CS in high school, so I only went to lectures 3 times.

I feel bad for Professor Zhai, I had her both for CS111 and CS112 and I can at least say that as a professor she's definitely trying her hardest. But, just like every other comment here, that accent is hard barrier to understanding in her class. It'll take a while to get used to it then she's a legit good professor who answers questions and helps
She speaks English extremely poorly. She teaches her class cursory and skips lots of details on every page of the lecture slides. It is so hard to understand what she is talking about.

She tries but her accent is one of the thickest I have encountered. As a result I struggle to understand the concepts of the lecture and I often have to teach myself. Unlike past semesters I can't just attend a different lecture because she is the only one teaching. This plus hard assignments, quizzes, and exams I'm praying for a generous curve.
If you are in CS 111 and don't have a background of computer science, don't take this professor. Very difficult to understand in class and not that accessible outside of class.

Her choppy way of speaking can hinder your ability to understand her unless you are 100% zoned in to what she's saying. Blackboard notes were slightly disorganized, and at times her explanations for runtime analyses are a bit hard to follow. She's however very patient and willing to explain concepts again if you ask during lecture. Not bad, overall

I wouldn't choose this section as first choice. Her accent is difficult to get used to it, and you need to have a mentality to listen what she is saying to not to be zoned out. She is new to teaching, and she does cover the topics that will be on midterms and finals. However, I'd recommend to attend Sesh's lecture over her. (Slides are online so.)

She's trying. The slides are pretty good... but that's about it. Her Chinese accent is thick but with a really brutal, capital 'K'. I think 80% of the class just never showed up after the 1st week. I stuck out till the end just so I could give an honest rating. All I can say is to pay attention to the slides... and YouTube. Third time's a charm :^(

You really have to pay attention in class to understand what she is saying since her thick Chinese accent. She is also very bad at answering the question asked. Many students just give up because they have reworded the question 3 times and she still hadn't understood the question.

This is the best class I've taken at Rutgers! Prof makes many resources available to students and is very approachable and caring. By no means is this an easy class. However, don't be mistaken-- this reflects not on the professor, but rather the topic itself. Overall, if you want to benefit, put in the work.
One of the few professors that is bad to a big extent
Based off his current ratings he would give himself an F. Very terrible professor. Takes an interesting subject like ML, and turns it into Hazing for people trying to get into it

Prof. Stratos made this course unnecessarily difficult, especially the quizzes, which prevented me from enjoying learning machine learning. He wasn't very receptive to student feedback, and often did things contrary to what students wanted out of the course. At least the assignments provoked critical thinking and had satisfying solutions.

This is one of the worst teachers I have ever taken at Rutgers. His lecture are useless and he doesn't give a *** about his students he tried to move our test up just because he wanted to go on vacation early. He only curved just the top potion of the class because maybe a handful people got A's and he did't want to look like everyone got C and B.
Just sit in the back of the class, everyone doing stuff legit didn't get an A lol

Not Good Lecturer. Half the class wouldn't show up to lecturers, and when they did it was for the quiz, which they sat in back and cheated. So the curve wasn't correct based on how people worked in the class, rather how well they cheated.

Basically does not exist outside of class and never answers emails. Is quite frankly a terrible educator and you would be better off watching lectures on youtube. He also wanted to move our final a week earlier without any sort of warning or consent, then posted a whiny and passive aggressive announcement after he was forced to revert it back.
Doesn't seem to care about students whatsoever. 50% of class didn't show up to class, because he was a bad lecturer.

In general the professor isn't fair to say the least. The requirements for the class are incorrect. He gives an entrance exam on the first day of class that is worth 5% of the grade. If you haven't done calc 3 or linear algebra that first exam right away takes away 5%of your grade. Also, he tried to move the final exam last second into study week.

Professor was disorganized and skipped over many relevant slides throughout the course. Although he is passionate about the subject matter, he often goes on tangents in which he seems like it's his first time seeing the words in his slides. The Cornell CS4780 course on Youtube is a much better resource than this class, although less in-depth.

Smart, funny at times, and caring. Very accessible and willing to help you succeed. You have to put in the effort as the class is not easy. Very math-heavy. If you do the work, it is a very rewarding course. This is a very modern deep dive into ML and one of the best courses I've taken in the CS department. 60% math, 40% python coding. No exams.

If you go to class and participate he likes it a lot. The grade at the end is curved heavily; He changes it a whole letter grade for some people. Make sure you take notes during lectures and ask questions it actually helps. The quizzes are difficult, but they are around 60% of the grade make sure to study for those. Hes a super chill and funny guy.
One of the best profs i've taken. Will go over a complicated subject again if even one person in the room asks for it. Knows how to engage students and truly cares about our wellbeing.
This professor is very caring and helps his students in every way possible. Recommended for Discreat Structure II (CS 206).

really good at lecturing, super nice guy. quizzes are really hard. midterm and final were relatively easy compared to quizzes. quizzes are majority of your grade, theres 6-7. highly available outside of class

I highly recommend Prof. His teaching is clear and engaging; he makes even complex topics understandable. I was apprehensive about taking 206 after 205, but his method made it accessible. Attendance is key to success in his class. His exams are fair, and he's supportive if you need help. Plus, he gives out free candy!"
Built = diff. Amazing professor. Hard class. Lots of extra credit. Try your best and exhaust your resources and you'll pass.
He likes to present bad rate my professor reviews in front of the class, wasting class time to whine about his poor feedback. Entirely unprofessional.

So far he has been my favorite professor I've ever had. I love the effort he goes to guide everyone to thinking about problems in new ways. For a foundational class, I think you couldn't possibly get a better rock solid foundation!

One criticism I have for Disc II would be that it feels like the recitations and lectures are somewhat disconnected

A bad professor trying to play cool. He will entice you to the course saying its very easy but load with homework and then grade negatively. Why lie to market your class? This is the only subject in my graduation that got me a bad grade. He grades on the curve so will find his victims very early in the semester and try to keep them at below D level
Attend as many classes as you can and sit somewhere in the front where he will see you attending lecture. Do this and you'll be fine, trust that this person really has your best interest at heart.

Good person & teacher problem starts when he start giving you too much extra credit where it gives you hope for a better grade but do not get fooled by it. 40 percent of the grade includes midterm and final so yeah if you want to pass the class you need to do well on the exams and they are very tough. 6 quizzes drop the lowest. Seems light; not so.

He is a good lecturer, an easy professor, and gives quite a bit of extra credit. However, I ended up doing quite poorly, and I don't blame him for this(had difficult personal stuff). But I do blame him for insinuating I was just being lazy(after a back-and-forth about a grade appeal), which isn't right to say even if you don't believe the person

Your grade will consist only of participation and assessments, but make sure you try because attending class isn't enough to get an A if you do not do well on the tests. Attendance isn't kept, but he remembers his students well. The only downside is that people may suck up to him or off-track questions will be answered and waste class time.

Brilliant professor who really cares about the success and effort of his students. Gave extra credit on all quizzes and exams. Recitations are mostly mandatory because that's when he gave his quizzes. Being able to register for on Webreg and take his class for CS206 is a privilege. 100% would recommend you take him

One of the greatest professors in Rutgers. Genuinely cares about his student's success and is reflected in how he teaches. Goes on a pace so that everyone can understand, and gives a lot of extra credit to make up for those "unlucky" moments when you take his assessments. Also makes a math class interesting somehow
Hands down one of the best professors I have ever had.

This professor is the GOAT for discrete 2. King of discrete 2. Super light grader, cares for his students, funny, actually wants his students to learn. Super generous teacher, loved this class. Best theory CS teacher I have had at rutgers so far.

One of the greatest professors in Rutgers. He does everything he can to make sure we succeed and goes at a pace even dumb ppl like me can follow.His first lecture was a bit intimidating, but he's a very caring and determined professor that truly wants his students to get something out of the class. You will never find a professor like him, TRUST ME

Best CS professor at Rutgers. Take him if you can. Unique lectures and teaching style. Genuinely cares about students' ability to learn the material and is always looking for student feedback. Graded by quizzes and midterms with extra credit on both. Provides extra problems for better understanding.

Fun class, easy if you pay attention/ You can see he cares about teaching. Taught in a strange way, but I liked it. Quizzes given during recitation make up the majority of the grade, and the rest is based on midterm and final exam. In the negative, I think he spends too much lecture time fumbling around or answering simple questions.

Absolutely amazing professor. The lectures are very clear and concise. Unlike most professors, he actually wants students to learn something and genuinely cares. He always has extra credit questions on quizzes and exams. If you pay attention in class and review your notes, the quizzes and exams are relatively straightforward.

His teaching often leaves the class confused and when it's made clear to him he asks someone in the class to explain it (which he never repeats so everyone can hear). His pacing is terrible; he'll spend half the class reviewing old concepts but will run out of time and rush through the harder concepts. Sometimes he just refuses to answer questions.

Michmizos truly was a gem of a professor. I think I'd describe his teaching style as "You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make it drink". He genuinely did everything in his power to make sure students took away something useful from his class. In my section, he took responsibility for poor quiz results. Easily the best professor in CS.
Very personable and great lecturer. Really emphasizes classroom interaction and makes everyone feel like they have a voice. Gives you every opportunity to improve and succeed

Professor Michmizos is definitely the best professor in CS department. He really cares about students' feeling and he can make sure everyone is learning in class. Learning knowledge in his lecture is an enjoyable experience.

Truly a great professor in every way possible. Great personality and cares about his students learning. Also one of the only professors I have ever seen blame himself for poor quiz scores at one point in the semester. He treats us like adults and leaves it up to the student whether they will reciprocate that maturity. One of my favorite profs ever.

Taking discrete math with him, and even though I am doing kind of terrible in this class. This professor is absolutely putting in crazy work to make sure we take something valuable from this class. His exams are getting a little scary and even though I'm not doing so hot I feel like I'm learning a lot about how to approach problem solving.
What an absolute ledge highly recommend this class

Hands down the best professor I have had at Rutgers. He is dedicated to ensuring that students learn, he has a great sense of humor, and he is good at explaining complicated material. The course will push you because it is not easy, but it is worth it because you are actually learning something useful as a student and learning it quite well at that
AWWWEEESSOOOMMEEE professor. Must take his class.
awesome prof

Thought I was going to die from this class
10/10

Probably one of the best Professors at Rutgers. Be warned: If you are not very interested in the material and ready to put in a lot of work, he is not the professor for you. He goes in-depth over mathematics most undergrads do not see. Overall a great introduction to robotics. He ran out of time at the end for material and projects though...

Bekris as a lecturer is awesome. There was a ton of material, but he was available in office hours and provided lots of resources to understand it. However, the projects were absolutely brutal. The algorithms alone took forever, and interfacing with Gazebo/ROS added undue complexity. This really should not have been offered as an undergrad class.

Assignments do take effort, but that is the purpose of a 400 level cs class. I got better at programming and learned about basic AI concepts and received a B+. There is a massive curve, and a c requires minimal effort. 4 assignments, 3 had programming tasks (50% of grade). 2 tests, highest one counted as 35% of grade while lowest counted for 15%
Lectures can be dry sometime. TA have no mercy grading. If you're not a very good programmer, please do not take this class.
He's really good

Does not add that much value to the detailed lecture notes that he posts online, but is able to answer questions well if you read the relevant book chapters and have an understanding beforehand. Group projects are homework assignments are very difficult. Midterm was more conceptual and final was more problem-solving. Average is low, curve high.

This is by far the worst class I've taken in my 4 years at Rutgers. The group projects are awful and require an insane amount of work. Lectures are extremely dry and the material was not well taught at all. Seriously avoid AI at all costs

This professor is really nice. For class CS520, you can learn a lot about Artificial Intelligence. The midterm and final takes up 50%, and 5 homework(including projects) takes up 50%. For each class, you can find a note on Sakai which covers up 85% of the possible test points in the exams. As long as you check the notes, you won't have a bad grade.

His lecture is fine but just reading his lecture notes. His homework is a lot that comes in just one week (I really mean a lot, including coding the algorithm, doing experiments and visualization in basically a week. Be prepared to not get to sleep!). Exams are basically book memorizing, very tedious but not hard (but he gives practice questions).
CS598 was Introduction to Robot Manipulation. Teaches really well, from basics. The final project was very hard. He grades for the amount of hard-work you put in.

AI is tough. Or at least, the material is. There are 4-5 assignments in Bekris's class, and while not particularly difficult (the average on one was 102), you still learn quite a bit. His lectures come straight from the lecture notes, which are condensed versions of text book chapters, so he can be a bit dry, but he teaches the material well.
have to be attentive all the time. Gives his maximum to explain things.

Best CS lecturer I've had to date! Everything was extremely well-explained and clear. He really cared about his students and was willing to answer every single question, ensuring that everyone had a full understanding of whatever was being taught. Extremely reachable and helpful in office hours as well.

I was looking to take algos 4summer and I saw this guy on webreg had no clue who he was or what to expect. He is so caring and wants you to pass, take this time to actually learn. I think my grade was like a 30 and got curved to an A. He gave so many opportunities for people to clutch up their grade. He doesnt want to fail u he wants u to learn fr.

Certainly one of the best professors I had at Rutgers. Though he's a grad student, he teaches with the expertise of an MIT professor. His 4-hour lectures feel swift because of how engaging they are. He clarifies concepts exceptionally well. If I could have him for every class, I'm confident it would further enhance my skills. Highly recommend!!!!!!

Hard to believe it was his first class teaching since he's such a natural at it. Very engaging and charismatic, made our 4 hr class bearable. HW's were a bit long with q's varying in difficulty. Extra credit available on every HW. Eager to help during office hours. Exams were long/tough, but he provided formula sheets + tips. Great prof overall.

All the lectures on zoom so you could attend online, uploaded on youtube, but I recommend attending class to pay attention. HW is very long and also challenging. Lean is one of the worst things invented by humankind. However other resources are available to help assist with HW ;). Ames has no midterms. Quizzes are online. HW: 60% and Quiz: 40%

Ames was an excellent professor. I got injured, and he would accommodate me even though I couldn't attend class. The exams were 70% of the grade, which was hard even though the final was an open book. But I learned quite a bit. Wish he is still at Rutgers.

He is a great professor and was nice. He made the finals online. However, his exams were a little hard. Even if you have online resources or open notes, it does not help much. The exams are 70% (20%+20%+30%). Homework assignments are easier for me.

Good. Lectures were clear, but it was too easy. It feels like I couldn't learn many things expected to be learnt during the Systems Programming lectures.

There are only 4 homework. Guideline is quite clear, but sometimes you need extra explanation.
Grading is so generous. I know students who can't earn a perfect score, but anyway he got it.

Professor Ames made exams due 70% and on exams, multiple choice would be around 5 points each question. Some questions on exams were one tiny detail from slides that were only mentioned for 5 seconds in lecture and yet they would be worth so many points. He talks extremely quietly, where sometimes you can't listen to him. He's not a mean person tho

This is my 3rd time taking a class with Ames. It is a bit hard, but I think it is okay. This is his first time teaching CS336, so he made exams with 70%. Hopefully, he will not do that again. He is a nice professor, and if many students email him, he will likely extend assignments or drop one hw. He is definitely not a bad professor.

The only downside is that exams are 70% of your grade, but they are significantly easier than any other CS classes exams. Even if you dont go to class, just review the slides the day before and do the homeworks. Its enough to get above an 80 on exams. Homeworks are easy almost everyone gets a 100. Dont let the high exam weighting scare you.

70% of your grade is exams. He doesn't post lecture recordings and is a boring lecturer so it's hard to pay attention. His questions are so arbitrary and tricky. It's hard to get a good grade when we had barely any assignments and mostly exams. I had him for other classes and he was fine, but this class was the worst

Seems like a nice guy, but I'd avoid him for this course. He refuses to provide format for his exams, and handwritten code was on both midterms (made up >50% of the first one). He got rid of the final last minute (

W projects & CS:APP based lectures.
A respectable lecturer who carries the CS dept.
He has no organization when it comes to teaching this class. Exams are worth 70% of your grade and I found it to be very difficult with the information he gives. Avoid him for this class and CS210

His lecture style is not helpful considering the difficulty of his exams/assignments. He puts trick questions on everything. Not to mention this class was 70% in person exams with assignments only worth 30% even though the assignments take a lot of time. I've taken him for multiple classes and have had bad experiences in all of them.

Ames is a great professor but he has some of the harshest TAs for grading. 60% HW 40% online quizzes. No midterm or final. He uses this weird programming language called LEAN - basically zero documentation on it. Half of the homework is LEAN programming. Quizzes were straightforward but HW takes days to complete. He is very helpful in office hours.

W professor, is really laid back and is always available through email or office hours. TAs slacked off and didn't grade hw for the entirety of the semester so you don't know how you do till the end. Quizzes are very simple and are based on lecture videos which are posted online with annotations. Just do your part and it'll be easy.

The course is only graded by quizzes and homework. Homeworks are difficult and time-consuming and don't get graded until the very last minute. Grading was pretty relaxed and quizzes are mostly multiple choice. Ames also records and streams his lectures for those who cannot come to class. All material is very accessible outside of lecture.

Ames is not that easy for CS214 but it is not that hard. Good thing is lecture recorded, does not have exam, quizzes is on Canvas 1h usually 10 questions, and group hw (1-3 per group). Bad part is lecture is conceptual, so you have to figure out how to use the concept to write the code. Quiz is harder so be careful. Try to choose good partner.

Great lectures. Classes consist of only 5-6 homeworks and 5-6 online quizzes, however this also means that you should be careful and not mess up a file submission on homework or skip a quiz, 1 file submission I messed up on the hw costed me a 3-4 point grade drop for my final grade.

Super nice and approachable professor. He held class in-person and online simultaneously this semester and even recorded his lectures. He doesn't give exams: Only HW and quizzes. HW is BRUTAL and very time-consuming, while quizzes are pretty easy. He does help a good bit with HW in office hours if you ask. Decent professor but expect to work hard.

Ames is a good dude and gave extensions on many of the hw's. Only thing is the actual material. Ames is the only professor in discrete 205 who teaches Lean basically a coding language for proofs and the only documentation for lean is the textbook and lecture slides which make hw problems almost impossible to complete. Overall an ok class

Quizzes are fairly easy. But he uses this weird language called Lean for hw. Homework is way harder than what we learn in lectures, and there is very limited recourses online because nobody uses Lean. He is also very slow. He is often late to class and grades our hw very slowly. The first assignment had not been graded for over a month.

Only review I've written bc best professor I've ever had. Calm and cool, lectures are well-paced and broken down fantastically. It's like teaching is in his blood. Accessible outside of lectures and answers students questions. As a beginner programmer who got an A, largely due to Professor Ames, other CS111 professors don't compare at all. Amazing!

Ames was a pretty great professor. I found 214 quite interesting and Ames was pretty good at presenting the material. His course slides were from CMU. However, I think the material was presented too theoretically and the projects came as a bit of a shock because of this. He was however super accommodating and provided ample extensions.

Even though it is back in person, Ames still keeps online zoom available which makes commuter and students that travels almost 70 miles to school convenient. Quizzes are easy and mainly testing on your concepts but homeworks are hard and time consuming but doable. Other than that, his class is pretty nice. He is nice and try his best to help. HW

Good lecturer and definitely one of the better people you will meet in the CS department. Originally we were suppose to have exams, then he switched to weekly hws/quizzes, then biweekly hws/quizzes. Quizzes are relatively straightforward (some are tricky), but HWs are brutal and time consuming. Still, its better vs exams if you're not a test taker.

Amazing guy. Class was all projects and quizzes. Quizzes were extremely easy. Projects were of moderate difficulty. Incredibly generous with extensions, even ended up dropping a project because there wasn't enough time due to extensions. Excellent grasp of the material and a great lecturer. Curve was extreme with C  55%.

Prof Ames is a nice guy and caring during office hours, answers all questions during lecture. But his mic volume is way too low during lecture and thats a big problem that he didn't fix. Quizzes fair game, lectures are fine, hw is too hard and doesn't line up with the quiz difficulty. CS214 needs to be revised and needs student input

Ames is a really nice professor, but async discrete 2 wasn't run that well. Grades take a while to get back and it's seldom you get partial credit for anything. The slides start out pretty useful but gradually get more muddled as the quizzes got harder. He does give a decent curve (I was away from A by just a bit) but overall, take it in person.

Lectures were fine and mostly easy to understand, but the example he gave in the video lectures did not match what was covered in the homework or quizzes. Quizzes were okay but homework was disproportionately and insanely difficult compared to what's discussed in the lectures. Found myself just completing assignments instead of learning.
He is good at explaining things and occasionally adding extra stuff to course materials, which makes the recorded lectures a bit more fun

(Asynchronous)Weekly quizzes which are easy(211)/hard+HW(206). 7 projects which get harder and complex each consequent project(START EARLY) besides the "Bomb Lab" which was a fun project. Lectures were really dry and boring(Asynchronous problems?) but material is ok. He is a caring professor because he gave extensions limited-211. No midterm/final
He gave out so much quizzes and very difficult homework to do. Almost impossible to do them by yourself. Tough grader and does not drop any quiz/homework grade.
Ames is the ï¿½ï¿½. Top 5 professor at Rutgers and a Top 2 individual overall ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The course itself isn't too hard since it is designed for people who have never learned programming before. Professor Ames is a really good teacher but you have to sit in the first few rows to actually hear him. His office hours are very helpful though. He's also incredibly nice and not at all intimidating like some other CS professors.

One of the best professors at Rutgers. Lectures can be a little dry, but always willing to help, is always understanding, very fair with grades/exams, and is overall pleasant (can't say the same for most other CS professors). Truly shows that he cares about his students.

This dude is awful at what he does. The guy is silent and really offers no help. The guy has 0 personality. CS111 was supposed to be an intro course... Unless you know coding going into his class DO NOT take it. Struggled so much and had to Withdraw.

Jeff Ames is a true gem in the CS department. He is one of the few professors that actually cares about his students. Sometimes, his lectures can be a little dry but he more than makes up for it with his charming persona and kind heart. I had him for Discrete II and Computer Architecture. I loved him for both classes. The man is a treasure.
A very nice professor that cares a large amount for the students he teaches. He does his best to make the material understandable and curved the class a large amount.

Barely replay anyone's email. Gave 2 lectures about cache and ask you to answer questions on the final after 2 days review, because he moved final earlier even before the reading week. you will learn more from MIT and GMU online course as everybody says

Willing to stop and answer questions or he will answer questions before or after lecture. If you have trouble hearing, sitting near the front is essential. Tests were fair but some challenging questions, homework was done in groups and the averages were 95% at the least.

Lecture is hopeless. Can't hear him so you move to the front. Now you hear him and nothing he says makes sense. Slides are copied verbatim from textbook. Reviews mislead you for what's on the exam(single worst part about him like why?!).If you do take him ignore the review he gives you.

Never taking a class with him again. One of those "nice guy" profs, which for some reason is a good reason to take him according to some people rather than being a good prof. Learned the entire course from MIT OCW, not from him.

when you read the textbook or find another source about the chapters he taught, you will understand how bad he is on teaching but anyway, people still like him, since he gives the extension as long as people asked
Hes the best professor at rutgers. Hes so kind & his personality shines through! Thank you Prof Ames
This man will put the time and effort into making a 170+ slides long midterm review with 50 different topics YET only 4 of those topics show up on the actual midterm. AVOID HIM
One of the best professors at Rutgers. Very understanding and nice and will help you and encourage you to chase success

Honestly Ames is the best professor at rutgers. He is so knowledgeable and answers the questions of every student so everyone feels comfortable with the material. I love him. Please take his class if you get the chance.

It is true that Jeff does not explain some concepts well as others are complaining about. I would give him a 3 for teaching. However, Jeff is so nice that I would not even hesitate to give him more than 5 for his personality which for me the most important part of choosing a professor.
He is a nice guy. But never explain stuff well. He is skipping the students' question. Slides always overlapped. I feel students give him a good review because he is kind.

This professor is usually great for other classes, but he spends almost no time going over the derivation or explanation for important theorems or equations in plain english. I haven't taken any tests or quizzes yet so maybe I'm jumping the gun here, but the lectures are really, really hard to digest.

ayo my man jeff a real homie, like this is my second review for this man and Im giving him a 5 just cause he a nice ass chill ass dude. This man is hella smart and if you can just bring hearing aid with you to class since hes so quiet then you set playa.

When he taught my summer 111 course, he was very quiet and somewhat timid, but you can tell that's he's genuinely knowledge and an overall friendly guy. I asked him a question in lecture once that he emailed me about weeks later to elaborate on. Just small things like that leave an impression of consideration and a willingness to help.
Great professor, take him if you can, a gem of the computer science department.
Very good experience with his class
I went to all the other ones teaching this course but his seems to be the best given his caring nature. Take him, others seem harsh.

Jeff Ames has sort of a shy personality but is really caring and even though he talks softly, his lectures are engaging. I would recommend him over the other professors teaching this course and I would definitely like to have him again.
Nice guy and helpful class

Jeff is a really nice instructor but is very quiet, if you do not sit in the first few rows then do not come to lecture since you will not be able to hear him. His grading is pretty lenient, but is a little vague and unclear about certain directions on group projects and on quizzes. Great during office hours and overall a great man.

He is good teacher in a way that he wants his students to succeed . Clear explanations, although sometimes could be a bit more engaging. And paying attention on lectures matter- some exam questions are right from his lectures.

Jeffrey Ames is the best. Not only does he care about his students but he will really go out of the way to help you with homework/concepts/projects. He literally gave me his Cracking the Coding interview book because I told him I was about to have some interviews.
b
Great prof and TA for 170, helped me a lot with homework and group projects.
I enjoyed the way the TA was helpful towards the students
He was okay. Could have been more helpful and clear with instructions.
Wohoo. Yummy. Loved the way he explained things. Everything seemed so easy. Hot turban btw.
Great TA. he genuinely cared about his students and how they performed. He was very informative and helped all of us out with everything in the course.
Literally the best CS professor. Dude cares about his students very much and is very lenient.

Professor Assadi is a kind and patient professor. The class may be hard, but he is willing to help his students succeed and learn the important concepts of this class. The class was organized and there is a clear grading criteria with extra credit. He is also very understanding and willing to accommodate his students. Office hours were helpful.

- worked with me in exam conflicts and resolved in the best way.
- generous curve
- cares about how his students do

The course content gets harder and harder towards the end, but our first 2 midterms are take home, and the final was in person. we got a huge curve on the final, and the result of the final was out in like a couple hours after the exam was over. The fastest exam grading ever seen in my life.

He has very clear lectures and lecture notes which caters to all learning styles. Super nice and approachable. His homeworks and exams can be challenging but totally fair. He cares a lot about his students and their input of the class, and is always willing to accommodate.

Truly an amazing professor. He is super accommodating and always listens to suggestions from students. He makes you want to learn the material and become a better student. Take him if you get the chance!
Assadi is a king. I love this man.

He is the most accommodating professor I have ever had. Offers a lot of extra credit, asks students what would work best for them, and really helpful in office hours. The class is not easy but Assadi does everything he can to help. All you have to do is put in some time and effort.
One of the Best CS Professors.
One of the best professors that I have ever had. Reasonable homeworks and exams and quite lenient when grading. Definitely take him if its an option.

Professor Assadi is one of 3 professors Ive met at Rutgers that truly wants his students to succeed. He is flexible with the class, moves homeworks and projects around to adjust for other courses, and is constantly asking for feedback from the class to improve himself. Almost impossible to fail his class as long as you try. Would highly reccomend!

This man genuinely tried to adapt his course to make sure that students took something away from it. He is also pretty funny sometimes. His course note were honestly fantastic. Homework and exams are somewhat challenging but he provides ample opportunities for extra credit, and you can totally do well without those opportunities as well.

Fantastic algorithms Professor who completely understands what his students want by catering to all learning styles. He posted his lecture videos from the previous semesters online, and his notes were all the content I needed to learn anything in the course. Textbook reading is not required as per Assadi. His office hours were a god send!
Assadi is very caring and considerate of his students. He has a sense good sense of humor and makes himself easy to reach outside of class.

A really awesome professor! He definitely cares about his students and teaching a lot, and is super accessible outside of class whether in office hours or over email. The homework and exams are somewhat challenging, but there is plenty of help available and they're definitely doable. Definitely recommend!

Hands down one of the best. Truly does care about his students and responds to a lot of feedback. Always clear and transparent. Some of the workload can get pretty difficult but office hours are very helpful. Def would recommend.

A god amongst gods in the Rutgers CS department. There's a lot of professors who care more about their research than their teaching responsibility; I can assure you Professor Assadi is not one of them. If you work hard in this class you are guaranteed an A, however, make sure you stay on top of your work! If Assadi is teaching algo, TAKE THE CLASS.

Professor Assadi really cares about his students and is super fair with the class and grading. He is always here to help you and will go out of his way to make sure you succeed as long as you put in the effort. Just practice what he teaches from the lectures & study hard. Do the homework as they will help prepare you for the exams.
Best professor at Rutgers.
Amazing professor with well organized and explained lectures/lecture notes. Always willing to explain concepts in or out of office hours, always tries to help struggling students as much as possible.

Assadi's CS344 was definitely the most well-organized async course I've taken. He is a very clear lecturer and provides extensive, nicely typesetted lecture notes on top of that. Homeworks are tough, but you're given a reasonable amount of time for them, and each assignment has more challenging questions for extra credit.

I had him for asynchronous & felt they were organized very well & easy to understand. Homeworks/exams are challenging but reasonable. Halfway through the course Professor gave us a survey to take, & based on our feedback he adjusted the HWs to be easier & made other adjustments. Quizzes are nice & easy. One of the best profs I've had at Rutgers. :)

Really good professor, he's always there answering any question you have and all his exams/HWs are straightforward questions of stuff you've learned. Nothing crazy but you should know the material, simple as that. But that's not that hard, his lectures are pretty chill and if you pay attention and do the HW you'll be good.

Coming from community college, I admittedly struggled quite a bit in this class. However, prof Assadi was very encouraging and helpful every step of the way. Aside from his lectures, he provides really in-depth notes online. Be aware that exams make up most of the grade. His HW's are no joke, but will help you if you put in the effort.

Take Assadi for Algo if you can. He cares about the material (he has some really impressive algorithms research), is super accessible in office hours, and puts in so much effort to ensure that students are learning properly. Hes got extensive lecture notes (better than the actual lectures), great exam prep, and is super understanding.

Sometimes his lectures can be a little hard to follow but overall, he explains everything very well. Would 100% recommend going to office hours. Once he breaks down the material in the office hours, it is very easy. The projects don't take too long and the exams are fair.

I took Compilers with Prof. Kremer in the spring. The class was very interesting and fairly useful. Register allocator project was pretty tough. The next two were very easy. Exams were fair. Lecture notes are good but have incomplete examples filled in during lectures. He uses Piazza, which is GREAT. Homework is 5% but great exam practice!

Kremer is undeniably one of the best CS professors at Rutgers. His comprehension of the material and his delivery of the information is spectacular. If you go to every class and listen, you should get at least a B+ in this course. The programing assignments are very doable. Just start early and try to understand them. STUDY FOR THE EXAMS!

Kremer is incredibly laid back. His material is really interesting, sometimes difficult, but he is very clear and helpful about it. The hws are pretty hard but he's the God of giving extensions. Exams and projects have been fair so far. Definitely worth taking. His German accent can get a bit thick but his lectures are still very enjoyable.

Does not care about the students If you cant make it to the office hours he will not care Wont help you out with the material whatsoever If u do not understand anything its not his problem He acts like a nice person in class but hes the total opposite during office hours Ruined my GPA just because of this single class Worst class to take him

Kremer is a great professor. You can tell he genuinely wants you to learn and is very generous on extensions for both projects and homeworks.  The exams are pretty similar to the homework, as long as you understand the concepts covered on those you'll be fine. The class is also overall pretty interesting. There is a reverse-curve though.

Kremer is a great guy and good professor. The material in the class was interesting, but the lectures were so boring and the recitations were useless. It was completely self-study and it sucked. Otherwise, the projects are easy and tests are similar to hw, and the curve is pretty dumb. 92 for an A, 88 for B+, 82.5 for B, 76 for C+, 60 for C.

One of the finest professors at Rutgers, with a good command on compilers. Very open, friendly, helpful, encouraging professor. He explains the concepts at ease with lot of clarity, crystal clear. All understanding happens at class itself.

Overall, the class was fine I guess. It wasn't very interesting. Hard homework every two weeks. Easy projects. Easy midterm. Basically the only thing that matters is the final. I had an A (A on everything) but bombed the final and it went down to a C+. DO NOT FAIL THE FINAL. There is NO curve! You have been warned!

Uli Kremer is a passionate and articulate professor who you can tell really wants to help you learn. He's very understanding and willing to cut students some slack on deadlines and such when it's reasonable. My only complaints are that project/exam grading took absurdly long and that I personally am not very interested in the subject matter.

He was pretty quiet in lectures but overall he wasn't bad. He was really organized - lecture notes, homework/proj forums, etc. - and pretty good with project extensions. Attendance for recitations was taken every week. Exams were straightforward. Don't really think he curved though.
Professor Kremer is a good lecturer but he does make his class hard, especially if you're not good with the material. If I were you, I would take another professor for Principles of Programming.

Explains things clearly and concisely, and is very helpful if you ask him questions in class or in office hours. Programming projects arent too bad if you dont wait until the last minute. Written HW is trickier, but if you know how to do it youre pretty much set for his exams since the types of exam questions are taken directly from it.

Comp sci majors don't get me wrong. Even though the class is considered easy, the curve is absolutely ridiculous. 92 was an A but most people ended with Cs. It was the worst elective I took this semester. Gotta work your ass off with this professor!!

Professor Kremer is a fair grader. He teaches the class a lot so the class seemed harder than what most people expected. Only 3 projects and a midterm and final. He is helpful but his class can hurt people who don't really get the stuff.  I ended up getting the worst grade on the exams.
Took this class last semester, actually attended about 3 classes and played hearthstone the entire time. Programming projects were very easy. Recommended.

The class was actually easier than I thought it was going to be.  He is definitely passionate about his work and will always try to answer any questions you may have as long as they are relevant to the class.   Coding projects were very easy, only took a couple hours.  Bi-weekly homeworks definitely prepared me for the exams.

The lectures always seemed long to me but you can tell that he's passionate about his work and that was awesome. Slides are online but it really does help to go to lecture and take your own notes or else it'll be kind of hard to understand. He's very helpful if you want an extension for projects. Exams are similar to homeworks too. I recommend him!

Quite possibly the most difficult professor to understand in CS. Thick accent, low volume, and a trailing vocal fry at the end of every sentence.  I tried to self-teach, but his notes were not stand-alone and the books were over-detailed for the level of the course. I had to drop the course despite my 4.0 GPA. Perhaps a good teacher otherwise.

One of the best professors in the CS department, in my opinion. Extremely knowledgeable and helpful. Lectures were always very interesting. He puts his slides online but you really need to come to class to understand everything. Homework is hard, but programming projects and exams are very doable if you understand the material well.

He's very nice and caring. He's very responsive through email. There's only two assignments. One individual and one group project. I did not like the group project but he didn't grade too harsh for the group assignment. Very informative about Cybersecurity.

Professor Ma expertise and passion for the subject matter were evident in every lecture and discussion, and his willingness to go above and beyond to help me learn was truly exceptional. I especially appreciated the way he helped me find and understand useful papers related to the course material. .

Worst professor I have ever had a class with. Did not teach based on his own syllabus, and introduced graduate level material to undergraduate students with no prerequisites. Incompetent during lectures, and answered students' questions poorly. Gave everyone in the class a C+ that would have otherwise failed to make himself look better.
Professor graded fairly.
She is the lecturer of Comp Sci 323 Numerical Analysis under Professor Mridul Aanjaneya. The best lecturer I have ever had in the CS department. It is highly recommended to attend her recitations.

I'm sure Professor Fan is a great guy outside of the classroom. But as a professor, he is incompetent to the point of absurdity. He reuses material from another prof and understands none of it, which is also drier than the Sahara. The practice midterm is nothing like the actual midterm. For the love of god, don't take this course with Professor Fan

The level of incompetence demonstrated by this professor is hilarious. Canvas announcements on one section but not on the other, exam out of the portions recommended in the book, and the worst part is in the lectures he just reads off his slides, which are very unclear. I took this class out of genuine interest, but I feel cheated out of my money.
The professor didn't know how to use Canvas. And he didn't explain everything well in the lecture. For the homework, he didn't fix the problem on time.

Professor Shan is the best. He wants you to do well and gives you tons of resources to help. This class is very hard and a ton of work but there are things you can do to help yourself. Go to all the lectures, use the discord as much as you can, go to the many tutoring hours that are almost all day most days.
He is a nice professor and person, but the way his class is structured and the work load is no easy task.
Great guy -- very knowledgeable and enthusiastic. Not an easy class but extremely interesting and exciting. Probably the best class I had at all of Rutgers.

Easily understandable during lecture.  He opens up the first few minutes of the lecture by offering to answer any questions people have, which is really helpful.  The amount of work is manageable if you go to class and pay attention.  Anything you don't understand can be cleared up by attending his office hours for a half hour.

Workload is unbearable! Lectures are very boring and not very helpful. He is often unclear when answering students' questions. The only upside of the class was that the exams are easy because he gave us the "redacted exam".

He is intelligent, as the previous reviewer pointed out and he is clear and helpful IF YOU DO YOUR WORK. And he will be more than happy to help you when you are stuck. You just have to express to him your concern.
Quizzes are very light. Exams are pretty tough, however, she lets you retake your exam so not too bad. Unorganized class, but not anything horrible.

One of the most disorganized classes I've ever taken. Wish I had seen more reviews before taking her as a professor. Her way of teaching is reading someone else's lectures and then doing random problems, spending more time on irrelevant info and less time on important, core material. I would literally take anyone else. Have to learn on your own.

Parkhi is fine. She did well explaining the reasons behind concepts, and the class wasn't overly difficult. Some exams questions were traps, but she let us retake the midterm and gave extensions on both homeworks. The schedule she gave did not line up with what we actually did, and we had to ask when things were. Not the best or the worst prof

DO NOT TAKE DO NOT TAKE HER lecture heavy class horrible at explaining cant understand with accent. Our exams were harder than all other MIS classes. The material we covered was more in depth. Everyone was lost. She had to give extensions because everyone would fail. Any other prof would be better. Very Difficult Avoid At all Cost

Nice & gave good advice. Made the lecture easy to understand. Exam is long & hard. He cut each PA by half compared to Fall. Made it half as much work due to class is half the time. Midterm was 3 hours and final was 4 hours; code(20-30%), mc(20%), short answers (30-45%), and long answers (6 sentence) (15-20%). The average was around 60 to 70%.

It was a pretty chill class. He uses his own presentations along with some chapters from the textbook, but his presentations alone are enough. He talks about technology in a way to make you feel inspired and provoke research. The class mainly concentrated on talking about the evolution of Computer Vision.

low teaching skills; heavy lecture; heavy workload; unreasonable presentation schedule; build up team randomly; no response; later announcement every time; grade only based on your report, not your work. VP may be a good researcher, but definitely not an ordinary teacher, he would get a C for his teaching, awful
Treats students terribly. Very arrogant and thinks he is above everyone else. Would not recommend taking

This class was an absolute joke. It is clear that the prof is focused on research and is not interested in teaching at all. And it shows. Absolutely zero effort into lectures. If you are Math/Physics Ph.D. student, maybe you can follow the lectures. Others, just run. What's more? No office hours. No responses to emails. He's better off not teaching

Lectures are deceivingly simple. Feels like he tried hard to make the subject matter easier to understand for everyone but ended up oversimplifying the material. When we got to harder more in-depth material people were too casual and ended up not understand the material. Bright side, the professor is exceedingly fair for grading and accessible.

Pretty nice guy overall, though his midterm was a lot more difficult than most of us were expecting. But he genuinely cares about the students' understanding of the material and always responds to questions effectively.

Unfair grading. Numerous mistakes on his quizzes and midterms. Gave certain students much harder questions than others during midterm, some people got very bad grades. He overestimates the ability of his students and does a poor job explaining complex concepts. I do better using Youtube self-teaching.

Not good at all. Almost every quiz had to be regraded after everyone took it because questions were worded incorrectly. He even regraded the midterm because there were questions that were worded wrong. Also, his lectures are very fast and confusing, which makes the in-class poll questions very difficult.
Best teacher ever

Clicker questions in every class (but not worth too much of the grade), hw every 1-2 weeks, and had a choice of 1 or 2 midterms, then a final  Expects you to read/learn on your own, then does a bunch of problems during his dry lectures. Put a lot of work into the class, and got a B.

He teaches at a level beyond introductory. He has given a week's notice for exams, including the most recent lecture on it. He expects you to read and learn on your own, but the text book is not very accessible. If you do not have prior knowledge in probability expect to invest a lot of time self studying and finding adequate resources.

The professor attempts to explain the concepts as best he can. However, he did not simplify the material enough. Without a good amount of background knowledge of statistics, his class will be extremely difficult.

Goes through slides extremely fast, and expects us to be done with half a dozen lines of calculus in 30 seconds for a single clicker question. Sometimes he will reveal our quiz answers as having a random distribution, then laugh. He says in many lectures "the only way to learn this is practice problems": and evidently, not through his explanations.

Very knowledgble teacher. But i'm screwed becasue i don't kn ow much math. Can't undersatnd a thing in the three hours. But it seems he really expalins everything clearly. Just hoping to survive this course

He could nearly answer any of your questions towards this course using deduction and equations. Very nice course if you would like to learn sth in this area. Rating is nice. Homework is super hard for people without prior knowledge.

I promise that this professor is  extremely good. He knows almost everything that he is teaching. But, I need to remind you, do not take his course without any background knowledge because ou will die very ugly!!!!!!!
Very knowledgeable in Math. But too geek. If you are in research track, he is the right guy to work with.

The guy knows his stuff and tries every angle to teach it. I like the fact he never rests. But the topics are so hard and the exams are real real hard. He has a rigid schedule and he follows it thru. Over all, if you have interest and prior knowledge, he is the guy to learn. Otherwise you are screwed!!

He is very boring, but his lectures are online. You wont need to go to class but you will have hard homeworks that count a lot. Grading wasn't too bad, make sure never to fall below a high average, he curves you down. He doesnt follow what other classes are doing.

not the best professor ever, but not the worst either. very hard exams, but very nice grading system. he also gave us instructions on how to use rutgers online with firefox which i thought was cool... but i'm a geek
wow.. this guy is a robot.. only cs class i ever dropped.. hard ass homeworks..

He is one of the best professor when it comes to teaching. He draws out stuff and explains well which is great since there are lot of professor who just read off the slides which could be boring. Professor Badri makes lecture interactive and fun.
good style of teaching
If you want to learn OS, he is the guy.

Awesome prof. Explains everything well. lots of stuff on latest in OS. If you want to  do well in a job interview, take his class. I learnt about virtual machines.  very knowledgeable on latest trends in OS.
learnt a lot about OS. Gives the latest  on OS and what is important.  his last lecture on virtual machines  was  great. Makes a lot of effort in helping students get the concepts.
excellent professor
Maybe the most boring professor I've ever had. The sample exams aren't too similar to the real exams. If you can manage to pay attention, you will learn a lot about OS

This class is awful. He has his slides but none of them is related to projects. His practice exams are nothing like the real exams. The project was a huge long BitTorrent Client for a whole semester with no help from either the TA or him. Never reply emails in time. I sincerely don't think he cares about this class. Avoid this class!!

Probably the driest lecturer I've ever had. He scribbles illegible things on the whiteboard while droning on. None of his in class examples are fully thought out or explained well. His slides are useless. You have a better chance of winning the lottery then gauging what could be on the exam. The information that he tests you on is pure memorization

His lectures are boring. For our semester, he threw the BitTorrent project on us without warning, while saying he was going to change the project at the beginning of the semester. Project and lectures are not connected in any way so there's no point in going to class. He and the TAs don't really answer questions in a timely manner. Exams are okay.
He gives lots of reading assignments and all the tests are based on them. If you miss a class you pay. Overall, the course is heavy and needs time.

The entire class is one large group project split into three steps.  Attendance dwindled to pitiful numbers once everyone realized he posts the slides online before lecture. Recitation was even less useful. Exams are mostly memorization and the TAs usually give a good amount of partial credit. Java experience is a must for the project.

Lectures and slides are clear, if a bit boring. The project (bittorrent client) is pretty tough. You better know how to code large Java projects in groups of 2-3. The average grade right now is a 60, so there will probably be a large curve.
Super easy, funny, and makes sure everyone understands.  I didn't use the textbook; reading the slides is good enough.
Probably the best professor in CS

Nath isn't a bad professor, but I had a hard time paying attention to him in class.  Don't bring your laptop or you'll get WAY too distracted.  He makes a good number of mistakes, so be on the lookout.  I also wasn't very interested in the class beyond C and binary (I'm more of a software guy than a hardware guy), but he's alright...
Excellent Class, excellent prof.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
trys to make class fun, makes sure all understand, so classes can be boring
This class was so bad only because of the professor, if anyone else taught this class it would be 100 times better.

Lectures are unclear, assumes you know everything. Any questions cant go to him, they must go to TAs. The quizzes, hw, exams are made by TAs (which he doesnt communicate with). 0 availability outside of class (which he often ends early before you can have your questions answered). Youll hear some cool stories though!
