Literally, the most confusing professor I've ever had, don't let the high rating fool you, he comes to class constantly unprepared, expects you to know the material you weren't taught in other classes and refuses to talk to TA's to coordinate HW + quizzes.

Prof Farach is definitely the best professor I have had at Rutgers by a stretch. He is extremely knowledgeable about the subject. He is also hilarious and is filled with funny anecdotes. He spends a third of the lecture on some irrelevant tangent, but this keeps the class really lively, I personally enjoyed it a lot. Every CS Grad should take this.

2 midterms and an optional final which couldn't hurt anybody's grade. Material for algorithms was tough in my opinion, but if you understand the optional homework he assigns and you take good notes during lecture you will be ok.

Very good professor. Great exams - just wants the right ideas, not code or irrelevant details  (that's how it should be in an algorithms class in my opinion). Sometimes it may get difficult to follow some parts of his lectures, but I would say that he is a good teacher. The hilarious stories he tells in each class are a plus.

The best professor i've had in my life till now. Crystal clear concepts, explanation is awesome. Keeps you entertained for the whole 3 hours. Most of the course topics were from his papers, which are going to be added in the next edition of CLRS. Very helpful with the queries. Must take if you are interested in Algorithms.

The best professor i've had in my life till now. Crystal clear concepts, explanation is awesome. Keeps you entertained for the whole 3 hours. Most of the course topics were from his papers, which are going to be added in the next edition of CLRS. Very helpful with the queries. Must take if you are interested in Algorithms
dont care about GPA take his class
Best Professor I had at Rutgers. If you want to learn algorithms, take him.

not all material for the exams is covered in the homework. more than half the material is from the papers he published, read over those if you can't understand something in the lectures. one more thing to note: exams are not "give algorithm for provided running time, prove running time". it's more "give best possible algorithm, prove running time".
Has very good knowledge of the subjects . Takes time to understand what he teaches
Very good professor   Scary tests gave me no sleep

Easily one of the best professors in the department. Teaches very difficult material *very* well, and doesn't ask that much of you. Easiest B ever, and the A is not out of reach. More importantly, he's the funniest professor there is. Super flamboyant and quite the story-teller.
Farrach-Colton was an awesome professor. The simplicity with which he conveyed complex sorting algorithms and graph theory was marvelous.

The best CS professor I had at Rutgers. He teaches clearly about a difficult subject, algorithms. Keeps your attention. Wants you to ask questions in class. Funny, opinionated, and flamboyant. Don't bother with the textbook, Wikipedia is enough for the class.

Farach is a really smart guy, and knows his algorithms well. He's funny and engages the  class. He's one of the only professors that's been able to keep my attention for an entire class.  His tests are very similar to homework. He answers questions really well, and is very helpful. Take algorithms with this guy if you get a chance to.

He is an awesome Professor, expert in what he teaches and presents everything in a manner accessible to all. He has a terrific sense of humor and his classes are a lot of fun. Don't miss the opportunity to take a course with him. Oh and he is super helpful too!

After he's done telling you how bad English food is, how annoying international copyrights that he infringes are, and stops pouncing on Indian students for saying 'x by y' instead of 'x times y', he'll start teaching. Exams and homework are not based on what he teaches. Hard to get in contact with and get help from since he lives in NY.

Excellent teacher, v brainy, v humorous, clear and lucid as can be. If you care about learning interesting algorithms and dont give the f**k about GPA, take his course. You'll learn a lot!
 One complaint I have against him is he's not original.. lifts all material out of Eric Demaine's course at MIT
Hard teacher, everyone does poorly on exams, but good curve.. on the bad side dude thinks hes too cool to help students during office hours

Farach may seem cool at first.
 Although the exams are tricky,
 Give "I Don't know" a shot.
 Get a 25% or above on the first exam
 Or you'll be asked to drop the course and
 Try again next semester.
Awesome professor.  He seems to really care about the material he teaches, and is very good at making the subject clear and understandable.

Professor Nazemi is a really nice guy who wants his students to succeed. The class was set up very simply, you watched some video lectures and then there were only 3 HWs across the semester where the instructions were given step by step to get 100's. The tests were the exact same way, not much studying needed just follow the steps

Nazemi is a cool dude. Class is really easy. Just follow in class exercises and his HW (only 2) to do well in the exams. Focused mainly on Excel and Access. Even gave us extra credit at the end of the semester to help people out before the final exam. Super caring. Wouldn't recommend anyone else for MIS. TAKE HIM!

He is amazing! Do the class assignments and you will be fine for the midterm and final. Because it was online, he just posts the lectures and if you watch it anytime before the following class, you get attendance credit. He is super helpful if you ask him during office hours or email him. You won't regret taking him!!!! TAKE HIM FOR MIS!

Online class posts 2 lecture videos a week and walks you through every concept on excel and access. Class is async despite what webreg says. Exams and hw are easy as long as you put in the work of doing all the practice assignments. If you fall behind on lectures you're screwed. Attendance is counted as watching the lecture before next class
He's an ok guy. If you talk to him one on one, he is understanding and helpful, but his class is so dry. Pretty easy class but its the department who makes the exams and work, not him.

Professor Nazemi is a great guy. He is younger than your average prof and is pretty laid back. His lectures are very clear and he is always willing to help his students. There are 3 tests which are not hard if you do the hw and in class exercises. Please do your self a favor and take him, you won't regret it.

Professor Kapadia has once again shown to be one of the best professors. I took him for CS523 in fall 2020 and topics in AI for spring 2021. Literally, this course picks up on the foundation from the CG course and basically, you innovate your own idea for your own research project. The course is purely research-oriented. This class was super fun!

Professor Kapadia is by far the best professor I have taken here. Not gonna lie his course is tough. having previous Unity experiences along with game dev & VR helped but his class is gonna take you above that and break your limits. You learn a lot about Games AI & crowd interactions. While it is time-consuming, your unity skillsets will advance.

Prof Kapadia is not only a good professor but is also a great person. I had a situation where I would have failed the class if he wasn't understanding enough to allow makeup work. The topics he teaches are quite hard to understand at first and he gets that and grades accordingly. Be ready to put in effort and be rewarded for the effort you put in.

Kapadia is a smart guy, but this course is the worst I've taken during my time at RU. Lectures are sped through, he assumes you have a graduate-level understanding of the material, and the TA adds critical info to every project last minute. Pandemic? Who cares, synchronous class time and withhold posting the recordings in a timely manner.

Super smart guy, very research-oriented. This class (Game Science) was relatively straightforward -- make a game with potential for real-world impact. No tests or quizzes. Just weekly deadlines. Expect to give a presentation every week and almost entirely group work. Lectures are mostly listening to other groups' feedback. Lenient grading.

-one week three hour lecture format. - Very little homework. - Your Presentations were leniently graded - One 5-page research paper - It's an open-ended project course - You do most of the learning on your own - The prof didn't really put much effort into the course - Not too hard to get an A thanks to the lenient grading - NO EXAMS

Well I have to say, for this class, you really need to be prepared for heavy work. For the whole week you will think about how to finish you team project and one day before the due date, the new project(homework) will come out. It just never ends. However, if you do finish most of the projects and fulfill the basic standard, you can get good grade.
One of the coolest professor at Rutgers. He coursework might be challenging but very much exciting and fun. He makes you push your limits. Value for innovation .
Fun and good professor, but gives so much work that it is almost beyond the realm human ability to complete. :( needs a reality check.
Great guy. Really makes an effort to get class involved :)

This class wasn't all bad, but I found it to be mostly really unpleasant and strongly advise against taking this professor. The biggest problem was the large amount of work required every single week, much of it tedious and repetitive. If you get stuck with unhelpful group members or fail to submit assignments correctly, your grade will suffer.

Professor Kapadia is the best professor I've had at Rutgers. He is intelligent and is very clear on what he expects out of his students. He has no intention of failing anybody and at the end of the day just wants everybody to have quality work that they can show off. Graphics programming is tough and he makes sure that you understand that fact.

This class is run on groups. Lectures are unclear, he speeds through them like it's a race. The TA's seem like they don't know what they're doing half the time and give vague feedback. He runs the course as if it's the only one you are taking because of the many assignments, plus the 15-20 page research paper. It's nearly impossible to do it all.

This class might be decent IF we focused on just one thing (SteerLite OR Unity). And if we went over how to code in C++ or C#. And if we didn't have so many assignments due at the same time. And if the lectures weren't made for Ph.D. math students. And if we didn't have a long term paper. And if we were explicitly told what to expect. Again: IF.

I have never actively loathed a class before CS 428. While the professor is a nice man, "nice" does not excuse insane expectations for the course. The lectures are sped through and never explained in detail, and the assignments are tedious and frequent. I hope the professor's inexperience is the sole reason for why course is so awful.

Kapadia is an excellent professor he teaches well. No exams. BUT Too much course material group projects(which means basically you end up doing less to little work because you know jack, and end up doing nothing at all) Too many course prereqs: Be prepared to learn C++/C sharp/Latex as basic things to work on. It feels like a grad level class
The overall standard of this course is high. Expect weekly assignments and lots of group projects.
No midterm/final. Tons of group work

It was the first time Prof Sayad was teaching an undergrad class. His lectures are full of scribble writing. Very useful website and also his presentation slides. He is very quick at responding emails and also available during office hours for any clarification. Fun class and takes student feedback always and he cares about his students learning.

Avoid this prof for undergrad, he took 3 weeks to start data science information. Website is unreliable and hosted on his computer. B/c of this, he had to change the final date 1hr before final because it got breached. Changed final weight 3 times, to 36%. A headache of a class, any good review from this class are people just happy they got an A.

He got under some peoples' skin because he changed stuff on the syllabus a bunch of times and had to reschedule the final because of a security breach. But he really is a very nice and helpful guy. If you ask him anything via email, he does the problem himself and sends you screenshots. He got COVID and was really sick, still finished the course.

godawful lectures, unclear grading criteria (which he changed multiple times throughout the semester), poor communication, lack of security practices which resulted in the final being rescheduled 1 hour before it was supposed to happen and also the leaking of personal data of almost 200 students. says nice things sometimes but can't run a class
Prof Sayed's website is very informative. Even through he suffered from COVID, he made sure that the students did not miss out the lectures. His final exam was tricky because of the time constraint.

He has his own ways of teaching and was always ready to help students alongside the TA's. He tried to make it as less stressful for students as possible by giving many opportunities to boost grades but some students are trying to make him look bad. He was severely sick due to COVID but decided to complete teaching Time Series rather than cancel it.

Prof. Sayad is very experienced in his field. His website is so informational and useful that it is used by other institutions for their Data Science courses. He tries to make the subject more intuitive for students which helps in understanding really complicated concepts especially for someone without a math background.

One of the best classes I have taken at Rutgers as it enabled me to actually learn the concepts really well. He appreciates students efforts (unlike some other reviews that suggest otherwise) and is always willing to help you out. Go to his office hours and he will be as helpful as possible.

His website is really good and explains the data science cycle in depth. I agree his class was not organized and multiple times his syllabus changed. He is a really nice guy, very quick in replying to emails. He really takes care of his students and he wants his students to learn.

It was the first time him teaching an undergraduate class and I agree that he changed the syllabus multiple times and the class was not organized. He is very quick at responding to emails and also during office hours he explains the concept of you dont understand. The TAs were amazing too. His website is amazing and I personally liked him.

Things on the syllabus changed often, however, overall the course work was very doable. He is a really nice guy. Always replies to emails and clarifies things very well. Because the course was somewhat unorganized, he is getting a lot of bad reviews. But if I consider everything, I liked it.
This course was very helpful. A good way for anyone looking to get started on databases. Best part - Hands-on projects. Not too tough, not too easy. Grading was fair.

Scribbles on one slide for 20 min. Goes on tangents which have little to no use. Repeats the same information from lecture 1 throughout the entire sem. His website is the textbook which crashes. Rescheduled the final one hr prior to the exam. Sends sensitive student information to entire class. Lecture is way too abstract and doesn't help with quiz

By far the most disorganized course in the cs department. Changes syllabus on a weekly basis, scribbles on one slide or 20 mins, uses his own site for assignments/quizzes which causes slow downs and lag. Moved final date one hr prior to final, material was not taught correctly, sends sensitive student information to entire class.

Completely unprofession. Disorganized, moving exam dates as late as an hour before the exam, for finals. Insists on using insecure personal site instead of sakai/canvas, and moves times at will to account for glitches/flaws in the site. Blames any problems on students. Material was taught so poorly I doubted the concepts I knew going in.

DO NOT TAKE HIM! I have taken 100+ credits and never seen a disorganized and horrible professor like him. He basically teaches horrible and super boring. Also rescheduled the final exam an hour before it started!!! Stay away from him, do NOT take him if you value your time

Very disorganized and constantly changes the structure of the class. He changed the final project twice and its weight multiple times. On top of this, he changed the date of our final 90 minutes before we were supposed to take it. Avoid this professor

I learned a lot in Prof. Sayad's course. The material was difficult at times and the projects were challenging but I came away with several new skills after the semester. He wants students to learn and understand. This class also helped me a lot with interviews.

This course helped me understand the concepts quite clearly. I also got an opportunity to polish my presentation skills as we had to present our assignments. As far as grading is concerned, if you put in sincere effort, you get a good grade. All things considered, I would definitely recommend this course.

The course started off great. Things were explained in detail and well. But as we reached the end of the course, classes were getting frustrating. There were group presentations in which 13 teams had to talk about the same thing. Listening to the same thing so many times is frustrating. Also, homework is often much more complicated than class work.

By far the best Professor I have had at Rutgers. Although CS 323 is a difficult class, Professor Xue makes sure you understand the concept and will help to whatever extent necessary to ensure you understand the concept. Truly cares about his students. I can go on and on about this guy but dont have sufficient number of characters left .

I took this class during the Spring 2021 semester(online) and I thought Prof. Kopparty was simply wonderful! He is very chill, goes over every topic well(and none of them are overly challenging FYI) and always does extra problems for those students who need a bit more clarification. If you want to save yourself a lot of stress, go for him!

His lecture is okay. It is not so boring. Sometimes, he would make a joke in his lecture, but nobody laughs. Only a few do laugh. He is a kind person. His lecture is basically about the concept and only a few examples. You have to study on your own if you want to understand more. Use the textbook questions and meet him. He is very helpful.

So I haven't completed my class yet because I have the final for Calculus I for Engrs in two days. I had a good time in this class because he was understanding towards during the COVID-19 pandemic. He always answered questions when the students asked, so we can understand more. If you're going to Engineering or CS, please take him.

The class takes a while to get used to. I remember the first couple weeks I had to use the textbooks, but overtime I got used to the way he teaches and it helped me a lot. He gives hw every week, but overall it prepares you for the midterms and final. On top of all that he's a really nice, funny guy. Best teacher I've had this entire year!

Professor Kopparty is hilarious. He is super nice and very intelligent. He will spend the entire lecture answering questions if that is what it takes for you to understand the concepts. He is clear in his explanations and really wants you to succeed. Take him!
Wow, a Rutgers math prof who gets it!! Genuinely really nice, wants the best for you, and makes exams very reasonable.

He is amazing. I always struggled with theory classes - I didn't do so hot in 205 and I barely passed 206 (that class still gives me nightmares). I was scared when I signed up for this class but, trust me, he explains things very well and is generous with partial credit and grades. If he's teaching automata, register for his section ASAP

The best professor I ever had! He is very helpful and caring about his students. He wants you to learn. Took cs 205 in Spring 2015 with him. He stresses the key points multiple times so when I missed some lectures, I could pick it up quickly. Hw much harder than exams(which is very good). Exams were tough but manageable. Take him if u can.

He's so smart and extremely clear and helpful. If you just pay attention to his lecture, you'll learn everything but you'll honestly be fine learning from the book. Attendance only mandatory for quiz days

Brilliant and sweet professor who really cares about his students. His analogies are fun and helpful in understanding concepts. Homework due every 2 weeks and one question quizzes on the day homework was due. Straightforward grading.

Currently taking Kopparty for 205 and really enjoying it. Exams are easy as long as you understand the homework. Kopparty is always smiling and cracks dumb nerdy jokes all the time (which I love). I highly recommend him.
Class is fairly easy. Kopparty generally goes at a reasonable pace and takes time to answer questions from students.

Amazing professor. Exams are fair and lectures are clear. One of the best professors I had at Rutgers Took him for number theory and learned a lot throughout the semester.  Taking him is highly recommended.

He has an incredibly sharp mathematical mind. His lectures are clear and interesting and he understands students well so he responds effectively to questions. He is incredibly nice and wants all of his students to succeed. Homework, quizzes, and the final are all completely fair and are excellent at helping the students learn. Highly recommended!
Prof. Kopparty is brilliant and great at teaching.

This is the worse teacher I have ever had! When your worried about your grade he doesnt even care he basically says figure it out and he grades for students to fail and not to succeed.I know of 3 other students who even emailed the president of the school bc of his unreasonable grading. Dont take him!! Youll regret it.

Loved Littman. He's adorable. Really tries to help his students succeed. The scratch programming is easy to use. a lot of extra credit .. practice exams are helpful. i didn't go to recitation, or class, got an a

Intro to comp apps. really knows his stuff. you do not need to go to class, just recitations. he posts his lecture slides and posts a practice exam that is REALLY helpful (very similar). Easy A if you do all the assignments and get help from littman or your TA.

Really cool. Material was really boring and I wasn't interested in it but Prof L made me want to go. He tries his hardest to make the material fun. He is very smart. Prac exams are the same as the exams with different numbers. MT and Final are open book. Homeworks are hard but he curves them. Lecture slides are online and the clicker questions.

I guarantee you will not find a cooler professor! You will actually want to go to class! Accomodates insanely with lecture podcasts for lazy people, practice exams are EXACTLY like the actual with different numbers. Both are open book and notes too.
Great professor!A really fun person. make you WANT to go to class, even though you might not be interested in the subject. though, you DO need to understand the materials to do well in class.

easy A class! clicker questions in class but u can do them online too, the class is kinda boring but fun at the same time. hes such a nice guy and the class is pretty easy, if u look at sample quizzes and learn them its great. i would def recommend this class!!! hes awesome!

Greatest Prof. EVER!!! Really helpful, funny (at times), and overall good person. Really wants you to get the concepts he's teaching/passionate about his field.Got an A. Take this class!!! Also, look for his robotic dog! Really cute!

awesome teacher. really into what he teaches. makes things so easy to understand. attendance is not required because he records his lectures and puts it online and clicker questions are also online too! awesome class. easy A! professor littman is one of the best professors i've had at Rutgers.
best professor ever! so energetic and funny and will do whatever it takes to get you to understand things. his music videos are too cute and hes just an all around truly nice guy. loved him!
hands down my fav professor at rutgers.. he always has something funny to say and teaches actually interesting things.. take this class, u'll laugh your head off when he plays u his music videos

was in his Great Insights into Computer Science, VERY GOOD CLASS. He made the class so understandable. Even though we were learning something as boring as bits and boards and systems, he was constantly adding energy into the class. You really need to see him running around and his unforgettable music videos with his kids.

This was a new class- conceptual comp sci, fulfills math req. Littman is awesome; he'll literally sing and dance, and is very funny. Very easy-going, fun to listen to. Even if half the concepts go over your head, it's still an interesting class to take, especially if you need to fill quantitative req. Really great guy
This is one smart man. Talk with him about stuff outside of the scope of class and be englightened.

Amazing! I actually wanted to go to class. He has humor and knows how to teach. The best professor I have had so far. Not an easy class, but curves are great, and the class is just so much fun. Recitation doesnt help much but if you go to him, he will def. help you. Take this class with him!
No Comments
Great teacher, no questions about it.
Excellent teacher that engages you in the lesson in as many ways as possible, using humor when things could get boring. Knows how to teach, which is a nice change from the norm.

An absolute rarity in this field in this school - an enthusiastic professor with a sense of humor, passionate about the subject, makes lectures and assignments interesting, and actually encourages you to learn things.  Highly recommended.
-ncouragement. Friend to people and robotic dogs alike.

Very enthusiastic and passionate about the field. Entertaining lecturer, sprinkles material with witty humor and trivia about history. Extremely approachable despite his celebrity status in the reinforcement learning literature. Provides inspiration and e

You should take this class if you want to be Data Scientist, the materials cover a lot of this career path. However, as the consequence, many of them are just a brief summary or a sip. If you are really interested in it, you need to do more research. BTW, take the Recitations or at least read the material, these are the skills you need for project.

Very softspoken and his lectures consist of reading off many slides, so it can get boring pretty quick if you prefer more lively professors/lectures. He's really nice though and was very accommodating in light of COVID-19. Few assignments, so don't miss a single one. Exams are quite short despite all the material covered. OK class overall

Need to read a lot of slides. But the lectures and slides are interesting. After graduating I still remembered the example given by him: Big data overload is like drinking from a firehose. The course gives an overview of data science for beginners. You will do a group term project to practice. Not easy A ! bad.

Extremely boring lectures, 3 assignments (one of which was an actual coding one) that were worth 30% altogether, and slide heavy lectures (90+ powerpoint slides). Not too difficult class if you are interested in the field of Data Science and have an interesting semester project. All the learning is done on your own.

An interesting CS class and a lot of material is covered, but most of it is generalized so I didn't really learn anything new. Extremely slide heavy so be ready to read a lot of powerpoint. There's only one semester long project in any language on any data set of your choice which can be finished in a week. Easy credit filler and interesting topic.
Gerard is a good professors. Although some lectures might seem a bit boring, but in the you can do very interesting projects and even publish them. definitely take it.

Professor bores us in teaching. The material covered is not solid, and the syllabus is ambiguous. Components are only a few, that is, 1-2, so care not to mess up those components. Overall not recommended.

Prof. Ray is certainly a nice man. It is hard to give him this rating because I could tell he cared for his students. That being said, his lectures were rough. The material is very difficult and he did not make it easier (despite him trying). Homework assignments and studying for exams became impossible and so the TAs became my greatest resource.

Everything you need to learn can be learnt at recitation. Professor knew a lot about the subject, but needs to improve a bit on the execution of teaching it. Nice guy, but not for people who have never done the slightest coding before.

Oh god, see this troubles me. Raj Ray is such a sweet guy. He would answer all of our questions and was very caring. But, he was just not a good professor. Some people just aren't meant to teach. His lectures were unclear and cluttered, we had no clue what we were doing. This course is so poorly coordinated, but he does have good resources for us.

Although the class is not difficult, professor Ray did a very poor job teaching. He did not keep up with the course schedule, he would just read the slides and he could NEVER figure out the projector. The recitations are the only helpful things - TA's are the only real teachers in this course.

Ray isnt a terrible teacher but combined with a terrible administration and his own faults, my experience was not entirely positive. He has a lot of knowledge and can help if you talk 1to1 but his lectures are not very helpful. Before the lockdown, his classes were useless, more so after. Ridiculous extra credit project, pray for a good TA!

Professor Ray is an adorable man. Test is tricky though. For cs170, the TA plays a big role. You may skip lectures, but ATTEND RECITATIONS. Because that is where you learn how to do your homework. They have computer lab everyday of a week, on all campuses. check the schedule for it, attending that would make homework much easier.
He's a nice guy. He's no the best professor but he definitely gets the job done. Just pay attention in class and you're fine.
Good professor, class mostly depends on who your TA is but still, he's a nice prof. do your assignments on time and you should get an A

Raj was very helpful during the semester. I had him during the COVID19 pandemic and the transition to online learning was challenging for both students and professors. There were a few technical errors but I feel that he tried his best and gave everyone the benefit of the doubt. When I asked to review my final exam he was more than willing to help.

Good professor. Although covid-19 didnt help and there were some difficulties he adjusted well to everything. Was always available for office hours and was helpful at all times. If you go to class and read the book you should pass with ease...

No chance of learning anything in his lecture. You're honestly better off not going to lecture and just reading the slides on your own. He seems like a really nice guy and I wish the best for him, but I don't think teaching is for him.

Dont take this course with Ray. His mumble lectures are undecipherable and disorganized. He will not help you with the course material because he throws the bulk of this class onto his TAs and does nothing. His extra credit is a complex project while other professors offer simple questions for points. He is clueless and unreachable all semester.

Decent professor, far from the worst at Rutgers. We had one project that took a good 30+ hours but after that the assignments weren't as difficult. Pretty interesting course. You learn a lot of AI algorithms which I personally found enjoyable. It's easy to dose off in his class but if you keep up with the material you should be just fine.

He seems like a nice guy and the online class was probably hard to manage, but in general this class was terrible. The slides are so confusing and difficult to understand. He and his TAs were completely unresponsive throughout the whole class. Especially during the final, they left us out to dry and showed no care for the students whatsoever.
Gives enough time for students to finish the assignments and answers all the questions students have.

I took him for Data Structures over the summer in 2020, and it was horrifying. He posted 2 problem sets, which are supposed to be posted weekly, a day before the midterm, some TAs didn't know what was covered last week during the recitation or did not know how to share their screen, and the midterm had 4 questions in total and 2 of them had errors.

He doesnt reply to questions from students. He doesnt post assignments or lectures in a timely manner. He is not clear about his expectations and on the final there was a lot of confusion that he did not clear up until the last few hours we had to take it. He never actually looks at the assignemnts that r submitted
He seems busy to teach this course. His lecture is not very difficult to understand, just a little messy.

He cares that students understand the topics and will backtrack and reexplain until everyone understands them. Responds to emails very quickly. The class was fast-paced, but Chun really helps guide everyone to an A.

terrible "teacher". he does not give a damn and reads off of scribbled powerpoints filled with errors. also he's deaf and can't hear you or answer questions. downcurved our class (94% to get an A wtf). puts random trivia on exams that he glossed over or barely mentioned.

I took 344 with Kalantari and his lectures are very poorly prepared. His powerpoint slides are basically scribbles and written with horrible handwriting. I received a B+ in the class even with a 92% average. He clearly downcurved the class. Unfortunately, he has no idea what he is doing when it comes to teaching a CS class. I learned nothing.
Do not recommend at all

He earned my respect on the way he handled the transition to online learning due to the pandemic. The class was mostly well-organized and we had access to the resources we needed. I just wish his lectures were better prepared.
Not the best lecturer, but he was extremely accommodating during the COVID-19 pandemic. He really does care about everyone and made sure that we had access to everything.
fuzzy rating principle, for your GPA, do not choose

Hard to understand what he says in lecture, no organization, and awful lecture notes, must be careful when selecting his course, make sure you have a deep understanding of linear algebra, and just for credit. Exams and projects are not hard, and talking to TA is useful.

2 types or grading criteria an only one midterm, that's the only thing I needed. I was at lower C in midterm but after homework and final, I ended up with a B+. Easy exams and most of the paper has True/False which makes him easy professor but grading is hard.

Most students attend his lectures only for attendance. He is often rude in answering questions, rushes the material without conceptualizing it, and clarification is often followed by condescension. For any difficult class, you will rely solely on the book. He is intelligent, but that doesn't make him a good lecturer or person to be around.
Lectures are crappy text book examples. Test is majority of grade. I would stay another semester not to take him. Basically have to teach yourself from textbook or youre screwed.

He is really knowledgeable, but he is not that great of a teacher tbh. He mostly reads off his own book and keeps writing a lot of math on the board. It gets very hard to follow at times. You should have a very strong hold on Linear Algebra before taking this course, else don't. I didn't and still took it, making it harder than it is for me.
you can replace each lecture by spending 10 minutes on you tube that should tell what kind of experience i had in that class. the material is not hard but u need to study it on your own.

Very smart professor. Makes class somewhat easy, but you still must keep on top of work and attend every class. Very few homeworks assigned which made each one worth a lot. His TA staff graded tests very quickly, but made lots of mistakes, about half the class had to fight for points back. Final was easier than both midterms.

You will need a solid understanding of the concepts(Linear Algebra) to even understand his first lecture. He has a pretty boring style of teaching. He'll make you sleep. Homeworks are tough. Will teach from his own book.

The material is pretty hard so you should really get prepared (numerical analysis and linear algebra) before you take his class. I have to admit that he is a nice professor, and basically he answers every question you have. Not many homework but very hard ones, and you can submit as a team. His lecture is pretty dry and just reading the book is ok.

He was literally the worst professor I had in my whole life. In the beginning he gave us his unpublished book and in the class he went through proofing all of the theorems in that book, nothing more. He did not explain concepts clearly and his exams were super tough. I had a really bad experience in this class.

Professor Kalantari is one the best professors i have dealt with. His explains each topic to the finer granularity. He takes care of his students in case of any doubts. Knows each and every students in the class. He is very lenient with the grades provided you are comfortable with the concepts. And gives a good curve.
no much learning very easy class but you will not get a grade so serves no purpose
Deaf. Lectures were basically textbook explanations followed by textbook examples. Spends more than half the class reviewing the previous class's material. Just read the book, it's about the same.

Takes attendance. Lectures are very boring and he's incomprehensible most of the time. Do the homework and come to TAs office hours and you'll do fine. Class itself isn't too hard. Curve was pretty good too.

I dont know what to say about this guy. At times he really tries to explain but his lack of speaking skills makes it hard to understand. His Exams are a bit strange and hard. But the final can change everything. Overall, if you have to take the class, go with him. He is little flexible compared to the others in the CS dept.

Awful. Midterms had little relationship with the material he presented in lecture, ignoring large topics in favor details that were mentioned in passing. Homework and quizzes are fairly infrequent and are not good practice for the exams and the majority of the entire course's grade is dependent on the final exam. Wait for someone else...
i just like him. he is elegant and smart. his class will be interesting 100% .

I took databases with Dong during his first semester at Rutgers. I hope he returns because he handled the class and exams and everything very well. He was very practical in his lectures and informed us about the newer norms and technologies alongside the material for the class. He was also very respectful and nice despite rude students being there.

Really knowledgeable, caring, and funny guy. As a new prof it took him a while to adjust, but overall it's been a rewarding semester with Prof. Dong. Quizzes usually once a week, few but long HW's, his exams and expectations for them were pretty clear. Even with the transition to online learning he's handled things very well. Take his class!

This was Dong's first time teaching at Rutgers. There were some difficulties towards the beginning, but he proved to be a very genuine and caring professor. He is always willing to help students and give us knowledge outside the scope of the class. I would take a class with him again in a heartbeat!

You will find professors that are good lecturers, and some that are the good people (willing to help outside of class, quickly replies to emails, etc), but its rare to find both. Not only is he a good lecturer that can answer any question but the guy seriously cares, he wants his students to learn and he's smart enough himself to make it happen.

Did a fantastic job of presenting the material in the course in a manner that both highlighted the large scale concepts and also presented the intricate details behind why some of the formulas came about. Very open about wanting students to pass, always helpful in conversation, either after class or over email. One of my top CS professors so far

Professor Bhrushundi is the best CS professor I've had so far. He is very passionate about what he is teaching and wants all his students to learn and succeed. He said he is not failing anyone and the lowest grade given will be a C. His office hours are amazing as he will go overtime if he needs to for you to fully understand everything. The GOAT.

My favorite prof. in the cs dept. & all of Rutgers. Super caring and diligent, provides numerous resources for students to succeed-practice sets, practice midterms. Gives personalized solution reviews and prioritizes students' learning. Engaging lectures, cracks jokes sometimes. Willing to adjust teaching style, so glad to learn from him.
He was a little disorganized, but overall cared so much and genuinely wanted people to do well. Would take again

If you want an easy CS class, go here. But beware, if you're seriously looking to learn, maybe pick another professor. Class was disorganized and he decided to omit the whole final section from the course and exams. Since I transitioned out of CS to Math, this was a GPA booster. Again, this prof. is extremely easy but may hinder you're CS education

Although the class was pretty disorganized and not much was covered, Professor Bhrushundi was a great lecturer who really cares about his students. His HW is pretty tough but he helps a lot if you ask. If you understand the HW, his quizzzes and exams are also straightforward, not to mention the extra credit he offers as well. I highly recommend!

This TA is the best TA I ever met. Intelligent guy, responsive, and extremely patient. If you have questions, definitely go for him. He is here for you almost 24/7. I hope I could have him in all my CS classes!
Dont ever trust the guy. Lies about practice exam being similar to difficulty to the midterm. Besides that his class is much easier compared to other advance calc professors.

He is so helpful! He wants to do anything possible to help his students do well. His lectures are SUPER clear, grading criteria is so fair, and his exams are also very fair. He just wants all his students to do well. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

Learning from his lectures are much easier than learning from the book. He genuinely wants everyone to pass, allowing calculators and a formula sheet on exams. He is extremely knowledgeable in every aspect of the course. He may seem careless at times. If you simply want to pass, he is the perfect choice. If you want to learn, you must inquire.
clear note
I loved her class so much!!! The most caring person in the entire department.

A very kind/caring teacher that cares a lot about how well people understand the material and a lot about what she teaches. She is relatively new at teaching and can make some errors but she does her best with the hacker hours.
101/10 would tak again

CS 110 is a baby easy class that could literally be taught to 5th graders. First third can be a little tough but once you're into Scratch it's brainless. I can't really give advice because all of it seems too obvious to give advice on, just know basic word comprehension in relation to Scratch.

He's really into teaching the subject and it's an easy class if you're good with computers and a little bit of programming (Scratch). It is a bit hard to get an A if you screw up on your assignments but the 2nd chance policy on the exams really can save you. There's plenty of extra credit to get you a good grade and get points back that were lost.
Its really not that hard of a class.
You will want to rate him under the listing "Jt" since most people know him as that. Excellent Professor. Knows his stuff. Cares about students.
He was awful! Did not fully explain material. very rigid. Unyielding to student issues or special needs. Can't understand the TAs, they barely speak english. A total waste of time and money.
he doesn't wear shoes. he gives hard review sheets btu easy exams.
Classes important for understanding concepts! Although he is not the course conductor, his lectures are pretty decent.

his lecture notes were very hard to follow and notes he uploaded were cryptic and abstract, they don't prepare you for the tests. his practice tests are nothing like the real tests. he's all over the place and you have to learn on your own. your grade will be up in the air and there's not much you can do about it. very tough and not worth takn him.
Bad lectures, Tough exams, Nothing good about this class.
No ppt, no textbook, only Notes on the lecture. We cannot read what he is writing on the board!

He really cares about you and the material he is teaching, he wants you to grasp it. He tries to use clear examples that demonstrate the ideas easily. Definitely take advantage of office hours if you need extra help. He doesn't make the class easy, by natural this course should be somewhat challenging, but he is an extremely fair grader.

He's all over the place and doesn't have a coherent or set grading scheme. We didn't cover half the syllabus. He often forgets what he's talking about in lecture, or spends half an hour on some random useless proof we don't need. I did alright in the class, but having my grade so up in the air sucked. He does say he won't fail anyone though.
He knows exactly how a class is to be taught. Classes are intense and fun and he gives questions to think about. Less tests, lots of time and availability on email makes him the best!
Gives low grades, not much of an overall curve it feels like. I did learn a lot though. This course is mainly about knowing how to count, and finding the probability for events.

Professor Steiger is very knowledgeable about math. He does make his exams and class hard. If you want to learn, Steiger is the man to go! It's not easy to get a good grade for his class and ended failing.

He is a good professor, but his exams are tough. A lot of what he says in lecture doesn't really coincide with his exams. Just try to study the homeworks. If you get below the average, then it is possible you can fail like me. Had to repeat the course after low exams and homeworks. Tough class and lower grades.
Great Lectures but  some topics were not explained clearly. Encourages you to ask questions and be clear about the topic. Good professor overall.

As Morgan Freeman mentions during Wormhole, probability is a subject most humans find extremely unintuitive. 206 is really just a prob. course in disguise, so it can be a bit stressful for some. Compounded with the fact your final average is determined by a relatively few amount of grades. (5-6 HWs & two heavily weighted exams), its a little scary.

Very enthusiastic about the topic. Unfortunately, the whole class is about paying attention to him writing on the black board. Such is life with a math course. He genuinely wants people to learn and get something from the material. Study from midterm/final practice instead of spending a lot of time on notes. Format will the same as exam.

I think the root of the problem is that he just doesn't know the stuff himself so the way he teaches it is even more confusing, he gave us stuff like we can do a proof but it didn't make sense. i.e. the negative version of this quadratic formula works out b/c it's 0/0 versus random#/0 basically he bsed a ton of proofs on the board.

As others have said about 206, the class is pretty hard. Exams are fair and the homework, while it can be hard, is straight forward once you understand the problem.He's a good professor, wants you to ask questions, but I really think letting this class be 3 hours long was very hard to grasp/care about the material as you lose interest after an hour

This class is very hard and he only makes it harder. He does not use a textbook and only gives class notes and online handouts. He is helpful if you ask him questions but he does not reveal any answers to HW. The HW is very hard and the examples are limited. You will learn a lot though.

You will learn a lot as he teaches well, but the format of the class will definitely hurt you. 75% of your grade is the midterm and final, very little margin for error to pass this class. He is also quite disorganized and that hurts with difficult problems.  He makes the material more difficult than it should be.
Course wasn't well structured. It's not a class where you learn skills. It's a class where your previous skills are judged.
good professor, posts notes, review sheets, and practice exams online too.

Steiger is the best professor I have ever had. He conveys concepts with amaizing aptitude, and always makes himself available to both help his students and to discuss material broader than the class' intended scope if for no greator reason than to broaden a student's horizons.
 Phil, RU-2000.

Guess not so many people like Numerical Analysis, but in William's class, he can make everything interesting and so clear that you can never miss anything. By the way, he seems has never been tired. Very helpful both in class and out of class. I will vote him "professor of the year" in the CS department.
Steiger rules.  Anyone who writes down "Backwards E (there exists) pretty algorithm" on a blackboard is simply awesome.
He's one of the best professors I've had.  I was never particularly good in mathematical courses, but when Steiger taught Numerical Analysis, I understood it and even found it interesting.
Guy knows his stuff and is able to explain it lucidly.
Good teaching!
He's awesome.
323 is a boring class, but Steiger made it bearable. The tests were very fair and the homeworks were easy. He also has really comprehensive notes available on his website.

Numerical Analysis is NOT the most fun CS course available, but required; Steiger's constant moving around the classroom, and easy-to-understand teaching style is helpful. Keeps you interested, and is very receptive to questions.
I would recommend him, good semester. No curve but you can track your grade during the semester, assignments were graded quickly.
He is a nice teacher and takes time for clarifications during lectures or on Piazza. Be ready for a lot of homework and projects, but a lof of tools are useful for other stuff (Amazon EC2, SQL, JSP).
He is a really dynamic teacher, and provided original examples. He also gives a lot of career tips for CS Majors.
Really helpful office hours! His lectures were really good and he provided a lot of examples to help better understand the material.

I probably learned more from his class than I have in any other CS/Problem solving introduction. Not only that but also puts in a lot of effort to make the work fun with concrete examples. He shares his slides with the students.

Very accommodating to new computer science students. Also very helpful with questions. Explains everything very clearly and is very open to questions. I am at ease in class and I am not worried about falling behind.

The professor won't put more effort in than straight reading his lecture slides from the early 2000s. Class is more like C with objects than modern C++. I would have been better suited reading a book and watching YouTube videos for C++, which I did anyway since the professor puts 0 effort into teaching. Complete waste of time.
nice person, patient, while not very helpful in lecturing. explicit slides that I dont even need to come to class.

The professor class is extremely useless. And if you want to take the class for a good grade, don't take it. He is an unpredicted professor with no knowledge. Read the course yourself is more helpful.
Very humble professor! He does have some accent issue. But if you listen carefully, he is actually explaining everything. Moreover, i like the way how humble he is.
Good at teaching C++ programing. Give half of the class a grade of A.

By far the worst professor I have ever had. Very unclear and dismissive. Cannot teach at all. Assumes that you know some of the material already and refuses to go over it. Office hours are completely useless. Never been so lost in my entire college career. Avoid at all costs.
Humble professor, but his teaching ability sucks..

The professor is polite, but utterly incomprehensible, and seems reluctant to actually put any effort into teaching the course, beyond lecturing. The project documentation, for example, was non-existent. There are a lot of jobs right now in databases; unfortunately I won't be filling any of them because I never learned anything in this class.

Cant understand a word he says, and he is not helpful in office hours. I had a classmate tell me he told him that he couldnt help him out because he doesnt know how to use a windows pc. Really? a CS prof? seems fishy. In class he literally reads you the book. Very bad/boring class
He is pretty bad

claims the book is not required, but he shouldn't flatter himself. Go to lecture to figure out what concepts he covers, and use google and the book to learn everything. if you don't, you won't know the material enough to compose solutions in the homework. Make friends, do the homework in groups. Get no less than 100 on the homeworks, it WILL help u

hes not a great teacher and ive learned nothing new in the class. but he did curve the class. no one got below a C unless they didnt take the midterm and final. just make sure u do the programming assignments, but u dont have to attend class or recitation to pass.

The worst CS teacher I have ever had at Rutgers.  Don't take if you can.  He loves doing proofs and they seem to have no meaning.  His lectures are REALLY bad.  No lecture notes.  Seems to be disorganized.
he can't teach. he just goes on and on and on about one thing and by the time he's moved on you're not listening anymore and you're totally lost. homeworks are hard. exams are like the homeworks

In my four years here, I have never gone to almost every single class, taken copious notes, done all the assignments, and been so completely clueless for the entire semester. The only saving grace was I wasn't the only one, and my 42 on the final was one of the highest grades in the class and got me a B. Good guy overall though.
His slides were completely useless and his lectures would put the class into a trance-like state.

Lectures aren't fun.  His slides suck.  His lecturing is boring.  The tough final project (most useful thing i've learned) has nothing to do with him (TAs).  His exams are very homework-based, but still unpredictable and have very vague T/F questions and never-seen-before queries.

Professor Stoll is easily the best Comp Apps prof in the department. I know people from other sections that used his notes instead of their own professor's slides because they were so much better. His lectures are interesting, and he is a very good professor. Absolutely take his comp apps sections

The lectures are boring; I have a friend who read the textbook instead of going to class and still got an A. He gives a lot of extra credit, and you need to study a lot for the exams, but getting an A or B+ isn't too difficult. I'd recommend Stoll because the grading structure makes it easy to do well. It's not the most enjoyable class, though.

Lectures can be boring, but are useful. He highlights key terms and concepts we should know, which helped for exams. If you can't figure out hw, he would help before class. If you do all the hw, extra credit, and go to recitation, you can get an A. Questions at end of each chapter helped for exams. Go to recitation to understand material

Professor Stoll is a kind guy, but struggles in other areas. I had to constantly email him (few times/week) about my grade because he kept marking them incorrectly. During lectures, he made mistakes on the code. At the end of the semester, there were less than 10 students left. Ended up with an 89.9 and he refused to round up. Very tough grader.

Honestly, Java is a pain in the ass. But he does his best to make it less of a pain. The grading system really sets you up to pass easily. Trick is to finish assignments ASAP, start them the day they're released. If you get an A on all assignments, you already have almost a 50% in the class. Go to TA's for help. You'll be totally fine with Stoll

The assignments are painful,so go to lab support and start them at least a week early because they take a lot of time. Reading the textbook is a must, but it was hard for me to read. It's Computer Science so it can be hard to understand. He goes at his own pace in lectures. Since the class isn't curved, there is a lot of extra credit opportunities.

If you put in the effort you should have no problem in this class. Lectures aren't necessary just read the book. Tons of extra credit to help boost your grade. Grading criteria is clear and is very manageable to get an A. Assignments can be a pain but go to TAs for help they are very helpful.

Stolls lectures were sort of dry but you can learn if you pay attention and as long as you have a good TA, you should be fine. The extra credit pop quizzes were online so keep an eye out for that if youre not attending class. Start the assignments early, they can get long. The second chance policy and the extra credit really bumped me to an A.

Professor Stoll's Comp Apps class was great. The grading rubric sets you up to do well and unless you really don't try, you can't fail. There are tons of extra credit and also a second chance policy which helps you fix your grade if you do poorly on either of the 2 exams. There's one HW a week that isn't too bad. Take this class!

I really likes professor Stoll. I did not like computer apps but he was a very caring and kind professor. He was understanding and tried to help. Lots of tutoring hours. He offered 20 points of extra credit which helped a lot. His lectures are sometimes cool, sometimes boring. It's not necessary to go but it helps. You should def attend recitation.

He offers a lot of extra credit options, mentions online quizzes during lectures but I just checked every couple of days if he posted any. Homework is extensive and hard, it sometimes took me almost the entire day. GO TO TA'S OFFICE & LAB HRS FOR HOMEWORK HELP! Read the textbook if you want to do really well on exams and review previous homework!

Overall this is a pretty easy class. He posts his powerpoints online so if you don't go to class, looking over them helps. TA grades hws. He was super nice and his grading policies were very clear and made it super easy to get an A. Just do the homeworks, extra credit assignments/quizzes and study some for the exams and you will be fine.

The course was coding so the only way you really grade these guys is based on grading criteria and theory. Stoll is really nice and gives candy if you answer a question. The course isn't bad if you go to recitation and do the homework. I'm lazy and got a B+ because the final has a good grading scale.

Professor Stoll was a nice guy, however the class corrected him more than he taught sometimes... Thank goodness I had a solid TA who helped me with all the projects and a friend to help me study for the exams. If you go to his lectures, he sometimes gives away exam questions so that makes it worth it!

Stoll is an interesting guy. He hands out candy during his lecture when you answer a question right or wrong.  His lecture style is a bit messy, it's kind of all over the place but you can tell he really cares about his students. His office hours are informative.  I would recommend going to class because he announces extra credit quizzes on Sakai.

Seems hard at first. TA's grade your homework so it really depends on them. Prof. Stoll only does lecturing and very willing to help if you have any questions or issues with your TA's grading. First two exams are hard. Make sure you can write the code on paper on your own and know the concepts very well.

He's a good man and there for you if you need help. Going to his and a TAs office hours are crucial for some assignments as they can be confusing. The class seems easier than it is with all the extra credit, but effort and studying are still required for an A. Recommended!

Some of the material in the course is tough if you're not a computer person, but go to your TA's office hours. Stoll had a hard time explaining some things during class. Assignments are tedious. Exams are at times difficult, but they are graded pretty leniently.

I went to the lectures to learn the material but it really wasn't necessary. The slides from lecture were uploaded online so you could read those. The actual class is fine but the homework assignments are a pain. Go to office hours or find some friends in that class because you will need help. Also take all extra credit, brought me from a B to an A

He's not the best with explaining concepts in class so you're better off reading the book. However, if you go to his office hours, he really takes the time to help you. His extra credit quizzes are based off of his slides so they're easy. This course overall isn't so bad if you take the time to practice everything learned in class.

He doesn't know what he's talking about and a lot of times students ask questions and he doesn't know the correct answer. He doesn't make the exams but also doesn't look over them so he isn't helpful in preparing. I got an A by reading the book and basically teaching myself. I also went to all the lectures and recitation & got all the extra credit

Class is only 50 mins, get let out early every time. Powerpoints are useless, just study the things from topic sheet in book to pass. When asking questions, he sometimes does not know the answer. Attendance is extra credit but is why I got an A. Assignments are hard, but grades depend on recitation TA. Seems impossible but possible to get goodgrade

Not that bad of a teacher, however I preferred reading the book to hearing him lecture, so I never really went. He tried to make a few assignments harder like the excel exam so if anything I would go for a different professor. Overall, the course is a breeze you'll easily pass as long as you do the assignments. If you want an A, just read the book.
I struggled with Calc 135 but Eliane was a great professor! Very nice and approachable. Will help you understand the material as much as she can. Don't be afraid to go to office hours!

I enjoyed taking Calc135 with Traldi because she really cares about her students and gave very clear/straightforward lectures. I took Calc1 before so I came in knowing a lot of the info but the tests were very fair and she prepared me for the final. I heard that she is apparently leaving for the Spring semester which sucks cuz she's amazing.
Traldi is a nice professor. She always stay in classroom for helping students to solve problems after class. She is in general friendly though the course failed almost 1/3 people in the end.

She is indubitably the best calculus 152 professor. She doesn't extremely well, but her lectures are understandable, and if you have doubts, there are always so many resources online and you can go to her office hours. Exams are fair and straightforward, and honestly, I was prepared for the final. Don't get worried , CALC II is overhyped.

She was always very lenient with the deadlines for webassign. Her lectures always involve the class and she encourages participation. Her tests were tricky and tedious, and they don't really reflect the homework at times.

Great lecturer,and she obviously wants everyone to succeed. One problem is,152 is pretty tough, but she spends lots of time answering the questions of confused students, and end up not covering all the material and examples. When finals come, we might not be ready. Those students should come to office hours instead of taking everyone's time.
She is a great professor. She really cares about teaching and her students. She will answer any question you have and her exams are really fair. I really recommend her!!

Absolutely amazing professor. I failed the first exam, but soon after realized that going to her office hours would truly make all the difference. She really cares about her students, and has amazing notes/examples in class (which she puts up online). Really keeps the class engaged and has an insane grade replacement policy. Highly recommend.
She is one of the sweetest lecturer at Rutgers. She really cares about all her student. The class isn't bad at all as long as you do your homework and go to the lecture.

I love Elaine. She is a great lecturer and does care about all her students. There are a bunch of homework and in-class quizzes but they are pretty easy as long as you go to the lecture and read her notes. The final is optional. I got an A without taking the final. BTW this course is more a Math course than a CS course.

I did not like him at all. His grading was so hard and compared to the other TAs, he took off more points if you get a little thing wrong. If you have him, switch out as soon as possible, otherwise get ready to get anything below a C+. He is terrible and could not understand him at all during recitation and gave up after 2 weeks.
4 HWs, 3 Exams. A great class. Best professor for MIS. Dont think too much, I have been where you are my fellow college student. Just take him. Thank me later!
He gave homework with same answers two completely different grades. Definitely not a careful grader. Having bais on the student for no reason.

Prof. Lee is a great guy, hilarious and easy to reach. You should go to class and take notes to get an A. Also, go to his office hour on time is also important. Go to his office hour, on time and learn. This class will be easy A.
So sweet, so helpful. Not easy material but he makes it understandable. Always willing to help. 5 HWs not bad at all but not super easy, super helpful for the exams. Definitely take him!!

Prof Lee was great! The course was slightly difficult, but for the most part he helped you out if you were struggling in any way. Make sure to ask questions during class because he goes over any issues you have very thoroughly. There was some HW, but it was manageable. Overall, he taught the material well and in an interesting way!
Great teacher
Chill guy, somewhat hard material so it did make the course really hard but he made it pretty interesting for the students, he also was really chill I even hung out with him on the weekends.
He makes class enjoyable and something to look forward to. Very down to earth and even hangs out with his students on the weekends, but his office is very far away.

I have no words for how amazing of a teacher, Professor Awasthi is. He is brilliant, and he can make the hardest topics seem easier than they should be. Very organized and he actually wants his students to succeed. I wish I could take every class with him.

Let's be real this class is hard, and a bit harder with him, but I think I learned a lot in classroom compared to all my CS classes. HW will make you hate your life and will test your critical thinking skills. Very smart and knowledgeable. Never smiles lol. NOT AN EASY A BUT SO EASY TO GET AN A WITH SOME EFFORT

Amazing lecturer. He explains key concepts very well during class. Accessible during office hours. The only issues with him are that he spends way too much time answering questions which ended in him teaching less material than I would have liked (still taught everything expected). Expect challenging problem sets and open note tests.

I really think he is one of the best CS Professors at Rutgers. You have to put in the time and effort to succeed in his class, but he readily helps anyone who asks for it in/outside of lecture. I would recommend his office hours especially, which are mini-reviews of the material. He also has an open-note policy for all exams/quizzes and curves!

The most inspirational and intelligent professor I have ever seen, but very generous in grading. Assignment and the practice are really hard. However,the process of doing the homework is a great way to internalizing the materials and think it deeper, while the exams are not that tricky. Highly recommended if you want to learn stuff.
although he always make us do some very hard homework but I think is doable if we try our best. Test is not so hard. I think this way to teach is inspirational for cs students. very nice prof
One of the best professors I've ever had. Explains everything clearly and gives good, clear answers to any questions students ask in lecture.
Professor Awasthi was a great professor for Discrete II. He put all his slides online and had a ton of useful practice reviews for class. I would recommend him to anyone taking this subject

Explains everything clearly, willingly takes questions, and takes great notes. Whats even better is he posts his own notes online, and the exams and quizzes were open notes. So as long as you study the class problems and his practice exams, and bring them with you to the quizzes and exams, you'll be fine.

Probably the best professor in machine learning department. Explains the intuition before doing the actual math. No step in his derivations comes out of the blue. Everything has a meaning that he explains clearly. Welcomes discussions and clarifies any questions reasonably well.

One of the Best Professors at Rutgers. Gives you the intuition of all concepts before deep diving into them. Great learning opportunity. My biggest regret is not taking his class for credit. Would 100% recommend him.

This professor is the reason why I finally passed Discrete 2: the hardest of the CS reqs. He writes his lecture notes (solving problems, mostly) as he lectures and then posts them afterwards, which is the most effective way to do lectures in a math-based class, I've found. Also usefully organizes topics around variations of a single sample problem.

Best CS professor i've had at Rutgers. The class isn't impossible while also being challenging but interesting.  From what I've heard Discrete 2 is a nightmare for some students but this guy makes it quite doable to learn and do well in the class. If he's open definitely take him.

Solid professor. Lectures are clear (good balance of theory + examples) and uploaded to Sakai, so attendance isn't exactly mandatory, but you should go because they're not coma-inducing like some other professors'. Homework and quizzes are infrequent, fair, and announced with ample notice. The hardest part about the course is the material itself.

Tejas is AWESOME. If you have the chance to get him as a TA for Comp Apps, TAKE HIS RECITATION. If you ask him for help on the assignments he will pretty much give you the answers and he is willing to help. Funny guy, definitely recommend as a TA.
Great TA for Comp Apps Business. Helps with every assignment!

His pronunciation is hard to understand, which is not his fault. However, the materials he posted out are clear and perfectly sufficient for students to learn and understand what they are learning. Projects are using unpopular programming languages, but as soon as you have basic programming logic and follow instructions, they are simple. Respect!

Material itself isn't that hard and he (along with the TAs) were lenient with partial credit and grades. Scheme and Prolog are annoying at first, but with practice you'll get the hang of them. I don't think there was an overall course curve but, tbh, the class itself is pretty easy. would highly recommend

I would definitely not recommend this professor. If you have the ability to attend a different lecture, do so! I get that Steinberg has a disability that makes it hard to hear him in lecture, but all he does is read off of power point slides something that can easily be accomplished at home. Definitely not worth the money you pay for education.

Many people here won't give Steinberg a chance because of his Parkinson's, but as long as you can get past that, Steinberg is a amazing and caring professor. You won't be able to understand him at lecture but he more than makes up for it with with his amazing slides. He's very caring , generous, quickly responds to emails and questions on Piazza.
Hes very fair. Makes the tests fairly easy. He is hard to understand not impossible. Will answer every question.  His piazza contributions helped a lot.

He is a very intelligent and reasonable man. He might be a little bland, but as a person, there's nothing wrong with him. However, much like everyone else is saying, his Parkinson's disease makes him IMPOSSIBLE to understand. He posts lectures online, but don't expect to get benefit out of asking him for help or attending his lectures.

im sure he might be a good prof but steinberg has parkinson's disease which makes it REALLY hard to understand him. after the first three lectures i never showed back up to his lecture again and neither did half the class. like i said, he might be a good professor but his disease really limits him. if you have him, switch.
He needs to clear his throat while speaking.
He is speaking in cursive 9/10 instances

At some point in the semester, I could count the number of students who attended lecture on two hands. Despite this, his lecture slides, which he posts online, are clear and pretty predictive on what will be on the exams. But I feel like I came out of this class having learned nothing except Lisp syntax and some interesting properties of Prolog...
Very difficult to understand
I had an A prior to the final. I ended up with a Cplus after the final. The final is ridiculous and will make or break you.

Steinberg is very knowledge and introduces cool material. However it is very difficult to understand him in lecture; he has Parkinson's disease so his speech is often slurred. He tries and gives great powerpoints but learning things from him lecturing IS REALLY HARD

Very good person and an extremely good helper. He will help you with anything you need help with.  He is very hard to understand and I did not learn much due to that which is not good for a class like 112.  I would recommend taking someone else
Prof. Steinberg is a great CS professor who's friendly and takes a vested interest in having his students learn.  So, you know, like a unicorn in this department.

Easy class, but lack of a curve (i.e. 90+ is an A, 85-89 B+...) and rather "harsh" grading (graders are pretty stingy with partial credit) make it more difficult than necessary.  Lectures are pretty pointless (not really his fault but it's almost impossible to understand him), but he's reachable by email and responds fairly quickly.
Very experienced and knowledgeable. Puts slides online.

Professor Steinberg is great, I had him in Spring Semester 2015.  His Powerpoints are very clear-cut, and he's very friendly and helpful- his Parkinson's sometimes makes lectures hard to understand, but he tries his absolute best to answer EVERY question clearly.  He covers lots of programming, which is essential for projects!  7-810 professor. :)

Had Prof. Steinberg for CS-112, Data Structures.  He's actually a pretty good lecturer, despite having Parkinson's- you just need to listen a bit harder.  He provides excellent Powerpoint slides which can be used later to study.  Only gripe with the course overall (not him) is that exams aren't taken directly from most lectures.  Great professor!
Study the slides, do the work, and you'll be fine.

He makes up for his speech by giving amazing powerpoints. All you need to do is study his powerpoints, and you will be fine on the exam. He's always incredibly nice and sweet, and he is by far my favorite Com Sci professor. Extremely helpful and kind!!

This was my first time taking Comp Sci and having him was not helpful. Maybe if i had another professor i would have performed better on exams but unfortunately I did not do well at all. If you already know comp sci, youll do absolutely fine in the class. If you do not know any comp sci, switch out.
DO NOT TAKE HIM. YOU WON'T UNDERSTAND A THING HE SAYS AND HE IS VERY UNHELPFUL AT HIS OFFICE HOURS TOO. Worst professor I've ever had at Rutgers. Just, DON'T.
Take him only if you want to mess up your grades.  Unclear as hell!!!
Easy exams, gives you practice midterm to help you prepare for them. A little difficult to understand at times, but overall great professor.

He is obviously very knowledgeable in the field. However, he has very bad Parkinson's disease. This makes it difficult for him to speak clearly. And when he attempts to write or type, he takes a while and it comes out difficult to interpret.
it is really understand him in lectures. i barely went to class. you can learn the material online and in recitations.

Was always available to help out either through email, office hours, or the discussion board. His slides are very clear and he even posts them on Sakai so if you can't make it to class or if you can't understand him during lecture then it is still easy to do well. Though, no matter the professor, CS 111 is a difficult class.

I didn't enjoy Steinberg's class. He might've been a good teacher before but since his disease, he is barely audible. That's why more than half the class is never there and those who are usually are doing work for other classes or playing games. Every class is him standing at the podium mumbling. I found it very disengaging, confusing, and boring.

Never went to office hours, emailed him, etc BUT i was always the kid asking questions in class. Not once did he ever blow me off, and he always answered my questions thoroughly(sometimes taking up to 8 minutes to answer 1 of MY questions). This guy is awesome and I understood everything he said. Make an effort and you'll do great.

I agree that he is hard to understand sometimes, but his availability through email and chat rooms makes up for that. If you missed something in class, he will help you quickly if you meet him half way.  His tests are fair and in-line with the material covered, which in itself is enough to deserve a positive rating. No surprises, and quick to help.

I did decently well considering I had absolutely no interest in taking this class. The assignments are okay, and the exams aren't too difficult, but you really need to put a great deal of effort in if you are just taking the class because you're a math major.  Class attendance isn't mandatory either.
Very knowledgeable person on the subject but It's very hard understanding him and very easy to get lost.

This guy has parkinsons to the point where he really shouldnt be teaching anymore.  He can barely talk and he's pretty incomprehensible. Not attacking the guy its just a fact. Also, I missed the deadline for an assignment due to a death in the family and he wouldn't even hear out my (completely legitimate) excuse, just gave me a zero.

Exam questions are pretty straightforward if you review the lecture slides and do the problems. Because of his Parkinson's, you need to have patience in order to do well in his class. Also, if anything is unclear or contradictory, talk to him in person or e-mail him. He's very helpful and compliant when you do.
