If you can't even talk, why teach? Seriously, do not take this professor if you don't want to learn anything at all. Absolutely useless - had a horrible experience with him in two classes and now I'm done for good.
He is a nice person,but his lectures were boring because he would just read off his powerpoints. The book was completely useless, so I suggest using Google to learn the material.
he's a nice guy, but he  can't teach. he told our class he has parkinson's, so it kind of comes thru his teachings. he tries to teach, but its hard to understand him.
Nice guy, Horrible professor.
one word..horrible
not helpful. quizzes are hard. useless teacher, reads slides. has no concern for your grade. dont take him hes useless.

I am sorry to say this but the classroom experience was not helpful overall. He was a nice guy, but his monotone quiet method of speaking always had me ready to fall asleep within ten minutes. He would make an effective hypnotist but unfortunately is not an effective educator in my mind.

Drives home the material without pushing it on you. Very enthusiastic and involved in class. Complaints that the other students in a lecture hall do not participate which makes class muddled and confusing. Great experience though

This course is not the monster everyone claims it to be. To find success requires only a working knowledge of logic and time to learn syntax.This professor knows programs written under stress does not reflect what one has mastered in java and structures his exam to make up for this.  The text used in 111 is absolutely useless- use an AP java text

This proffesor knows his material well, he keeps on reiterating things until he feels everyone understands it, if you don't get it just speak up!!! He is knowledgable and understanding also, i had an issue with one exam and we came to a very fair agreement.

This course is a lot like a Calculus (but harder for some) in that it's an ocean of work/material. To do well, you must practice programming and complete/understand all assignments. Professor was clear and patient and did his best, and although I learned a lot, I don't recommend this course unless it's a must. BEWARE OF THE PROGRAMMING EXAMS.

Extremely hard for non computer science majors such as myself.  First exam was pretty straight forward but the second exam had questions and material we had never learned (guess we were just supposed to pick it up from reading?).  He presents the material pretty straight forward but is extremely boring and doesn't add to my learning experience AT A

Possibly the most boring class I have taken.  He is great with offering help (office hours, email, even phone) but he is not the clearest professor.  If you take this class and do poorly on the first exam, don't worry, there is not much code for the next exam and final.

Really nice guy, but really hard to learn from. Really tough entry level class for non computer science majors; I'm a meteorology major and it was ok at first, but then the material got really hard and he couldn't teach it well so I had to devote almost all my time to this class to pull off an A. Find a professor who teaches really well for this.

a nice guy, but not that great of a prof.  puts most of the work on the shoulders of his TAs. very helpful and will make sure you understand the material, but his parkinson's hinders his ability and quality of teaching.  stick with the other CS111 profs if possible

Class is super hard. Don't take unless you have to. Steinberg is a very nice guy but not the greatest professor. Don't let these people fool you, his parkinsons hinders his teaching capabilities. I went to Pradip Hari's (other CS prof) lectures and hes much better. Steinberg is really good with help after class. The CS material is inherently hard.

Good professor.  If you didn't understand something, he exlained it until you got it.  If you have never taken any compsci courses before, I'd suggest learning a lot about Java.  I didn't know anything before this class and I really wish I had.  I dropped it beore the semester ended, but Prof. is great!

Kinda hard course because of the number of completely different style languages needed throughout the course. If you haven't programmed in function or logical languages you may have a hard time. Cant understand him to well during lecture, but he does a great job making sure everyone understands. Very nice grading saved me from his hard exams.

he was alittle disorganized but his tests were on topic with the lectures...the book was a waste of money, but i thought the class was fair. he is a very easy to understand and approch. he would always ask if everyone understood and if you didnt he would explain it until you got it...good man
He presented the material very well, but I feel like the tests were not representative of the "important" material.  If you go to class and listen you should do well

His parkinson's doesn't stop him from being a great teacher.  His lectures are informative and very on-topic for the class and exams.  His exams are very fair and raesonable.  His enthusiasm is high and makes you want to come to class.
If you are in a real tough spot, email the prof. He's very fair and caring
Class is tough, but I loved the prof
Homework grades are important
A little goofy, but I loved him

For an upper level CS course, this class is definitely on the easy side. Gerasoulis is lenient with HW extensions. He wasn't very clear of what he expected us to do on HW; much of the it was just a guessing game of what he wanted to see. He is also lenient with exam scales - but beware, the exams are long and you probably won't finish them on time.

Professor Gerasoulis is probably one of the funniest CS professors at Rutgers. He will call you out if you aren't paying attention in class, and he will make a joke about it. He is really light-hearted with his lectures and always tries to get students to participate. Professor Gerasoulis also is very nice about HWs and will give you extensions.
em. Yes the lectures are sometimes unclear but you will be fine if you do work by yourself.
This professor is very unclear. But numerical analysis is a good class to take.

Great teacher, easy class, you learn useful material that you can take outside the classroom. Good lecturer too, breaks down coding so it's easy to understand, goes over many examples in class. If you go to class and listen, you will enjoy.
probably the worst teacher i have ever had speaks broken english and half of the programs he writes dont work PSA matlab is the devil and so is he
This professors lectures aren't clear but he does help a lot.

Frequently steps over himself in lectures and muddies what should be pretty straightforward material. For a Computer Science professor, he was impressively inept at using Sakai correctly. Quizs were supposed to be weekly but quickly turned into "whenever I feel like it." Don't blow off homeworks, attend class, and you'll do fine despite Gerasoulis.

Awesome professor. he engages in  conversations with students and gets to know them on a personal level. doesn't take attendance but doesnt like when a lot of people skip. he gives "review sheets" with solutions that are basically the exams. he does give a lot of extra credit questions for students who do attend class. dont have to go to recitation

Great professor really cares about his students if you complain that you don't have enough time for an assignment, he gives you more time. I likes to put people on the spot and comments if your late or absent. Also enjoys going on tangents, his quizzes/test are extremely fair, he gives practice exams WITH SOLUTIONS which are practically the test xD

His lectures can be confusing at times and sometimes it is not clear whether or not something that seems out of place was intentional or not.  He is extremely helpful and wants you to succeed.  Attendance not mandatory, but he gets offended when a lot of people start ditching.
poor quality
Good professor, just study and do your work.
No Comments

One of the best professors in the CS department. He makes a subject which is generally tough if you take with another professor, quite simple as long as you pay attention. The exams are pretty easy (final is much easier than the midterm). Very generous in terms of grading and gives extensions for projects. Lots of extra credit. Project heavy class.

Had Professor Russel for CS 211. Best professor I've had so far in the CS dept. He does not use slides so you have to go to class to take notes. He takes his time to explain the material and answer questions. Has a great sense of humor and makes sitting through 4 hours of lecture bearable. Assignments can be rough, gives extra credit. Take him.
Professor actually cares about the students. As long as you put in effort the professor will notice.

Very approachable and friendly professor with a quick wit and dry sense of humor.  Be sure to have C as your main bread-and-butter, so picking up some reference material always helps.  Assignments are graded fairly but are a bit involved, especially if you're still shaky with C from 211.

Russell's like that uncle that shows up to family occasions and asks "where's your sister?" He knows a lot of stuff and is probably one of the few professors you'll find with real world software engineering experience. I suggest you view him as a cow that produces knowledge and milk him... milk him until his udders are numb, red and chaffed.

No textbook. Professor refused to post notes because then people won't come to class.  Course was disorganized. Doesn't respond to emails. Not difficult, but don't expect to learn much. I hope you like C because that's what you'll be using. Professor is very approachable outside of the classroom and generally a nice guy.

Dr. Russel is a man of principal. With a delightful sense of humor and a charming wit, Dr. Russel captivated the class and encouraged interaction amongst peers. I give Dr. Russel the highest honor I can bestow amongst my teachers. A wonderful RateMyProfessor score. Show up, talk to him, learn what he knows. You'll become a solid programmer.
My ears have never felt more fervid than when listening to Russel's baritone voice caressing my inner cochlea. To say I enjoyed Russel's class this semester would be a gross understatement.

He isn't very clear with the grading criteria and he is awful at giving lectures. He will make very cheesy jokes with the front row and talk really soft and write incredibly small, so most of the time people are asking him to clarify what he wrote. He gives no practice or much aid, avoid him at all costs

Pros: LOTS of extra credit Lenient grading on projects as long as you justify your design Laid back lectures Good at explaining concepts Easy final  Cons: No powerpoints posted online Midterm is pretty tough Hard to get in touch with him outside of of class and a single office hour every week  Also, don't buy the book.

He was a bit dismissive/rude at times when I tried to ask him questions after class, but the amount of extra credit Russell offered this semester makes up for this. Start the assignments EARLY (especially the last one because it's brutal), and make sure you study hard for the midterm. Final is easy. Do all of this to get an A. Take him!

Morbius is absolutely hilarious, but he isn't the greatest lecturer. He can be hard to follow at times, but if you pay attention and ask questions you'll be fine. Overall his class is stupid easy, if you do the projects on time, its almost a guaranteed A. He gives enough extra credit to bring your grade up 40%. Easy class if you are not an idiot.

Dr Russel is a great professor. Very down to earth and open to discussion with students. Will frequently ask you 'how's this working'. If its not working, let him know it's not working. Ask for help with your assignments early,  take notes and you'll easily pass with an A.

Russell likes to make lectures fun by making jokes and interacting with students. He does not teach based off of the book or lecture slides, so go to class and take notes! He is very helpful during office hours and if you ask specific questions in lecture. He is open to suggestions to make his class better. He also gives tons of extra credit!

Cracks a lot of jokes during class and is a very laid back guy. Assignments almost always get extended, and if you go to office hours he's helpful. Class itself requires work, but he is a good professor to take it with. Only con is some his teaching can be a little better/clear.

my favorite thing about 214 with BKR is that he gives meaningful projects that you can be proud of after you finish them.  Side note: the textbook is really good for this class. I missed a few lectures and was able to catch up by reading the textbook.
Professor Russell was great for Systems. But the problem was that his TAs took forever to grade the assignments.
A good class and great professor. Gives extra credit, but assignments can be worded vaguely. The average was high for the class and exams were alright.

Class lectures were helpful for assignments. Take notes and pay attention to the topics he focuses on in class and you should be fine. He was always fair about grading and gave a lot of extra credit. I would say he did not write the exams to confuse people but just wanted to see if you understood the big picture. Great class
A good class if you like programming and good if you like to learn. Exams and assignments were very tough. They can be graded harshly. Difficult to get A or B+.
This was a good class, but the professor words his assignments ambiguously. He is willing to help.
Horrible professor, the entire class has been waiting on 3  5 assignment grades for over 2 months. Lectures are long and he rambles when you ask questions. Do not take this class.
Would've liked clearer explanations and more examples.

After taking classes with other CS professors at Rutgers, Russell is great. He is always helpful and reachable by email. Spends hours with students after class and in office hours. Covers 100% of what is required and what should be taught and knows his stuff inside out. The material is pretty boring to begin with but he keeps it fun and relevant.

Brian is great professor and you will learn a lot in this class. The most important part that is EXTREMELY HELPFUL! He will always find some time for you to clarify things. He will even be looking in your code if needed (very few professors are ready to do this for their students). If you work hard enough - you will get easy A.

Does everything he can to help his students. Cares about their progress and that they actually learn the material. Exams are fair and if you pay attention in class he gives you most of the answers. He is one of the best professors I have had at Rutgers. He works in the industry and presents the material in a very straightforward manner.

A wonderful professor. Saved many of us from the nightmare that was Parashar's section by letting us attend his lectures. Willing to stay after class for over an hour just to give advice. Has flexible office hours. 6 projects in total with fair extensions, but the TAs took forever to grade them. (Not his fault)

The lectures are basically him vomiting man pages on to the board, but he's willing to take suggestions that might make his lectures better. Projects really help you learn the material and aren't that hard; neither are the exams. Really shines in office hours, too.

He should not be teaching. Writes useless stuff on the board and he just mumbles the important materials. The whole course lacked of info. Everything learned by my self. Passed the class with an A thanks to the tutor.

His lectures are hard to follow, as he just reads off his notes to you and then elaborates on the concept with a sentence or two. The code presented in lecture is illegible and tiny. Just like any other CS class, his exams are random programming questions. HW assignments are doable but some are tricky. He is an overrated professor.

Cool guy, but he does not answer his emails ever. This definitely becomes a problem when you really need to get into contact with him about grades or something. Take him if you're willing to teach yourself nearly everything or if you're just that good at C programming. Also, the projects are not what you have to worry about, it's the exams.

He's nice, funny, and great at teaching. There are no slides for CS214 which is nice. Lectures consisting of PPT presentations are so boring. He writes on the board, draws diagrams, shows code snippets, demonstrations, anything to help people understand the material. Personally I found the class easy. If you pay attention in class you'll do well.

I have had this professor two semesters now and I have to say that while he is a very personable teacher, he is not the easiest of lecturers to follow. He has not used a single powerpoint for 214 (he did for 211), making it a difficult to figure out what he did if you missed a class.  I also don't feel that I had adequate prep for any exam.

The classes are not easy. However, Russell tries really hard to make it easier for the students. Gives extensions and extremely generous curves, but of course don't take it for granted. He cracks a lot of jokes and he really is a cool guy. Every Computer Science major should meet this man at least once before graduating..!!
Easy professor, gives assignment extensions and extra credit. Assignments are not worded clearly though.

Very nice and entertaining guy  ,but my biggest complaint is that he doesn't prepare for class at all. He uses code that he did years ago at his former job that barely applies to the topic. He uses the terminal in black background, making impossible to read what he teaches. All in all, he is a fine professor but you will need to study by yourself.

He taught me so much while keeping it very fun.  Expect tons of jokes that others would be afraid to tell.  Incredibly light-hearted and intelligent.  This class was a lot of work for me, but I had a great time and am quite thankful for all that he taught me.

Very cool and laid back teacher. He is very lenient on programming assignments and tests. Also is very educated in the subject. He wants you to learn the material and is very helpful in office hours if needed. Very comical too. Makes the class really interesting and helps you pay attention. Take this professor you will not regret it.

retook w/Bhattacharjee & he's a breath of fresh air. Prof B went the extra mile giving us voice recordings of lectures, extra time for assignments, extra credit, using feedback to modify the class. He explains the material in a way that is easy to understand & thoroughly answers questions. Plus class was fun! I couldn't ask for a better teacher

Wish I took Menedez's section instead of his. Bhattacharjee's great at teaching, but he lacked in course organization. He had the unofficial head TA, who was not so great at teaching, teach a couple lectures. He also had the class use the Sakai chatroom, which is garbage, esp. when sites such as Piazza exist and have been used by other CS profs.

Where do I even start with Abhishek. He's literally the god of Computer Architecture. Very intelligent, teaches the material very well, and makes sure you understand concepts. He's so knowledgeable that it's as if he's there's a comp arch textbook implanted in his brain. He's a genius. Abhishek, if you're reading this, thanks for inspiring me!

Lectures are great he conveys the material very well and I you raise your hand he will go over the material until you get it. A little intimidating to raise your hand because he is extremely bright. Projects are tough start them early and get help from tas if you need it.

Great professor. The only point of criticism I have is that he often lectures very quickly. However, he responds to any questions you have proficiently, and he will go out of his way to help you understand the concept. He is energetic and funny. He even changed the future direction of the class based on student input. Great professor.
Hes young, knowledgeable, has high-enegy, passionate and very charismatic. Makes the material very enjoyable to learn. 10/10 would take again.

He is very nice professor, hilarious also. He answered every single question that student ask in class. Attendance is not a mandatory but you have to be there and pay attention to pass the class. he upload ppt, recommend to print them and bring to class. project it self is hard, so please start early.

I love this man. A hilarious lecturer, an incredibly bright individual, and a kind and caring professor. He is probably one of the best in the CS department, and his class actually teaches you interesting things. Definitely take him for Comp Arch if you can - he only teaches in the fall. Curve is great too.

Honestly he makes it really easy on you. Material is hard, but Abhishek has a super generous grading scheme, he basically gives you the exam questions before the test, and the average is usually a B/B+.  Also he gives great lectures, and I really learned a lot with him. Great professor, probably the easiest CS class I've taken so far.
The best class on Computer Architecture. Abhishek if you reading this , thanks for inspiring me. We love you!
AB is the man.

There's a lot of material in the class but the good news is that assignments and practice questions prep you for the final. Dont sweat it if you tank an assignment here and there. Material is presented crystal clear so take notes in class. Bit of a hottie too.

211 is notorious for being a "C" class, but Bhattacharjee emphasizes digital logic much more. He threatens to give (and thus makes you prepare for) harder questions than actually appear on exams. When he tells you to "go home and stare at this slide", actually do it, because some things seem to make perfect sense when he explains it, but not later.

I was not looking forwards to this class but the professor made the class amazing. He definitely gives you a TON of information in lectures but it's always super clear. The coding assignments weren't too bad. Curve is really good. Possibly my favorite CS course so far.
c, assembly, digital logic is a lot to put into one class.  grading is cool though. talks too fast, so stop him and ask questions. but he's hilarious/cute so that helps :)
go to lectures and definitely go to recitations. also be prepared to spend time looking up other resources online. you learn a lot by the end though.
Way too much material but it really helps to go to lectures. He's also easy on the eyes so that always helps ;)
Tough class.

Really genius Professor and very motivational. too lenient with grades if you show a liitle hard effort in his course. really enjoyed studying and got to learn a lot from this course  Grade Received -A

Very clear and concise professor. Knows the material very well and very interested in it. He keeps the class moving but makes sure that you understand the material, so you learn a lot in lecture and never get bored. Possibly the best professor I ever had. Highly recommended

He is very clear in lectures and good at explaining the material.  Some of the assignments can be very difficult with a lot of work involved but don't get too stressed out with them he gives a very good curve.  I completely bombed one of the assignments and still managed an A in the course.

Tough class but he's clear (and funny). Reasonable exams but some hws are not. Know people who went to school with the dude and he has a reputation - an academic whiz (one problem is that he can go through stuff too quickly) and baller at tennis (he's hot). He'll work with you to get an A (he's considerate, coached disabled kids tennis in school).
Great class! very sweet guy. i would definatly recoomend going to all classes, and  even if you dont do well on the assigemnts its all good. He is hot too another motivation to go to class.
I learned most of the stuff from the TA classes because he was not be able to attend so many lectures. Don't take this course if you want to learn something from himself!!!

Class is easy if you go to lectures and pay attention, etc. But the real reason I'm leaving this review: Abhi is sooooo hot. I would sit there and get so distracted by his forearms and other ahem things. sorry for perving Abhi, I'm sure you read these, but yeah I didn't have trouble motivating myself to go to class. I want you, are you single?
He is not a good teacher at all. useless class

The dude is a really nice guy and is very knowledgeable about what he's teaching. He lectures a bit fast for some people but he encourages students to stop him if they fall off his high-speed train of thought. The course has a juicy curve so don't sweat it if you tank an assignment or two.

Abhishek is one of the best professors in the CS department. He's extremely reasonable, if you talk to him about any situation you're in, he'll work with you. He talks quite fast so when he says something will be on the exam, make sure you write it down. Pay attention and ask him questions and you'll do fine.

Great professor. Didn't really have to go to class and he drops a lot of grades to help everyone do well. Exams are made up of mostly old midterm questions, including the final! Also has an awesome curve. Would take another class with this guy
not clear at all. low knowledge. hard to follow. not good professor. I shouldn't have taken this course with him.
He's really knowledgeable, one of the best professors at Rutgers CS. His exams are straight forward and easy. He really gets you interested in what he's teaching.

Possibly the best professor I've ever had. Extremely approachable and helpful, does whatever he can to make sure you learn and do well. Course is curved heavily in whatever way helps the most people, regardless of whether it needs to be or not.

It was difficult but he made the experience worth it. Seeing his luscious curls made my whole week. He's a wonderful motivator when he catches my gaze with his naughty smile. I did poorly on a test and asked if there is anything I could do. He let me make it up w/ another assignment though I was hoping for more. Recommended-I'd go back for more

Excellent and brilliant professor. This class is hard. Pay attention, dedicate a couple of hours a week to study and you will really enjoy his class. He takes a lot of time to answer student's questions and really wants you to understand. Anything that you ask, he will have an amazing answer. 100% recommended but you still need to study by yourself
Here are my two cents...if you are a computer science nerd and don't do anything else in life, he will be a great teacher. otherwise, he is speaking a different language.

He knows what he's talking about, is organized, and speaks clearly. I think he tries too hard to be "cool" though. So undergrads don't like to go to class or read the textbook. Joking about it as a professor is in poor taste. Also, word of advice to students, GO TO RECITATIONS. Much of the test material will come from there. Read the textbook, too.
Best professor. very knowledgeable. Well designed course structure.

LOL the person above is prolly mad because he did not do well. He is a nice guy who keeps the class interesting. The 1st time through a topic can be confusing but he takes all questions and can clarify things well if you ask. Gives reasonable hw. THE ONLY TIME he ever sounds condescending is for questions like, "Wait, the HW is due in 2 days?!" LOL

Laughs/mocks at students when they ask questions. Very unhelpful and gives unclear and confusing assignments. Thinks he is funny, and sort of is, but he is full of himself. He went to princeton and thinks he is better than us.
Great if you're seeking help, she's more than willing to offer extra help but very bad during lectures. She constantly goes off topic and always confuses students with the disorganization.
Does not teach you how to code but rather teaches you everything that's not important. Teaches to only a few in the class as well
Nice as an individual but terrible as a teacher Should avoid.
I learned all the material myself and using google. This professor is a no no
Cant teach and super unorganized. Youre better off learning the material yourself.

Terrible teacher, going to lecture was a waste as she would only really teach a handful of students at the front. You wouldn't learn anything from her so you're better off spending the time learning it on your own

Im one of the first-row students Haldeman mumbled to this semester. I dont think these other reviewers properly utilized her. Shes not a great lecturer, but she was willing to answer anyones questions. Anyone couldve sat in the front, since the room was only about 25% full. If you sat in the back & didnt ask questions, thats your fault.

Professor Haldeman is a really good person who knows her subject but just needs to be more organized. She is very passionate about Computer Science and one can see that but she needs to structure her classes better. For instance, she should have a programming goal each class and try to stick to what's required cause its an intro class.

Took CS 111 to learn more about software, not as a major class. Georgiana's a quiet graduate student in Computer Science who can't lead a class. She's unorganized and unprepared every time. The whole lecture is her mumbling to the first row of student and bouncing around on tangents for things not in the scope in the class. Take with anyone else!

Bounces between topics and often talks to herself when teaching. When asking her a question, she won't explain in clear detail and will often give a very underwhelming response. Attended most of the lectures and did not learn anything at all. If you are coming into this Computer Science course without any background, you will have a tough time.

Professor Haldeman is a new professor just hired to teach the course in spring 2018 semester. She is a PhD student at Rutgers and she doesnt know how to teach, she bounces from one topic to another and sometimes doesnt know whats wrong with the code. I took the class because prof cowan was listed for the section but then it switched. I would avoid

Your grade this semester was based off of 2 midterms and a final- no homework. The course material is challenging so get ready to practice by yourself outside of class. Muthu is a cool guy, some may critique his teaching style but he uploads useful notes from class. The textbook is not mandatory but it is a good tool to work out practice problems.

His temperament is very unpredictable and he seems to be chill most of the time, but then gets annoyed if you don't understand something, even if he himself doesn't know the answer to what you're asking, and when you explain why you don't understand it, he just repeats that you should be able to get it.

The topics he covers in this course change every semester, but you are guaranteed to be tested on Count-Min Sketch, since he invented that algorithm. Lectures are very spontaneous; sometimes he will decide that he didn't like how a lecture turned out and will repeat it the next time. Tells you not to worry about things then tests you on them. Scary

the material itself is impossible to understand but the curve is AMAZING. yes, the legend is PARTIALLY true; a 0% on an exam wasn't a C this semester, BUT do well on HWs (get an A avg & ask for help if you need it) and get avg scores on exams (i'd say between 30 % to 40% inclusive, they're pretty lenient with grading) and you will PASS. recommend!

Loved his class. TBH algorithms, you can't really learn too much in class. If anyone spent 90 mins teaching algorithms, I would zone out. He is very eccentric. He tells stories in class and tries to make you enjoy class. Most people don't enjoy that, you really have to love algo to like him. Get ready to watch a lot of MIT lecs on youtube to prep
His lectures are REALLLILLY HARD to understand.

If you want to love algorithms (and already proficient), he's a great professor.  Probably more of a bro than a professor though. It's hard material and he fails to see that. It doesn't come to the class as easily as it does him.

Very nice and funny guy, but the material is very difficult and he seems to assume that the students understand everything he explains and moves very quickly with the material. He seems to be generous in terms of grading so that a B is within reach for many, not sure about an A.
Likes to talk about his life a lot which is kind of funny. However, I along with many of my classmates have trouble following him in lecture. The way explains concepts is very confusing :(
Muthu goes to fast. And goes off on weird tangents all the time so its really hard to follow along.
Dudes a bro... and a wizard at algorithms
Hard

I made a mistake of taking her class. The level of difficulty in her class is too low because she takes the easiest available examples and tries to teach. If you're seriously looking to learn stuff, textbooks are better. Other than that she is a nice lady, attractive and always smiling.

She is a nice person but because of the material, although she seemed really passionate and tried a lot, it tended to be dry with sloppy notes sometimes. Though, it was her first time teaching 205, but the class felt a little uneasy at times too. Don't get me wrong, the work wasn't bad, but gradingcurve was opaque and should have been on sakai.

Saraf is a good professor. She explains things very clearly and is very enthusiastic about helping answer questions. As the material more confusing, she was noticeably harder to understand, but that'll happen no matter who you have for 205. Overall shes helpful, reliable, and the exams arent too difficult if you do your HW. Highly recommended.
One of the nicest teachers I've had at Rutgers and is always so willing to help students out in any way possible. Definitely would recommend her to anyone
Very helpful and always there for you if you have a question. Good lecturer and tried to make sure her points got across. Wish more professors cared this much.

Very sweet and helpful. She encourages asking questions and clearly cares that everyone understands the material. Recitation is useless, but lectures are helpful. You don't have to participate if you do well on the quizzes, and vice versa.

I had her for graduate courses on algorithms as well as discrete geometry.  She is a great instructor.  She's very clear, and she uses class time well.  A lot of the times, class was spent with us talking about our ideas about proofs.  This gave the course a good feel, and I thought she balanced student discovery and guided discovery well.
This is the Rutgers coding boot camp course. You receive a certificate upon completion and is a pass fail.

Literally this man could convince any ordinary Rutgers student to be a CS major or minor. His lectures are funny, and they drill the concepts right into your head. He addresses issues which people faced with assignments and exams quickly. I just love him. #tjangisbossbae

Professor Tjang is always very enthusiastic in his lectures. He explains things thoroughly and simply, and always praises the people who ask him questions when they don't understand. He makes sure to give an overview of what's going to happen next, and tries to take into account everybody's knowledge level. A very nice person overall, as well.

He has double standards. In lectures he's remarkable. But, when I approached him personally, he had a very cold attitude and the only thing he said was "you're not following instructions" (I had no programming experience). I would rather do bad on an assignment than approach him again.

Tjang is honestly one of my top three fav professors at Rutgers. He really cares about this course and shows it through his lectures. It is sad that he is leaving, but when he comes back I recommend everyone to take him! This man lit af! Take this mans you wont regret it! Note: It is honestly doable to do well if you put in work

Tjang made every topic easy to understand and clear. He was also funny from time to time and very good at getting the class to think about algorithms/efficiency analysis. I would still recommend clarifying little details between Tjang and Sesh; how they taught an algorithm sometimes made the difference between getting credit on parts of a test.

I've had the privilege to have Tjang for both CS111 and CS214. I can say for sure that he is one of the best professor in Rutgers CS department. The guy's energy and passion for the material and teaching is incredible. If you have even the slightest interest in the material you wont fall asleep in his class. Always register for his class if you can
Cheeky and cunning. Friendly but don't let one professor determine your major. Major in something that you enjoy.

This guy is why I'm a CS major- his lectures are hilarious, and he's passionate about teaching and very informed. 111/112 are generally assignment/exam heavy, but he's always open to questions. He's not the most accessible given the size of his lectures, but he always responds to emails and forum posts. TAKE HIM FOR BOTH 111 AND 112 IF YOU CAN!

He's really smart and really good at lecturing. He conveys material very effectively and responds to questions well. I took him for 111 and even when I didn't have him for Data Structures, he held online review sessions that I watched and were still very good. Amazing professor. Also he's funny.

Tjang is an awesome, incredibly intelligent man. He really knows his material, and presents it clearly and effectively in lectures. He is funny and makes lectures entertaining as well. I would highly recommend him for Data Structures. He had me well prepared for exams and any homework material given.
Very smart and charismatic. A great professor!
Prof. Tjang is a really funny guy and good at lecturing. The assignments can be difficult, but that's with every other CS class.

He's a very fair professor and one of my best this semester. The homework is pretty intense. I have spent 6 hours outside of class working on them, but it's very fun and doable. He makes lectures interesting and interactive. Piazza questions are answered very quickly and frequently. I'd say the tests are very easy, especially if you listen in class

Get ready to take one of the best CS professors. However, if you don't attend lectures, don't bother. He is an outstanding lecturer, conceptualizes the material very well, and is always energetic. Friendly person, but typically overloaded with people during office hours. Be careful though, he encourages questions, but "dumb" questions he'll dismiss

If you are taking CS111 take him--he's really good tbh. Just take him, he's the one who writes the tests and stuff too. The only hard part about the class was autograder and the project you will do. Apart from that he seemed to be very fair and he's a good speaker. You will love him.

This was the first time for Tjang to teach Systems Programming. He is as great as he was in 111 (if you took it with him) and made the class much easier than other professors teaching the same course. Good curve. Got an A with 85.25% total.
The best professor I've ever had! Very clear and makes the material interesting! He is also VERY accessible and replies to the questions immediately! He's the best!!!

Andrew Tjang is a good professor as he explains the content in simple terms making it easy to grasp it. However the exams are not fair as he DOES NOT provide clear and precise exam and project instructions. For example Java is an object-oriented language but the final did not have any related to OOP.

He keeps things interesting and teaches using real world examples that make the concepts pretty easy to understand. He is thorough and is easily accessible outside of class. The topics presented could easily be boring but he goes out of his way to make it fun to learn about Java programming.
pretty good proffesser, just get ready to deal with an autograder for assingments, the thing can be pretty ruthless.
Clear and passionate.
Great professor
Reply my email in 30 seconds with solution, damn, he's the most efficient staff i ever seen!
He is a great teacher, I procrastinated towards the end and kinda screwed up but still ended with a B, so its a very doable class for a A.

Absolutely fantastic professor, very helpful and engaging. Prior CS experience is not needed to do well in his 111 class, anybody who says that is utterly wrong. Make no mistake, CS is difficult, and he will not spoonfeed you the material. That said, f you like CS and are willing to put in work you'll be happy to have him as a professor.

Tjang is an awesome professor.  Datastructures is a difficult lecture but he keeps everyone in the class interested no matter what.  It's really off to doze off in his class and he is hilarious and very dedicated in teaching

Gives hard tests but a very good lecturer. Highly recommend attending lectures if you do not know any programming before taking this class. As others said, most people know basic programming before this course and it can be annoying. Tjang is known for not being that great for office hours and his tests are definitely difficult.

If you have no programming experience at all, this class is going to be super rough. Most of the students in the class already know what they're doing because they have programming experience. There are 2 midterms (15% each), recitation attendance (10%), Weekly codelab (10%), Assignments (10%), Project (10%), and Final Exam (30%).

Tjang is a great lecturer and a kind professor. However, he is not as knowledgeable about 112 assignments and tests as he should be. Part of the reason is that Sesh runs the course, but I still think Tjang could have tried to guide us in the right direction. Regardless, I learned a lot with Tjang and did pretty well. Take him or Sesh for 112.

You just have to work hard in his class in order to do well. Just start your assignments a few days before they are due and you should be good. Class was entertaining and he is a great lecturer and seriously loves what he does. I'd recommend him.

Great teacher, however can be hard on you but he is just trying to be realistic and honest. Mos t people who do not do well are just lazy unmotivated students. Fall in love with computer science and work hard and you will do well.

112 in Spring 2015. Tjang was crystal clear in explaining the concepts. When a student asks a question, whether it is an easy one or a hard one, he lights up. I really liked that about him. He makes the student think, clarifies some concepts and allows the student to reach answer on his own. Really great teacher and makes you understand and love CS
He's a good lecturer but this is just a hard class especially if you have no programming experience. You will have to sacrifice A LOT of time to succeed.

A very good lecturer and explains things very well, but he's a straight savage once he's behind the keyboard. If you ask him a "dumb" question in class he might get a bit annoyed but still answer it as well as he can, but ask that same question online (there's a website for asking questions) and he will roast you and shut you down. Expect to work.

This class is for people with CS experience. If you are new to CS, you'll have to do A LOT work. In terms of help he's OK, has a website to ask him ?s. But he often views them as whining. There is a lot of snobiness by the profs. and some of the students that have CS experience. If you don't understand something, you'll be mocked rather than helped

I had to leave a comment because of the negative comments left below. Professor Tjang is extremely resourceful and WANTS to help people understand whats being taught. He is an excellent lecturer and is enthusiastic when explaining concepts. Yes, you need to work and practice. Even if you had no prior programming experience like me, you can do well.

He is INCREDIBLY arrogant. He shuts down kids who he thinks "asks stupid questions" or if you ask something that he went over a minute ago and need clarification. If you want a good experience, don't ask him anything. He is a good lecturer but need better people skills.

His lectures are very long, and he usually goes over everything in minute detail (If you already have Java experience, it can be incredibly boring). You can miss a couple of lectures here and there and be fine. He has a very strict guideline for turning in assignments, so make sure you follow that! But yeah, overall he is a good professor.

While I don't think I'm going to fail this class because of curves and dropped grades, I think the entire CS curriculum needs an overhaul, at least the intro classes because they seem like they're geared more towards people with programming experience and you take Intro classes because you don't have experience in the field. I've learned nothing.

He's probably my favorite teacher I'm taking this semester. He's so funny and active in class. He's clear and breaks everything down well. He assigns reading but I wouldn't say it is essential to passing but it might make your life easier, especially if you don't have programming background. Overall amazing! Highly recommend!

Funny prof. Weekly codelabs, and 6 assignments and 1 project, 2 midterms and a final. Huge curve for the final grade. Pay attention in class and make sure you do your homeworks. Some grades will be dropped too. Could had done alot better. Made a few mistakes. Be prepared to work hard esp if you dont have programming experience

Although he was great for CS 111, I'd take Sesh for CS 112 because Sesh is the program coordinator. I felt like Tjang didn't focus on the key points of what Sesh really tested you on. But Tjang still did a great job teaching the class.
Funny professor, great lectures. CS 111 was really easy and he explains it well (even if it's your first time programming). He is also the program coordinator for 111.

I took the class because I was interested in CS, and thought it might be interesting. Tjang himself is an okay teacher. This course and most of his methods were painful, however. I cannot recommend Tjang in any class unless CS comes incredibly easy to you.

Tjang is a great teacher and if you attend his lectures you wont need to even look at the text book. His homeworks will most likely kick your ass even if your code does work and the sad thing is there is not feedback to know what went wrong in your code. Exams are pretty rough. He generates a lot of interest in material though. 7.810 too much code
Good guy. Great sweaters.
He is a great lecturer, but the problems that are worked through in class are 100x easier than the homework assignments and the exams!

He's a great teacher, but he can be a little hard to work with in terms of rescheduling tests and such. That said, I really appreciated how he tried to engage lecture halls and keep the class interested. He is also extremely open to answering questions. Just make sure you're on top of your work and you should be good.

He's a young and positive guy. He is more than happy to engage and help you in discovering the solution but he will by no means hand you the answer (that's a good thing). You will count yourself lucky to have him as a professor. He care's that you succeed and you see that every class when he's up in class trying his best to engage lecture halls.

Tjang is a good lecturer and an overall helpful person. There are plenty of resources to get an A but in order to do so, you need to practice practice practice programming. I was a bit disappointed in some of the instruction provided on the assignments however, since they were ambiguous I lost a letter grade. Exams are hand written, so practice.

He's perfect. I recommend taking him. He runs 111 and Sesh runs 112. Watch out for 112. Do the assignments, because they are saving grace. 112 Exams average usually is F so, it should say something. Unless you are a CS geek or love CS, 112 will make you hate CS forever !!! Every time after 112 exams, my hair turns grey :(
Great Prof, would take again!

Pretty patient guy.   Greatly encourages class participation, and positively responds to it, but at the same time doesn't make anyone feel scared to give an answer.    His class is great- you get what you put into it, as CS goes.  I recommend sitting as close to the front row as possible and answering questions, to stay interested and involved! :)
he's a great lecturer, the class itself is really a reflection of what you put into it but tjang is really helpful in terms of clarity and providing a positive relationship between prof and student
Professor Tjang is a fantastic professor, and always manages to make class a good time. The class isn't easy, but if you put in the time you'll be happy with the grade you get.

He is one of the best instructors at Rutgers and basically what made me switch to CS as a major. His lectures are engaging and clear. The class itself requires a lot of effort. The homeworks, codelab, assignments keep you busy throughout the semester but you come out learning a lot. Not an easy A but do take it if you're interested in the subject.

He was extremely welcoming of people without any experience at all. He in fact oriented the course, 111, for the complete noobs like me. He's got a sense of humor and is the best professor I've had so far. Had to get him for 112. He's nice and very clear in his teaching.

Tjang is the best professor I had freshman year. I wish I was lucky enough to have him for 111 as well. Clear, funny, helpful, relatable--pretty much anything you want in a professor. He really wants to see everyone enjoy Computer Science. If you are taking 111 or 112 and want to learn a lot with someone who will keep you interested, TAKE HIM.

This guy is absolutely brilliant. He has shown me great insight beyond what any textbook would show and he is in my opinion the best lecturer at Rutgers. If you pay attention and contribute in lectures he will get to know you and might even help you if you have a problem, depending on the circumstance. Feel free to talk to him. He encourages it.

Finance mjr w/ no cs experience. bombed the midterm. Went to office hours once and he gave me confidence. Asked questions in class and he remembered me. As I handed in my final exam in a huge lecture, he approached me and asked what I thought, since he knew the subject was a challenge for me. Ended up getting an A. Great professor & a great man.

Andrew Tjang is so hot. Well, I don't know if he's conventionally hot, but i definitely have the hots for him. Just take his class, you'll see what i mean. Not to mention he's a superb teacher-- hardworking, fair, and knows what his students need.

Professor Tjang was a really good teacher and explained it very well for everybody in the class to understand. He is also very helpful when you email him or post on Piazza. Overall, I learned a lot this semester and I thank him because he is really good at what he does. Computer Science is not easy but he is good at teaching it.

You'd be crazy to take any other professor than Tjang for computer science.  He is extremely knowledgeable, hardworking, & interesting.  His class isn't easy, but it isn't impossible either.  He has a good sense of what students are capable of & pushes you to find your limit.  Has online office hours via Piazza & response time less than 1 hour.
He's easy and hot!

Tjang is basically the best teacher you could have for CS111 and CS112 at the moment. His explanations are crystal clear and he doesn't threaten you to come to lecture (I skipped like 5). There is a chance that he will drop homework hints at the lectures. And he is very helpful on the online discussion forum. His sense of humor helps too.

Andrew is manages to teach his stuff really well while still keeping things interesting. I had no prior programming experience before taking his class and didn't struggle at all so I don't really know what everyone's talking about.
Trust me, he's the best ever!

I'm a guy and I would probably do him. Anyway he's a great teacher and very interactive. I felt very alert the entire time in class and learned a lot of information. Just keep up with the work and go to class.

not an easy class if you have no cs experience. he's good at teaching the basics but the homework and tests are much harder. The homework is doable and gives you practice but the tests are extremely hard and pretty much were to the advantage to the seasoned cs person, rather than a newbie. grading was very generous though. not an easy A

This guy makes you feel inadequate simply because you are inexperienced. When it comes to teaching, Tjang is an analog player in a digital world. Average at best; don't expect anything from him, and you won't be disappointed. He gets half of a star for showing up.

To keep up with the course, I watched the MIT OCW Intro to CS. At MIT the chair of the dept. teaches the intro course, not a grad student, and he makes it very clear that he doesn't want any students with prior experience in his course because they intimidate the rest. Tjang is the opposite. He absolutely discounts beginners. Poor quality teacher.

Best professor I've had so far. Lecture could be more interesting and homework does take some thinking but this is only to help students understand the material. Take the time to do and understand the homework and an A is easily obtainable.

For 112, I don't recommend him because he has no impact on the hw/exams, it is all sesh. So he doesnt prepare you well for the exams that are really hard. He goes too fast, and he and sesh seemed to be on different wavelengths in terms of the material being covered. I thought he was decent 111, but inefficient in data structures.

111 is a tough class but Tjang does his best to make it easy. He REALLY wants everyone to do well and continue on in computer science. Not too difficult to get an A if you have programming experience already, but otherwise expect a challenge. Only point of readings/attendance is the occasional clicker quiz
very helpful. makes everything simple for you and big lecture halls don't feel so big because of his attitude. One of the best professors I've had so far.
It was my pleasure to learn from him. Great professor with a  sense of humor.

Andrew is great. Extremely committed and professional. I believe that he is if not the best, one of the best professors I've ever had in my entire academic career (two full BAs). I strongly recommend taking any class with him.
good professor. too bad the A was not curved though, other letter grades were.

The major problem with any CS class is that you have people retaking the course or that have programmed a good while competing with people just starting to code. Tjang is a good professor, and tries to make the class fair, but i feel the whole CS111 system is against him in per experience vs. inexperience. I liked him overall.

Andrew is awesome! First time at Rutgers that I've noticed that a professor genuinely cared about my grade. It's a very straightforward class taught at a really slow pace. Andrew works with you and really tries to make sure you understand.

the exams are hard. if u have prior comp sci knowledge u will ace this class but beginners will struggle. no curve either bc of more experienced people take it with only a few  beginners. no hw/practice test solutions. really difficult to study for the exam. no material posted up on webpage.

Tjang was one of the best professors I've ever had, let alone just at Rutgers. He was approachable and answered questions successfully during office hours. His lectures were thought-provoking. The exams were hard, but if one studied they were not impossible. I wish I could take him for every CS course.

Andrew is a great teacher! Always kind and helpful!the exams are pretty fair and are similar to the hw's which take a long time to do but once you get it you get it. the TAs are sticklers though and dont really care about your grade

Lectures do not correlate well with assignments and exams. He barely scratches the surface on topics during lectures because he wastes time with  group exercises and clickers. Exams are hard, they aren't really covered in lecture. This is a do-it-yourself class. No experience in programming can be a killer, while experienced ones have a free ride.

He is a great professor! His lectures are very clear and helpful. He always answers students' questions well and is willing to help whenever you need it. Coming in with no prior programming experience, homeworks and exams were a bit challenging. However, once you get used to his style, you will be fine.
Great teacher. Lenient on exam grading.  Understands students and wants them to do well

Coming into this class with prior knowledge, I found it a generally easy class.  As long as you go to lecture, attend recitations, and do HW, you should be okay.  Tjang is a very helpful, and somewhat lenient professor.  It's clear from the first day of class to the final exam that he really wants to improve CS111's curriculum.

Andrew was a great teacher! Probably because he's closer to our age so he remembers what it's like being a full time student. Anyways, I SHOULD have gotten an A, but I had some difficulty concentrating on account of the fact that he was sooo HOTT! I ended up staring at him and barely focusing during classes.

Easy and very little workload. As long as you somewhat pay attention during class and meet all the requirements for the project, you will get an A will very little effort. While it is a very easy course, it also means you don't really learn anything. Not sure why Rutgers still lets him teach but hey, easiest A of my life.

This is by far the worst professor I have ever had. His accent was terrible, his handwriting ineligible, whenever he was asked a question that wasn't on script he could rarely answer and if he couldn't he'd just say "bad question". he doesnt care if u cheat as when i looked half the class had phones out during midterm hes just a real piece of work

This class has absolutely no structure - most likely because Minsky doesn't even know what needs to be taught. He'll start an example on the board, and erase it midway through when he can't figure it out. He says he will give an announcement online about when quizzes are, but doesn't; so you might miss one. Grades take 3 months to be put up.

He knows nothing about the class he teaches. Handwriting is practically illegible, constantly gets confused and messes up his own examples. Will start a problem, get lost after 10 minutes, and quits. Answering questions has to be exactly how he wants to hear it. Grades arent put in for months. He is rude and demeaning when a student asks a question

He's simply the worst professor that I've had at RU. He would get confused in the middle of examples he was writing on the board and forget what he was doing. WORD OF ADVICE: prepare examples BEFORE you come to teach the class. He seems to be going a bit senile with age and I just *really* wish RU would have him stop teaching.
The worst professor in the CS department. Doesn't understand the material he teaches, NEVER gives back grades in any reasonable time frame,  his course has NO solid structure. AVOID AT ALL COSTS

He will spend 15 minutes on an example only to erase it after he cant figure out what the answer is and stumbles over his own examples/words half of the time.  Extremely frustrating. If you can swing it, wait until the next semester to take Discrete if your only option is Minsky. Its that bad. Or be ready to read the textbook on your own and grind.

Worse professor you can ever have. If you try to do the work yourself your in for a wild ride. He felt that one of his random quizzes were really easy but the average grade on it was a F. Your best bet is to read the textbook or better yet have the midterms and finals of previous years. he recycles his exams from what I've seen and heard

About pop quizzes, he will sometimes tell you online when there is a quiz in the future. I only went to the first 10 lectures then stopped going because I learned everything from the book. Lectures are somewhat unclear. If you have good problem solving skills with logics and proofs, easy A. Just be ready to read.

Sometimes seems confused about problems. He will repeatedly reject a student's (correct) proof until someone puts it in the exact wording he expects. Be prepared for long, grueling lectures studded with bursts of pertinent information. Often seems like he doesn't want to be there and has difficulty with classroom technology.
Confusing at times - but nice guy.
Taking CS547 with him. I have just one word to say: Yuck.

Do not take, he may seem easy but his lectures are 100% useless and so you may say ok I'll just self study. That's possible but it's hard to self study when he doesn't really tell you what to study and you can't understand his lectures. Good for bookworms, bad for anyone else HE ALSO DOESNT KNOW PI. HE WROTE 1.45 AND COULDNT SEE WHAT WAS WRONG

I don't wear my seat belt driving to Rutgers because I want to die before I can make it to this class. Horrible. He barely understands the material he is teaching at times, and will start a problem, realize he doesn't have the paper show him how to do it, and just stop. Exams will have each problem count for like 5-8% of your grade. Switch out now

Worst professor I have ever experienced, and that's saying a lot. His quizzes and exams are nothing like the homework, its impossible to learn in class because his examples either make no sense, or he isn't able to finish them himself. I pray every night that there is a curve for this class...
He is a terrible professor and a mean guy. The class is very unorganized. Wish I had taken the class another professor.

More often than not starts a problem and then stops it because he doesn't know how to complete it. Confuses himself about whether a particular problem is in the textbook or not. Spends about 10 minutes each class scolding students for sitting in the back, not paying attention, or for not being able to complete a problem when randomly called upon.

He literally told us pi was 1.45 without thinking twice about it until one student corrected him and then had to actually think about what the correct number was.  Not to mention his general rudeness and inability to speak clearly when asked (he'll raise his voice for a few seconds then go back to mumbling and blame us for not understanding him).
He thinks pi  2.14 Enough said.
Doesn't allow electronics and is a painfully boring lecturer, so I never went to class. Exams are harder than the homework, which tripped up a lot of people.

Soft. Engineering. If you want the easiest A ever, please take him. If you are serious about learning, DO NOT take him. He's been the worst professor I have ever had. No exams and going to class is useless. It is just a shame that Rutgers allows this guy to teach. The final was an oral exam about our future!!. Did not learn anything in this class.

This guy is the goofball of the century. He can't teach and admits he doesn't know anything. Confuses himself and tells class that he didn't have time to prepare for lecture because he had friends over at his house.
Boring, confusing, unhelpful. Lenient with grades, but I don't feel like I learned much from the class. His apathy rubbed off to the students =/
Lecture was pretty boring and no one ever showed up. He also didn't answer very well to questions and got angry very easily. Made an easy class overall, but didn't learn much in the end.

If you know Java and Just wanted to get a grade without getting any use out of this course, go take this. He teaches his research interest. Does mention some interesting stuff but its something you can learn by reading any SW engineering book. There is no final exam so you may be in for a surprise when you see a grade in the End!!!
SW engneering is the course, but the whole course is about LGI (which is his research!!!) Total waste of time. No Exams, quizes.. Its all ONE PROJECT.. which is in Distributed systems. Sucked..!

Utterly useless. He has no idea or agenda to cover. His whole aim is to teach his research interest. LGI is useless in real world. All you learn here is LGI and Distributed Systems. He does talk a few good interesting points.

Very disorganized course. The professors has no idea what he wants to cover(other than his reasearch). Never assigns grade until the end. Grades are just subjective. Overall, pointless course, you will not learn anything, and the won't even get a fair grade. DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE

Too much focus on distributed systems in his class.  No choice of the project, so you end up being his research ****es.  He does talk about a few interesting topics, but I'd recommend taking someone else for Software Engineering.

his class has nothing to do w/ software engineering. he fails to cover all the important points of the subject. the whole class is 1 pointless project, most of which is his research. You won't know your grade until the end, because there's no exams or quizes.....Don't take this elective.

It's true through Borgida's teaching you can tell he thinks like an engineer but he works with students. If you ask questions and go to his office hours as needed then you will get a good grade. It's that simple. He's not wildly entertaining and his teaching may leave you with questions but all you need to do is ask. He's a good prof

Alexander Borgida genuinely cares about teaching, but his lectures are structurally flawed. Borgida reads slides for an hour and a half; this is not an effective way to learn. Yet he takes attendance, so you are required to subscribe to this ineffective teaching method which, at least for me, but I suspect many others, was a waste of time.

The lord of vagueness who mastered in the art of making students confused. Get ready to work your butt off. He will read the slides, but show up for the attendance. HW are like decoding crypted message. Demands billion features in the project. Did I just say billion? yes, BILLION in capital. TA's have no mercy grading.
His lectures are very dry and redundant. Good thing the concepts for this subject are straight forward because this professor isn't the brightest for a CS professor. I've had worse professors though.

Professor Borgida was a very good professor for Discrete Structures, aka CS205.  His greatest strengths were his care for his students, and his very thorough visual slide decks he constructed.  He always did what he could to make sure we were rewarded for putting work in.  His lectures were a bit hard to understand sometimes, but self-study helps.
He gives a semester long web project that is ungodly long and expects a billion features.  Don't procrastinate on this or you're screwed.  Tests and homeworks are quite difficult too.
Awful.
prof doesn't really believe, in posting solutions online, also no practice midterm, basically you are on your own after the lecture.

So like Professor Borgida was an unclear professor, we all have to admit that he is a bit ambigous during his lecture. But he is a very smart and inspirational. I said "Keep asking question", in class, in office hours, ... whenever you have a chance. If you ask the right questions, he would not be that ambiguous, and you'll learn alot!
Borigda isnt very clear in lectures but hes very always very helpful. Tries to help the class pass with quizzes and hws. Tests are nothing like the review

It's a confusing class but if you're willing to put in the work you will do well. Also if you go to office hours/ just ask questions professor Borgida appreciates that and helps you understand.  Just don't be lazy with this class, actually try.

My god, his lectures were torture. I fell asleep half the time and the other half I couldn't even pay attention. This wouldn't be so bad if he didn't make attendance mandatory.  Also, his assignments are very vague in what hes asking. I have never felt like i learned so little after taking a CS class until this one.

Teaches Software Engineering, does NOT know how to code. Arbitrary grading. Changes syllabus on a whim mid-semester. Extremely disorganized. Rambles about occasionally vaguely relevant high-level concepts. Never gave us grades for 80% of the work we did - only a final grade, on Jan 2nd. Learned a lot, via google, thanks to a massive project.

Its 2013, I'd say his material is over 20 years old but someone in 2003 said that. Extremely unclear! Tries to nitpick at your project. Project is lame. Embarrassed to say hes a professor at my school. Avoid at all costs. You can thank me later.
Not the clearest professor in the world. He goes around in circles explaining things that really arent that hard. At the end of class you cant help but think wth did i just go through
Really makes the content difficult to understand. He does go out of his way to help though, which is great. Really nice guy, but he does have trouble explaining things so that they're understandable.

Very committed to teaching and helping students. Expect heavy workload for homeworks. The only minus is that his lecture presentation is very incomprehensible. Otherwise, one of the most committed individuals. Exams are top-notch.

Horrible teacher in every sense of the word. Makes every topic complicated regardless of how simple it may be. Can ramble on about something the lecture is not related to just because he wants to give "insight" into the topic.. I do not recommend taking this professor.. if you do make the book your best friend..
Alot of material taught seems unecessary.  The project was alot of fun but a LOT of work. I recommend the Software Engineering course and Dr. Borgida.

Extremely helpful if you approach him outside of class. He is pretty knowledgeable but sometimes takes the wrong direction to teach some topics and make it too complicated. His projects are easy. He is very flexible in grading.

Very Smart. Very helpful. Sometimes tries to go thru the hard way to explain things which is sometimes a failure. But his lecture notes are good and clear. Listens to any of your issues and works with you. Some of his topics are really interesting and he really try to give out the best to the students.

(1)All examples are at least 20 years old. (2)I have learned nothing I don't already know. (3)He has missed many lectures - about five. (4)Homework is poorly written and pointless. (5)Website imposible to read! (6)Homework refers to online lecture notes that do not exist. (7)Project is lame. (8)Wastes time during lectures!  I could go on forever..!

Smart guy...not the most interesting lecturer.  Tendency to morph any topic into something relating to a complex logic system or Datalog of some sort.  Fairly approachable...will try to help you out. 205 exam was really hard, but 442 a bit easier so far.

Very rude person, the book was even more useless, they should just post lecture notes on the internet and tell the students what they'll need to know for the exam - and I guarantee that they'll do better than actually going to lecture.

Insufficiently technical.  Constantly claims to 'not be a good programmer.'  Takes anti-cheating stance too far, prevents what would otherwise be helpful and learning colloboration.  Posts projects with instructions which are intentionally ambigous.

Professor puts extremly little effort into class preperation. I found the fact that I had to remove my jacket and place my bag in an area out of my control insulting, by the time you take his class he may be doing anal probes to prevent cheating.

Took the class roughly a year ago, and finally remembered to post.  Very well-spoken lecturer, if a bit dry.  Tells you everything you need to know in class for the exams, with a bit of side-reading.   Assignments are long-ish, but rewarding once you understand.  As long as you read the material and take VERY good notes, you will do just fine.

I haven't completed the class yet, but I think this professor is the best I've taken so far throughout my experience at Rutgers. His explanations are amazing, and I might be biased (since I love security/hacking) but he is one of the few knowledgeable professors who can both research and teach well. He doesn't waste time and teaches efficiently.

The lectures are very dry and boring but you get breaks in between. No 'hw' assignments  but the 3 projects make up for it. Recitations very helpful 4 projects. Very little information on given on exams. (says to study everything but thats not helpful, thats obvious). Lots of reading, not many 'probs to solve'. No curve, at all, for anything, ever.

Never, ever have I worked for so long on homework that I contemplated suicide. Don't take this class as it's a lot of work and most of it is fairly hard. It kind of feels like doing a research paper but for a measly 3% of your grade. TA grades very strictly and makes you feel like it's a great achievement when you get 1 out of 100 on an assignment

Had him for Computer Security. He is a really nice professor. The class has alot of work, but you will get a broad spectrum of Computer Security. I thought the class was useful. He explains everything clearly, but he talks a little too fast. The projects were interesting also.

Had him for my Comp. Security elective. Overall, a pretty good teacher.  He can explain concepts very well and in proper English. He's willing to work with you and help you understand material. Just note that the class is a bit heavy on the work, though some of the work is fairly interesting. Expect to spend countless hours studying for the final.

This was, by far and away, the hardest class I have ever taken at Rutgers. His homework problems and exams are ridiculously difficult. Thankfully, he's definitely aware of this and gives very good scales (a 40% was the minimum to pass for my class). Cash is also very helpful and approachable outside of class and during office hours. Take him!

Cash is really one of the best professors I've had at Rutgers. His lectures were very clear, there was rarely a time when I felt he didn't explain a topic clearly enough. Exams were incredibly fair. He always gave tons of practice for the exams. If you're taking Discrete II, DEFINITELY choose him if you can. He's just such a great dude.
Good teacher. Class is pretty easy if you show up and pay attention. There are homework and quizzes nearly every week.
Did a right choice by taking this course

He's the 206 professor most likely to make the material interesting and relevant. Always has anecdotes from the latest research, and assigned us to study the practical applications of Markov Chains. Despite doing pretty well on the exams, I failed the class for not attending enough lectures (there are weekly quizzes) and submitting enough homeworks
Cash is pretty cool, writes all notes on the board, actually listens to students and adjusts testsquizzes accordingly. His office hours are extremely helpful. More importantly - THE CURVE IS AMAZING.

Cash is a great guy and a great professor. His lectures are very clear and almost always interesting, and exams are very simple. He's very helpful in office hours and before exams. His homework can be annoying, but it prepares you very well for the midterms and final. I'd definitely recommend him for 206.
This guy is the man. Exams were easy and lecture was clear and useful, Homework was hard but doable. Wish he taught another undergrad class so I could take him again, highly recommended.

Reads from the book almost verbatim when going over new material in class. HW is much harder than anything that will be on tests. Quizzes were given every other class after the first midterm. Excellent curve throughout the semester. Pretty much impossible to fail this class if you pay attention and do the work.

One of the coolest professors ever. Explains things extremely well and makes the lectures interesting. You still have to work hard and study to get an A, its not an easy class, but Cash makes it enjoyable

Ca$h is the man! Gives practice exams that really help set you up for the actual midterms. The homework can be pretty confusing (though I think that has more to do with the TA's grading scheme), but Cash takes time to explain how to think problems through in lecture. Also, he looks just like Hugh Dancy. Definitely a fantastic, lively professor!

David's lectures were always focused on making sure you understand the material. He walks you through simple examples, and explains everything in a clear manner. Homeworks prepare you for the exams, and the exams closely follow lecture material. David is also very nice and doesn't have a big ego. Easily one of the best CS professors at Rutgers.
Didn't use class time very well. Went over long theorems instead of going over useful examples that would help on upcoming assignments and exams.
This guy is amazingly clear and interesting.  He goes over the intuitive ideas before digging into the gory details.  Totally worth waking up early to go to this prof's lectures.

Good teacher in a small class setting. When asking for clarification on topics, he refines on the small details of the given explanation, but doesn't often try to approach the concept from a different angle that might be more intuitive to some.

Wonderful man, lectures are just kind of dry. Labs are long, but easy and count for 60% of your grade. His exams are long and very detailed, so you really need to know every detail of anything that was mentioned in class to do well on them

Great guy- really there to help you. Attendance is required and he marks you off for being late, but you can talk to him about anything and he is really understanding. Labs are long but easy, Ed & the TAs are real helpful.
Professor Robinson is a genuinely kind man! The class was pretty easy overall, especially if you listen and just follow directions in lab. He is so helpful! Definitely take him if you can!
I thought this class was very easy and I'm only average when it comes to computers. The tas helped a lot if you had any questions

Nice teacher and extremely helpful, but does not know what he's doing at times. He sometimes asks kids during lecture if they know how to do something. And mostly all of the questions on the two exams are random. Easy class though if you're good on computers.
Extremely nice and easy-going guy. Attendance is important- you can't really afford to miss more than a couple of classes or labs. As long as you show up, this is an easy A.
The material is moderately tough. He makes it interesting. His jokes are not great but good. Attendence is mandatory. Come to class and read the book and you'll get an A. Overall, a good professor.
Hes mad chill but the class is tough cuz u gotta go to every lecture and lab :(
I bet the same person made all 3 of those comments...this class is pretty hard

One of the best professors at Rutgers.  You don't have to read, you just have to slightly pay attention, and have good attendance.  You learn a lot.  It's a fun, easy A.  He's pretty funny too.  I highly recommend him, and the class.

Really nice professor. EASY class if you go and read before the exam. Just pay attention in class and go to the review before the exams. The assignments are 60% but they're easy. The exams (2) are pretty easy if you read and he tells you a lot of what's on it. Easy A.
Awesome Professor. Simple Class. He's very funny and witty. Goto Class and Lab and its an easy A.
